← Back

polaris-alpha

+ Mythology-Inspired — Gods Wore Sneakers (Chapter Avg: 79.7 | Final: 76.5)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Mythology-Inspired Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Gods wore sneakers.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Mythology-Inspired Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Gods wore sneakers. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming 1. Big-picture angles for “Gods wore sneakers” - Modernization angle: - Gods live hidden among humans in a contemporary city, wearing sneakers as their everyday footwear. - Sneakers signify their attempt to blend in, but also channel divine power (enchanted soles, wings, storm-treads, etc.). - The story follows a mortal who discovers that certain sneaker wearers are deities and gets pulled into their conflicts. - Myth remix angle: - Classic pantheons (Greek, Norse, Hindu, etc.) reconceived as streetwear-obsessed, urban myth figures. - Each god’s sneaker style reflects domain: Hermes has winged high-tops; Poseidon’s shift color with tides; Athena’s are undefeated in any contest. - Rival gods launch competing sneaker “brands” as avatars of their philosophies. - Creation-myth angle: - Sneakers are relics: artifacts created at the dawn of time to let gods walk the mortal plane without burning it. - If a mortal wears a god’s sneakers, they inherit temporary godlike attributes. - The plot centers on the loss, theft, or trade of these sneakers, destabilizing cosmic order. - Coming-of-age angle: - Teenage protagonist: aspiring runner, artist, or skater, living in a rough neighborhood where legends circulate about “divine kicks.” - They acquire a pair—either stolen from a disguised god or gifted in a moment of mercy—and suddenly can see or interact with gods. - The story is both mythic and personal: balancing normal life (school, family) with cosmic responsibilities. - Myth-industry satire angle: - Olympus as a global sneaker corporation: “Zeus & Co.” manufactures miracle sneakers. - Gods are executives, heroes are brand ambassadors, monsters are PR crises. - Mortal protagonist interns at the company and uncovers a truth: each sneaker sold siphons worship/attention/power for specific gods. - Street-myth noir: - A mythologically-aware city where minor gods are washed up, hustling. - Sneakers as contracts: whoever laces them up becomes the god's avatar. - Detective protagonist tracks supernatural crimes tied to these shoes: lightning-strike robberies, impossible getaways, etc. - Post-apocalyptic angle: - Divine war wrecked the world; only remnants are sacred sneakers that let users perform one miracle at a cost. - A small band of survivors, one blessed pair among them, must cross a ruined landscape where gods walk in battered sneakers. - Lighthearted ensemble: - Slice-of-life vignettes about gods forming a rec league basketball team, each in custom divine sneakers, accidentally causing small miracles. - Stakes: community center closing, mythic rivals, or a big celestial tournament. 2. Potential protagonists - Mara (or similar name): - 17-year-old track star who keeps losing by fractions of a second. - Works part-time at a crumbling sneaker shop with surprisingly “old” inventory. - Finds / is given a pair that lets her break records—turns out they belong to Hermes or another messenger god. - Eli: - Sneakerhead, low-income teenager reselling rare shoes to support family. - Gets hands on a rumored “God Pair”: each wear brings him closer to apotheosis but also draws divine predators. - Cass: - Intern at Olympus Athletics, a god-run sportswear mega-corp. - Disillusioned after discovering their product line feeds off worship; must decide whether to expose them. - Aten: - A forgotten sun god now working as a delivery rider in a glowing pair of limited edition sneakers that barely keep his power alive. - Supporting cast possibilities: - Hermes as charismatic courier/hustler. - Athena as a sharp-eyed coach or history teacher. - Ares as aggressive fight-trainer or drill sergeant running a gym. - Nike (the goddess) as the literal embodiment of victory branding. - Tricksters (Loki, Anansi, Coyote) in hypebeast aesthetics. - Furies/Fates as sneaker customizers who stitch destiny into laces. 3. Core conflicts and stakes - Identity vs. power: - Protagonist gains power via divine sneakers: speed, charisma, strength, sight into hidden realms. - But power comes with strings: obligations to gods, curses, gradual erasure of their humanity. - Old gods vs. new gods: - Classic deities losing influence to new “gods” of algorithms, virality, and consumer culture (personified). - Sneakers are the remaining battleground for worship: brands, trends, sponsorships. - Choice of allegiance: - Multiple deities court the protagonist, offering different sneaker-boons. - Each path changes the world subtly (more war, more wisdom, more chaos). - Catastrophic imbalance: - Someone steals or mass-produces divine sneakers, diluting or corrupting divine power. - If mortals widely wield godly abilities, the mythic order collapses. - Time-sensitive quest: - The protagonist must deliver, destroy, or return a legendary pair by a fixed celestial deadline or a prophecy triggers. - The sneakers degrade with each misuse, echoing their moral choices. - Personal stakes: - Family survival, scholarship, avoiding arrest. - Pressure of expectations: to win, to provide, to be “chosen.” - Fear of being discarded once the gods are done. 4. Tone and style options - Wry, contemporary, grounded: - Mix of humor and wonder. Gods bicker over endorsements, but genuine awe and danger lurk. - Accessible voice, vivid urban imagery, emotional core. - Mythic-epic in a modern wrapper: - Poetic metaphors, resonant symbolism; sneakers as modern sandals of Hermes or seven-league boots. - Slightly heightened language to give weight to otherwise familiar settings. - Darkly comic satire: - Target consumerism, branding, and the transactional nature of worship/fame. - Straight YA fantasy/adventure: - Strong focus on character growth, friendship, moral choices, quests. 5. Setting possibilities - A single city: - Analog of NYC, LA, or Chicago; neighborhoods with distinct mythic influences. - Underground train stations as portals, rooftop courts as minor arenas for the gods. - A global city-network: - Gods commute via courier routes that crisscross the world; sneakers tuned for different terrains. - Hidden layers: - Sneaker boutiques that are thresholds to divine markets. - Stories told on street murals come to life. 6. 8-chapter structural sketches (multiple variants) Variant A: Classic YA Quest - Ch 1: Ordinary life & inciting incident: - Protagonist established (Mara/Eli type). - Introduced to unique sneakers via shop, theft, or gift. - First hint: reality glitches when worn; glimpses of gods. - Ch 2: Revelation of the divine: - Protagonist meets a disguised god (Hermes/Nike/Athena). - Learns sneakers are god-tier artifacts tied to cosmic balance. - Refusal or reluctance: “I just want to run/pay rent.” - Ch 3: Training & temptation: - Tests of abilities, rules of magic, comic and cool scenes. - It becomes clear other beings are hunting these sneakers. - Introduce rival: another chosen, or a minor god. - Ch 4: Conspiracy surfaces: - Discover gods are using sneaker-culture as worship funnel. - A dangerous new line of counterfeit divine sneakers is coming. - Ch 5: Midpoint crisis: - Big public event (race, game, festival) becomes battleground. - Protagonist’s power surges out of control; collateral damage. - Relationships strain; trust in gods shaken. - Ch 6: Loss and descent: - Sneakers (or a pair) stolen or broken. - Someone close hurt or memory erased by gods. - Hero confronts the cost of serving divine agendas. - Ch 7: Choice and uprising: - Protagonist regains/repairs sneakers or forges new pact. - Rejects simple allegiance, determines own terms. - Plan to sabotage gods’ scheme or redistribute power. - Ch 8: Climax & resolution: - Showdown at mythic/sneaker nexus (headquarters, temple-court). - Hero uses sneakers in unexpected way (sacrifice, sharing power). - World slightly changed; gods forced to adapt; hero claims identity. Variant B: Corporate Olympus Satire - Ch 1: Intern’s first day at Olympus Athletics. - Ch 2: Meet divine executives, glimpse weirdness. - Ch 3: Discovers testing lab with god-tech sneakers. - Ch 4: Brand scandal reveals sneakers’ worship siphon. - Ch 5: Attempt at whistleblowing sabotaged by gods. - Ch 6: Allies among lesser staff/gods; infiltration. - Ch 7: Launch event descent into chaos. - Ch 8: Public revelation, new equilibrium between gods/humans. Variant C: Noir Anthology Feel (but still continuous) - Ch 1: Detective introduced; case starts with weird “impossible runner.” - Ch 2: Underground sneaker scene, first god suspect. - Ch 3: Interview with fallen goddess in cracked Converse. - Ch 4: Bigger pattern: murders tied to stolen relic-sneakers. - Ch 5: Midpoint: detective forced to wear god-sneakers. - Ch 6: Temptation and hallucinations of pantheons. - Ch 7: Confrontation with mastermind god. - Ch 8: Bitter victory, moral ambiguity, lingering myths. 7. Specific god-sneaker concepts to mix and match - Hermes: - Sneakers with subtle wing logos; grant speed and navigation through any barrier (locked doors become “routes”). - Nike: - Glowing soles when wearer is on track to “victory” (in sports, exams, arguments). - Ares: - Heavy red high-tops; wearer becomes fearless, volatile. - Athena: - Clean white trainers; wearer gains tactical genius, clarity. - Dionysus: - Party sneakers: ecstatic charisma, but loss of inhibition. - Poseidon: - Ocean-spray mids: water-walking, tide-calling. - Hecate: - Shadow runners: crossroads magic; choose between timelines. - Modern “new gods”: - Algorithm: adaptive shoes that predict and manipulate movement for max engagement. - Hype: sneakers that are more powerful the more people desire them. 8. Thematic threads to potentially emphasize - Worship as attention: - Likes, hype, endorsements as modern prayer. - Gods hustling for relevance via sneakers and sports. - Embodied divinity: - “Gods wore sneakers” as literal grounding: they walk with us. - What it means when cosmic beings choose to stand on the same pavement. - Power democratized vs. hoarded: - Should divine sneakers be rare relics or widely shared tools? - Youth agency: - Young protagonist deciding how the next age of gods/humans functions. - Legacy and story: - Myths evolve: from temples to brands, scrolls to social feeds to shoes. 9. Pacing considerations for 8 x ~1000 words - Need tight, efficient storytelling: - Each chapter gets a clear function: incite, reveal, deepen, twist, break, regroup, climax, resolve. - Limited cast: protagonist, 1–2 god-allies, 1 antagonist, 1 close human relationship. - Only a few set-piece scenes: one early power-demo, one midpoint disaster, final climactic confrontation. # Reflection What works well in these brainstormed ideas: - Modern-urban myth mashup: - It directly fits “Gods wore sneakers” both visually and conceptually. - Strong opportunities for humor, sharp imagery, and thematic resonance (gods adapting to pop culture). - Easy to explain within 8 chapters; readers quickly “get” the world. - Relatable protagonist (teen runner/sneakerhead/intern): - Gives us a clear emotional anchor. - The tension between personal goals (race, family, job) and cosmic stakes is a strong engine. - Divine sneakers as artifacts: - Clean narrative device: shoes = power, temptation, responsibility. - Simplifies magic system (only certain pairs matter) which is crucial given limited word count. - Old vs. new gods / worship as attention: - Feels current and thematically rich without needing long exposition. - Supports conflict: gods struggle for relevance and try to instrumentalize the protagonist. - A focused quest structure (Variant A): - Naturally supports a chapter-by-chapter arc: - Ch 1: Hook with “gods in sneakers” and protagonist. - Ch 2–3: Discovery and training = fun, character building. - Ch 4–5: Conspiracy and public disaster raise stakes. - Ch 6–7: Loss and choice bring emotional peak. - Ch 8: Resolution ties mythic and personal changes together. - Sustainably epic yet compact for ~8000 words total. Potential issues and what might not work so well: - Overstuffed pantheons: - Pulling in too many mythologies risks clutter and shallow treatment. - 8 chapters don’t give room to properly develop dozens of gods. - Pure satire/corporate focus (Variant B): - Fun conceptually, but might skew too jokey or expositional for the prompt. - Risk: emotional flatness if it leans heavily into critique over character. - Noir/detective complexity (Variant C): - Mystery pacing can be tough in 8000 words while also building a mythic world. - Risk of not resolving the whodunnit satisfactorily or underdeveloping the myth angle. - Post-apocalyptic or huge-scale divine war: - Hard to depict a fully realized devastated world and its history in the space given. - Might distract from the very specific, playful promise of “gods wore sneakers.” - Anthology / slice-of-life structure: - Charming, but lacks drive and cohesion if the goal is a singular compelling short story. Elements that feel especially promising to carry forward: - Single-city, grounded setting: - Lets us showcase gods in hoodies and sneakers on real streets, keeps logistics simple. - Hybrid tone: mostly grounded with streaks of wonder and some humor: - Good fit for a mythology-inspired story that feels fresh instead of solemn. - A single main divine sneaker pair plus 1–2 others: - Keeps the magic system clear and symbolic. - Can cue specific character arcs (e.g., speed vs. patience, victory vs. compassion). - Focused cast: - One mortal lead; one divine mentor/antagonist; one close human friend/family member; one main opposing force (a god, corporation, or chosen rival). - Supports emotional investment and clarity. - Thematic focus: - How power is earned vs. bestowed. - How old stories survive in new packaging. - The choice to be more than a mascot for someone else’s divinity. At this stage (still not formally deciding), the strongest direction seems to be: - A contemporary, urban, coming-of-age quest (Variant A-ish), - Where divine sneakers are both plot device and metaphor for attention, power, and potential, - Featuring a tight, 8-beat structure with escalating stakes and a personal, satisfying resolution. Next step would be: lock in one protagonist, one primary godly conflict, and map out an 8-chapter outline tailored to the ~1000 word rhythm, making sure each chapter has a clear turn and showcases “gods wore sneakers” not just as a gimmick, but as the spine of the world and the character’s evolution.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention I’ll center the story on a contemporary, urban coming-of-age narrative where “gods wore sneakers” is both literal worldbuilding and thematic spine, not just a quirky image. Key decisions: - Protagonist: - Mara, 17, high-school track runner in a dense modern city. - Working-class background; needs an athletic scholarship to escape narrowing options. - Grounded, observant, a bit stubborn. Not a chosen-one cliché; she earns her choices. - Core premise: - Gods survive on attention/worship in the modern world. - They’ve taken to the streets in human guise, wearing sneakers that let them walk among mortals without burning the world. - Certain pairs are true artifacts: if a mortal wears them, they channel that god’s aspect. - Hermes, in disguise, leaves one such pair in Mara’s orbit. It wakes her to the divine layer of the city. - Central conflict: - Mara discovers her “miracle” sneakers are Hermes’ lost pair, coveted by a coalition of gods and a slick divine brand, Apex, run by Nike and Zeus-like CEO-figure. - Apex plans to mass-produce diluted divine sneakers, turning human devotion into a controlled worship economy. - If successful, it will centralize power among a few gods and lock humanity into being brand-devotees instead of free agents. - Mara must decide: keep the power for herself, give it back, or rewrite the terms of how gods and humans share it. - Stakes: - Personal: her future (scholarship, family stability, identity apart from being “the fast girl”). - Relational: loyalty to best friend/teammate; trust/distrust toward an oddly kind, frustrated god (Hermes). - Cosmic: who controls miracles, stories, and attention; whether gods become tyrannical brands or cohabitants. - Tone and style: - Grounded, clear, present-tense or close third-person past (I’ll use close third-past to balance immediacy with flexibility). - Mix of: - Street-level realism: cramped apartment, school stress, track practices. - Understated humor: divine beings dealing with broken escalators and bus delays, gods in hoodies arguing about metrics. - Genuine wonder: the city’s hidden divine shortcuts, glowing laces at midnight, murals that move when she runs past. - Avoid: - Overly ornate or myth-dump prose. - Too many pantheons; will focus mainly on a Greek-inspired cluster (Hermes, Nike, Zeus-like figure), with tiny hints that others exist. - Pure satire that flattens characters into jokes; the gods can be funny but must be dangerous and complex. - Magic/power rules: - Mara’s pair: authentic Hermes sneakers. - Grant speed beyond human ability, plus partial access to liminal spaces (shortcuts, thresholds, routes no one else sees). - Power grows with use but erodes distinction between her will and the god’s agenda. - Other divine sneakers: - Nike’s: amplify victory and admiration. - Zeus-figure: command, spectacle. - Very limited set to keep things clear. - Rules will be simple, intuitive, and shown via action, not explained in long lectures. - Structure: - 8 chapters, ~1000 words each. - Each chapter has a distinct narrative job and a clear emotional or plot turn. - The story must feel complete: an arc from “ordinary girl who wants to run” to “person who impacts how gods walk the earth.” - Themes to emphasize: - Power and choice: - Being handed power vs. earning it; refusing to become a mascot or pawn. - Attention as worship: - How our focus feeds systems and figures larger than us. - Myth evolving: - Temples to sponsorships, lightning bolts to neon soles; but core questions remain. - Grounded divinity: - Gods in sneakers as a metaphor for sharing the same pavement; choices gods and mortals make when they’re side by side. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1: The Girl, the Race, and the Sneakers - Purpose: - Establish Mara’s world, needs, and personality. - Introduce the inciting incident: acquisition of the Hermes sneakers. - Beats: - Open at a crucial track meet: Mara narrowly loses the qualifying race that could secure her scholarship. - We see: - Her determination, her frustration with being “almost.” - Glimpses of city life, family pressures: mom working double shifts, looming bills. - On the way home she stops by “Lace & Legend,” a small, dusty sneaker shop run by an odd old man (Hermes in disguise, though unnamed). - He offers her an old-looking but pristine pair—sleek, light, with subtle winged stitching—for almost nothing. - As she leaves, she notices small oddities: the shop wasn’t there last week, the city sounds dim for a second when she touches the shoes. - End: She tries them on in a nearby alley “just to feel something go right” and briefly blurs forward far faster than possible—shocking herself. Chapter 2: Streets of Two Worlds - Purpose: - Deepen Mara’s connection to the sneakers. - Reveal the hidden layer of the city and hint at divine presence. - Beats: - Mara experiments with the sneakers on an early-morning run: - Time dilates; her path “opens up” into side streets and rooftop edges that shouldn’t be reachable. - Sees fleeting silhouettes: someone with lion eyes at the bodega, a woman with bronze owl feathers in the reflection of a window. - She realizes she can cut through locked gates and slip past traffic as if the city rearranges to let her through. - Back at school/track practice: - She’s tempted to wear them but is cautious; senses they’re more than gear. - Brief scene with best friend/teammate (who believes in her even when she loses). - After practice, a stranger bumps her, eyes lingering on her duffel. He’s too polished, his shoes’ soles glow faint gold (Apex rep; we’ll later learn he’s an envoy of Nike/Zeus). - He comments cryptically: “Those aren’t for just anyone.” - That night, she returns to the shop to ask questions—finds it boarded up and abandoned, as if it has been for years. - End: Uneasy wonder. Decision: she’ll use them, at least once, in a smaller race to test. Chapter 3: Victory, and Its Echo - Purpose: - Show the payoff and cost of using the sneakers publicly. - Introduce active divine interest. - Beats: - At a local meet, Mara secretly wears the sneakers. - She crushes everyone, obliterating records, experiencing exhilarating freedom. - But: - Spectators’ attention feels tangible; sound distorts; phones capturing her glow slightly. - A sudden, almost electrical charge runs through the stadium lights. - Post-race: - Teammates are thrilled, coach is stunned; scholarship scouts are now interested. - Best friend is proud but also slightly unsettled by how un-human Mara’s run seemed. - In the crowd stands the Apex rep, now introduced as Kade, alongside a poised woman in pristine white and gold sneakers (Nike). - They congratulate her, hint at “opportunities,” and invite her to visit the Apex flagship for a “partnership discussion.” - On her way home, a ragged courier in beat-up Converse jogs alongside her in a place traffic shouldn’t allow; he reveals himself partially as Hermes: - Tells her the shoes are his. - Says gods walk in sneakers now because bare divinity is too much for this era; shoes are contracts, restraints, channels. - Warns: Apex wants exactly what she just did—turn mortal talent and worship into a controlled power grid. - Leaves her with: “They’ll say you’ve earned it. Ask what they earn from you.” - End: Mara torn between intoxicating success and suspicion. Chapter 4: Apex of Worship - Purpose: - Expose Apex’s true nature and the broader divine economy. - Force Mara to confront the manipulative side of the gods. - Beats: - Mara visits Apex’s flagship HQ/showroom, drawn by the promise of sponsorship and helping her family. - Sleek, temple-like architecture; big screens looping victorious athletes in Apex sneakers. - She meets Nike, charismatic and warm, and a CEO figure channeling Zeus (not named Zeus explicitly, but thunder motifs, commanding presence). - They pitch her: - A custom line, funding, her name in lights. - They praise her “natural” greatness while staring at the Hermes sneakers. - Subtext revealed through what she observes: - Map of global “engagement nodes” showing where Apex sneakers concentrate belief. - Product lines designed to grant slivers of godly ability for continuous “subscription worship.” - Nike hints that her Hermes pair is “wild power” and “dangerous;” they offer to “upgrade” her with an Apex-approved divine pair. - Mara hears faint whispers (Hermes’ voice) when she touches other sneakers—warning her they are leashes. - She leaves with a contract offer, freebies, and growing unease. - End: On the way out, she sees a kid putting on demo Apex shoes; his eyes briefly glow as screens flash his image: a tiny, involuntary sacrifice of self to the brand. The cost becomes real. Chapter 5: The Race that Breaks the Sky - Purpose: - Midpoint: a big public event escalates stakes, exposes the danger, and damages Mara’s trust in all sides. - Beats: - Major citywide invitational race; scouts, media, Apex sponsors present. - Kade pressures Mara subtly: wearing Hermes’ shoes is a liability; Apex’s pair would ensure “safe” victory. - Hermes appears privately, tells her to keep his shoes; warns that Apex wants to serialize miracles, making gods of a select few and batteries of the rest. - Mara chooses Hermes’ pair, half out of defiance, half belief in herself. - During the race: - She runs faster than ever, slipping fully into liminal lanes: part of the track is suddenly a causeway of light; for her, gods in the stands reveal their true forms. - Apex tech tries to hijack: some competitors in Apex shoes surge with unnatural power, destabilizing. - The interference causes a rupture: - Lightning fractures the stadium screens. - Energy whiplash knocks people down; a small stampede; someone gets hurt (possibly her best friend on the sidelines). - The crowd’s fear and awe feed all present gods; frenzy of overlapping influences. - End: - Mara wins, but the victory is tainted; officials and Apex reps close in. - She sees her friend injured, hears accusations that she “cheated,” feels complicit. - Conflicted toward Hermes (who pushed her to defy), and Apex (who engineered a spectacle). Chapter 6: Broken Laces - Purpose: - Take power away or complicate it. - Deepen emotional stakes and force Mara into real choice. - Beats: - Aftermath: - News and social media debate: miracle runner or fraud? Rumors of “enhanced” shoes. - Scholarship in jeopardy; school and family stressed, scared of lawsuits or bans. - Best friend confronts her: “What did you do?” Pain of almost-betrayal. - Apex publicly offers to help her “clear her name” if she signs with them and hands over the Hermes sneakers. - Mara confronts Hermes in some hidden transit-space (subway that turns into a corridor of doors). - She demands answers: Did he set her up? Why her? - Hermes admits: - He’s losing territory to Apex; needed a mortal who still runs for the love of it, not the deal. - He chose her because she had something they can’t manufacture: stubborn integrity. - But yes, he also used her as a move in a divine turf war. - In anger, Mara tries to tear the sneakers off; their laces snap like lightning, temporarily severing the connection. - She loses access to the liminal spaces; feels abruptly small and slow. - End: - Alone, with damaged Hermes sneakers, no clear allies. - Realization: both sides see her as leverage, not a person. She must decide on her own terms. Chapter 7: Rerouting - Purpose: - Mara reclaims agency and forges a third path. - Set up the final confrontation and her solution. - Beats: - Mara visits her injured friend, apologizes honestly, explains as much as she can (without full cosmic info dumping). - The friend’s response highlights a key idea: “If that power depends on people watching, maybe you decide what they watch for.” - Inspired, Mara repairs the sneakers: - Takes them to an underground sneaker-mender—an older woman who is quietly Hecate-ish (guardian of thresholds). - With her guidance, Mara re-laces them with her own terms: intention as contract. - Not to outperform others for worship, but to open paths for people, to share access. - She confronts Hermes: - Sets conditions: if she runs with his power, it won’t be for his exclusive gain. - Hermes, amused and impressed, agrees—partly because choice itself gives him a different kind of relevance. - Plan: - At Apex’s upcoming massive launch event (their push to dominate), Mara will: - Use the Hermes sneakers to hijack the spectacle. - Reveal to everyone the nature of divine sneakers: how attention feeds them, and that the power doesn’t have to be monopolized. - End: - Hermes offers one last warning: “They’re not used to mortals rewriting terms.” - Mara: “They can learn.” - She laces up, feeling the sneakers respond not as a leash, but as a channel she co-authors. Chapter 8: When Gods Touch Pavement - Purpose: - Deliver climax and resolution. - Show Mara executing her choice and altering the balance. - Beats: - At the Apex launch: - Stage show bordering on religious ceremony: huge screens, pro athletes, Nike and Zeus-CEO hyping the “democratization of greatness” (actually controlled devotion). - Gods in the crowd cloaked as influencers, execs, idols. - Mara crashes the event by running: - Uses the remade Hermes sneakers to cut across media feeds, projections, even physics. - Every step peels back illusion: people see flickers of gods feeding on their awe, see how sneakers glow brighter as crowds chant brands. - Nike and Zeus-figure try to shut her down: - Invoke lightning, security, algorithms; they attempt to brand her as malfunctioning, dangerous. - Hermes appears—not as savior, but as a subtle ally: - Opens routes that let her stay ahead, but leaves choice to her. - Mara’s move: - She stops mid-spectacle and does something unexpected: - Invites others onto the track/stage. Kids, amateurs, bystanders. - Uses her access to open a shared liminal lane just enough for a handful to feel a spark—showing that power isn’t inherently proprietary. - Declares (in simple, human terms) that no shoe, no god, owns anyone’s worth; that they walk the same ground. - The effect: - The crowd’s attention splinters from Apex’s singular narrative. - Some gods lose a bit of control; others are intrigued. - Apex’s launch is spoiled: they can’t promise exclusive miracles anymore. - Hermes gains a different sort of relevance: patron of open paths and choice, not just secret contracts. - Aftermath: - Mara likely sacrifices something: - Full, easy access to the sneakers’ god-tier power dims. - Her run-times remain extraordinary but just within human plausibility. - Scholarship: maybe uncertain but possible because of prior performances; more importantly, she’s claimed her agency. - Relationship with friend: mending, built on honesty. - Closing image: - Mara running through the city at dusk, in worn but responsive sneakers. - On a nearby corner, a god in scuffed high-tops nods at her—equals sharing pavement. - Implied new balance: gods still wear sneakers, but mortals know more about the terms, and one girl helped reroute the story.
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
Great question. Let’s zoom out and be blunt about this. You’ve got a strong, fun premise (“Gods wore sneakers”) and a neat, functional plan—but “functional” is exactly what often exposes AI-written work. Let’s look at how a human might come at this, what LLMs habitually do wrong, and how our current plan risks those missteps. Then we’ll brainstorm adjustments to make it feel more human. I’ll stay focused on critique/analysis and not rewrite anything yet. 1. How a human might naturally approach this prompt A human writer—especially one intrigued by this prompt—might: - Start from a specific feeling or image: - A god tying their laces in a locker room. - Hermes doing food delivery on a bike. - Thunder gods scuffing their Jordans. - The unreal quiet right before the starting pistol of a race. - Linger on details they personally care about: - Their own relationship to running, class, hype culture, immigrant parents, religious doubt. - A weird coach from high school. A specific subway station. The one pair of shoes they saved up for. - A messy, idiosyncratic voice: jokes that don’t completely “land,” obsessions that repeat. - Be less tidy: - Endings might be ambivalent; solutions are partial, sometimes unsatisfying in an interesting way. - Characters are contradictory: a god might be petty and noble in the same scene. - Exposition is uneven: some parts over-explained, others left implied, because that’s where their interest/energy goes. - Risk tone or theme: - Some harsher stuff: exploitation, injury, poverty, burnout, faith crisis. - Critique of branding/worship that isn’t neatly resolved by a heroic speech. - Use language that isn’t always “correctly” balanced: - Sentence fragments, slang, personal rhythms. - Weird metaphors that feel too specific to be generic. In short: a human often proceeds from obsession + personal texture + unevenness. LLMs proceed from coverage + coherence + neatness. 2. Typical LLM approaches that can hurt this piece Common LLM habits (especially on a prompt like “gods wore sneakers”): - Safety: - Avoiding real ugliness: poverty is aestheticized; danger is reversible; gods are quirky, not truly terrifying or exploitative. - Over-structuring: - Super clean 8-beat arcs. - Each chapter doing exactly one clear job; every gun goes off. - Feels like a workshop outline more than a story someone had to tell. - Over-clarity and over-explanation: - Magic systems explained with rules. - Themes explained inside character dialogue (“worship is just attention”) rather than discovered. - Bow-wrapped endings: - Big speech fixes systemic problem. - Main character “changes the world” in a singular gesture. - Everyone leaves with insight and stable growth. - “Impressive” rather than honest prose: - Neat metaphors, elegant symmetry, polished thematic echoes. - Little grit. Almost no truly awkward, embarrassing, or morally compromised moments. - Consensus morality: - The story pushes safe, socially approved lessons: - “Be yourself.” - “Reject corporations.” - “Share power.” - True but flat if not grounded in weird, specific, lived-feeling stakes. 3. How our current intention and plan fall into those traps Let’s interrogate our plan with that in mind. a) Over-tidiness of structure - The 8-chapter arc is textbook: - Inciting incident, discovery, offer, midpoint disaster, loss, reframe, grand act, resolution. - This is functional, but: - It risks feeling like an outline written to demonstrate competence. - A human version might let some chapters meander emotionally: - A chapter where “nothing big” happens, just Mara dealing with her friend and noticing gods on the bus. - A chapter that blows up unexpectedly instead of landing exactly at midpoint. Potential humanizing direction: - Allow one or two chapters to be structurally “inefficient” but emotionally dense. - Consider an ending that shifts, not solves, the problem. b) Moral clarity that’s too clean - Apex = bad corporate gods. - Hermes = tricky but ultimately aligned with “freedom.” - Mara = principled mortal who finds a third way. - Final act = she disrupts the brand spectacle and models power-sharing; gods must adapt. Risks: - Feels like a correct take, not a complicated one. - Apex’s villainy is very on-the-nose: exploitative, glossy, obviously suspect. - Hermes using her as a pawn but then respecting her is a comforting arc. Potential humanizing direction: - Let Apex have a point: - Maybe they genuinely do spread miracles more widely than old gods did. - Maybe Hermes is more self-serving than the outline admits. - Let Mara’s “solution” have costs: - People get hurt because of her disruption. - Not everyone wants democratized power; some prefer the security of a brand or a patron. - She might be co-opted by another narrative immediately afterward. c) The ending is too bow-wrapped Current outline: - Mara exposes the gods’ scam, shares access, and alters the balance. - Gods are chastened/adjusted; Mara keeps some possibility of success. Risks: - Classic LLM closure: - Big symbolic moment. - Clear statement of theme. - Earnest, uplifting final image. Potential humanizing direction: - Ambiguity: - Make the climax tactically effective but strategically unclear. - Let gods spin her move into new PR immediately. - Let her scholarship/future remain uncertain; give emotional, not career, closure. - Quietness: - Consider a smaller climax: - She refuses all contracts, runs one last illegal night race with subtle miracles in the background. - Or she makes a bad choice, then has to live with it. d) Worldbuilding explained instead of implied - Current plan: - Hermes explains the sneakers. - Apex HQ visually and verbally reveals the worship-economy. - We make “attention = worship” explicit. Risks: - Diagnostic exposition: very LLM-ish. - Readers are not allowed to feel uncertain. Potential humanizing direction: - Show Mara’s confusion: - Mixed explanations. Some gods lie. No single info-dump. - Use suggestive imagery: - Apex shoes that leave faint sigils on the floor. - Billboard eyes following her. - Let attention/worship be something readers infer from patterns. e) Limited emotional mess We’ve built: - Friend slightly unsettled, later injured, then reconciled. - Mom as pressure point. - Mara as strong, slightly stubborn, doing the right thing. Risks: - Emotional arcs are streamlined: - Conflict, hurt, apology, forgiveness. - Mara rarely behaves terribly. She is tempted but mostly noble. - We don’t see deep shame, pettiness, envy, contradictory impulses. Potential humanizing direction: - Let Mara: - Lie badly, more than once. - Maybe secretly love the adoration at first, even after seeing the cost. - Snap at someone who doesn’t deserve it. - Resent her injured friend for “making it about them” for one ugly moment. - Let the friend: - Not fully buy her explanation. - Have their own selfish or frightened reactions. - Let at least one emotional break remain unresolved by the end. f) God characterization is a bit archetypal, not weird enough Right now: - Hermes: charming trickster who pushes choice. - Nike: sleek motivator of victory branding. - Zeus-CEO: thunderous corporate overlord. Risks: - They’re thematic positions more than people. - They talk like the roles they represent. Potential humanizing direction: - Make them petty, specific: - Hermes leaving three identical voicemails in a row, each more self-justifying. - Nike checking her reflection in dark windows, clearly insecure about waning relevance. - Zeus-CEO exhausted, drinking terrible office coffee at 2 a.m., grumbling about shareholder gods. - Let gods have side obsessions: - Poseidon addicted to aquarium cams. Ares coaching kids’ boxing with confusing tenderness. Even sprinkled lightly, that specificity screams “human writer.” g) Safety around class, race, and culture Our outline: - Lightly touches working-class stakes. - Uses Greek pantheon as default. - Critiques corporate worship but at a comfortable distance. Risks: - Flattens real-world dynamics into aesthetic set dressing. - Feels like it’s tiptoeing: inclusive, but vague. Potential humanizing direction: - Deliberate choices: - Decide concretely where Mara lives, what neighborhood feels like. - Anchor in one cultural context and treat it with specificity. - Allow some friction: - How Mara’s background shapes her susceptibility to Apex’s promises. - The discomfort of saying “no” to what could actually help her family. 4. Brainstorm: How to make this concept and plan feel more human Again, not rewriting yet—just seeding possibilities. Character-level ideas: - Make Mara less pristine: - She initially uses the sneakers for petty stuff: - Skipping lines. Humiliating a bully in a race. Running away from a family argument. - She feels genuine guilt when her friend is hurt, but also denial and rationalization. - She only slowly admits (even to herself) that she likes being worshipped. - Deepen relationships: - Friend isn’t just supportive; maybe they: - Want their own shot and resent being in Mara’s shadow. - Are seduced by Apex’s polished narrative even more than Mara is. - Mom isn’t just weary: - She might actively push Mara toward Apex: “Take the deal. We need this.” - That complicates the moral choice deeply. - Unresolved threads: - Mara never fully repairs one relationship. - Hermes doesn’t cleanly become “good.” He’s amused, opportunistic, affectionate. World/plot-level ideas: - Messier climax: - Mara’s big act doesn’t cleanly “wake everyone up.” - Instead: - Some people cheer; others boo; most scroll on. - Apex reframes her as part of their “authentic rebel” branding. - Gods adapt; they always do. That’s unsettling, more truthful. - Smaller, sharper stakes: - Rather than “altering cosmic balance,” emphasize: - She refuses to let her narrative be fully owned. - She wins (or loses) a personal boundary with consequences. - Ambiguous magic: - Are the sneakers empowering her, or just amplifying what’s there? - Did the stadium disaster happen because of gods, or because of faulty tech? - Let doubt coexist with spectacle. Stylistic ideas: - Allow tonal shifts: - Deadpan funny moments right next to sacred-feeling images. - Embarrassing or awkward dialogue that isn’t smoothed. - Ditch some clean metaphor: - Don’t always neatly equate attention=worship in the text. - Present contradictions: - A kid’s joy at fast shoes that’s not sinister. - An Apex-sponsored athlete who’s genuinely proud, not brainwashed. - Make gods surprising: - Give at least one god behavior that defies their symbolic role. - Or show that “brand” is one mask; they have older, stranger facets. Meta-structural ideas: - Play with chapter rhythm: - One chapter could be largely internal, low-key. - Another could be disorientingly quick episodic snapshots (journalistic coverage, social media snippets) of the aftermath. - A human writer might disrupt the exact “one big beat per chapter” template. - Build in silence: - Let some questions never get explained. - Let Mara hold back information from reader briefly, then confess. 5. Summary of critique Where we are: - The plan is strong, clear, and cinematic. - But it’s also very “LLM textbook”: neat structure, high thematic clarity, clean moral arc, controllable gods, resolvable conflict. What to aim for: - More specific, less generic. - More contradiction, less moral tidiness. - More uncertainty and cost. - Gods and systems that are adaptive, not easily defeated. - Emotional dynamics that don’t fully heal on schedule. When we move to revise the plan, we’ll want to: - Introduce intentional rough edges. - Let the ending resist full closure. - Ground the magic/world in personal, sensory detail. - Complicate the roles of Apex, Hermes, and Mara. If you’d like, the next step can be: take this critique and redesign the chapter plan to intentionally break a few of those “AI-neat” patterns while keeping the core premise.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention Core goal: Tell a compact, emotionally honest, slightly messy modern myth where “gods wore sneakers” is not a gimmick but the living logic of the world: divinity is how you move through it, how you’re seen, what you stand on. The story should feel like something a specific human cared to write, not like an exercise in clean structure. Key choices: - Protagonist: - Mara Ortiz, 17, Latina, public school kid in a dense modern city (concretely: Queens/NYC, but we won’t overdescribe). - Fast as hell, but always a fraction short of what scouts want. - Family: single mom (Rosa), younger brother; money is tight; pressure is real. - Mara is not spotless: competitive, proud, tempted by shortcuts, very sensitive to humiliation. - Gods and world: - Old gods exist here, mostly Greek-flavored but with hints that others are around. - People don’t know them as “Zeus” or “Nike” outright; they’re executives, influencers, coaches, hustlers. Their names and brands blur. - “Gods wore sneakers” = literal (their divinity would crack concrete otherwise), and symbolic (they walk among us, chasing relevance in our lanes). - Sneakers are contracts and converters: - Authentic divine pairs channel real aspects (speed, victory, storm, etc.). - Corporate/divine hybrids (like Apex) are gods industrializing worship through consumerism. - Core situation: - Hermes slips Mara a pair of his sneakers, for reasons that are not pure. - Apex (a divine-tech sports brand led by thunder-god CEO + Nike-like figure) wants to standardize miracles via their own shoes. - Mara becomes contested ground: her talent + Hermesian kicks draw both interest and danger. - She must decide what to do with power that is at once gift, trap, and amplification of what she already is. - Tone and style: - Close third-person past, anchored in Mara’s POV. - Language: clear, lean, but with spikes of strangeness; not over-poetic. - Mood blend: - Grounded teenage life (buses, group chats, fluorescent-lit hallways). - Weird sacred bleed-through (murals watching, laces glimmering, subway tunnels bending). - Dark humor and vulnerability; room for pettiness and selfishness. - Emotional honesty over thematic tidiness. - Intend: - Let some questions hang. - Let some relationships stay strained. - Let gods remain dangerous, adaptive, not neatly fixed. - Thematic focus: - Attention and worship: - How brands, gods, institutions feed on what we look at. - Nobody is above wanting to be seen. - Agency and compromise: - You can’t stand outside systems entirely, but you can choose how you’re used. - Power as amplification: - The sneakers don’t create a hero; they crank up whoever wears them. - Myth as street-level: - Gods at crossings and locker rooms, miracles at bus stops, epiphanies on cracked asphalt. - What to avoid: - Over-explaining the metaphysics. - Cartoon-villain corporations; Apex should have seductive logic. - A clean “we solved exploitation” ending. - Overly ornate moralizing or Instagram-deep insights. - Too many gods / pantheons; we’ll hint but keep focus tight. - Structure philosophy: - Still 8 chapters (~1000 words each), each with a purpose, but: - Allow emotional “waste” (quiet, uncomfortable beats). - Accept an ending that’s a shift, not a cure. - Keep lens tight on Mara; cosmic stuff filters through her needs and blind spots. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1: False Start Purpose: - Drop us into Mara’s life fast. - Show what the stakes feel like from the inside. - Introduce Hermes’ sneakers via a vivid, personal moment. Beats: - City invitational heat. Mara in worn-down trainers, heart hammering. Scouts in the stands. She needs this. - We stay tight in her head: her mom’s hands counting tips, her brother’s asthma inhaler, the future balanced on a starting pistol. - She runs a personal best—but loses by a hair. Again. Public, humiliating, familiar. - After, her best friend and teammate Lila tries to console; Mara snaps a bit, ashamed of her own bitterness. - In a cold, dim mood she wanders and ducks into a tiny sneaker shop she doesn’t remember seeing: shelves of every era’s shoes, faint smell of rain on hot pavement. - Behind the counter: a wiry older guy in a track jacket, smirking. (Hermes, but he never says so.) - He calls out her time before she tells him. - Offers a pair of light, white-and-gold runners with tiny stitched wings: “On the house. Consider it… overdue.” - Mara protests weakly, then takes them. Outside, she looks back: the shop’s fluorescent sign flickers, name half-legible, already different. - She slips the shoes on in an alley. The city’s noise hushes. One testing step carries her twenty yards—too fast, too clean, like space folded. - She yanks them off, shaken, both thrilled and scared. Chapter 2: Ghost Lanes Purpose: - Show what the sneakers do and hint at the gods, but keep mystery. - Ground this in Mara’s daily grind and flaws. Beats: - Dawn run. Mara wears the new sneakers “just to see.” - The streets tilt. Crosswalk lights hold green for her. Locked park gate blurs as she passes through a gap that shouldn’t exist. - Peripheral glimpses: - A man on a bench with antlers’ shadow. - A woman’s reflection with an owl’s eyes. - A delivery rider on a bike who is in three places at once. - Vertigo: she stops by the East River, shoes humming. She realizes: this is not normal gear. - Back in school: - Teammates awe at her sudden ease in drills when she tests just a fraction of the shoes’ power. - Lila jokes, “What, made a deal with the devil?” It hits too close. - At a bodega, a sharp, handsome Apex rep (Kade) notices her duffel, her shoes’ glint. Says, “Careful where you run in those. People notice.” - That night she returns to the shop—finds a dusty, long-closed storefront. Gates rusted. A homeless guy out front says it’s been like that for years. - Scared, she tells herself she imagined things. Then she pulls the sneakers out again. They look back at her, almost expectant. - She decides: one real test, at Saturday’s smaller meet. If it’s real, she’ll use it. If it’s cursed, she’ll deal with it. Chapter 3: First Miracle, First Lie Purpose: - Show the high of using the shoes publicly. - Introduce consequences: attention, corporate/god interest, and Mara’s own dishonesty. Beats: - Local meet, bleachers half-full. No scouts, supposedly. Mara laces up the winged shoes. - Gun goes off. The world tunnels. She floats, flies. Wins by a ridiculous margin. New record. Audience stunned. - For a second, everyone’s gaze is on her; she feels it like a warm electric tide feeding into the shoes. - The scoreboard glitches; the PA system crackles with distant thunder. - Coach pulls her aside: “What happened? That’s not just training.” - Mara laughs it off, lies: “I’ve been pushing. Guess it clicked.” It stings to say; it also feels good. - Lila’s conflicted: proud but wary. Saw something in Mara’s stride that didn’t look human. - On the sideline: Kade, in a sleek Apex bomber, with a tall woman in clean, luminous sneakers (Nike-like figure, goes by Ny). - They’re “impressed,” invite her to tour Apex HQ, talk partnership. - On her way home, the wiry shopkeeper (Hermes) is suddenly jogging beside her on a stretch of highway shoulder that shouldn’t allow pedestrians. - He calls the shoes “mine, on loan.” Tells her gods have to wear sneakers now so they don’t shatter the pavement. - Half-warning, half-flirting with danger: “Those people from Apex? They want to package what’s on your feet. And what’s in your head.” - Won’t answer straight why he chose her. Vanishes mid-stride. - Mara gets home buzzing. Checks her socials: shaky videos of her impossible run going minor-viral. DMs from randos. - Last beat: She tells her mom only that she “did good.” Leaves out everything else. Chapter 4: Apex Offers Purpose: - Temptation and partial revelation. - Show Apex as seductive, not just evil; complicate choices. Beats: - Mara visits Apex HQ: glass, screens, sneaker museum. It feels like a temple that knows it’s a temple. - Ny (Nike-ish) and the CEO (call him Mr. Zeno; thunder motifs) meet her. - They’re disarmingly human: Ny jokes about bad turf fields; Zeno mentions growing up poor. - They frame Apex as “giving average kids a piece of the divine stride.” - They talk scholarships, family support, a signature shoe line: MARA//MERCURY. - Subtle off-notes: - A wall-sized map pulsing where their shoes “light up” in cities—worship metrics. - Testers on treadmills running in Apex shoes, eyes a bit glazed, images beamed to big screens. - They ask to see her shoes. She hesitates; they drop it but exchange a look. - Ny quietly warns: “Wild relics like that? They burn people up. Our tech makes it safe. You deserve safe.” - It sounds almost kind. - As Mara leaves, she sees a kid trying cheap Apex trainers: - For a heartbeat, the kid’s outline gilds and stutters onto a screen labeled “RISING.” The kid blinks, dazed, pleased. - Nobody screams. It’s normal here. - Outside, Hermes loiters, eating a pretzel. - “They’re not lying, you know,” he says. “Safe is boring. Safe is theirs.” - Mara goes home with a glossy Apex packet and a knot in her stomach. Chapter 5: Impact Zone Purpose: - Midpoint disaster: power, desire, and systems collide. - Show Mara at her ugliest and most vulnerable, not just heroic. Beats: - Big invitational. Real scouts. Apex banners everywhere. Ny and Kade present. - At home pre-race: - Mom urges her to sign with Apex: “They’re offering what nobody else will. This is how we get out.” - Mara resents that it sounds like selling herself; also resents that it’s obviously practical. - In the locker room: - Lila confronts her about secrets, Apex, the weirdness. “Are we still running the same race?” - Mara deflects, defensive. Lila leaves hurt. - Kade corners Mara trackside: - “Wear ours. We’ll back you no matter what happens out there.” - He hands her prototype Apex shoes that hum faintly. They feel wrong. - Hermes appears briefly near the starting blocks: - “My shoes, my rules,” he says. “But you choose who gets your stride.” - Mara, pissed at being cornered by everyone, chooses Hermes’ sneakers. - Not purely noble; also out of spite. - Race: - When she runs, the world tears open. She’s in ghost lanes: gods in the crowd peel out of disguises; Apex shoes on other runners flare, trying to keep up. - Ny and Zeno activate something—remote tech, a blessing—that spikes power to their sponsored runners, clashing with Hermes’ current. - The clash manifests as a shockwave: - Lights explode; part of the track buckles. - Lila on the sidelines gets knocked down badly. Panic. - Mara wins—but sirens wail. People are hurt. Videos show unnatural glitches. - Zeno steps in as savior publicly; implies Mara’s “unauthorized equipment” caused it. - Mara, shaking, sees Lila loaded into an ambulance, meets her accusing, scared eyes. - End on Mara’s sick realization: “I did this. I liked doing this. And they’re already using it.” Chapter 6: Fracture Purpose: - Strip away illusions, allies; force Mara inward. - Make things not okay. Beats: - Aftermath days: - Media clips: “Miracle or menace?” Apex subtly pushes narrative that unregulated relics/endowed athletes are dangerous; Apex tech is responsible. - School, coach, federation asking what shoes she wore. She lies, inconsistently. - Rosa is furious and afraid: “If they’re offering to help, take it. We can’t fight these people.” - Hospital: Lila with a concussion, sprained shoulder, season wrecked. - Their conversation goes badly: - Mara tries to explain “it’s bigger than us” without sounding insane. - Lila: “You chose bigger than us over not killing me.” - No clean forgiveness. - Mara meets Hermes in a liminal subway car that is briefly empty, moving nowhere. - She demands truth: Did he set her up as his weapon? - Hermes, deflective then honest in flashes: - “I liked you because you run angry and honest. Thought you’d tear holes in their pretty plans.” - “Yeah, I used you. We all do. That’s how stories work.” - He offers no apology; only a shrugging, painful respect. - In rage and grief, Mara rips at the sneakers; the laces snap—not just rubber but a crack of distant thunder. - Power drains. The city feels flat. - She walks home barefoot, noticing how much slower pain arrives without magic. - End quietly: Mara staring at the broken shoes in her room. No idea what to do. No epiphany yet. Chapter 7: Terms and Conditions Purpose: - Mara chooses a path that’s hers, not cleanly heroic. - Prepare a climax that is personal-scale but symbolically sharp. Beats: - Time jump: a week or two. Lila not talking to her. Apex narrative settling in. - Mara gets a final, formal offer: Apex will “clear her name,” pay Lila’s bills, sponsor her family—if she signs and hands over the relic shoes. - Rosa wants her to sign; it hurts. “I am tired of you having to be noble.” - Mara wanders the city with the broken sneakers in a tote. - Notices small divine leaks: a woman with too many keys (Hecate-ish), a kid whose beat-up sneakers sparkle when he jumps. - She finds a tiny repair kiosk under the tracks; old woman with cigarette, thick glasses. - The woman recognizes Hermes’ work, says: “You can’t unmake a pact, only write over it.” - Offers new laces cut from dull red bus handles and police tape—mortal materials. “Tie them the way you mean it.” - Mara relaces the sneakers herself, fingers shaking. - She makes no grand speech; just thinks, fiercely: No more being anyone’s mascot. If these amplify me, they amplify my terms. - She meets Hermes on a pedestrian bridge: - Tells him: “I’ll wear them once more. Not for you. Not for them. If you try to spin it, that’s on you.” - Hermes grins, half-proud, half-predatory. “That’s the spirit.” - Plan: - Apex launch event is coming: they’ll unveil a line that “safeguards” humanity from wild miracles. - Mara’s not going to expose all gods or free humanity. She’s going to ruin their neat story in front of an audience—and live with the fallout. - Stakes are both small (her getting blackballed, family pissed) and huge (narrative control). Chapter 8: Gods on Asphalt Purpose: - Deliver a climax that serves the prompt and the themes without fake closure. - End with a textured, unsettled, human-feeling resolution. Beats: - Apex launch: outdoor stage, cameras, drones, star athletes in glowing shoes. Feels like church with better lighting. - Zeno and Ny preach “responsible miracles” and “ending chaos.” Subtext: centralizing worship. - Mara appears uninvited, in her relaced Hermes sneakers, stepping onto the track that circles the stage. - Security moves; Ny signals to wait. The spectacle loves drama. - Mara runs. - Not as blindingly fast as before, but wrong enough: the screens ghost, trying to track her; other athletes’ shoes flicker. - People see double: for moments, the gods behind Apex shine through—beautiful, hungry. - She doesn’t give a neat speech. When handed a mic (because of course they try to co-opt), she says something short and dangerous: - That no brand can promise safe miracles. - That what’s on her feet is older and not for sale. - That they almost let her trade a friend’s body and her own name for a logo. - It’s halting, imperfect—not a TED Talk—but it cuts. - Then, crucially, she doesn’t smash the shoes or hand them to a new savior. - She steps down off the stage into the crowd. - Runs a small impromptu relay on the asphalt outside with a cluster of random kids/teens who chased her there. - For a blink, when they grab the baton or brush her shoulder, their cheap sneakers spark—tiny, uneven miracles. - Apex can’t fully spin it: - Some will: “We empower rebels too.” Others see the crack. - Hermès laughs from a rooftop; Ny looks furious and impressed; Zeno’s jaw tight but calculating. - Later: - Mara is likely blacklisted by federations tied to Apex. Some scouts still call; others don’t. - Rosa is upset but also realizes her daughter refused to be owned; that’s not nothing. - Lila messages once: “Saw what you did. Still mad. Also… it was badass.” No hug; just a thread. - Closing image: - Evening. Normal city noise. - Mara runs alone across a bridge, in the Hermes sneakers now stained and scuffed. - A man in busted high-tops and a woman in glittered trainers nod as she passes; something in their gaze older than buildings. - Her stride is strong but human; sometimes, on certain steps, the world leans in her direction. - Final line (spirit, not verbatim): gods still wear sneakers, and so does she. The difference is who’s writing the story in the soles. This plan keeps the 8-chapter spine tight enough for ~8000 words, leans into specificity, imperfection, and ambiguity, centers the prompt (gods in sneakers as the site of power and compromise), and resists the easy, over-neat resolutions of typical AI plotting.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Mara Ortiz Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - 17, lives in a small two-bedroom apartment in Queens with her mom and 9-year-old brother, Nico. - Dad bailed when she was 10. His old Knicks hoodie is still in her drawer; she never wears it, but doesn’t throw it away either. - Has been “the fast girl” since middle school; it’s the only category that’s felt like hers, not handed down or taken. - Carries a constant low-level fear of becoming stuck—still in the same grocery aisles, same buses, counting coins at the register at 30. - Idiosyncrasies: - Counts breaths and sidewalk squares when she’s anxious. (Four steps inhale, four steps exhale.) - Eats cereal dry from the box at midnight while watching race videos on mute. - Hates running with headphones; wants to hear her footfalls, other people’s footsteps. - Secretly loves tacky angel wing tattoos/shirts/shoes but is slightly embarrassed by it. - Flaws: - Stubborn to the point of self-sabotage; if pushed, she’ll say no just to prove she can. - Prideful: lies instead of admitting fear; can’t stand being pitied. - Competitive with Lila in ways she’d never confess; sometimes mentally keeps a ledger of who got more praise. - Tends to turn anger inward until it explodes sideways at the wrong person. Physicality: - 5'4", compact, runner’s build: strong legs, wiry arms, not fragile. - Dark hair usually yanked into a too-tight ponytail; curls frizz out around her hairline when she’s stressed. - Scar on her left knee from wiping out on a cracked playground track as a kid. - Usually in school-issued track gear or faded tees and sweats; her regular sneakers are worn smooth. - Carries herself like she’s braced for contact—shoulders tight, chin up. Eye contact is direct when she chooses, evasive when vulnerable. - In motion: precise, efficient, almost economical—like she’s allergic to wasted movement. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Get a track scholarship: not for glory so much as escape and proof she isn’t stuck. - Protect Nico from the grind she sees wearing down her mom. - Be recognized for her work, not just used for someone else’s story. - Once she gets the shoes: figure out if this miracle is hers, or if she’s just a delivery system for someone else. - Allegiances: - Family first, but that gets complicated when “family” urges her toward choices she distrusts. - With Lila: complicated loyalty; she loves her, envies her, doesn’t always choose her. - Deep reluctance to belong to any institution (Apex, gods, etc.) after she feels their hands closing. - Relationships: - Rosa (mom): Love mixed with resentment; Rosa is tired, blunt, sometimes too practical. Mara hates feeling like an investment. - Nico: Soft spot. They have dumb in-jokes. He times her sprints with a toy watch. - Lila: Best friend/rival; they met on the freshman track, both pushing too hard. - Hermes: A dangerous mentor/annoying uncle vibe; Mara doesn’t trust him but is drawn to his honesty about his dishonesty. - Apex (Ny, Zeno, Kade): Temptation and threat; she’s angry they understand her hunger so well. Voice samples: - Internal: “If I were just a little faster, just a little less me, this would be easy.” - To Lila, snapping then regretting it: “Not everything I do is some conspiracy against you, okay? Sometimes I just run.” - To Hermes: “If this is a fairy tale, you picked the wrong girl. I don’t do chosen.” - At Apex, under her breath: “You people really put stained glass in a sneaker store.” # Lila Park Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - 17, Korean-American, lives a few subway stops from Mara in a quieter, slightly better-off neighborhood. - Parents run a laundromat. Lila does homework by the humming machines, studies meet footage between folding shirts. - She started running after a PE teacher told her she wasn’t “built for sprints”; turned that into a grudge-fueled project. - Personality: - Calm on the surface, razor-focused underneath. - Observant; picks up on moods before words. - Has a drier, sharper sense of humor than Mara—less fiery, more surgical. - Idiosyncrasies: - Color-codes everything: notes, playlists, even her socks before a race. - Taps out race rhythms with her fingers on any surface. - Has a tiny notebook of race times—hers, Mara’s, pros she admires—with notes like “ate garbage; still won; icon.” - Flaws: - Jealous of Mara’s raw explosiveness; feels like she has to earn every centimeter. - Hates confrontations; lets resentment compost until it’s bitter. - Low-key terrified of being left behind; this makes her clingy, then passive-aggressive. Physicality: - 5'3", lean, with deceptively powerful thighs; people underestimate her. - Straight black hair usually in a practical braid; wisps everywhere after workouts. - Wears glasses off-track, contacts for races; constantly losing her lens case. - Demeanor: composed, a bit reserved. Laughs in quick bright bursts and then shuts down again. - On the track: fluid form, technically perfect; she looks like she’s done every drill twice. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Get into a good college; running is a means, not the whole story. - Prove she’s not just “Mara’s friend;” she’s her own athlete. - Protect Mara from self-destruction while resenting that role. - Allegiances: - Loyal to their track squad; hates when it becomes a backdrop for someone else’s myth. - Initially trusts structured help (coaches, brands) more than stray weird old guys. - Relationships: - Mara: closest friend, closest rival. Loves her, fears her light. The hurt when Mara lies lands hard. - Lila’s parents: push for stability, not fame. They like Mara, until headlines happen. - Apex: Sees the allure. It sounds… reasonable. That makes their manipulation effective. - She becomes the human cost in the midpoint disaster and the barometer of whether Mara has truly changed. Voice samples: - To Mara, early: “You know you’re allowed to win without apologizing to the universe, right?” - In her notebook (never shown aloud): “Mara 55.2 / me 55.9. Not mad. Just… tired.” - To Mara, in hospital: “You say it’s bigger than us, but I’m the one who hit the ground.” - Later text: “I’m still mad. Also, you completely torched them. So. Yeah.” # Hermes (a.k.a. "Mr. Vega" in the shop) Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Old Greek god of messengers, roads, liars, athletes, and thieves. In this era, also patron of delivery drivers, postal workers, smugglers, late-night subway musicians. - Has been many people in many cities; currently prefers a 40s-ish wiry guy with a runner’s build, faded tattoos, cheap gold chain. - Personality: - Charming, glib, too quick. Dodges straight questions on instinct. - Genuinely loves mortals who move—runners, walkers, hustlers. - Thinks in routes and angles; rarely goes straight from A to B. - Idiosyncrasies: - Leaves half-eaten snacks everywhere. “For luck,” he says. It’s really offerings to himself. - Constantly fiddling with laces: tying, untying, looping elaborate knots without looking. - Swaps languages mid-sentence; not to show off, but because they’re all his. - Flaws: - Habitually instrumentalizes people. He may like you; he’ll still use you. - Addicted to the game: if there’s an easier, kinder route and a trickier, clever one, he picks the trick. - Cowardly at scale: avoids direct war with heavier gods; prefers proxies. Physicality: - Lean, restless body; moves like a runner warming up, always. - Buzzed dark hair with a streak of silver; mischievous eyes, crow’s feet that suggest laughter and trouble. - Sneakers always immaculate, no matter how beat-up the rest of him looks. - When his mask slips, shadows around his ankles look like fluttering wings; reflections show multiple copies stepping in sync. - Occupies space like he owns—and is bored by—it; leans on counters, lounges on air. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Undermine Apex’s attempt to centralize divine power; he doesn’t want a regulated pantheon. - Keep the world full of back doors, shortcuts, contraband miracles. - Stay worshiped, in the small ways: a whispered “please” before crossing, a lucky coin, a well-worn pair of shoes. - Allegiances: - Nominally with old gods threatened by Apex, but allergic to committees. - Loyal to the concept of movement itself more than any person. - Relationships: - With Mara: fascination. She’s quick, pissed-off, resistant. Ideal piece for his kind of play. - With Ny/Nike and Zeno: ex-colleagues, frenemies. He likes needling them. - With humans generally: amused, half-affectionate. He doesn’t want them crushed; they’re his favorite chaos agents. - He does feel a twinge when Mara is hurt by his choices; he just won’t call it guilt. Voice samples: - First meeting: “Nice form. Shame about the shoes.” - When she confronts him: “You’re not special, kid. You’re just the first one to call me on my crap out loud. It’s… refreshing.” - Offhand: “Gods wear sneakers now. Sandals were murder on the MTA.” - After she sets her own terms: “See, this is why I picked you. You steal the deal right back.” # Ny (Nike-esque) Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Embodiment of victory, adapted. Once winged in marble; now the brand-side genius behind Apex’s image and athlete program. - Manifests as “Ny,” head of athlete relations and brand vision. - Personality: - Polished, magnetic, and genuinely good at making people feel seen. - Believes in excellence, discipline, image consistency. - Thinks in tags, not hashtags: labels that stick to people. - Idiosyncrasies: - Collects old finish-line photos; can recite times and wind speeds decades back. - Adjusts people’s posture unconsciously when talking to them, angling them toward cameras. - Never fully sits back; always exquisitely on the edge of something. - Flaws: - Believes ends justify branding: if people feel inspired, who cares if their awe feeds gods? - Patronizing without realizing; assumes she knows what’s best for “her” athletes. - Blind to those who can’t or won’t fit a clean victory narrative. Physicality: - Tall, lean, in that runner-model way. Muscles like drawn lines, not bulk. - Brown skin with a subtle, permanent sunlit sheen when she moves. - Always in spotless, limited-release sneakers; laces sharp, symmetrical. - Smile that feels like a camera flash. - When divinity leaks, faint translucent wings shadow behind her shoulder blades in reflections. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Save victory from randomness. Systematize it. - Make Apex the altar where all future champions are crowned. - Protect mortals (and gods) from “wild” relics causing chaos that breaks the brand. - Allegiances: - Firmly tied to Zeno/Apex’s centralized vision; it gives her reach. - Loyal to winners; less so to anyone who can’t keep up. - Relationships: - With Mara: sees a brand story: scrappy, fast, savable. Frustrated when Mara goes off-script. - With Hermes: exasperated by his chaos; half-suspects he’s necessary, hates that. - With Zeno: power partners; they argue aesthetics vs. control. - She is not lying when she says she can help Mara; that sincerity makes her dangerous. Voice samples: - To Mara: “You don’t owe anyone smallness. Let us make sure you’re big on your terms.” - In a boardroom: “Fear is off-brand. We sell awe and safety, in that order.” - To Hermes, quietly: “Every mess you make, I turn into a highlight reel. You’re welcome.” # Zeno (Zeus-adjacent CEO) Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Thunder god rebranded as apex executive: CEO of Apex, Lord of Launches, keeper of coverage. - Personality: - Authoritative, charming in a practiced way. - Plays benevolent patriarch to young athletes; knows their pressure points. - Calculating: always factoring legal, divine, and PR risk. - Idiosyncrasies: - Weather changes slightly when he’s furious; barometric pressure drops in meetings. - Drinks terrible office coffee; refuses artisan stuff. “We sell aspirational, we drink whatever’s in the pot.” - Keeps a lightning-bolt paperweight he taps when thinking. - Flaws: - Hubristic: convinced only he can manage gods + mortals without catastrophe. - Believes control is kindness; can’t see the violence in it. - Thin-skinned about disrespect; will overreact to small acts of defiance. Physicality: - Late 40s appearance, broad-shouldered; tailored suits cut so he can move quickly if he had to. - Hair shot with dignified grey, never out of place. - Apex sneakers subtly integrated even with suits: monochrome, authoritative. - Carries himself like a keynote stage is his natural habitat. Occupies vertical space. - When power leaks: faint ozone smell, lights flicker. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Consolidate divine power streams into something predictable. - Prevent loose gods and relics from causing PR disasters that weaken all of them. - Maintain his primacy in this new order. - Allegiances: - To Apex as his vehicle. - To a curated pantheon of “responsible” gods; would sideline the rest. - Relationships: - With Ny: respects her; needs her. They disagree in private, united in public. - With Hermes: sees him as a liability and an old friend he’d rather domesticate. - With Mara: a potential asset or a threat. If she won’t sign, she must be framed, contained, or broken. - He genuinely thinks Mara + Apex could be a win-win. When she refuses, he takes it personally. Voice samples: - To Mara (warm): “You’ve been running alone a long time. Let us run with you.” - In a meeting: “We don’t crush miracles. We license them.” - After her stunt: “She thinks she’s made a point. She’s made content.” # Rosa Ortiz Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Mara’s mother. Late 30s. Came to NYC from Puerto Rico in her early 20s. - Works two jobs: diner mornings, night cleaning at an office tower. - Personality: - Tough, practical, emotionally guarded. - Loves her kids with a ferocity that comes out sideways, as criticism or orders. - Prays sometimes, but mostly to keep going. - Idiosyncrasies: - Saves plastic bags; folds them into tight little triangles. - Falls asleep sitting up with the TV on; claims she heard everything. - Has a superstition about new shoes: never put the box on the table; it’s bad luck. - Flaws: - Puts unrealistic hopes on Mara’s success; sees it as “our way out.” - Dismisses emotional nuance as “drama” because there’s no time. - Will push Mara toward deals that feel wrong because immediate survival trumps abstract danger in her mind. Physicality: - Short, sturdy; strong arms from work. - Deep undereye shadows; chipped nail polish. - Moves briskly, efficiently; rarely sits for long without multitasking. - Voice can cut through a room, but softens when she thinks nobody’s listening. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Pay rent, keep kids safe, maybe one day breathe. - Make sure Mara has better choices than she did—and fears those choices may come with prices she can’t calculate. - Allegiances: - Family over pride. If Apex offers security, she’s listening. - Relationship with Mara: - Fraught tender core. Projecting her desperation onto Mara’s talent. - Constant tension: “Be exceptional” vs. “Don’t risk anything.” - With Nico: more openly gentle; he’s still small, still “fixable.” Voice samples: - To Mara: “Mijita, I don’t need miracles. I need the landlord off my back. If they give you that, you take it.” - On seeing Apex contract: “Rich people don’t offer you something for nothing. Read the small letters.” - After the disaster: “I don’t understand this god business. I understand bills.” # Kade Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Apex talent scout / handler. Mortally born; got pulled into Ny’s orbit young. - Former almost-pro runner whose injury ended his career; Apex gave him purpose and a paycheck. - Personality: - Smooth, affable, makes you feel like he gets you. - Dangerously good listener. - Genuinely believes Apex saves kids from getting eaten by wilder gods. - Idiosyncrasies: - Always in branded gear but scuffed—lives in it. - Fidgets with his smart watch; tracks his steps obsessively. - Knows everyone’s PRs by heart; compliments with eerie precision. - Flaws: - Compartmentalizes: “I’m helping” to drown out doubts. - Cowardly about standing up to Zeno/Ny when they cross lines; survival instinct strong. - Sees athletes as stories first, people second, without admitting it. Physicality: - Late 20s, lean, with a slight limp when tired. - Handsome in a “local sports anchor” way: open face, neat beard. - Easy posture, hands open, nonthreatening; moves like he’s always arriving, never intruding. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Spot talent before anyone else; deliver them to Apex. - Believe he’s preventing kids from being used worse by others. - Secure his own precarious status. - Allegiances: - To Apex; they saved him. He owes. - But he has a soft spot for stubborn kids like Mara; they remind him of himself. - Relationships: - With Mara: equal parts handler, big brother, and recruiter. He likes her; will still sell her out if told. - With Ny: admires, mildly scared. - With Hermes: uneasy; can sense something “off” when he’s around. Voice samples: - To Mara: “I’ve seen kids blow out their knees chasing ghosts. We can give you something solid.” - Alone after her refusal (to himself): “Could’ve been easy, kid.” - To Ny: “She’s not like the others. You can’t just slap a logo on her and call it a day.” These profiles should give us enough specificity, contradiction, and texture to write them as people, not placeholders—while keeping them compact enough to fit inside an 8-chapter, ~8k-word spine.

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Mara had run this race in her head a hundred times, and it never ended like this. “Set.” She crouched into the blocks.
