satire aimed at the fictional secret parasite bureaucracy instead. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1 – The Text - Late night in Immy’s boxy bedroom above the nail salon. - She’s awake past midnight watching a trashy vampire film and messaging Callum. - Her cracked phone buzzes: unknown number, just “🩸🩸🩸”. - She and Callum: - Roast it (“edgy,” “2014 Tumblr called,” etc.). - Briefly wonder if it’s a scam, cult, or Aaliyah’s new drama promo. - Throwaway but eerie detail: - At exactly 00:03, power flickers, the street goes oddly quiet. - She notices a pale boy (Leon) standing under the streetlamp looking up at their block, but when she blinks he’s gone. - She shrugs it off with a horror-movie joke and goes to sleep. - Cliffhanger: in the morning, she discovers several classmates also got the same text; one kid (Kyle) hasn’t shown up to the group chat at all. Chapter 2 – The Crimson Service - School day: grey skies, dull tutor period, assembly. - Rumours: - Several students got the 🩸🩸🩸 text. - A Year 11 (Kyle) is “off sick” according to office, but no one’s heard from him. - Assembly: - Eleanor (perfect prefect) announces the school’s prestigious new “Crimson Service”: - A student leadership/charity scheme about “lifesaving donations” and “supporting vital medical research.” - Overly sleek slides featuring tasteful drops of red (eerily like the emojis). - Mildly sinister buzzwords about being “selected for something special.” - Aaliyah is excited, wants in for UCAS points and drama. - Callum is suspicious; Immy makes vampire jokes; they clock: - Some kids’ phones buzz during the assembly with the same emoji. - After school: - On the way home Immy sees Leon again near a mobile blood drive van parked on a side street; he seems out of place, almost too still. - End beat: - Immy gets a follow-up text from the same number: “Report: 7/3 confirmed. 🩸” - She has no idea what that means but it’s less funny now. Chapter 3 – Targets - Immy, Callum, and Aaliyah compare notes at lunch. - Aaliyah: didn’t get the text (wounded ego). - Callum: did get it; hates that he’s “mysteriously chosen.” - Immy: shows them the “7/3 confirmed” message. - They notice: - The people with 🩸🩸🩸 texts are a random cross-section but all: - Under 18, reasonably healthy-looking. - No obvious pattern, which annoys Callum’s pattern-hunting brain. - Encounter with Eleanor: - She approaches people who got the texts with unnerving confidence and invites them to a Crimson Service “information evening.” - She brushes off questions (“All will be explained; it’s an honour, really”). - Humour: the trio mock the cult vibes, plan to attend and expose the cringe. - After school: - Immy spots Mr Beckwith talking quietly with Leon in the corridor, handing him a stack of forms marked “Parental Consent.” - Leon glances at her, his eyes a bit too dark; Immy gets a shiver. - Night: - Another text: “Attendance mandatory. Midnight. 🩸🩸🩸” - Location: an attached image of the school’s science block floor plan with one lab highlighted. - Cliffhanger: - Immy jokes about being lured to a murder lab, but the text auto-deletes after she shows Aaliyah: properly spooky. Chapter 4 – Midnight Lab - Immy and Callum sneak out; Aaliyah fakes sleepover permissions but actually sneaks too. - Light comic beats: failed stealth, dodging nosy neighbour, discussion of appropriate footwear for potential murder. - They reach school; science block door is suspiciously unlocked. - Inside Lab: - A small group of students who got the text. - Eleanor running the show; Mr Beckwith present, trying to look benign. - Leon at the back, awkward and silent, sunglasses at midnight (“medical sensitivity,” Eleanor claims). - Presentation: - Eleanor frames Crimson Service as “elite voluntary donor programme” for an off-the-books “research partnership.” - Heavy on heroic rhetoric, light on specifics; contracts with tiny print. - Immy’s internal commentary undercuts the pomp. - Then: - A girl, Jaya, who hesitates to sign, suddenly goes faint; Leon tenses visibly. - For a moment Immy catches his teeth looking…wrong; blink-and-miss. - Tension spikes: - Eleanor implies that “the chosen” don’t really have the option to back out. - Mr Beckwith is uneasy; tries to stress “consent,” gets shut down. - End: - The trio refuse to sign, get a cold smile from Eleanor. - As they leave, Immy gets a new text: “Non-compliance flagged. 🩸” - The lab lights flicker red. Chapter 5 – Vampires Are Real (Unfortunately) - Next day: - Kyle is still missing. Staff give vague answers. - Jaya has a bandage on her arm and looks drained. - Immy confronts Mr Beckwith after class (half-joking, half-serious): - Tosses out vampire jokes. - He panics more than a normal person would, blurts: - “It’s safe. Mostly. No one’s meant to be harmed.” - Realises he’s said too much; ushers her out. - They follow Leon after school, spying. - Comic stealth failures; Aaliyah over-committed in disguise. - Alley confrontation: - Leon catches them. - They accuse him of being a cult recruiter / weirdo. - He reluctantly reveals: - Yes, he’s a vampire. - No, he doesn’t do murders. - The Crimson Service is supposed to be an ethical supply channel: fully voluntary donors, monitored, payments in bursary schemes, etc. - Mr Beckwith is his handler/liaison. - Someone, however, is abusing the system: - Rogue texts. - Pressure tactics. - Kyle’s disappearance. - Tone: - Played both funny (vampire apologising for being a cliché) and tense (they realise they’re in real danger). - End: - Another text to Immy: “Next in line. 🩸🩸🩸” - Leon looks horrified: “That’s not us.” Chapter 6 – The Rogue - Leon explains: - The official messages don’t look like that; the triple blood is a corruption. - The “7/3 confirmed” suggests numbers of compliant vs resistant recruits; someone tracking targets. - The trio: - Process the “vampires are real” revelation with snarky commentary and minor freak-outs. - Investigation: - Snoop through Crimson Service materials; Aaliyah charms a gullible sixth-former. - Callum hacks (clumsily) into a shared drive; finds: - Files indicating Eleanor has been arranging unsanctioned “appointments.” - References to “harvesting” under euphemisms. - They learn Kyle was scheduled for a “special opportunity” off-site and never checked back in. - Leon: - Admits vampires who go rogue attract lethal enforcement from their own kind; he suspects Eleanor is acting independently with an unknown buyer/partner, maybe not vampire. - Stakes: - The triple-blood texts to Immy and Callum mean Eleanor has marked them for a demonstration. - Plan: - Use the upcoming all-school evening event (Crimson Service launch) to expose Eleanor and intercept whatever she’s planning. - Leon will help but can’t be seen doing anything too overt without blowing wider secrecy. - End: - Text to all “chosen”: “Final selection tonight. Attendance compulsory. 🩸🩸🩸” - Our lot know that’s the trap. Chapter 7 – Blood, Fire Alarms, And Poor Life Choices - Evening at school: - Polished Crimson Service event with parents, governors, banners. - Eleanor glowing with self-satisfaction. - Our trio + Leon in infiltration mode: - Aaliyah backstage messing with AV. - Callum planted near fire alarm and mains switches. - Immy in the “chosen” group, wired (figuratively) to observe. - Discovery: - Eleanor plans to hand over selected students (including Immy) to a shadowy buyer in the science block after speeches; the buyer is a human trafficker-esque figure supplying blood / bodies to off-grid vamps (kept off-page, implied). - She uses the triple-blood texts as her control system. - Comic-chaotic sabotage: - Aaliyah hijacks the presentation: - Projector starts showing incriminating emails and files instead of Eleanor’s slideshow. - With some accidental memes thrown in. - Callum sets off fire alarm and cuts lights at key moment. - Tense showdown in red emergency lighting: - Eleanor corners Immy and a couple of others in the lab, ranting about “necessary sacrifices,” “system too slow,” “you should be proud.” - Leon intervenes; brief but sharp confrontation: - Eleanor uses a hidden blade/needle; Leon shrugs off small injuries. - Immy uses improvised weapons (Bunsen stand, mop) in fumbling, funny ways that still work. - Resolution: - The buyer flees when Leon bares actual fangs: fun reversal. - Eleanor tries to use a hostage; Immy bluffs that the whole thing is livestreaming (it isn’t). Eleanor falters. - Sirens audible: someone’s called real police/ambulance. - End: - Eleanor is pinned (by Leon/Immy/Callum teamwork) as adults burst in. - A last ominous triple-blood text pings on Eleanor’s phone from an unknown contact: hint of bigger world, but not resolved. Chapter 8 – Aftermath And New Rules - Next days: - Official story: some vague scandal about “misuse of student data and charity funds.” - Eleanor “withdrawn for personal reasons”; buyer quietly disappeared (off-screen vampire justice implied). - Kyle found alive (weakened but safe); Jaya recovering; no permanent on-page horrors. - Immy, Callum, and Aaliyah: - Debrief with Leon and Mr Beckwith in the science lab. - Learn: - Vampires have strict laws; Eleanor had been groomed/manipulated by an external contact. - The Crimson Service will be shut down/restructured. - Banter about: - How this is the worst extracurricular ever. - Whether they can put “prevented blood-trafficking ring” on CVs. - Tone: - Reflective but light. - Recognition that they were genuinely scared but handled it, mostly by sticking together. - Final beats: - Leon offers Immy a semi-official role as “consultant,” should any more weirdness crop up: “Sometimes it helps to have a human who watches too many horror films.” - Immy gets a new text: - From a now-saved contact “Leon (Definitely Vampire)”: - “🩸🩸🩸 = emergency. You’ll know if it’s real. Tea soon?” - She rolls her eyes but smiles: the symbol’s been reclaimed as their code. - Stinger: - As she puts her phone down, a different unknown number flashes once with: “👁️ See you soon.” - One last dry remark from Immy about sequels, then cut.
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
Good question, and great timing to ask it before drafting. I’ll break this into three parts: - How a human might naturally approach this piece from the given prompt. - Common LLM behaviours/tics that would hurt this kind of story (with specifics). - A deep critique of our current intention/plan through that lens, plus brainstorms on how to humanise it. Note: I’ll be frank and specific; this is about interrogating weaknesses, not self-congratulation. 1. How a human might approach this piece Given the prompt: “The text came just after midnight: 🩸🩸🩸” A human YA writer, especially with a darkly comic British brief, would likely: - Start with voice, not plot architecture: - They’d hear the protagonist’s voice first: the exact way they’d react to that text (the one-liner that pops right after). - They’d likely write a scrappy opening scene to find the tone—bedroom details, notification glow, an over-tired brain trying to decide if it’s creepy or just crap. - Draw heavily on specific lived/observed textures: - Actual council-estate stairwell smell. - The passive-aggressive posters in the school corridor (“Lateness is Theft!”). - How British teens actually talk when they’re tired, scared, or taking the piss. - Group chat dynamics: the ratio of text to reaction emojis to lurkers; the way one friend is always online at 00:03 for the wrong reasons. - Be less tidy, more instinctive early on: - They might not know it’s vampires or a cult yet. - They’d follow the unease, the social reality: “Who would send that? Why to me? Is this just some little psycho’s idea of banter?” - They’d be more willing to sit in the ambiguity for a bit, to let the weirdness and humour co-exist without a worked-out mythology. - Use humour that has edges: - Jokes that are a bit too mean, then walked back. - Moments where someone uses humour to dodge a genuine emotional beat or fear. - In-jokes that don’t get explained to the reader; you either catch them or you don’t. - Allow some structural mess: - Not every chapter ending would be a clean “cliffhanger line.” - Some scenes might linger on “unnecessary” but vivid details that build authenticity. - The resolution might leave more moral mess: complicated consequences, partial truths. - Let genuine risk and stakes bleed through: - Dark comedy doesn’t mean no one gets hurt. - A human might allow a truly unsettling moment (e.g. the way someone disappears, the way adults gaslight the kids’ worry) and not instantly undercut it with a quip. 2. Telltale LLM approaches that would hurt this piece Some general LLM tendencies and why they’re bad news here: - Overly safe: - Always pulling punches: danger feels theoretical, villains are cartoonish, nobody really gets hurt. - In darkly comic YA, this flattens tension. It reads like someone trying not to get in trouble. - Overly tidy: - Every setup paid off neatly, every mystery resolved, antagonist caught, authorities swoop in. - Feels artificial; real life—even in genre fiction—leaves residue and loose threads. - Also risks moralizing: “And the lesson is…” - Over-engineering the plot: - Prematurely locking into a well-organised conspiracy, clear factions, polished lore. - Teen characters become pawns in a schematic rather than agents making messy decisions. - Trying to sound “writerly”: - Overly ornate metaphors and similes, straining for “literary.” - It clashes with a British YA voice, which generally leans toward clean, sharp, observant, not purple. - Generic voice: - Interchangeable protagonists; sarcasm that could belong to anyone. - Banter that has the rhythm of “banter” but no specific content or callbacks. - Thin emotional interiority: - Characters feel anxious/afraid, but we get summary (“she was scared”) instead of that awkwardly human mix (fear + boredom + a weird craving for crisps). - Neutered specificity: - Content sanded down to avoid touching anything sharp: vague town, vague school, vague home life. - The story then floats; it’s “a” British town, not this one. This particular piece needs: - A point-of-view that’s so concrete and funny it couldn’t be auto-generated blandly. - Stakes that feel slightly unsafe (within boundaries) so it’s not just Scooby-Doo with emojis. - Mess: morally, emotionally, structurally. Not chaos, but some frayed edges. 3. Critique of our current intention & plan (where it lapses into LLM tropes) + brainstorms to humanise it I’ll go through key elements of the plan and call out likely pitfalls, then suggest more human directions. a) Core concept: ethical vampires + rogue human - LLM-ish pitfall: - This is neat. Too neat. - “Ethical vampires with bureaucracy” vs “evil prefect misusing system” is clever and tidy, and slots easily into an 8-chapter outline. - It risks reading like a high-concept CW pilot rather than a story filtered through one girl’s messy life. - The moral schema is obvious: “Some monsters are better than humans.” That can work, but it’s also a go-to trope. - Humanising brainstorm: - Muddy it a bit: - Let the “ethical” vamps be genuinely constrained but uncomfortably pragmatic, not perfect cinnamon rolls. - Maybe one of them has slipped before; Leon isn’t entirely clean. - Don’t make Eleanor purely cartoon evil: - Give her a warped rationale that has bite: resentment of how the school treats certain kids, pressure to be exceptional, fear of obscurity. - Let Immy half-understand her, which complicates the final condemnation. - Make the system messier: - Fewer clean labels (“official vs rogue”); more sense of a confused compromise between monsters and bureaucrats. b) Plot structure: classic 8-episode arc - LLM-ish pitfall: - Each chapter currently has a clear function: hook, escalation, twist, plan, showdown, epilogue. - That’s structurally sound but risks formula: - Cliffhanger every time. - Exactly one new major revelation per chapter. - Climax with perfectly synchronised sabotage. - Reads like “following a template” rather than following characters’ bad decisions. - Humanising brainstorm: - Allow some missteps and dead ends: - They suspect the wrong person for a whole chapter. - An attempted reveal flops; nobody believes them; it’s awkward, not heroic. - Let some chapter endings be small, unsettling moments: - Not a stinger text, just Immy realising she’s actually scared and can’t tell her mum why. - Introduce one or two unstructured scenes: - E.g., a bus ride conversation that doesn’t advance plot but deepens relationships and voice. c) Tone: darkly comic but careful - LLM-ish pitfall: - The intention leans hard on “no graphic, no real-world heavy stuff” (which is sensible) but the combination with vampires + cult + trafficking risks the opposite problem: - Sanitised horror: signalled but never properly felt. - Villainy existing in a consequence-free abstract space. - This is where LLMs often default to a weirdly frictionless faux-edginess. - Humanising brainstorm: - Let some consequences land: - Show Kyle’s absence actually affecting someone specific. - Have a moment where a character realises they nearly died and responds in an un-pretty way (anger, shaking, lashing out). - Integrate humour as defence, not eraser: - Immy cracks jokes that clearly cover panic. - A friend calls her on it once, briefly. - Allow one genuinely upsetting image: - Not gore, but, say, a row of consent forms with forged signatures, or a drained-looking kid being dismissed as “tired.” d) Characters: functional roles vs specific people - LLM-ish pitfall: - The current plan labels people by function: - “Sardonic goth protag” - “Anxious best friend” - “Chaotic drama friend” - “Awkward ethical vampire” - “Posh villain prefect” - These are good starting points but very stock. Output risks “quirky ensemble banter” without individual weirdness. - Humanising brainstorm: - Get oddly specific about each: - Immy: - Very particular fixations (a trashy horror franchise she irrationally defends; fear of dogs; hoards mugs). - A relationship with her mum/guardian that occasionally intrudes at the worst possible time. - Callum: - A niche hobby (speedcubing, weird Wikipedia wormholes, amateur FOI requests). - One moment where his anxiety is actually strategic and saves them. - Aaliyah: - Not just chaos gremlin; give her one sharp vulnerability—e.g. desperate to be seen as “big” after always being the comic relief. - Leon: - One genuinely un-vampirey trait; maybe he’s squeamish about needles, hates glamorising vampirism. - Eleanor: - Show her under pressure (family expectations, teacher favouritism); let her prick when people call her “perfect.” - Bake these specifics into plot beats: - Callum’s weird knowledge is what cracks something, not a generic “hacking.” - Aaliyah’s drama skills help her improvise convincingly when they’re nearly caught. e) The texts and tech: props vs lived reality - LLM-ish pitfall: - Using the emojis as markers for chapter beats: text arrives → cliffhanger → spooky. - But without capturing how teens actually interact with phones: delays, read receipts, leaving someone on delivered, spam, screenshots, chaotic group chats. - Humanising brainstorm: - Make the texting culture itself part of the story: - Short bursts of actual group chat transcripts with in-jokes, typos, confusion. - Moments where Immy stares at “typing…” bubbles that vanish. - Someone misreads the blood emoji as a period joke; creates tonal clash (funny but real). - Let tech screw them: - Phone dying at an actually inconvenient moment (not just ritualistic). - A crucial screenshot failing to send in time; a message deleted in front of them. f) The resolution: wrapped with a bow - LLM-ish pitfall: - Eleanor exposed, police come, Kyle okay, alliance with Leon, reclaimed emoji code, sequel hook. Classic “everything’s tied + gentle tease.” - Very TV-pilot-polished; readers may feel the author flinched from mess. - Humanising brainstorm: - Make resolution less frictionless: - Authorities mislabel what happened. Some truth never comes out. - Adults suspect Immy’s involvement in something but can’t pin it; trust is dented. - Kyle is back but different; doesn’t want to talk; their guilt lingers. - Complicate the Leon–Immy alliance: - She’s not instantly “secret supernatural consultant.” That’s genre-wish-fulfilment. - Have him say: “If something else happens, I might need help,” and she’s like: “Absolutely not,” then later: “Text me.” - Let the final beat underline cost as well as cool: - The new creepy emoji/text lands, but Immy’s reaction mixes dread and grim humour, not just a wink at the camera. g) Thematic safety: - LLM-ish pitfall: - Clear moral messaging, no ambiguity: ethical vamps good, rogue bad, protagonists noble. - Real human pieces often have subtler questions: - Who gets asked to sacrifice? Who gets believed? How do institutions absorb or deflect horror? - Humanising brainstorm: - Thread subtle critique: - The school was willing to hand student welfare to a shiny “initiative” without scrutiny. - Eleanor exploited the same metrics/values (“leaders,” “high achievers”) the school celebrates. - Let Immy register discomfort: - Maybe the vampires’ “ethical” system relies heavily on economically precarious kids volunteering; that’s not harmless. - She doesn’t resolve how she feels about that in 8k words; she just…notices. In summary: - The current plan is competent, coherent, and very “outline-y”—which is halfway to a good story but also exactly where LLM writing often stalls: high-concept, neatly paced, emotionally undercooked. - To make it feel human: - Anchor everything harder in Immy’s idiosyncratic perception. - Inject stubborn, unnecessary specifics (habits, objects, side jokes) that don’t feel like template furniture. - Loosen the rails: allow a few wrong turns, some uneven beats, imperfect resolution. - Let the dark bits be genuinely dark for a second before the joke comes in. If you’d like next, we can go through the chapter plan once more and mark specific spots where to inject that human mess/texture—without drafting yet.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention Core aim: - Write a darkly comic British YA short novel(la) in 8 x ~1000-word chapters that: - Feels sharply human and specific. - Takes the prompt literally and seriously: the midnight text “🩸🩸🩸” is the spine, not a disposable flourish. - Balances genuine unease with humour rooted in character, not quips-for-quips-sake. - Leaves a few edges frayed rather than sealing everything into a perfect bow. Key choices: 1. Protagonist, POV, voice - Protagonist: Imogen “Immy” Clarke, 15. - Lives in a cramped flat above “Glam Claws” nail salon with her mum. - Horror nerd in a way that’s slightly embarrassing (hyper-specific about one trash franchise). - Dry, observant, quick with jokes that sometimes land a bit too hard. - Very online but not impossibly witty: she misfires, backspaces, overthinks. - Voice: - First-person past, close and chatty, with occasional present-tense slide when anxious. - British, but lightly: no forced slang storms, just natural turns (“bit grim,” “dodgy,” etc.). - Humour as defence: we see when she’s using jokes to deflect. 2. Setting - Town: - Faded English seaside town: peeling arcades, charity shops, vape shops, gulls screaming like they’ve seen things. - Concrete details: bus route numbers, grim underpass, the rebranded pier that never quite opened. - School: - Bayview High, a bog-standard comp with motivational posters, erratic heating, and a terrifyingly cheerful attendance officer. - Feels lived-in: corridors, canteen queues, that patch of grass everyone pretends is a field. 3. Core premise - The text: - “The text came just after midnight: 🩸🩸🩸” - Sent to a cluster of students. No words, no number saved. Initially read as: - Period joke. - Edgy meme. - Scam. - Recurs: variations of blood-drop emojis used as a code by someone orchestrating things. - The threat: - There is a small, real vampire presence in town. - An unofficial scheme at school—the Crimson Service—was set up as an “elite volunteering/charity” initiative that doubles as a regulated channel for voluntary blood donations to said vamps. - Someone in that system is corrupting it: weaponising the emoji texts to mark “targets,” coercing students, and arranging unsanctioned “donations.” - Not a grand conspiracy—one ambitious, messed-up prefect (Eleanor) plus a shadowy buyer contact; enough to be scary but containable in 8k words. - Ethically: - Vampires are not sparkly saviours; they are constrained predators trying to be less awful. - Eleanor is not moustache-twirling: she believes she’s being efficient and necessary, shaped by school pressure and worship of “exceptional leadership.” 4. Supporting cast - Callum Shah: - Immy’s best mate. Nervy, clever, tends to catastrophise and then be right. - Very into odd facts (FOI requests, forum rabbit holes). - Uses caution and spreadsheets as coping mechanisms. - Aaliyah Brooks: - Older by a year, loud theatre kid, unofficial big sister energy. - Covers her own anxiety with bravado and performance. - Wants life to be A Story and hates being sidelined. - Leon: - Looks 17, actually much older vampire. Works late shifts at a grim coffee kiosk. - Extremely unglamorous; hates horror stereotypes about his kind. - On the hook to keep things “ethical” at the school; failing. - Mr Beckwith: - Science teacher. Underpaid, tired, in over his head as human liaison. - Means well; compromised by secrets. - Eleanor: - Head girl/perfect prefect. Polite, polished, intense. - Genuinely believes in “maximising impact.” Uses Crimson Service to play god. - Her wrongness has roots (pressure, class, image), not just evil genes. 5. Tone and style - Dark comedy: - Jokes from: - British understatement in absurd situations. - Institutional stupidity (school policy vs actual horror). - The gap between Immy’s horror know-how and the messy reality. - Humour never fully neutralises threat; it glances off it, shows how teens cope. - Horror: - Creepy more than gory: - Vanishing classmates. - Too-intimate knowledge signalled by texts. - The wrongness of being farmed by people meant to protect you. - At least one or two moments that are properly uncomfortable, but not exploitative. - Style guardrails: - Clarity over fancy prose. - Specific sensory and social details instead of generic “spooky corridors.” - Minimal exposition dumps; worldbuilding through implication, dialogue, Immy’s guesses. 6. Structure principles (for 8 x ~1000 words) - Each chapter: - Has a concrete situation. - Moves the mystery or relationships on. - Ends at a meaningful beat (sometimes quiet uneasy, not always twisty). - Overall: - Start grounded and funny. - Let the weirdness grow in Immy’s peripheral vision before it’s undeniable. - Keep some mess in the resolution: - Not everything exposed publicly. - Emotional fallout skimmed but not erased. - The emoji signal reclaimed, but with a bitter edge. 7. Things to avoid - No omniscient plot-puppet feel: plans should go wrong; info arrives piecemeal. - No squeaky-clean moral at the end. - No generic quirky banter without roots in their relationships. - No sprawling lore: keep vamp politics implied, off-page. - No fully sanitised danger: there is risk, fear, and at least one character who doesn’t bounce right back. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1 – The Text Came Just After Midnight Purpose: Establish Immy’s voice, setting, friendships; deliver the prompt; seed unease. Beats: - Immy in her tiny bedroom above the nail salon, watching a terrible straight-to-streaming vampire sequel she’s irrationally loyal to, half doing homework. - Group chat (“Cryptids & Chemistry”) with Callum and Aaliyah: - Real-feeling back-and-forth, some in-jokes. - Sense of their dynamic: Immy + Callum as anxious gremlins; Aaliyah chiming in from a party she’s already over. - The moment: - 00:01: notification: unknown number: “🩸🩸🩸” - Immy’s immediate reaction: annoyance, period joke, “edgy”. - She drops it into chat; responses: - Aaliyah: “Art.” / “New play promo?” - Callum: “Probably a phishing scam for your veins.” - More unnerving: - Immy sees “Imogen Clarke – read” under the mysterious message as if it’s in some other app (a weird UI beat) or a brief second of “typing…” that vanishes. - She notices a lone figure by the shuttered arcades when she looks out; too still, but she talks herself out of it. - She goes to sleep, sort of. Last thought: it’s dumb, but why does it feel targeted? - Quiet end: Morning bus; offhand mention that Kyle (Year 11 she knows vaguely) posted a story at 23:59 and then nothing. Chapter 2 – Crimson Service Purpose: Bring horror into the school’s normal world; introduce Eleanor and the “respectable” front. Beats: - School day: stale corridor smell, rain-soaked blazers on radiators. - People talking about weird texts overnight: - Not everyone got one. - Some got “just three drops,” some got nothing. - Assembly: - Headteacher introduces Crimson Service: “elite volunteering,” “partnering with cutting-edge medical charities.” - Eleanor presents: poised, too-polished PowerPoint with red droplet motif that looks a lot like the emoji. - Immy’s running commentary in her head; Callum noting buzzwords. - Eleanor: - After assembly, she works the rows, quietly inviting certain students (including Immy and Callum, not Aaliyah) to an info meeting. - Her phrasing: “We’ve identified you.” Off. - Immy and Callum compare: - Both had the text. - Both got a paper invite with a little printed blood-drop. - Aaliyah is theatrically offended she didn’t; they reassure/tease her. - Strange adult behaviour: - Mr Beckwith seems tense when Crimson Service is mentioned. - Immy glimpses a pale boy (Leon) in the corridor in daylight; he flinches from a sunstripe through the window, but it’s subtle. - End beat: - Info meeting flyer time-stamped: “Tonight, 19:00, Lab 3.” - Immy gets a second anonymous text: “Attendance appreciated. 🩸” - She deletes it, annoyed at herself for feeling watched. Chapter 3 – The Meeting Purpose: Show how banal and weird the scheme is; tighten tension; Aaliyah inserts herself. Beats: - Early evening at school: - Rain, flickery strip-lights. Small group of “chosen” kids in Lab 3. - Aaliyah shows up “by accident” to support Immy; Eleanor’s smile tightens but she lets her stay. - Presentation: - Eleanor and Mr Beckwith talk about “lifesaving donations,” “advanced study,” “piloting a youth engagement programme.” - Everything couched as voluntary, prestige-building, “for your personal statements.” - Clipboards with forms: health questions, consent boxes, parental signature lines. - Immy clocks: - Branding uses the same triple blood-drop motif. - Eleanor says “We’ll be in touch directly” in a way that makes Immy think of the text. - Something off: - When one boy jokes “What is this, vampire scouts?” Leon, lurking at the back as “external rep,” looks sharply up. - Jaya wobbles on her feet; Leon tenses like he can smell it; Eleanor ushers Jaya out briskly. - Immy’s mind: - Half mocking (“honestly, if this is a cult, at least give us robes”). - Half snagged on details: Eleanor’s fixation on “the right kind of candidates.” - They leave: - Immy and Callum do not sign yet. - In the corridor, Immy’s phone buzzes: “Pending. 🩸🩸” - Feels unreasonably like a threat. Chapter 4 – Wrong Kind of Special Purpose: Push from uneasy to actively sinister; first missing person; Immy’s fear breaks surface. Beats: - Next day: - Kyle is “off sick.” His mate mutters he didn’t come home; staff gloss it as “mix-up.” - Jaya back in class with a plaster in the crook of her elbow, saying she “donated” something vague. - Group chat: - Callum shares that he’s seen three kids with fresh donation plasters; all had the emojis. - Aaliyah says this is officially “too on the nose” and suggests, only half joking, that if it is vampires, they should charge rent. - Immy starts tracking: - Notes in her planner: times of texts, who’s got bandages, who’s absent. - She realises every “chosen” kid got at least one blood emoji beforehand. - Confrontation-lite: - Immy asks Eleanor what happens if someone doesn’t want to join. - Eleanor’s answer is superficially gracious but laced: “Refusal is… noted.” - After school: - Immy spots Leon outside the mobile blood unit near Tesco. He doesn’t go in; he watches. - She approaches him, tries a joke: “Nice branding on your creepy club.” - He looks genuinely alarmed that she connects the emojis and the Service. - That night: - Immy can’t sleep; scrolling Kyle’s socials, last post, comments from people asking where he is. - Another text: “Non-compliance complicates things. 🩸🩸🩸” - This time it lands like a punch. She doesn’t show anyone yet. Chapter 5 – Things with Fangs Purpose: Reveal vampires are real, but with a mundane, compromised twist; focus stays on Immy’s POV. Beats: - Immy snaps the next day: - Corners Mr Beckwith after class, shoves her phone at him, asks what Crimson Service actually is. - He flusters, says it’s above his pay grade, drops enough hints (blood, necessity, “agreements”) that Immy walks out shaken. - She and Callum follow Leon after school: - Not very well: hiding behind bins, almost run over by a mobility scooter. - Leon catches them and drags them into side alley before they get themselves mugged. - Alley scene: - Immy confronts him with everything: texts, plasters, Kyle. - Leon, exhausted, admits: - Yes, vampire. No, not into capes. - There’s a sanctioned scheme: consenting donors, frequency limits, boring forms. - School signed on for money/research kudos; Beckwith is liaison. - The triple-blood texts, threats, Kyle’s disappearance? Not sanctioned. “That’s your humans.” - He’s angry and scared too: a rogue operation threatens his whole precarious existence. - Immy’s reaction: - Not instant acceptance. Fear + “of course my life has budget vampires” + guilt that some part of her finds it cool. - Callum both vindicated and horrified his wild theories were understating it. - Key: - Leon shows Immy a “legit” text format (totally different tone), proving the threatening ones are off-book. - They realise: whoever is sending 🩸🩸🩸 is both plugged into Crimson data and escalating. - End: - New text to Immy (as they stand in the alley): “Next trial: Clarke. Midnight selection. 🩸🩸🩸” - Leon reads it over her shoulder and swears. Chapter 6 – Unmasking Eleanor (Badly) Purpose: They try to act; things don’t go cleanly; Eleanor’s motives surface; stakes sharpen. Beats: - Strategy in Immy’s bedroom: - Immy, Callum, Aaliyah, and (reluctantly) Leon talk. - Good human scene: cramped, mum knocking to ask if anyone wants chips, Leon perched awkwardly among Immy’s horror DVDs. - Leon explains: - He’s supposed to flag any irregularities; he’s been slow. - Another vampire enforcer will be sent if this blows up; he does not want that. - They suspect Eleanor: - She has access to student data and Crimson comms. - Her language matches the manipulative texts. - But proof is thin. - Aaliyah insists on confronting Eleanor: - They corner her after school, but it misfires: - Eleanor stonewalls; flips it, implies Immy is jealous/excluded. - Aaliyah loses her temper publicly; they look like the unhinged ones. - Later: - Callum, using his boring-but-useful IT skills and knowledge of where teachers stick passwords, finds: - A hidden folder on a shared drive with rosters, notes: “Prime candidates,” “non-compliant,” all tagged with blood emojis. - Messages scheduling a “midnight collection” in Lab 3 with an external “partner.” - Motives hinted: - In one note, Eleanor frames it as “We can’t rely on chance donors. The gifted can give more.” - Immy sees her own name highlighted: mixture of terror and weird, furious hurt. - They take this to Leon: - He’s livid; this could expose everything. - He wants to handle it quietly; Immy refuses to be sidelined. - End: - They learn there is an official Crimson Service showcase that night with parents/governors. - Hidden in Eleanor’s notes: that’s when “the handover” happens. - They know when and where, not exactly how. Chapter 7 – The Showcase (Also, Crime) Purpose: The messy climax. Plans half-work, stakes real, some genuine fear before relief. Beats: - Evening: school hall dolled up; banners, fairy lights, biscuits that taste of nothing. - Immy’s group: - Not a slick heist, more a loose bundle of intentions: - Aaliyah at the AV booth, ready to switch slides. - Callum by the alarm panel and fuse box, hands sweating. - Leon lurking, promised he won’t go full Dracula unless necessary. - Immy circulating with the “chosen,” wired and watching. - Eleanor’s speech: - Glossy, heartfelt about “sacrifice,” “leaders stepping up where others won’t.” - Parents beam. Staff clap. - Aaliyah triggers the AV sabotage: - Instead of promo slides, the projector shows Eleanor’s notes: “Prime stock,” “non-compliant,” emojis. - Also accidentally flashes a meme folder; briefly undercuts drama, but the substance is clear. - Chaos: - Murmurs, staff scrambling. - Eleanor kills the projection, denies, pivots: claims files are “draft language.” - Meanwhile, a text pings on several phones (including Immy’s): “Plan B. Lab 3, now. 🩸🩸🩸” - Two fronts: - Immy, seeing a few dazed “chosen” start to drift toward the science block, peels off to follow. - Callum sets off fire alarm intentionally to disrupt; sprinklers go off (slapstick + discomfort). - In Lab 3: - Eleanor and one adult “partner” (shadowed, more implied than explored) trying to rush through with a small group, including Jaya again and Immy. - Cold, efficient: syringes, cooler, forged consent forms. - Confrontation: - Immy refuses to sit; calls out Eleanor with the files. - Eleanor’s mask cracks: she defends her logic (some people’s blood “does more good”; “you get to be important for once”). - Leon appears; the adult partner bolts at sight of his fangs—this is beyond what they signed up for. - Brief struggle: - No slick martial arts, just Immy clocking Eleanor with a lab stool, Leon blocking a jab, Callum uselessly waving a fire extinguisher until it goes off. - Security, staff, and confused parents arrive mid-mess: - They see enough: syringes, kids, Eleanor, chaos. - Leon is gone by then, too fast; looks to humans like a blur and a broken window. Chapter 8 – What We Say Happened Purpose: Aftermath with emotional truth and imperfect external truth; reclaim the emoji with ambivalence; linger human. Beats: - Day after: - Official narrative: “serious safeguarding breach,” “misconduct,” lots of vague emails. - Eleanor “withdrawn”; rumours eat the gaps. - The adult partner “no longer associated with the school”; police statements, but details blur. - Immy, Callum, Aaliyah: - Tired, slightly dissociated. - Some peers treat it as drama; others are shaken. - Kyle is quietly back; pale, closed off, avoiding Crimson kids. Immy tries a “you okay”; he shrugs, walks away. No pat closure. - Meeting with Mr Beckwith (and later Leon): - In Lab 3, now scrubbed; smell of bleach. - Beckwith apologises, admits they thought they could control it; they were wrong. - Leon thanks them, awkwardly: - They’ve stopped something bad; also made Leon’s undead HR situation a nightmare. - Hints: - There will be stricter oversight; Immy doesn’t know if that comforts her. - Emotional check: - Immy alone briefly: - Thinks about how close she came to being “useful” on someone else’s terms. - Admits to herself that some part of her had liked being “chosen” before it twisted. - That mix scares her more than fangs. - Group scene: - On the seafront, chips in the cold, post-mortem banter: - They make jokes that are a bit too sharp and then soften. - Aaliyah points out Immy never would’ve believed this if it was fiction; Immy snorts. - Emoji reclamation: - Leon texts Immy from a now-saved number: “If anything like this stirs again, I’ll send 🩸. Just once. You can ignore any other drama queens.” - Immy replies with a single 🩸 and “Terms and conditions apply.” - Final note, not too neat: - That night, Immy scrolls; someone’s already turned the Crimson Service fiasco into a meme account. - She gets one last unknown ping: just “👍”. - She stares, half amused, half exhausted, decides not to tell anyone—for once choosing not to turn everything into a story. - Closes with her voice: a dry line acknowledging the unease is still there, but so is she. No grand moral, just a human shrug in the dark.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Imogen “Immy” Clarke Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Only child. Lives with her mum above “Glam Claws” on the high street. Parents split when she was 9; dad lives two towns over with a new family, visits irregular. - Money’s tight. She’s hyper-aware of it, jokes about it harder than anyone else. - Big horror nerd, but in a lopsided way: - Owns the full DVD set of a critically despised vampire franchise (“Nightbite”) and will write a thesis-length defence of film three. - Cannot be bothered with the classics everyone references to look clever. - Clever but not a “gold star” student: - Bs and occasional As when she tries; often doesn’t. - Teachers clock her as “capable, disengaged.” She resents that because it’s true. - Default mode: sardonic commentary. - Uses humour to pre-empt being mocked. - Has a good read on people but sometimes too quick to assume the worst/most clichéd motives. - Idiosyncrasies: - Hoards mugs on her windowsill; all chipped, all with some story. - Writes to-do lists on old flyers, never completes them, doodles fangs in the margins. - Cannot stand wet socks. Will turn back home for different shoes even if it makes her late. - Flaws: - Avoidant: ducks hard conversations with her mum, with Callum (about his anxiety), with herself. - Reflexively dismissive: - Calls things “cringe” to avoid risking earnestness. - Initially treats the 🩸 text as beneath her attention, delaying a response that might’ve helped. - Has a mean-streak in jokes when stressed; sometimes punches down then feels sick about it later. Physicality: - Slightly under average height; wiry rather than delicate. - Dark brown hair usually scraped into a messy ponytail or half-grown-out dye job. - Lives in oversized hoodies, black jeans, battered trainers doodled on in biro. - Carries herself like she’s trying to take up less emotional space but ends up radiating “Don’t.” - Expressive eyebrows; deadpan face when amused. - On the bus she curls in on herself with headphones, but eyes are always scanning. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Short-term: Survive school without being humiliated; keep her mum from worrying; avoid thinking too hard about The Future. - Story-specific: Figure out who’s messing with her and her friends; reclaim some control after realising she’s being farmed as “useful.” - Underneath: Wants to matter on her own terms, not just as “promising from a poor background.” - Allegiances: - Fiercely loyal (in her prickly way) to Callum and Aaliyah. - Suspicious of authority; soft spot for tired adults who try. - With Leon, moves from distrust to wary, eye-rolling alliance. - Relationships: - Mum: love + gentle guilt. Mum works long hours doing nails; they share gallows humour about nightmare customers. Immy hides weird vampire stuff to “protect” her. - Callum: best friend, safe person. Shares memes, academic stress, low-key codependency. - Aaliyah: aspirational chaos; Immy’s braver mirror. They sometimes clash when Aaliyah pushes too hard. - Eleanor: walking embodiment of everything Immy resents: polished, approved, trusted by teachers. Sample lines: - “If this is how I die, at least it’s on-brand. Lured to a science lab by shit emojis.” - (Seeing Eleanor’s presentation) “Nothing says ‘totally chill’ like a sixth-former with a custom logo for ‘sacrifice.’” - “I’m not scared, I’m… pre-panicking. It’s different.” - (To Leon) “You realise you’re about three degrees of eyeliner away from a Hot Topic window display, right?” # Callum Shah Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Lives with his mum and nan in a small terrace. Dad died when he was 11; not a secret but not a topic. - On a partial scholarship/bursary thing tied to “high potential” kids, which he finds both validating and suffocating. - Anxious in a running-systems way: - Knows homework deadlines for the term. - Knows evacuation routes in every building he’s ever been in. - Special interests: - Wikipedia rabbit holes. Once spent three nights reading about obscure train accidents. - FOI requests and public data portals: he’s weirdly into “seeing the spreadsheets they don’t think you’ll read.” - Idiosyncrasies: - Always has a pen behind his ear and another in his pocket. Both leak. - Turns everything into a list; even his lists have sublists. - Says “statistically” too often. - Flaws: - Catastrophises, which sometimes paralyses him. - Avoids confrontation; will complain in group chat instead of speaking up. - Can come off as condescending when he’s actually trying to reassure (“The odds of us being murdered tonight are low, okay?”) Physicality: - Gangly; limbs a fraction too long for his blazer. - Medium-brown skin, dark curly hair that refuses to sit flat. - Glasses that slide down his nose; pushes them up when nervous. - Hunches into himself in crowds; fiddles with zips, laces, headphone wires. - Has the look of someone computing exit strategies in the background. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Wants safety and predictability; hates not knowing things. - Story-specific: if someone is targeting classmates, he needs to understand how/why; knowledge feels like protection. - Allegiances: - Immy is his person; he’s more himself with her than anyone. - Aaliyah he admires and fears; she drags him into things he later admits he’s glad he did. - Relationships: - Immy: They share a sense of humour built on shared references and mild despair. - Aaliyah: He’s the brakes to her accelerator; she teases him into small acts of bravery. - Leon: Initially terrified / suspicious; later, grudging respect. - Teachers: He’s “the good one,” which annoys him; they rely on him too much. Sample lines: - “Right, so, I’ve done some quick mental maths and concluded: we are, in fact, doomed.” - “No, I’m not paranoid, I’m— okay, yes, but I’m also correct.” - (Looking at the blood emoji) “At least send a link. Terrible user journey.” - “I’m only breaking into this shared drive because the alternative is getting murdered semi-politely in Lab 3.” # Aaliyah Brooks Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - 16, Year 11. Lives with her mum and two younger brothers on an estate near Immy’s road. - Dad lives overseas; relationship intermittent, Instagram-based. - Big personality. Local youth theatre star; thrives on a stage, any stage. - Reinvents her “aesthetic” monthly; currently: sharp eyeliner, retro jackets, Docs with paint splatters. - Idiosyncrasies: - Calls everyone “darling” when she wants something. - Carries a highlighter in every pocket. Highlights unrelated words when anxious. - Narrates life: “Previously, on My Terrible Decisions…” - Flaws: - Impulsive to a dangerous degree. - Makes everything a performance; struggles to have private feelings. - Hates being left out; her hurt at not being “chosen” by Crimson Service is real and messy. - Sometimes steamrolls quieter friends, only realises when called on it. Physicality: - Tallish, solid; moves like she owns the pavement. - Natural hair in a puff or braids; experiments with beads, ribbons. - Expressive hands; talks with her whole body. - Big laugh; teachers both adore and dread her. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Wants out: out of town, out of being “just” from the estate. - Gravitates to anything that feels like an audition for a bigger life. - Story-specific: refuses to let some secret club decide who matters. - Allegiances: - Ride-or-die for Immy and Callum, even if she pretends she’s only there “for the drama.” - Relationships: - Immy: She sees through Immy’s “I don’t care” act; pushes her, occasionally too hard. - Callum: Little brother energy; she both teases and fiercely protects him. - Eleanor: She despises Eleanor’s smoothness; they have quiet class tension. - Leon: Flirts with him for sport initially; later, oddly kind, brings him chips. Sample lines: - “If this is a cult and I’m not invited, I will sue.” - (Seeing Crimson branding) “Oh, they’ve got a logo. That’s never good.” - “We’re not victims, babes, we’re protagonists. Start acting like it.” - (To Eleanor) “You don’t get to call it ‘donation’ when you’re picking the cast behind our backs.” # Leon Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Turned in his late teens several decades ago; stopped counting properly around Britpop. - Migrated between towns under different names; now “Leon Hart,” quietly embedded. - Works nights at a kiosk coffee stand by the station and does odd jobs. - Personality: - Dry humour, understated. - Fed up with vampire melodrama; prefers quiet, boring survival. - Feels responsible for keeping things “ethical,” resents being unpaid supernatural compliance officer. - Idiosyncrasies: - Drinks tea obsessively as a sensory placebo; complains it does nothing but keeps doing it. - Collects lost-and-found items from the kiosk (gloves, scarves). - Hates being cold even though it doesn’t affect him much anymore. - Flaws: - Passive. Let Crimson Service creep into grey areas without stepping in hard enough. - Avoidant like Immy, but with more centuries of practice. - Can be condescending to humans: assumes they’ll screw it up. Physicality: - Looks 17-ish: pale, tired-pretty, permanent shadows under his eyes. - Dark hair, usually tucked under a beanie or hood. - Dresses in layers; neutral colours; nothing flashy. Moves carefully, like he’s used to not drawing attention. - When he forgets himself, he’s too still; no fidgeting, unblinking. That’s when he looks wrong. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Stay off the radar of both human authorities and vampire enforcers. - Maintain his “ethical feed” to avoid hunting. - Story-specific: shut down Eleanor’s rogue scheme before it burns everything. - Allegiances: - Bound by some agreement with Beckwith and whoever runs the more official vamp operation. - Begrudgingly allies with Immy & co when he realises he’s outpaced. - Relationships: - Mr Beckwith: co-conspirator; Leon has a complicated almost-friendship with his guilt. - Immy: sees too much of his younger self in her; respects her spine. - Callum: recognises the value of his anxiety-logic. - Aaliyah: baffled, slightly charmed by her theatrics. Sample lines: - “I don’t sleep in coffins. They’re terrible for your back.” - “If I wanted to kill you, I wouldn’t text first. That’s… tacky.” - (Looking at Eleanor’s files) “Humans shouldn’t need fangs to be terrifying, apparently.” - “I’m not your spooky mentor. I’m the idiot who thought a memorandum of understanding would fix this.” # Mr Daniel Beckwith Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Early 30s, Science teacher. Grew up locally, left for uni, boomeranged back when the job market laughed at him. - Teaches Chemistry and random PSHE; runs Science Club that three kids attend. - Personality: - Earnestly nerdy, fumbling. - Too trusting of systems and “partnerships.” - Deeply conflict-averse; intellectualises guilt. - Idiosyncrasies: - Overuses “right” at the end of sentences. - Owns three identical grey cardigans. - Draws terrible diagrams on the board and apologises to them. - Flaws: - Went along with Crimson Service because it sounded like funding and opportunity. - Didn’t push back hard enough at red flags; convinced himself oversight was enough. - When cornered, initially more worried about his job than the kids. Physicality: - Slim, slightly hunched from years over lab benches. - Perpetual five o’clock shadow he never quite manages to shave clean. - Glasses, ink-stained fingers, scuffed staffroom mug saying “World’s Okayest Teacher.” - Moves nervously; drops things; laughs in small bursts. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Wanted to help bright students; got out of his depth. - Wishes fervently to fix this without a scandal. - Allegiances: - To the kids, ideally, but compromised by his deal with Leon/the vamp bureaucrats. - Relationships: - Leon: strange colleague; semi-friend. Owes him. - Immy: sees her potential; feels he’s betrayed her trust most. - Eleanor: initially impressed; later frightened by her certainty. Sample lines: - “It’s all, um, very above board, I assure you. Mostly. I mean— it is.” - “Imogen, you have to understand, the funding— no, that’s not… that’s not the point. Sorry.” - “I thought if there were rules, it would be safe. I was wrong.” # Eleanor Price Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - 17, head girl, UCAS poster child. - From a middle-class family in the “nice” part of town; parents on PTA, talk about “maximising opportunities.” - Personality: - Razor-focused, high-achieving, good at smiling in ways that make adults relax. - Believes deeply in meritocracy; despises “wasted potential.” - Treats people like resources on a spreadsheet. - Idiosyncrasies: - Keeps a colour-coded planner; ticks items off with a flourish. - Says people’s names a lot in conversation—weaponised politeness. - Adjusts her blazer and badge when stressed. - Flaws: - Zero tolerance for mess or refusal; sees hesitation as weakness. - Has convinced herself ends justify means; no one has successfully challenged that. - Sees poorer / less “driven” students as needing direction, even if forced. Physicality: - Tall, neat brown hair in a low ponytail or immaculate bob. - Always in regulation uniform plus badge and lanyard; shoes polished. - Perfect posture; controlled movements, calculated eye contact. - Smile that never quite reaches her eyes when she’s angry. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Get into a top uni; leave town; leave mark. - Crimson Service is her legacy project; ethics warped by pressure and opportunity. - Thinks: if some kids’ blood can serve greater good, and they’re “strong enough,” why not? - Allegiances: - To her constructed self-image as indispensable leader. - To an abstract “system” of excellence, not to individuals. - Relationships: - Teachers: adore her; trust her too much. - Peers: respect/fear; very few close friends. - Immy: barely on her radar initially; later, sees her as a troublesome anomaly. - Beckwith: a tool; disappointing when he wavers. Sample lines: - “We’re all asked to give something, Imogen. Some of us are brave enough to say yes.” - “Language like ‘harvest’ is unhelpful. It’s allocation.” - (When confronted) “You think the world will thank you for being difficult? I’m offering you purpose.” - “Do you know how many zeros are on the grant letter? You’d rather let that vanish than part with a few millilitres?” These profiles should give us enough grain and contradiction to keep the cast feeling like people rather than roles when we move into drafting.

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The text came just after midnight. I was in bed but not in any meaningful way on the path to sleep. The duvet was up, lamp off, headphones in, laptop balanced dangerously on my stomach. On-screen, a man in a PVC trench coat was giving a monologue about destiny to a woman in suspiciously impractical lingerie. A bat screeched somewhere off-camera; lightning flashed even though five seconds ago that scene was indoors. Nightbite 3: Blood Rebooted. My comfort film. Objectively dreadful. Perfect. My phone buzzed against my wrist. I flinched, stabbed pause on the trackpad, and squinted at the notification bar. Group chat. Aaliyah had sent a video from some house party: bodies, bad strobes, her doing duckface with a bottle of something luminous. I typed, under the video: I: ur liver ok? The little “Aaliyah is typing…” bubble appeared, vanished, reappeared. A: pls, I’m networking C: statistically speaking, that luminous blue is 40% antifreeze Callum’s avatar: an owl with glasses. Of course. I smiled into the dark. The only light was the laptop and the sodium-orange seep from the street outside my curtains. The flat hummed: the boiler’s faint groan, the fridge fighting for its life. The phone buzzed again. New notification. Not the chat. Unknown Number 🩸🩸🩸 No text. Just three neat blood drops in a row. I stared at it for a second, then snorted. Even my scam texts were trying too hard. I screenshotted it and dropped it into Cryptids & Chemistry. I: new admirer C: oh good, the murderers are emoji literate A: !!! aesthetic A: is that, like, minimalism marketing? “come to our show or die”? should I be flattered I didn’t get one I: menstruation awareness month but make it ominous C: don’t click any links they send or donate any of your organs etc etc There weren’t any links. Just the three drops, sharp red against black. I tapped the number. Just digits. No profile picture, no name. WhatsApp couldn’t decide if it existed. My thumb hovered over “Block.” Felt dramatic. Also, a little cursed, like those films Callum hates where the girl deletes the warning and then the demon eats her intestines first. “You’re not getting me with that,” I muttered to the empty room. I muted the thread instead. Through the thin ceiling I could hear the muffled whine of the nail drill from downstairs; Mum must’ve taken a late walk-in. Midnight biab emergency. Glam Claws never slept. I went back to Nightbite. On-screen, the vampire anti-hero climbed into a coffin in slow motion while nu-metal howled. I could recite the next line. I didn’t get that far. The laptop screen flickered. Once. Twice. The audio stuttered like it was buffering, though I’d downloaded it years ago. My bedside lamp blinked on and off on its own. “Oh, piss off,” I told the universe. The lamp steadied. The laptop sulked itself back into motion. The coffin lid slammed; the vampire whispered, “Darkness is a gift.” The usual. My phone, on the duvet, lit up my peripheral vision. I tried to ignore it. Failed. Unknown Number Read 00:01 For a second, stupidly, I thought: It can see me. Of course it said “Read.” I’d tapped into the thread. That was all. My brain was just helpfully overlaying creepiness like a filter. I flung the phone to the far side of the bed anyway, on principle. Outside the half-open curtains, the glow from the high street looked wrong. Too still. I slid my headphones off one ear and listened. No scooter engines. No drunk laughter. No distant bass from the bar two doors down. Just the faint roar of the sea and a gull doing a noise like a demon being blendered. I shifted up onto my elbows, pushed the curtain with two fingers. Bayview High Street at 00:03 on a school night: shuttered shops, sickly streetlights, puddles. The Glam Claws sign buzzed, pink tubes flickering. Across the road, the arcade letters that still said A CA E because the R and D never got replaced. Under the dead letters stood a boy. He was directly under the broken A, where the light didn’t quite reach. He had no umbrella. Hood up. Hands in pockets. Not moving. I told myself he was waiting for someone. People waited. That was normal. People stood like just… standing. Motionless. In the rain that had started needling down without me noticing. He looked up towards our building, as if he’d heard me think. The angle of his face caught the light. Pale. Too pale. I jerked the curtain closed and dropped back onto my pillow, heart doing a double-kick. “Okay,” I whispered. “You’re being mental. It’s a guy at a bus stop that doesn’t have a bus.” I picked up my phone again. No new messages. The blood drops sat there. Condescending. I: (to chat) so I: anyone else get goth spam The typing bubbles pulsed as I watched. C: yeah actually wtf C: just 3 drops, no text? A: rude. zero serial killers in my dms C: maybe it’s random C: or someone’s idea of a joke I: it’s a bit 2016 for a joke tbh A: ur all cowards, I would simply reply “k x” I considered it. Three blood drops back. Or three neutral thumbs. Or an aubergine, just to confuse whoever was behind it. I didn’t reply. Mum knocked twice on my wall, our signal for “I’m locking up, go to sleep.” The nail drill whine clicked off. The hallway light went dark, one strip at a time, like the building was shutting its eyes. “Night,” I called. “Night, love,” came muffled through plaster. I closed the laptop, shoved it down beside the bed, plugged my phone in. It lit the room for a moment, harsh and blue. The blood emoji thread sat above everything else. I scrolled up. Just the one message. No previous. No profile picture. No nothing. “It’s nothing,” I told myself. “It’s probably Aaliyah, bored in a bathroom queue.” That made me feel better. It also made me a bit annoyed with her, which helped. I set the phone face-down. The room exhaled. Sleep didn’t land so much as creep in around the edges. Last thought: I’d tell them tomorrow, we’d figure out which little psychopath had everyone’s numbers, and that’d be that. Another stupid story we’d make fun of in the canteen. Down on the street, a police car went past, blue lights washing the ceiling for half a second. I registered it as a colour without meaning. Turned over. Let the dark take me. In the morning, my alarm shrieked at 7:00. I slapped at it until it shut up and lay there with that instant fog of vague dread that usually meant “double Maths.” Then the previous night unspooled: the text, the boy under the arcade sign, the lamp. I reached for my phone. Notifications stacked up: Instagram, school app, three from Cryptids & Chemistry, one from Mum (“Breakfast in the fridge”) and, in the middle: Unknown Number 🩸 Just one this time. Below it, timestamped 02:14, a story notification from Kyle Davies: kyle.dvs added to their story. I tapped it. Spinning lights. A can of something cheap. His trainers on a curb. Caption: “Dead.” I checked the time again. 02:14. On the bus, half an hour later, his seat was empty.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This opening chapter succeeds in establishing both its premise and protagonist with confidence. The author deftly follows the prompt, opening exactly as specified with the midnight text containing blood emojis, while building a foundation for the darkly comic British YA tone promised. Immy's voice emerges immediately as authentic and engaging—sardonic without being artificially witty, observant without being implausibly precocious. Her horror movie obsession serves multiple functions: character development, subtle foreshadowing, and establishing her as someone who thinks she knows how these stories work. The choice to make her devoted to a critically despised franchise rather than prestige horror shows character specificity. The group chat sequences feel particularly natural, capturing genuine teenage digital communication—the casual abbreviations, the way conversations drift, the mix of supportive banter and gentle mockery. Callum's statistical anxiety and Aaliyah's theatrical confidence come through clearly in just a few exchanges, establishing distinct voices that align well with the provided character profiles. The British setting materializes through accumulated detail rather than heavy-handed signaling: the nail salon, the broken arcade sign, the specific urban geography of a faded seaside town. These elements feel lived-in rather than touristic. The tension builds organically from mundane irritation (spam text) through gradually escalating unease (the figure outside, Kyle's absence) without rushing toward revelation. The author resists the temptation to oversell the supernatural elements, instead letting them simmer at the edges. Some technical elements work particularly well: the phone interface details add verisimilitude, the interplay between Immy's internal monologue and external responses shows her defensive humor in action, and the ending provides genuine foreboding without cheap shock tactics. Minor weaknesses include occasional strained metaphor attempts ("like a demon being blendered") and some descriptions that push slightly too hard for effect, though these don't significantly detract from the overall effectiveness. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The rain turned the playground into a shallow, grim soup. Half the school was crowded under the thin overhang by the canteen, steaming gently in damp blazers and cheap aerosol. I sloshed off the bus and joined the queue of misery. “Morning,” Callum said, appearing at my elbow with his hood up and his bag zipped to his chin. His glasses were spattered. “You look like death.” “Rude. Any mysterious suitors in your inbox?” He hesitated. “Yeah.” He fished his phone out, keeping it angled away from the rain. The same unknown number. The same three blood drops from last night. Underneath, a new one from 6:02 a.m.: 🩸 “Copy-paste job,” he said. “Zero effort.” “Lazy murderers,” I said. “I also got the deluxe one-blood follow-up.” He exhaled slowly. “Right. Great.” We squeezed through the doors. The warm corridor smelled of wet fabric and Lynx Africa. Everyone was shaking hoods, combing hands through hair, shoving each other off radiators. On the noticeboard, someone had Blu-Tacked a bright red poster: COMING SOON: THE CRIMSON SERVICE BE THE DROP THAT STARTS THE WAVE ELITE VOLUNTEERING OPPORTUNITIES LAUNCH ASSEMBLY TODAY Three stylised blood droplets in a row. Neat little logo. “Oh, for f—” I started. “Coincidence,” Callum said, instantly, which is what he says when he’s sure something is not a coincidence. “Okay, but that slogan,” I said. “‘Be the drop that starts the wave.’ That’s definitely how you get a plague.” He tugged my sleeve. “Assembly. Now. I want to see how bad this is.” Bayview High’s hall looked particularly lifeless in strip-light grey. The stage curtains were a faded maroon that somehow made everything else seem beige. We filed in by tutor group, wet trainers squeaking, chairs scraping. Aaliyah slid into the seat behind me, smelling faintly of coconut and regret. “Darling,” she hissed. “Why did no one tell me there’d be a goth rebrand? Crimson Service? Very cult. I approve.” “You should be in bed,” I whispered. “You look like your mascara’s filed for divorce.” “It’s a look,” she said. “So. Emojis?” “You got one?” I twisted round. “No.” She pouted. “Do I not look like prime murder material? I’m offended.” “Count your blessings,” Callum muttered. Up front, Headteacher Dr Lewis did her microphone tap. “Good morning, Bayview.” A ragged “morning” came back. “Today, I’m very excited to introduce a new initiative in partnership with some wonderful organisations.” She did the smile she always did when grant money was involved. “This is a chance for some of our students to really shine. To tell you more, please welcome our Head Girl, Eleanor Price.” Polite clapping. Eleanor walked on stage like the concept of posture had hired a PR team. Blazer immaculate, badge straight, hair smooth. She smiled, pressed the clicker. Slide one: THE CRIMSON SERVICE. Three drops. Same neat logo as the poster. Same as my phone, minus the smugness. “Thank you, Dr Lewis,” Eleanor began. Clear, warm voice. “The Crimson Service is an elite volunteering and leadership programme, unique to Bayview. We’ve been selected to pilot this in partnership with several important medical charities.” The next slide: pictures of happy people in lab coats. Stock photo heaven. “Members of Crimson Service,” she said, “will have the chance to support lifesaving research and treatments. You’ll gain experience that will stand out on future applications and show that you are the kind of person who doesn’t just talk about making a difference, but does it.” “Oh my God,” Aaliyah whispered. “She rehearsed that in the mirror for three years.” I watched the slides. Looked harmless enough if you stripped away the colour red. Bullets about “community impact,” “leadership workshops,” “exclusive opportunities.” The logo hovered in the corner like a tooth. Eleanor clicked again. “Selection is by invitation only. We have looked carefully at attendance, grades, behaviour, and involvement in school life. If you are approached today, please consider it carefully. Not everyone will have this chance.” Flattering poison. My phone buzzed once against my leg. I risked a glance. Not a text; Cryptids & Chemistry. C: this screams organ harvesting I bit back a laugh. Aaliyah poked me. She held up her own phone. No new anything. Her drawn-on winged eyeliner twitched. Dr Lewis wrapped it up with something about “opportunity” and “pride.” Dismissal row by row. As we shuffled out, Eleanor and two prefects stood strategically by the doors, holding crisp white envelopes. She handed them out with laser accuracy. “Thank you, Benjamin. We’d love to have you on board.” “Amelia, this would be perfect for you.” Her eyes flitted over faces, cross-checking some internal list. Then: “Imogen.” I nearly kept walking, assuming there was another Imogen. There isn’t. She stepped in front of me, blocking the flow, and handed me an envelope. “We’ve identified you as a strong candidate,” she said, with that politician smile. “Have a read.” “Oh,” I said. Eloquence. “Thanks.” Callum was behind me. She pressed one into his hand too. “We’ve had our eye on you for a while,” she said. “That’s not creepy at all,” he blurted. She pretended not to hear. Aaliyah reached out hopefully as we moved past. Eleanor’s smile didn’t widen. “We’ll be in touch,” she said. No envelope. We spilled into the corridor. “I hate her,” Aaliyah announced. “On principle. Give that here.” She snatched my envelope, tore it open. “Aaliyah—” “Relax, your destiny awaits.” She unfolded the letter, read aloud in a pompous voice as we walked. “Dear Imogen, based on your exemplary potential, you have been selected for consideration for the Crimson Service. This is an exclusive opportunity to demonstrate leadership through discreet participation in life-saving donation programmes…” She slowed. “…‘discreet participation’?” “Sexy,” I said. “There’s an information meeting this evening, Lab 3, seven p.m. Bring this letter and an open mind,” Aaliyah finished. She wrinkled her nose. “Corporate cult vibes. I love it.” Callum had his open too. “Same wording,” he said. “Plus a health questionnaire. ‘Have you ever fainted giving blood? Are you currently on any medications?’” “They’re just filtering out wimps,” Aaliyah said. “It’s… targeted,” he said. We stopped by the stairs. The corridor surged past us. “So. Honest thoughts,” I said. “On a scale from school charity scam to full occult sacrifice?” “It’s a scheme,” Callum said. “They get free student labour, maybe some PR. The emoji thing is… tacky. Probably someone thought it was clever branding.” “But the texts came before they announced this,” I said. “And not to everyone. And you got them.” He chewed his lip. “Correlation is not causation.” “You’re wobbling,” I said. “I’m… open to data,” he said. Aaliyah snatched both letters and tucked them under her arm. “We’re going,” she said. “Obviously.” “You didn’t even get invited,” I said. “Rude. I’m your emotional support extrovert,” she said. “And if it is a cult, they always need someone to replace the High Priestess when she trips.” “Looking forward to that transition plan,” I said. “Assuming this isn’t just Eleanor’s personal LinkedIn farm.” As we argued, someone brushed past us. Mr Beckwith, clutching a stack of exercise books and a mug that said “World’s Okayest Teacher.” His cardigan sleeve was pushed up; a strip of red Crimson Service lanyard peeked out from under it. “Sir,” I called. “What’s Crimson Service? Actually?” He jumped slightly, slopped coffee on his hand. “Oh, ah, Imogen, hi. It’s—well, it’s all in the letter, right? Fantastic opportunity. Great partners. Very safe. Very controlled. Right.” “You’re involved?” Callum asked. “Just as staff liaison,” he said too fast. “Science, blood, that sort of thing.” “‘That sort of thing,’” I repeated. “Yes. Anyway, bell’s about to go.” He hurried off, almost colliding with the janitor. We watched him go. “Very safe,” Aaliyah mimicked. “Very controlled. Right. He’s hiding a basement of bodies.” “He can’t even control his mug,” I said. “If this is his cult, we’re fine.” The bell shrieked. In Maths, I couldn’t focus. The Crimson logo floated behind the equations. At break, two Year 10s compared their envelopes near the vending machine like trading cards. By lunch, whispers had started: “Only top sets got picked.” “My mate who does rugby got one.” “Eleanor’s favourites, innit.” By the lockers, a girl from my Science class rolled up her sleeve to show a small square of white plaster in the crook of her elbow. “Mum took me to give blood last week,” she said proudly. “I put it on my form. Got Crimson invite this morning. Told you it mattered.” Little patterns. In the canteen queue, I checked my phone under the table. New school app message about the Crimson launch. Mum asking if she should save me a plate. A DM from an old primary school friend I never answered. And from Unknown Number, time-stamped 10:26: Attendance appreciated. 🩸 My chest felt tight for a second. I typed back: who is this The three dots appeared. Blinked. Vanished. “Immy?” Callum nudged me. “Earth to Clarke. You’re holding up the line.” “Oh.” I grabbed a tray. “Sorry. Just being recruited into the blood Illuminati.” “You’re not actually going, right?” he whispered. “Obviously we’re going,” Aaliyah said from behind him. “If they’re giving out free tote bags, I’m taking two.” I looked at the message again. The neat single drop. If it was Aaliyah, she was committing to the bit. If it was Eleanor somehow, we’d have material for weeks. If it was neither, and it knew my name and timetable and the way my stomach dipped reading it— “Seven o’clock,” I said. “Lab 3. We go. We see. If it’s boring, we leave.” “And if it isn’t?” Callum asked. “Then,” I said, “we at least get a good story.” The three dots blinked once more on my screen, then disappeared for good.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively builds on the established premise, demonstrating strong character work and atmospheric tension. The writing maintains the darkly comic British YA tone while advancing the mystery surrounding the blood emoji texts and the Crimson Service. The character voices are particularly well-executed. Immy's sardonic commentary ("I hate her. On principle") feels authentic to a 15-year-old using humor as armor, while Callum's nervous intellectualizing ("Correlation is not causation") and Aaliyah's theatrical assertiveness ("Obviously we're going") remain distinct and consistent with their established profiles. Eleanor's calculated manipulation comes through clearly in her controlled presentation and selective invitation process. The chapter structure follows the planned beats effectively, moving from the morning aftermath through the assembly to the targeted recruitment. The integration of the blood emoji mystery with the school's institutional framework feels natural rather than forced. The writer skillfully uses mundane school details (wet blazers, radiator crowds, squeaking trainers) to ground the supernatural elements in recognizable reality. The dialogue feels authentic to teenage speech patterns without relying on forced slang or overly witty banter. Exchanges like Beckwith's nervous deflection ("Very safe. Very controlled. Right") capture character-specific speech patterns effectively. The group chat integration and text message format work naturally within the narrative flow. However, some plot developments feel slightly predictable for the genre - the exclusive selection process and Eleanor's obvious manipulation follow familiar YA villain patterns. The mystery advancement, while competent, doesn't surprise beyond expected genre conventions. A few metaphors border on trying too hard ("the concept of posture had hired a PR team"), though they generally work within the character's voice. The writing maintains good pacing and builds genuine unease beneath the humor. The blood emoji texts create authentic tension, and the institutional setting adds credible menace. The balance between comedy and threat feels well-calibrated for the target audience. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
By seven o’clock the rain had given up and left everything slick. The science block looked wrong in the dusk, all its windows black squares instead of sleepy rectangles full of bored teenagers. “This is how every Netflix series starts,” Callum said, shoving his hands deeper in his pockets. “Season one: ironic kids.
