Season two: trauma.” “Season three: they recast me with someone taller,” Aaliyah said. “Come on, the door’s open.” It was. Lab 3’s yellow strip of light cut across the corridor. Inside, someone had tried very hard. The blinds were down. The harsh strip-lights had been swapped for softer lamps. At the front, a laptop and projector cast the Crimson Service logo huge on the board. Three perfect blood drops over an abstract wave. Chairs were set out in neat rows. A tray of supermarket biscuits sweated under cling film. Bottles of water formed a sterile little battalion. About a dozen students sat scattered: a couple of rugby boys, two top-set girls with revision cards in their laps, Jaya from my Chemistry class twisting a bracelet off her wrist and on again, Kyle’s mate Liam hunched low. No Kyle. “Welcome,” Eleanor said from the front, as if we’d walked into a spa instead of a lab that usually smelt of Bunsen gas and despair. She clocked us. Her gaze paused a fraction too long on Aaliyah, who technically wasn’t invited. “Please find a seat,” she said. “We’ll start in just a moment.” Aaliyah gave her a wide, fake-innocent smile and chose the middle row. I sat beside her; Callum took the aisle, like he wanted a clear escape route. Mr Beckwith hovered near the whiteboard, shuffling papers. He looked like he wanted to be invisible. At the back of the room stood the boy from under the arcade sign. Same pale skin, same too-straight posture, hood down now. In the forgiving lamplight, he looked less horror-film and more…annoyed. Hands in the pockets of his dark jacket, shoulders slightly hunched away from everyone. His eyes flicked over us and moved on, as if he was counting. A flicker of recognition jolted through me. My brain supplied: stalker. Then: bus stop. Then: you are being ridiculous. “Thank you all for coming,” Eleanor began. “Firstly, congratulations. You’re here because we see something in you. Not just grades, but character.” Aaliyah mouthed “vomit” at me. “The Crimson Service,” Eleanor went on, clicking to a slide of smiling volunteers in red T-shirts, “is about leadership through action. We’re partnering with exciting medical charities to support life-saving work. That includes awareness campaigns, events, and for some of you, the opportunity to participate directly in donation programmes.” The word hung. “Donation,” Jaya repeated quietly. “Blood,” one of the rugby lads said, too loud. Eleanor smiled. “Some programmes do involve giving blood, yes. Completely voluntary, fully supervised. Many of you will be eligible at seventeen. Until then, there are other roles.” “So we’re being recruited as walking blood bags,” Aaliyah whispered. “Iconic.” I elbowed her. Beckwith stepped forward. “It’s all properly regulated,” he said. “You’ll have information, consent forms for parents. Nothing happens without, um, proper procedure.” The pale boy at the back shifted, as if that phrasing irritated him. Why was he here? He wasn’t in uniform. No lanyard. “Is that your cousin?” Aaliyah whispered. “He’s got your playlist.” “I’ve never seen him in my life,” I whispered back. Eleanor clicked to another slide: bullet points about “skills,” “training,” “references.” She talked smoothly, every sentence polished. I half-listened, half-watched the room. The kids here weren’t random. Most were the ones teachers smiled at in corridors. The reliable ones. The “you’ll go far” nods. I caught Callum’s profile: jaw tight, eyes flicking between the biscuits and the exits. On the table near the door sat a stack of forms and a plastic box of pens. On the forms, I could see the words Health Questionnaire in bold. “Some of our partners,” Eleanor said, “work in experimental therapies. They need carefully screened young donors. People like you, strong and prepared to do more than just repost petitions.” That made something in me bristle. Like the implicit: If you say no, you’re lazy. Jaya raised her hand. “Is this, like… the NHS?” “A range of organisations,” Eleanor said. “Some public, some private. All thoroughly vetted.” I glanced at Beckwith. Sweat at his hairline. He nodded along like he was being paid per nod. A hand went up at the back. Not rugby. The pale boy. “Yes?” Eleanor said. He stepped forward a bit. His voice, when it came, was low and flat. Local accent blurred around the edges. “You should emphasise it’s voluntary,” he said. “Strongly. And that no one will be penalised for declining.” Something taut flashed behind Eleanor’s eyes. “Of course,” she said. “As Mr Beckwith said. Voluntary.” “But selective,” the boy said. “Right.” It wasn’t really a question. “Thank you, Leon,” Beckwith said quickly. “Everyone, this is Leon Hart. He’s one of our external coordinators. He’s, er, here to help ensure best practice.” Leon. Not Arcade Boy. Leon Hart. He looked about seventeen. I knew he wasn’t a student—I would’ve noticed. His skin had that odd undertone of someone who’d never seen the sun in person, only on TV. “Hi,” Aaliyah whispered under her breath. “I’m uncomfortable and intrigued.” “Later we’ll have a chance for questions one-to-one,” Eleanor said, reclaiming the rhythm. “For now, please take a form. If you’re interested, fill in the basic details. We’ll send more information home.” Chairs creaked as people shuffled up. The biscuits were finally breached. Aaliyah tugged me up with her. “Come on,” she said. “We’ll get data.” “Just don’t sign my life away,” I said. At the table, Eleanor smiled directly at me. “Imogen,” she said, like she enjoyed saying names. “I’m glad you came. People like you are exactly who we need.” “People like me,” I echoed. “Bright. Underutilised. Principled.” She slid a form towards me. “We’re offering a chance to turn that into something concrete.” “I like being abstract,” I said. “Less paperwork.” Her smile didn’t flicker. “Have a read.” Callum took his with two fingers, as if it might bite. Aaliyah reached for one; Eleanor’s hand paused. “This is invitation-only,” she said. “She’s with me,” I said before I could stop myself. Eleanor considered that. “You can sit in,” she said to Aaliyah. “Observe. For now.” Power. Tiny, stupid power, in an after-hours lab with bad biscuits. I suddenly understood why she liked this. We sat again. I scanned the form. Name. Date of birth. Medical conditions. “Have you ever experienced dizziness or fainting after blood tests or injections?” “Are you currently taking any medication?” “Do you have any conditions that affect your blood?” The last question: “Would you be willing to be contacted about future donation opportunities and research participation?” I left it blank. Jaya’s pen hovered at that line too. Her leg jiggled under the table. At the front, Leon leant against the bench, arms folded. Under the too-soft lights, his eyes looked almost black. When someone laughed at the “donation” line, he didn’t. Eleanor wrapped up. “If you’d like to proceed, leave your form with us before you go. If you’re unsure, take it home. We’ll follow up.” Follow up. Like debt. As people began to stand, I saw Jaya sway. Her hand went to her forehead. The pen skittered from her fingers. Leon was there before she could fall, crossing the space in a blur so fast my brain stumbled. One second against the bench; the next, beside her, steadying her elbow. It might’ve been adrenaline. I might’ve imagined the speed. “Probably just hot,” Eleanor said quickly. “Do you need some air?” “I’m fine,” Jaya mumbled, cheeks flushing. “Didn’t eat.” “Sit,” Leon said, voice low. He guided her back into the chair with a care that didn’t match his bored expression. Up close, I saw his fingers against her wrist. His jaw clenched once, hard. He looked up. Our eyes met. Something unreadable passed there: surprise at being seen. I looked away first. “Nothing to worry about,” Beckwith said too cheerfully from the front. “Happens all the time in labs. Right, grab a biscuit on your way out, don’t forget your consent forms.” Slowly, like they were waking from a spell, people drifted to the table. Some left forms, some folded them into blazer pockets. We hung back until the crush thinned. “Thoughts?” Aaliyah said brightly. “Ten out of ten red flags,” Callum said. “That questionnaire is more invasive than my GP. And who ‘follows up’ on voluntary stuff like that?” “I’m giving it a solid seven for production values,” Aaliyah said. “Minus three for no snacks that aren’t beige.” Leon was by the door now, talking quietly to Beckwith. Eleanor collected forms into a folder with practised hands. I took a step towards the bin with my blank one. My phone buzzed. Unknown Number Pending. 🩸🩸 A cold ribbon unrolled along my spine. “Immy?” Callum asked. I showed them. Aaliyah’s joking smile slipped. “Okay, that’s…” She glanced at Eleanor. “She’s sending those, right? This is, like, her weird branding?” “How would she have my number?” I said. “And why not just say it to my face?” “Well, she likes drama,” Aaliyah said, recovering. “Queen of ominous stationery.” “You can always decline,” Callum said. “They said we can say no.” I looked up. Eleanor was watching us. Not with a glare, not with friendliness. Assessing. Leon’s gaze flicked from her to me to my phone. His mouth tightened, just a fraction. “Yeah,” I said, folding the form in half, then in half again. “They said.” We left it on the table. Walked out into the corridor that suddenly felt too long. Behind us, the door clicked shut.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully executes a tense recruitment scene that balances mundane institutional horror with genuine character dynamics. The writing demonstrates strong control of voice and pacing, creating an atmosphere where the sinister gradually emerges from the banal. The character work is particularly strong. Immy's first-person narration feels authentically teenage - sharp, defensive, using humor as armor. Her observations like "Lab 3 looked wrong in the dusk, all its windows black squares instead of sleepy rectangles full of bored teenagers" capture both the physical space and her unease effectively. The dialogue between the trio feels natural and lived-in, with each character's distinct voice coming through clearly - Aaliyah's theatrical bravado, Callum's anxious pragmatism, Immy's sardonic deflection. The chapter builds tension skillfully through accumulating details rather than dramatic revelations. Eleanor's corporate-speak presentation, Leon's unnaturally fast movement, the invasive medical questionnaire, and finally the ominous text message create a mounting sense of wrongness. The vampire element is handled with refreshing unglamourousness - Leon appears tired and bureaucratic rather than romantically mysterious, which fits the story's grounded approach. The worldbuilding feels authentic, from the "supermarket biscuits sweating under cling film" to the realistic school setting. The author shows rather than tells, letting character reactions and specific details convey information about the Crimson Service's true nature. The dark comedy emerges naturally from character and situation rather than forced quips. Aaliyah's "So we're being recruited as walking blood bags. Iconic" and Immy's "I like being abstract. Less paperwork" feel like genuine teenage responses to an absurd situation. Some minor weaknesses include occasional over-explanation of character motivations and a few slightly clunky transitions between beats. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise well-crafted chapter that successfully advances plot while maintaining strong character development. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Kyle wasn’t in form the next morning. His tutor, Mr Hughes, read out “authorised absence” like it was a spell that made concern optional. Liam muttered something about “must’ve crashed after Sam’s,” then went quiet when he saw no one was laughing. By break, someone said Kyle hadn’t been on Insta since that 2 a.m. story. Someone else said his mum had put in the year group WhatsApp that he’d “gone to stay with family.” Both could be true. Neither made my stomach stop knotting. My phone buzzed in my blazer pocket three times during double English. I ignored it until Mrs Bray turned to the board. From: Unknown Number Non-compliance complicates things. 🩸🩸🩸 I stared at the words until they blurred. When I blinked, I could almost see Eleanor’s neat handwriting around them. I jammed the phone face-down under my copy of Macbeth. On the page, Lady M was doing her “screw your courage to the sticking-place” bit. I was not feeling especially screwed or courageous. At lunch, Callum and Aaliyah cornered me by the vending machines. “New creepy fan mail?” Aaliyah asked. “Because I got nothing and I’m starting to think they don’t value me.” I showed them. Callum swore under his breath. “Okay. That’s… specific.” “Non-compliance,” Aaliyah read. “That’s the least sexy sext ever.” “It’s not funny,” Callum said. “They’re tracking who signs up.” “I am aware it’s not funny,” she said. “I’m choosing to fight dread with camp.” “Look at the timing,” I said. “We didn’t hand in forms. Now this.” “They could’ve seen,” Callum said. “Eleanor was right there. But why anonymous? Why not send a follow-up email like a normal tyrant?” “Because anonymous is scarier,” Aaliyah said quietly. We turned, in unison, to the Crimson Service posters plastered along the corridor. Those little blood drops now looked less like cheerful branding, more like tally marks. “Maybe it’s a prank,” I said, forcing the words out. “Like, someone in on it. Testing commitment. Annoying, but not… you know.” “A prank that references compliance?” Callum said. “That’s not Year 10-level banter.” “Sixth-form boys enjoy the illusion of power,” Aaliyah said. “Trust me, I’ve done plays with them.” In Science, Beckwith was more distracted than usual. He spilled copper sulfate on the floor, laughed too loudly, wrote “DONNER” on the board instead of “DONOR” and scrubbed it out like it had personally betrayed him. When the bell went, I hung back. “Sir,” I said. “Quick question.” He flinched like I’d thrown something. “Yes, Imogen?” “The Crimson forms,” I said. “Who sees them? Who sends…communications?” “Communications?” “You know.” I tried to sound casual. “Texts. Follow-ups.” He rubbed his forehead. “All official contact goes through the school channels. Letters home. The app. Nothing… nothing personal, right? That would be inappropriate.” “So you haven’t been texting me emojis from a burner?” I said. His eyes widened behind his glasses. “What? No, of course not.” “Okay. Just checking.” I watched his reaction like Callum would. “And if someone was?” “I—if there’s something odd, you should bring it to Dr Lewis,” he said. “Or me. But it’s probably just someone having a laugh. Don’t let people spook you.” “I’m not spooked,” I lied. “It’s just… weird.” He hesitated. “If you’re uncomfortable, you don’t have to be involved with Crimson. It’s voluntary.” “That’s not what the texts say,” I said before I could stop myself. “What texts?” he asked, too quickly. We stared at each other for a beat. He broke first. “I have a meeting,” he said. “Hand in your homework Thursday. Right.” I stepped out into the corridor, pulse up. Callum and Aaliyah were waiting by the stairs. “Well?” Aaliyah said. “Is Sir our mysterious dom?” “No,” I said. “He’s terrified of everything. Including me and the word ‘text.’” “So either he knows and can’t say,” Callum said, “or he doesn’t and someone’s freelancing with Crimson branding.” “Either way,” I said, “I don’t like that I qualify as ‘non-compliant’ on anyone’s spreadsheet.” We headed towards the lockers. A group of Year 10s were crowded around one boy, Tom, who was rolling up his sleeve to show off a little white plaster in the crook of his elbow. “Gave blood with my mum last week,” he said. “Crimson Service invited me this morning. Boom.” “Look at you, human Capri-Sun,” someone said. I exchanged a look with Callum. “Pattern,” he murmured. “Strong, healthy, high attendance, no meds,” Aaliyah recited. “Like you,” she nudged me. “Like you,” she nudged him. “Like me, except they didn’t pick me, the cowards.” “Maybe they think you’d bite back,” I said. “Accurate,” she said. On the way out of school, I saw him again. Leon, by the gate, talking low to Beckwith. “…have to be clearer,” he was saying. “Voluntary. No pressure. That’s the agreement.” “They know that,” Beckwith muttered. “Mostly.” Leon’s eyes tracked a group of kids walking past, flicking down to bandages, up to faces. Assessing. Then his gaze landed on me. I made the mistake of holding it. His eyes were dark, almost black in the grey afternoon, and tired in a way that didn’t match seventeen. He looked away first this time. That made me feel both victorious and stupid. “I’m going to follow him,” I said as we turned onto the high street. “I’m going home,” Callum said. “I’m going to eat toast and pretend we live in a benevolent universe.” Aaliyah stretched her arms. “I have rehearsal. Also I’m one detention away from indefinite grounding. But you two enjoy your stalking date.” “Stalking observation,” I said. “For science.” Callum groaned, but he came with me. We hung back as Leon walked down towards the seafront. He moved like he knew the town without looking. Past the chippy, past the vape shop, towards the row of shuttered arcades. “You are aware we’re bad at this,” Callum whispered. “Yes,” I said. “But he doesn’t know that.” Leon stopped briefly outside the old A CA E, looking up at the dead letters, then crossed to the other side where a mobile blood donation van was parked. Its side read GIVE BLOOD, SAVE LIVES in cheerful NHS font. He didn’t go in. He leaned against a lamppost opposite, watching the door like he was on break. “Maybe he’s just waiting for someone,” Callum said. “In front of a blood van,” I said. “With my life, yes.” We ducked into the doorway of the Pound Saver two shops down. “Okay,” Callum said, “I will admit: the aesthetics are damning.” The van door opened; a woman in scrubs stepped out, smoking. Leon said something to her. She laughed, swatted his arm, went back inside. “Is he flirting with the blood nurse?” I whispered. “Professional networking,” Callum said. Leon checked his phone. His face tightened. He looked straight over at us. I flinched back into the doorway. “He saw us,” I hissed. “Of course he saw us,” Callum said. “We’re literally in a doorway staring at him like Victorian ghosts.” When I risked another glance, Leon was gone. My heart thumped. “Okay. Fine. That’s fine.” We walked home the long way, skirting the seafront. The air tasted of salt and chips and something metallic underneath, or maybe that was my brain overcommitting. “I don’t like this,” Callum said. “I like patterns. I don’t like being in one.” We parted at the corner near my building. “Text me if you get anything,” he said. “If I get murdered, I’ll let you know,” I said. On the stairs up to our flat, the Glam Claws sign buzzed at my back. Mum was in the kitchen, in the pink polo with GLAM CREW on it, counting coins out of the tip jar. “You’re late,” she said without looking up. “Got trapped in a leadership seminar,” I said, dropping my bag. “You know how it is.” “Did they give you a lanyard?” she asked warily. “Not yet,” I said. “I think that’s stage two of the indoctrination.” She snorted. “As long as you’re not signing up to work for free for the posh kids.” “Would I do that?” I asked. “Yes,” she said. “If they made it sound intellectual.” Later, in my room, I sat cross-legged on my bed with the Crimson leaflet. The words blurred. “Elite.” “Opportunity.” “Impact.” My phone lay beside it, black screen. I opened a new note and started writing names. People with plasters. People with invites. People with texts. Immy (🩸🩸🩸 + 🩸 + “Non-compliance…”) Callum (🩸🩸🩸) Jaya (invite + nearly fainted) Tom (blood donor + invite) Kyle (🩸? last story 2:14 / now MIA) Others from Lab 3. It was messier than any conspiracy thread on Callum’s forums. But there was something there. My phone buzzed. My heart jumped so hard I nearly threw it. Unknown Number Next steps soon. 🩸🩸🩸 I swallowed. Fingers hovering. I typed: stop messaging me Dots appeared. Disappeared. Then nothing. I set the phone down, palms sweaty. Somewhere below, the shop’s shutter rattled down. The flat seemed to contract, quieter, as if listening. I lay back, staring at the crack in the ceiling that looked like a river on a map. It was just some overachieving psycho with a bulk-text app and a God complex. It had to be. On the bus the next morning, Kyle’s seat was still empty. Liam scrolled through his phone, jaw clenched. “He hasn’t opened my snaps,” he muttered to no one. I checked Cryptids & Chemistry. C: kyle’s still not online? A: maybe his mum hid his phone, mine did that once, I almost chewed through the door C: the school app says “authorised” I: “authorised” by who tho As if on cue, another notification from Unknown Number slid down over our thread. Tonight. Midnight. Lab 3. 🩸🩸🩸 The bus shuddered over a pothole. No one else seemed to feel it.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively advances the darkly comic British YA narrative while maintaining the established tone and character voices. The writing successfully builds tension around the missing Kyle subplot and escalates the threatening texts, creating genuine unease beneath the characters' defensive humor. The character work is strong, particularly Immy's voice, which remains consistently sardonic and observant. Her internal monologue ("I was not feeling especially screwed or courageous") and defensive humor ("If I get murdered, I'll let you know") feel authentic to a teenager using wit to process fear. The dialogue between the three friends flows naturally, capturing their distinct personalities - Aaliyah's theatrical bravado ("human Capri-Sun"), Callum's anxious precision, and Immy's dry deflection. The chapter follows most of its planned beats effectively: Kyle's absence, the pattern of students with donation plasters, Leon's suspicious behavior near the blood van, and the escalating anonymous texts. The detail work is solid - the mobile blood donation van, the specific school locations, the mundane details like Mr. Beckwith's nervous tics all contribute to a believable setting. However, there are some structural weaknesses. The planned confrontation with Eleanor is absent, which disrupts the intended escalation. Some exposition feels mechanical, particularly when characters recite patterns they've noticed ("Strong, healthy, high attendance, no meds"). The stalking sequence, while acknowledged as bumbling by the characters themselves, still feels somewhat perfunctory. The threat escalation works well, with the final text about "Tonight. Midnight. Lab 3." providing an effective cliffhanger. The writing maintains the balance between comedy and genuine menace without undermining either element. The prose is clean and functional without being bland, though it occasionally relies on safe choices rather than taking creative risks. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 12 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The message sat there like a dare. Tonight. Midnight. Lab 3. 🩸🩸🩸 The bus juddered, kids shouted, someone in the back played tinny drill out loud. I stared at the words as if they might rearrange into something sensible. When I looked up, I caught Leon standing at the school gate as we pulled in, hood up despite the half-hearted sun. He wasn’t looking at me; he was scanning faces as people trudged past, like he was counting again. Like the text had gone to a specific list and he was checking who’d show. “Don’t,” Callum said, sliding into the seat beside me. He’d clearly seen my expression. “I didn’t say anything,” I said. “You’re doing your ‘tempted to do something obviously stupid’ face.” A notification slid down over the last one. C: we’re not actually going to midnight science, right? I: define “we” A: babes if there’s a midnight lab cult and we *don’t* go, I’ll have to move schools for shame I: there it is Callum rubbed his eyes. “If we go, we tell someone. An adult. A real one. Dr Lewis. Or your mum. Or the police.” “And say what?” I asked. “‘Hi, some emojis invited me to a blood party, can you arrest the font?’” He grimaced. “Fine. We gather data. Then maybe police font.” We drifted through the day, everything taking on that over-sharp edge it gets when you’re counting hours to something you’re pretending not to be scared of. In Chemistry, I tried to catch Jaya’s eye. She looked wan, a faded version of her usual precise self. The plaster on her elbow was gone, replaced by a faint yellow bruise. “You okay?” I whispered as Beckwith banged on about covalent bonds. She shrugged. “Just tired. My mum made a big deal out of the donation. Keeps telling people at church. I feel like I should have a medal or something.” “Did you get any Crimson stuff after?” “Yeah,” she said. “They sent another questionnaire. And that meeting. I’m not sure.” She hesitated. “Did you get the weird texts?” “Maybe,” I said. “Probably spam.” “Yeah,” she said. “Probably.” At lunch, I shoved chips around my tray. “Option A,” I said. “We go tonight, it’s dramatic and boring, we go home and roast it.” “Option B,” Callum said, “we go and it’s not boring, and we die.” “Option C,” Aaliyah said, “we don’t go, and spend the rest of our lives wondering if there was a hot vampire and we missed him.” “There is a hot vampire,” I said. “He works nights and glowers.” “So we’re agreed,” she said. “Option Chaos.” Callum inhaled. “If anything looks seriously off, we film. And we run. And we call actual authorities. We do not split up. We do not drink anything they hand us. We do not sign anything.” “Okay, Dad,” Aaliyah said. “Call me when you’re not in a ditch,” he said. By seven, my mum was in her pyjamas on the sofa, watching a dating show where everyone had veneers and unresolved issues. “Science club thing,” I said, hovering by the door with my bag. She raised an eyebrow. “Since when do you go to science club?” “Since there’s snacks,” I said. “I’ll be back by ten.” “If you end up in McDonald’s, text me,” she said. “And don’t sign up for anything unpaid past five p.m.” “Would I do that?” I asked. “Yes,” she said. Outside, the evening had that flat blue light that makes everything look like a set. Callum and Aaliyah were waiting by the corner shop; Aaliyah had swapped her blazer for a massive tartan coat like a villain. “You told your mum?” Callum asked. “Partial truth,” I said. “You?” “My nan thinks I’m at your house,” he said. “So don’t die, it ruins my alibi.” We slipped round the back of school, over the grass that tried and failed to be a field. A side door to the science block was cracked open. “No,” Callum whispered. “That’s too on-the-nose. At least make us pick a lock.” Inside, the corridors were lit by emergency strips, greenish and thin. Our footsteps echoed. Posters for exam prep and safe internet use glowed faintly. Lab 3’s door was shut. Light seeped underneath. “Listen,” Aaliyah whispered. Muffled voices. Eleanor’s, crisp. Beckwith’s, fluttery. Another tone, flat: Leon. I gently pushed the door. It opened a few inches. Enough. Inside, about ten students—fewer than this morning—sat in a half-circle. No biscuits. No slides. Just clipboards and a steel trolley with sealed packs, tubes, wipes. Clinical. Eleanor stood by the trolley. Beckwith hovered. Leon leaned against the far bench, arms folded. “…completely confidential,” Eleanor was saying. “Your contribution tonight will kickstart something incredible.” “This is too much,” Beckwith said, low. “We should wait for the full sign-off.” “We have it,” Eleanor said, in that tone that brooked no argument. “If we don’t move now, we lose the slot, and do you want to explain that to our partners?” I flinched when I saw Kyle. He was there. Sat at the end of the row, hoodie sleeves shoved up. He looked wrong. Not hurt, not chained, just… hollow. Eyes unfocused, skin a waxy shade that didn’t suit a seventeen-year-old who played football. “Immy,” Callum breathe-whispered behind me. “He’s here. He’s fine.” He didn’t look fine. “Alright,” Eleanor said, louder now. “Those of you doing preliminary sampling, we’ll start with small draws. Purely diagnostic. If at any point you feel unwell, we stop. You’re in control.” She said it like a script, like a box to tick. Leon’s jaw clenched. “Emphasise,” he said. “They can say no. No one’s obliged to be here. You invited them, you didn’t summon them.” A boy laughed. “Sounds like vampires.” Leon’s gaze snapped to him so fast it was almost funny. Almost. I pushed the door another inch. It creaked. Leon’s head turned. Our eyes met through the gap. He moved. One second he was by the bench. The next he was at the door, hand flat against it, stopping it opening further, stopping it slamming shut. I choked on my breath. “For someone trying not to get caught sneaking,” he murmured, “you’re terrible at doors.” Up close, his eyes weren’t black. Dark brown, almost amber where the light caught. They looked tired. And, annoyingly, a bit concerned. “You shouldn’t be here,” he said. “Neither should you,” I shot back automatically, then realised that made no sense. “Is someone out there?” Eleanor called. Leon didn’t look away from me. “Just me,” he said. “Door was ajar.” A beat. Then she went back to her script. Callum tried to pull me back. Aaliyah leaned over his shoulder, eyes huge. Leon’s voice dropped. “Are you invited?” “Clearly not,” I whispered. “I like crashing.” “This isn’t…” He exhaled. “Go home.” “Are you draining them?” I heard myself say. “Like Kyle. Is that why he looks like extra in a zombie film?” His expression did something complicated. “I’m not,” he said. “I’m here to stop worse.” “Doing amazing so far,” I muttered. He glanced over his shoulder at the room. “This part is legit,” he said. “Samples. Minimal. There’s a bigger problem.” “Like the texts?” I asked. His eyes narrowed. “What texts?” I realised I’d given something away he hadn’t known. My stomach swooped. “You really don’t know?” I said. “I wouldn’t ask if I did,” he said. “What texts?” Inside, I heard Eleanor say, “Kyle, you’re up first, if you’re ready.” He moved like a puppet, took the chair by the trolley. Beckwith fumbled a tourniquet. Leon swore under his breath, a language that wasn’t English, then pushed the door fully open, stepping through before I could decide whether to follow. “Stop,” he said, louder now. “You’re not drawing that much from him. He’s already borderline.” Eleanor’s smile went cool. “He agreed.” “He’s had three sessions in as many days,” Leon said. “He’s not baseline. He’s supply.” The word hung. Beckwith froze, needle halfway uncapped. “What’s going on?” one of the lads asked. “It’s fine,” Eleanor said. “Leon is being overcautious.” Leon looked at the faces in the room, at us in the doorway. Something in him crunched. “Everyone leave,” he said. “Now.” Nobody moved. “This is ridiculous,” Eleanor said. “You are a consultant, not in charge.” “I’m the one answerable if this crosses a line,” he said. His voice had dropped into something older, heavier. For a second, maybe three, something in his expression slipped. The lamplight hit his teeth. And there, between the polite white, a flash of too sharp. Gasps. Nervous laughter. Beckwith whispered, “Leon, for God’s sake.” “Vampires,” the rugby boy said. Trying it out. “Leon,” I said, without meaning to, “the texts.” He turned his head slightly towards me. “This isn’t me,” he said. There was more in it than denial. Offence. My pulse pounded. “Okay,” I said. “Then who thinks they can schedule me for a midnight science sacrifice?” “What?” Eleanor snapped. “No one is sacrificing anyone.” I pulled my phone from my pocket, thumb shaking, flicked to the messages, held it up. “Then explain this,” I said. Tonight. Midnight. Lab 3. 🩸🩸🩸 Beckwith made a strangled noise. “That is not from us,” Leon said. No hesitation. “Then who?” Callum asked from behind me. Silence, for a beat too long. Eleanor’s gaze flicked to my screen. Something like annoyance crossed her face before she smoothed it out. “Probably a joke,” she said. “Someone being dramatic. We can look into it.” Leon took a step towards her. “You didn’t authorise that?” “I do not use emojis,” she said, with faint contempt. “If I wanted you here, Imogen, I’d have asked you properly.” It wasn’t a denial, not really. We stood there in a stupid tableau: me with my phone up like a crucifix, Leon coiled, Beckwith sweating, Eleanor poised, Kyle pale. “Everyone out,” Leon said again, quieter. “We’re done for tonight.” “Leon,” Eleanor started. “You want to explain to them what you are?” he asked, just as quiet. The air in the room seemed to thicken. Eleanor’s jaw flexed. She looked at the students. She calculated. “Fine,” she said. “Thank you all so much for your interest. We’ll be in touch with next steps via the usual channels. Please don’t share any details yet; we want to make a proper announcement.” Half-dismissal, half-command. The kids filed out, confused, muttering. Kyle moved slower, like he was wading through something heavy. As he passed me, I caught a whiff of antiseptic and something metallic. “You okay?” I whispered. He blinked at me as if I was a light too bright. Didn’t answer. Kept going. When the last of them had gone, Leon shut the door. “Right,” he said. “Tell me everything about those texts.” And suddenly it was just us in Lab 3: the ethical vampire, the guilty teacher, the power-hungry prefect, and three idiots who should’ve stayed home.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively delivers on the core promise of revealing vampires while maintaining the story's grounded, darkly comic tone. The writing successfully balances humor with genuine tension, particularly in the Lab 3 infiltration sequence where the mundane school setting becomes genuinely unsettling. The character voices remain consistent and distinct throughout. Immy's sardonic observations ("For someone trying not to get caught sneaking, you're terrible at doors") feel authentic to her established personality, while Callum's anxious planning and Aaliyah's theatrical bravado continue to ring true. Leon's revelation scene is handled well - his reluctant admission and tired frustration feel earned rather than melodramatic. The dialogue is particularly strong, with natural back-and-forth that avoids exposition dumps while still advancing the plot. The group chat interjections and quick character exchanges have the rhythm of actual teenage conversation. Leon's line "I'm not a consultant, I'm answerable if this crosses a line" effectively conveys both his supernatural nature and his position in the bureaucratic mess. However, the chapter deviates significantly from its stated plan. Instead of confronting Beckwith and following Leon as outlined, it jumps directly to the midnight Lab 3 meeting. This creates some structural confusion and suggests the writer may have gotten swept up in the dramatic scene rather than following their roadmap. The pacing works well, building tension through the day before the nighttime infiltration. The clinical details of the blood draw setup effectively contrast with the school setting, creating the right kind of institutional horror the premise demands. Some minor weaknesses include occasionally unclear action sequences (the door opening/Leon moving scene could be clearer) and a few moments where the supernatural revelation feels slightly rushed. The vampire reveal through the teeth flash is effective but could have been given more breathing room. The chapter maintains the British setting convincingly without forced slang, and the horror elements feel genuinely unsettling rather than cartoonish. The ethical complexity around consensual blood donation versus coercion adds moral weight that elevates this above simple monster-hunting narratives. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 13 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 8 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Leon didn’t sit. He perched on the edge of a lab stool like he might lose patience and leave mid-sentence. “Start from the top,” he said. “What messages, what times, who got them.” His voice wasn’t loud, but it had weight. Beckwith hovered by the trolley, twisting a wipe packet in his hands until it split. I held onto my sarcasm like it was buoyant. “I thought you didn’t do emojis.” “I don’t,” Leon said. “Because I’m not twelve. Talk.” So I did. Because being told off by a maybe-vampire in a school lab was somehow less scary than the thought of someone unknown planning me like a meeting. “The first one came Sunday night,” I said. “00:01. Three drops, no text. Callum got it too. Some others. Then single drops, then ‘Non-compliance complicates things.’ Then the invite for tonight. All from the same unknown number.” “And those went to Crimson candidates?” Leon asked. “As far as I can tell,” Callum said. He’d got his notes app out. Of course he had. “I’ve got four confirmed: me, Immy, Tom, this Year 10 from my bus. Same pattern.” “The language,” Eleanor said, stiff. “Reads like a silly prank. ‘Non-compliance.’ No one associated with Crimson would be so…on the nose.” “That’s your objection?” I said. “The phrasing?” Her eyes flashed. “If I wanted leverage, I wouldn’t send unsanctioned messages from an unregistered number. I’d talk to you.” “Comforting,” I muttered. Beckwith cleared his throat. “Right, so, hypothetically,” he said, “if someone is using that, ah, imagery, without authorisation, that’s a breach. Of guidelines.” Leon looked tired. “It’s more than a breach of guidelines. It’s stupid and dangerous.” “Dangerous how, exactly?” Aaliyah asked. “Beyond the obvious ‘threatening children’ thing. And the anaemia.” Leon hesitated. “You already know too much.” “Understatement of the century,” Callum said. Leon swore under his breath again. “Fine,” he said. “Short version: We don’t hunt. Not here. Not like that. We have agreements. Legal-ish. Monitored donations only, from informed adults. School programme was a pilot. Limited, voluntary. It was never supposed to escalate.” “And yet,” I said, gesturing at the room, the trolley, the echoes. “We have Kyle: the trilogy.” “I’ve been arguing with her,” Leon said, tipping his head at Eleanor. “She’s keen to impress. Our…contact is impatient. And someone’s taken it on themselves to speed up recruitment.” “I am following the framework I was given,” Eleanor snapped. “You asked for reliable sources. I identified them. Efficiently.” “You also started planning midnight sessions without telling me,” Leon said. “And someone is sending threats to kids who haven’t signed. That’s not efficient. That’s feral.” “Do not call me feral,” she said, so cold it could have frozen the Bunsen burners. “Enough,” Beckwith said weakly. “We’re all on the same side.” I laughed. I couldn’t help it. “Which side is that, sir? The one where you nearly drained a boy in front of us? Or the one where Emo Dracula here gets all huffy about brand guidelines?” Leon shot me a look. “I’m trying to stop anyone getting drained,” he said. “And my name is Leon, not Emo Dracula. That’s offensive to both of us.” “Prove it,” I said. “About stopping it. Because from where I’m standing, the only people acting like this is messed up are us.” “All due respect,” Aaliyah said, folding her arms, “I don’t trust anyone in a cardigan or with a prefect badge right now.” Eleanor inhaled sharply. Beckwith looked down at his cardigan like it had betrayed him. Leon pinched the bridge of his nose. “Okay,” he said. “Here’s what I know. There is a group out there—the unregulated side—who will pay a lot for certain kinds of blood. Young, healthy, above-board paperwork if they can get it. Easier to hide in plain sight. Eleanor has been approached through ‘partnership’ channels. I’ve been trying to keep it inside the ethical lines. I didn’t know about the texts.” “So the emojis are…marketing?” Callum said faintly. “Control,” Leon said. “Whoever’s sending them is marking people. Testing how suggestible they are. Who comes when called.” “Like a loyalty programme,” I said. “Collect three drops, get a free draining.” “Stop,” Beckwith said. “Please.” “If you didn’t send them,” I said to Leon, “and you didn’t,” to Eleanor, “that leaves, what, some mystery admin with a God complex and my number?” Eleanor’s mouth thinned. “There are only a handful of people with access to the invite list and contact details,” she said. “Me. Mr Beckwith. The office. Our external coordinator.” “External coordinator?” Callum echoed. “The buyer,” Leon said flatly. “Although we don’t call them that. We call them a ‘partner institution.’ They have their own person. I’ve never given them direct access to students.” “Until now,” I said. “You, specifically” —Leon pointed at me— “were not on any supply list. We avoid staff kids, vulnerable backgrounds, anyone who’d be missed by more than a stat line. You’re trouble.” “Wow,” I said. “Honoured.” “So why is she getting texts?” Aaliyah said. “If you’re so careful.” “Because someone’s freelancing,” Leon said again. “And if I can’t prove we’re keeping it clean, someone from higher up will come down and clean it their way. You don’t want that.” “Define higher up,” Callum said. “No,” Leon said. Eleanor tapped her nails on the trolley. “We’re wasting time. Whoever is sending those messages is undermining the integrity of Crimson. We find them, we cut them out, we move on.” “‘Integrity of Crimson,’” Aaliyah repeated, sotto voce. “I’m begging you to hear yourself.” “We’re not moving on,” I said. “Not until Kyle stops looking like a corpse and my phone stops impersonating a horror trailer.” “This is above students,” Beckwith said. “I should— we should inform Dr Lewis.” “And say what?” Eleanor said. “‘We almost accidentally industrialised teen bloodletting but don’t worry, it was voluntary’?” Beckwith wilted. “So we handle it,” Leon said. “Quietly. We trace the texts. That number must be linked to someone.” “You can’t trace it,” Callum said. “It’s using one of those online-sender things. I tried.” He flushed when we all looked at him. “What? You think I wouldn’t check?” Leon’s brows went up. “Useful,” he said, almost on reflex. Callum blinked, thrown by the compliment. “It’s not bulletproof anonymous,” he said. “But we’ll need access to logs. School network. Phone records.” All eyes turned, inevitably, to Beckwith. “I can’t,” he said. “That’s—I’d get sacked.” “You’re going to get more than sacked if an investigator finds goth spam in your safeguarding audit,” I said. A long, horrible moment where everyone was thinking about worst-case scenarios in their own flavours. Finally, Aaliyah sighed theatrically. “Right,” she said. “Since all the adults in the room are morally compromised or undead, here’s what we’re going to do.” “Excuse me?” Eleanor said. “You’re excused,” Aaliyah said. “Immy’s getting the texts. That makes her bait. Not ideal, but narratively satisfying.” “Thanks,” I said. “We lean into that,” she went on. “If they think she’s scared, they’ll push. We push back. We catch whoever’s sending them somewhere we control. Preferably not with needles.” “I’m not using a child as bait,” Leon said automatically. “She’s fifteen,” Aaliyah said. “That’s, like, three years from uni offers. Practically decrepit.” “I’m in the room,” I said. “We also,” Callum said carefully, “secure some evidence. Screenshots, files. In case we do need to go to someone external. Police. Or the terrifying safeguarding woman with the lanyard collection.” Eleanor looked offended. “I am not the villain you think I am,” she said. “I am trying to make a flawed system work. If some idiot has decided to turn my programme into a joke with emojis, I want them gone as much as you do.” “Cool motive,” I said. “Still counts.” Leon looked at me. Really looked. “You’re scared,” he said, as if surprised. “I’m not auditioning for your tragic heroine fan club,” I said. “Of course I’m scared. Some stranger has my number and a calendar.” “It’s not higher up,” he said slowly. “They’re not subtle. This feels…petty. Local.” “Which narrows it down to the entire sixth form,” Aaliyah muttered. “My money’s on whoever did the Crimson design,” I said. “You can’t trust people that into branding.” Silence again. Then Callum, reluctantly: “We know Eleanor has the names and numbers. We know Beckwith does, but he doesn’t have the spine. We know there’s an external contact who might have leaned on them for ‘more supply.’ If that person or someone they talked to got access…” “The texts mention ‘non-compliance,’” I added. “That’s… administrative. That’s someone who sees a spreadsheet, not a vampire in an alley.” Eleanor’s cheeks flushed. “I would never threaten a student. I don’t need to. They listen.” “Alright, Jesus,” I said. Leon hopped off the stool. “I’ll talk to my side,” he said. “See if anyone else has noticed this number. Beckwith”—the name came out like a warning—“you quietly see if there have been any weird requests from the ‘partner institution.’ No emails you don’t normally get. No extra attachments.” “And us?” I asked. “You,” Leon said, pointing at me, “block that number.” “I tried,” I said. “It keeps coming through. It’s like it’s not…normal. It shows as unknown every time.” “Then don’t answer,” he said. “Don’t follow instructions. Don’t come here at midnight alone like an idiot again.” I bristled. “I didn’t come alone. I brought backup idiots.” “Me,” Aaliyah corrected. “Us,” Callum said faintly. Leon’s mouth twitched, like a half-dead smile tried to surface and thought better of it. “You have very brave friends,” he said. “Or very stupid ones.” “Often the same thing,” I said. He moved towards the door. “I’ll be in touch,” he said over his shoulder. “Not with emojis.” “And if the psycho is listening right now?” I asked. “If they’re in this room?” Eleanor bristled. Beckwith paled. Aaliyah raised her hand like she’d confess to a prank, just to break the tension, then dropped it. “Then,” Leon said, pausing in the doorway, “they should know this: if they escalate, they’ll have to deal with me.” It was dramatic. It shouldn’t have worked. But his eyes had that flat, old look again, and I believed him. The door swung shut behind him. Beckwith sat down heavily on a stool. “I’m going to be sick,” he said. “Not on the samples,” Aaliyah said. “We might need those for court.” Eleanor straightened her blazer. “You three stay out of this,” she said. “You’ve interfered quite enough.” “You’re welcome,” I said. “By the way, your pilot scheme is bleeding people.” I walked out before she could answer. In the corridor, the emergency lights hummed. Outside, the night was thicker than it had any right to be. My phone buzzed in my pocket. Unknown Number You were told to come alone. 🩸 “Leon?” Callum asked. I showed them. “Okay,” Aaliyah said. “New rule. We don’t go anywhere alone. Not toilets, not canteen, not emotional breakdowns. Buddy system.” “Agreed,” I said, even as my skin crawled. Because someone knew where I was, and they weren’t in the room we’d just left.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively maintains the established voice and character dynamics while advancing the plot through a tense confrontation scene. The writing demonstrates strong control over dialogue, with each character maintaining their distinct voice - Immy's defensive sarcasm, Leon's tired pragmatism, Eleanor's calculated defensiveness, and Beckwith's nervous deflection. The chapter succeeds in deepening the mystery while avoiding exposition dumps. Information about the vampire bureaucracy and "ethical feeding" arrangements emerges naturally through dialogue, and the revelation about external "partner institutions" adds complexity without overwhelming the core dynamic. The mundane, administrative approach to vampirism (referring to buyers as "partner institutions," discussing "guidelines" and "frameworks") maintains the darkly comic tone effectively. Character work is particularly strong. Eleanor remains nuanced rather than cartoonishly evil - her belief that she's being "efficient" and following proper procedures makes her more unsettling than simple villainy would. Leon's frustration with both the system and the students feels genuine, and his reluctant respect for their capabilities adds depth. The group dynamic among the teens feels authentic, with Aaliyah's theatrical confidence, Callum's anxious competence, and Immy's sharp-edged humor working well together. The pacing builds tension effectively, culminating in the threatening text that proves someone was monitoring their supposedly private conversation. This creates genuine unease and raises stakes appropriately. However, there's a significant disconnect from the stated chapter plan. The plan called for a failed attempt to confront Eleanor publicly, finding evidence in hidden files, and Eleanor's mask slipping more dramatically. Instead, this chapter focuses on information-gathering and planning, with Eleanor remaining largely defensive but composed. The planned "they try to act; things don't go cleanly" structure isn't present. The writing is clean and unfussy, avoiding purple prose or forced metaphors. Dialogue feels natural rather than overly witty or artificially clever. The British setting comes through in natural speech patterns rather than forced slang. Minor weaknesses include some repetitive elements (characters repeatedly expressing disbelief about the situation) and a few moments where the exposition feels slightly mechanical, particularly Leon's explanation of the vampire system structure. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 8 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The school never looks more cursed than on a big evening event. By six, Bayview’s hall had been attacked with fairy lights and borrowed dignity. The Crimson Service banner hung over the stage. Parents milled, governors hovered, staff wore their good cardigans. The biscuits had been upgraded to tiny quiches. I’d managed about three hours of sleep. Every creak of the flat had been the unknown number crawling through the walls. The messages since Lab 3 were short and spiteful. You were told to come alone. 🩸 You like being difficult. That can be fixed. 🩸🩸 Tonight we prove who’s serious. Lab 3 after the showcase. Selected only. 🩸🩸🩸 I’d screenshotted them all. Callum had printed them and kept the pages in a plastic wallet like cursed revision notes. Now we were at school with an audience, and the air hummed with low-grade smug. “They went all out,” Aaliyah said, surveying the hall. She’d swapped uniform for a black dress and Docs, using “it’s an evening performance” as excuse. Dr Lewis fluttered past, cheeks flushed. “Isn’t this exciting?” she said. “Such a vote of confidence in our students.” “Thrilled,” I said. “We’re so proud of Eleanor,” she added, moving on. Eleanor stood near the front, immaculate, greeting parents like a minor royal. If she was rattled from our midnight encounter, it didn’t show. She caught my eye, gave a small, neutral nod, as if we were co-workers. Leon lurked by a side door in a shirt that actually fit, looking like he’d rather be set on fire. Beckwith hovered near the stage, gripping a folder like a flotation device. Callum sidled up, clutching his cursed plastic wallet. “I’ve been thinking,” he said. “That’s never ended badly,” I said. “Whoever’s texting you,” he murmured, “they knew you weren’t alone in Lab 3. And they want you there after this. That’s… that’s someone on the inside. With eyes.” “On-brand,” I said. “Evil, but observant.” “It might not be Eleanor,” he said. “If I were sending illegal threats, I wouldn’t also be onstage accepting a certificate.” “She has lieutenants,” Aaliyah said. “Little prefect minions. Anyone handling the tech? That’s who I’d be.” “Speaking of,” I said. “Positions.” We’d gone over it on the walk here: messy, not a heist, but something. - Aaliyah at the AV desk. She’d charmed the actual AV kid into letting her help. - Callum near the fire alarm panel; he’d memorised the layout like it was a dungeon map. - Me floating as a Crimson “candidate,” so I could track who moved when. Leon was our unofficial nuclear option. He’d said, “I won’t do anything obvious unless there’s no alternative.” Which I’d translated as: there is an alternative level, and it has fangs. Parents and students filtered in. The hall filled. The lights dimmed, leaving everyone’s faces in that washed-out blue. Eleanor took the stage to polite applause. “Good evening,” she began, confident. “Thank you all for coming to celebrate the launch of the Crimson Service. Tonight, you’ll hear about the incredible work our students are already doing to support vital research.” She clicked the remote. The projector hummed. On the screen behind her, the Crimson logo appeared. A beat too long. Then, instead of the planned slide deck, a folder of files popped open. Big, black letters at the top of the screen: CRIMSON SERVICE – CANDIDATE PRIORITISATION Somewhere at the back, Aaliyah went, “Oops,” into the AV mic, which was still on. It echoed around the hall. Half the teachers winced. The cursor moved, highlighting lines seemingly of its own accord: Prime stock – O negative, healthy, low absenteeism. Non-compliant: follow up. 🩸🩸🩸 Selection window: midnight. The hall murmured. Dr Lewis stepped forward. “If we could just—technical glitch—” Another window opened: screenshots of my messages from the unknown number, enlarged for the back row. Non-compliance complicates things. 🩸🩸🩸 You were told to come alone. 🩸 Selected only. 🩸🩸🩸 The words were huge and obscene in the school hall, hovering over Eleanor’s rigid shoulders. Teachers turned like a flock. Parents’ heads snapped towards me, toward the screen, back again. “Kill it,” Eleanor hissed. “Now.” At the AV desk, the real AV kid slammed keys. “It’s not—it’s not—” Aaliyah leaned over and oh-so-helpfully unplugged the laptop. The screen went black. A guillotine. Silence. Thick. “I’m so sorry, everyone,” Eleanor said, voice level by visible force. “That file is internal draft language and does not reflect—” The murmur rose. Words like “prime stock” don’t go down well with parents. Dr Lewis grabbed the mic. “There appears to have been an error with the presentation materials. We will—” She was cut off by the shriek of the fire alarm. Callum, by the panel, looked extremely guilty. Red strobes flashed. Sprinklers didn’t, thank God; the system wasn’t that functional. “Everyone, please proceed calmly to the nearest exit,” Dr Lewis shouted, flipping to Teacher Fire Drill Voice. The crowd began to shuffle, complain, grab bags. In the confusion, a handful of students at the back—Crimson invitees—checked their phones, eyes flicking to me, to the side door. My phone lit up. Lab 3. Now. 🩸🩸🩸 “Showtime,” I muttered. “Do not go,” Callum said, appearing at my elbow. “You promised no splitting up.” “I’m not splitting,” I said. “You’re coming.” “Excellent,” he said faintly. Aaliyah skidded over, hair wild. “They’re blaming the AV kid,” she reported. “We should flee before they realise I’m art.” Leon materialised like a bad mood. “That wasn’t subtle,” he said. “Neither is kidnapping,” I said. I held up my phone. He glanced. His jaw hardened. “That’s our rat,” he said. “They won’t resist the lab, not now. They’ll want to grab what they can before this blows.” “Who’s ‘they’?” Callum asked. “Stay behind me,” Leon said, which wasn’t an answer. The hall emptied into the dark. Teachers in hi-vis vests waved torches, counting heads. We peeled off down a side corridor while everyone else queued for the playground. “Flaw in the plan,” Callum whispered. “Everything about the plan.” The science block was lit only by emergency strips again, pulsing faintly. Lab 3’s door was ajar. Classic. “Of course,” Aaliyah muttered. “They love a door ajar.” Voices inside, low and urgent. “…no time,” someone said. Not Eleanor. Older, male, unfamiliar. “Take what you can. We’ll relocate. They’ve seen too much.” “I told you not to use the damn emojis,” Eleanor snapped. “You’ve made us look insane.” The blood went cold in my hands. We edged closer. Leon gestured us back, but I needed to see. Through the gap: Eleanor, pale but composed, standing near the trolley. Beside her, a man in an ill-fitting suit with a visitor’s lanyard flipped backwards. His hair was slicked, his skin sallow. He held a cool-box. Actual cartoon villain kit. Two students were in there: Jaya, looking scared; Tom, trying to look hard and failing. Both had that floaty expression I’d seen on Kyle. “I didn’t make you text children threats,” the man said. “I simply provided a system. You wanted commitment. You wanted numbers.” “Not like this,” she said. “You knew what the contract was,” he said. “Prime samples. Efficiently sourced. You were very keen on ‘impact’ on our call, Miss Price.” Leon pushed the door fully open. “No more,” he said. The man spun. His gaze slid over Leon, tried to place him, failed. “Who the hell—” “External compliance,” Leon said. “You’re done.” He stepped between the man and the kids with lazy, precise movement. For a second, I could almost see how he might have been before: frightening because he didn’t need to be. “I have authority,” the man blustered. “You’re just a local asset.” “Try me,” Leon said. The man’s hand dipped into his coat. A flash of metal. Not theatrical fangs; a stubby syringe. He lunged—not at Leon, but at Jaya. I didn’t think. I shoved the door open and barreled into him. We both went sideways. The syringe clattered, rolled. Callum kicked it reflexively. It slid under a cupboard. “You absolute idiot,” the man hissed, trying to scramble up. Leon grabbed him by the collar and slammed him against the bench with inhumanly casual force. The man’s feet scrabbled. “You can’t—” Leon bared his teeth. Properly. No pretending. They were wrong. Too long, too sharp. The emergency light made them glint. “Oh, he can,” Aaliyah breathed. The man’s bravado evaporated. “I—I’ll report you up the chain,” he stammered. “I hope you do,” Leon said. “I’d like a word.” Eleanor looked like her operating system had crashed. She stared at the syringe, at the cool-box, at the kids. “I thought—” she started. “That you’d be the hero,” I said. The words came out harsher than I intended. “That hurting the right kids for the right reasons made you special.” “Nothing actually—” she tried. “Prime stock,” I said. “Non-compliant. Selection window. That’s you. That’s your language.” Her mouth snapped shut. Footsteps thundered in the corridor. Adults. Dr Lewis shouting, “Everyone out! Has anyone checked the labs?” “Perfect timing,” Aaliyah muttered. Leon leaned in close to the man’s ear. “You’re leaving,” he said. “Now. And you’re telling your bosses this route is burnt. If anyone comes back, they’ll find me.” The man nodded so fast he blurred. Leon let go. He bolted, stumbling, out the side door that led to the car park, clutching his empty cooler. Gone into the dark. “Eleanor,” Beckwith gasped from the doorway, sudden, taking in the scene: the trolley, the kids, Leon, us. Dr Lewis appeared behind him. “What is going on?” The room froze. Eleanor opened her mouth. For once, nothing came out. “They were about to take blood from underage students without proper consent,” I said. My voice didn’t shake. Small victory. “We stopped it.” “That is a serious allegation,” Dr Lewis said, automatic. “There’s evidence,” Callum said quickly, shoving his folder at her. “Files. The slides. The texts. Check the USB. The AV kid’s still crying.” Jaya made a small sound. “They said it was for research,” she whispered. “They said it would look good for uni.” Dr Lewis’ face did something I’d never seen before: the mask cracked. Genuine horror. “Everyone out of this room,” she said, tight. “Now.” Her eyes swept over Eleanor, over Beckwith. “To my office,” she said to them. “Immediately.” Eleanor’s smile was gone. She looked…young. And furious. At us? At herself? I couldn’t tell. She brushed past me. For a second our shoulders touched. “You’ve ruined everything,” she hissed. “If your ‘everything’ involves cool-box traffickers,” I said, “good.” She stalked out. Beckwith trailed, grey. Leon started to follow, then stopped by us. “You shouldn’t have rushed him,” he said to me. “You’re welcome,” I said. He almost smiled. “Reckless,” he said. “Effective.” “Also, fire alarm,” Callum said. “We committed at least three health and safety violations for this.” Dr Lewis turned. “You three. Office, tomorrow morning. We will need statements.” Aaliyah gave me a tiny thumbs up. “We’re so expelled,” she whispered. “No,” I said. “They can’t. Not when—” My phone buzzed. Unknown Number 🙂 A single, smug smiley. No blood. Leon saw it. His jaw ticked. “It’s not over,” he said quietly. For once, I didn’t have a joke. Out in the corridor, the alarm still wailed. In the hall, the fairy lights dripped. Outside, parents waited in the drizzle with half-understood outrage. We had stopped something. We had not tied it up with a bow. And someone out there was still enjoying the show.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully executes a climactic confrontation while maintaining the established tone and character dynamics. The writing demonstrates strong craft in several areas: the pacing builds effectively from the awkward school showcase atmosphere to genuine danger in Lab 3, and the character voices remain consistent and distinct throughout. The dialogue feels natural and serves multiple functions - advancing plot, revealing character, and maintaining the darkly comic tone. Lines like "If your 'everything' involves cool-box traffickers, good" capture Immy's sardonic voice while landing the moral point. The interplay between characters during the crisis feels organic, particularly the way Aaliyah, Callum, and Immy support each other. The chapter follows its planned structure faithfully, moving through the AV sabotage, fire alarm chaos, and Lab 3 confrontation as outlined. The revelation of the adult "partner" and his methods (the syringe) raises genuine stakes without veering into overwrought territory. Leon's moment of revealing his fangs is handled with restraint - threatening but not cartoonish. However, there are some minor weaknesses. The transition between the hall chaos and arriving at Lab 3 feels slightly rushed. Eleanor's character arc in this chapter, while consistent with her profile, could use more internal conflict - her shift from composed to defensive happens somewhat abruptly. The final emoji from the unknown number, while ominous, feels like a slightly obvious tension-maintenance device. The prose remains clean and functional throughout, avoiding the trap of purple description during action sequences. The British setting details continue to feel authentic rather than forced. The balance of humor and genuine threat works well - the fire alarm causing confusion provides levity without undermining the real danger of the trafficking scheme. The chapter effectively serves its purpose as a climax while setting up remaining complications, maintaining character integrity, and delivering on the darkly comic British YA premise. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 17 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The fire alarm finally cut out at half past eight, leaving a ringing hush. Parents were hustled away with vague apologies about “technical issues.” The Crimson banner sagged. By nine, Mum had me caged at the kitchen table with a mug of tea I hadn’t asked for. “What happened?” she said. No TV voice, no jokey deflection. Just the quiet that meant she was scared. I’d rehearsed with Callum and Aaliyah on the walk home: half-truth, half-omission. “There was a problem with that new charity thing,” I said. “Couple of teachers got ahead of themselves. They were taking blood without the right forms. Someone hacked the slideshow. It got messy. We… told Dr Lewis.” “‘Got messy’ how messy?” she asked. “Not me-messy,” I said. “Promise.” She watched my face, looking for the flicker. There wasn’t one. I wasn’t lying, technically. Just leaving out undead compliance officers and emoji stalkers. She exhaled, shoulders dropping. “You don’t have to impress them,” she said. “You know that, yeah? They’ll take and take and call it opportunity.” It hit harder than any text. “I know,” I said. “Eat something,” she said, ruffling my hair like I was five. “You look like a crisp.” I took my tea and toast to my room. Closed the door. Checked my phone. No new unknowns. No smiley. The last one sat there like an unwanted sticker. In Cryptids & Chemistry, Aaliyah was already spinning. A: tell me we’re getting a Netflix doc C: I’d take “stern letter from academy trust” I: no fame until my breakout role as “anonymous source” I hovered, then typed: I: u guys home ok? C: yep C: nan thinks alarm was “drill that went wrong” A: my mum thinks it was an art installation A: she’s not entirely wrong I: can’t believe they didn’t arrest us for cyber war crimes C: they’re too busy panic-lawyering A: my condolences to eleanor’s ucAS statement We were supposed to be in Dr Lewis’ office at ten the next morning for “formal statements.” Suspensions hung in the air like a possibility no one wanted to say. I slept like someone had unplugged me. In the grey light of morning, school felt hungover. Kids clustered in whisper knots; rumours sprouted. “They were selling our blood online.” “Apparently Eleanor’s in prison.” “My mum says we’re all getting tested.” In reality: Eleanor was “suspended pending investigation.” Mr Beckwith looked like he’d aged a decade overnight. Lawyers had been mentioned in staff emails. Governors were “reviewing safeguarding protocols.” The Crimson posters were gone. Torn rectangles of blue-tack the only trace. In Dr Lewis’ office, the blinds were half-closed. She looked tired in a way that made me feel bad for her for the first time ever. “We are treating this extremely seriously,” she said. Her usual iron tone had frayed. “You did the right thing bringing those files to light.” I waited for the “but.” “But,” she said, “pulling the fire alarm without authorisation is still a breach—” “It was an emergency,” Callum said, voice surprisingly firm. “They were about to move students off-site with a man who wasn’t on your visitor log.” He slid a copy of the visitor sheet he’d grabbed under the door last night onto her desk. He’d circled the name of the man in the bad suit: RICHARD MAY, PARTNER REP. Dr Lewis stared at it. “Where did you get this?” “It fell,” he lied baldly. “I picked it up.” She pinched the bridge of her nose. “I have never been so disappointed in some of my staff,” she said. It took me a second to realise she meant them, not us. “You will not be punished,” she said. “For this. Officially.” Her eyes flicked to me. “Unofficially, please try not to hijack my assemblies again.” “No promises,” Aaliyah said, then coughed. “Sorry. Yes, miss.” Afterwards, in the corridor, the three of us leaned against the lockers like our bones had dissolved. “So,” Aaliyah said. “We’re heroes.” “We’re liabilities,” Callum said. “Heroes are liabilities with better PR.” “I think I’m going to throw up,” I said. “We can do it as a team,” she said. “Coordinated nausea.” Leon was waiting in Lab 3. The door was propped open now, lights on, everything aggressively normal. No trolley. No cool-box. Just periodic tables and last year’s volcano models. He stood by the window, hands in his pockets, looking out at the grey playing field like it offended him. “You survived,” he said as we walked in. “Not through lack of trying,” I said. Beckwith was there too, perched on a stool. He looked wrung out. “Dr Lewis has reported everything up,” he said. “To the trust, to the regulators. The… external partner has been cut off.” He swallowed. “I’m on… leave, while they investigate. Which is fair.” “You going to tell them about the vampire clause?” Aaliyah asked. He flinched. Leon rolled his eyes. “No one’s mentioning the words you people keep saying too loudly,” Leon said. “Officially, it’s ‘inappropriate medical procedures’ and ‘rogue contractor.’ They don’t actually want the full story.” “That makes four of us,” Callum murmured. Leon looked at me. “Thank you,” he said. “For the slides. The alarm. The tackling. All of it.” “Don’t get soppy,” I said. “You’ll ruin your aesthetic.” He ignored that. “The buyer won’t be back,” he said. “He’s been… discouraged.” A flash of something flickered behind that: satisfaction edged with something darker. “And the texts?” I asked. “We traced what we could,” he said. “Our charming partner set up the system. But someone local was sending them. Using his access.” “Well?” Aaliyah said. “Name and shame.” “Office manager,” Leon said. “The one who does the mail merges. She thought it was ‘motivational.’ She didn’t write the threats, just sent what she was given, didn’t question it. Says she deleted everything once she got nervous.” “That’s it?” I said. “Killer stationery vibes and zero critical thinking?” “Told you,” Callum said. “Admin.” Leon shrugged. “The texts with… flavour were May. The smiley.” His lip curled. “He thought it was funny.” “Nothing about him is funny,” I said. “He’s being handled,” Leon said. “My side and yours, for once, in agreement.” “Cool,” Aaliyah said. “Love a bipartisan takedown.” Silence settled for a moment. “So what now?” I asked. “Now,” Beckwith said, “we rebuild trust. We make sure nothing like this can happen again. We—” “You resign,” Aaliyah suggested. He winced. “Possibly.” Leon said, “Now we shut down the school scheme. For good. No more pilots. If I need supplies, I go back to anonymous adults with proper forms and less drama.” “You’re welcome,” I said. He tilted his head. “I meant it. You three are… annoyingly effective.” “We aim to irritate,” Aaliyah said. Callum chewed his lip. “So there are more of you,” he said to Leon. “Out there.” “Yes,” Leon said. “Most of them extremely boring. I am, tragically, considered rebellious.” “That is tragic,” I said. Leon’s mouth twitched. “If anything like this stirs again,” he said, “I might need help. Someone who recognises certain patterns. Preferably someone who doesn’t immediately post them on TikTok.” “I’m not your intern,” I said. “Obviously,” he said. “You’d unionise.” A beat. We were all, inexplicably, smiling a little. “Give me your number,” he said. “Properly. No creepy unknowns.” I hesitated. “You’re not going to send me blood emojis?” I asked. “God, no,” he said. “If you ever see three of those again, it won’t be from me.” I tapped my number into his battered old Nokia—of course he had a brick—and watched him save it as “Imogen (Do Not Drink).” On my screen, a new contact request popped: Leon (Definitely Not A Vampire) “You’re hilarious,” I said. “It’s aspirational,” he said. We left them there, two compromised adults in a bright lab, and stepped out into the corridor. The day had brightened a bit. Through the glass doors we could see kids on the field, shrieking, footballs flying. As if nothing had nearly turned into a farm. “Do we tell anyone?” Callum asked, as we loitered by the stairs. “About the vampire bit.” “Who’d believe it?” Aaliyah said. “Plus, imagine the safeguarding form. Too much admin.” “I think,” I said slowly, “we hold it. For now. We keep an eye. We annoy anyone who starts talking about ‘prime stock.’ We don’t walk into midnight labs alone.” “Buddy system forever,” Aaliyah said, hooking her arm through mine. “Statistically speaking,” Callum said, “if anything weird happens again, it’ll find us.” “Great,” I said. “Love that for us.” Later, after a day of half-hearted lessons and full-throated gossip, after giving a sanitised statement to an actual police officer (“No, I didn’t think the texts were serious at first. Yes, I’m aware that was dumb.”), after Mum squeezed me so tightly my ribs complained, I lay on my bed with my phone on my chest. A notification pinged. Leon (Definitely Not A Vampire): If you see anything else odd, text. No heroics. 🩸 Just one drop. I snorted despite myself. Typed back: I: that is not reassuring branding also: terms & conditions apply Three dots. Then: Leon: noted I locked the chat. Left it there. I was about to toss the phone aside when another notification slid down, from a number I didn’t recognise. Unknown: 👍 Just a thumbs up. No name, no thread history. Every muscle in my body went tight. “Not funny,” I told the ceiling. I stared at it for a long moment. Waited for more. Nothing came. I screenshotted it. Forwarded it to Cryptids & Chemistry. I: plz tell me one of you thinks you’re hilarious Aaliyah: not my brand send me address, I’ll fight them Callum: could be someone fat-fingering a group chat or may or okay I’m spiralling I: new rule, no unknown emoji ever I didn’t reply to the unknown. I blocked it, knowing that might not mean much. Then I put the phone face-down. In the dark, I could still see the first message in my mind. The neat three drops. The moment when it had been just another joke. I thought about Kyle, pale and quiet but back in class, his mum holding his arm a little too tight at pick-up. About Jaya, deleting an email with shaking fingers. About Eleanor, somewhere with her planner and no title, replaying the moment her perfect story cracked. I thought about my mum’s line: they’ll take and take and call it opportunity. I thought about how, for half a second when the envelope had landed in my hand, I’d felt flattered. That was the bit that lodged under my ribs. “Never again,” I told myself. The street outside flicked from day to night. Glam Claws sign buzzing, gulls screaming, buses sighing. My phone buzzed once on the duvet. My heart kicked. It was just Callum. C: if we get murdered by a thumbs up emoji I’m suing microsoft I: that’s windows this is google’s fault probably A: breathe, cryptids u ruined a blood cult, you can handle a hand I exhaled. Smiled, slightly. Outside my window, under the half-lit A CA E sign, a figure in a beanie stood for a moment, hands in his pockets, looking up. When the bus passed, blocking my view for a second, he was gone. I didn’t freak out. “See you soon, maybe,” I said quietly. “But only if I text first.” No grand moral. No neat ending. Just me, my stupid heart, my cursed phone, my friends, a possibly ethical vampire, and a town that would absolutely turn this into a rumour by Monday. It would do.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This final chapter successfully delivers on the story's promise of "darkly comic British YA" while providing a satisfying but deliberately imperfect resolution. The writing demonstrates strong character work and authentic voice throughout. **Strengths:** The chapter excels at emotional authenticity, particularly in Immy's interaction with her mum. The line "They'll take and take and call it opportunity" feels genuinely painful and cuts to the heart of class anxiety that has subtly threaded through the story. Immy's moment of self-reflection about feeling "flattered" when chosen is psychologically astute - acknowledging how seductive being selected can feel even when it's harmful. The dialogue remains sharp and character-specific. Leon's deadpan humor ("You'd unionise"), Aaliyah's theatrical responses, and Callum's statistical anxiety all feel true to their established voices. The administrative revelation about the texts is brilliantly mundane - "office manager" doing "mail merges" perfectly deflates any remaining melodrama while staying believable. The pacing works well, moving from immediate aftermath to official resolution to personal reckoning. The decision not to reveal the vampire element publicly feels mature and realistic rather than frustrating. **Technical execution:** The prose is clean and purposeful without forced poeticism. Details like Beckwith's "three identical grey cardigans" and the "torn rectangles of blue-tack" create vivid specificity. The chapter maintains its established tone - never fully light but never oppressively dark. The emoji reclamation works effectively, with Leon's single drop becoming an agreed signal rather than a threat. The final unknown emoji creates appropriate unease without resetting the entire plot. **Areas for improvement:** Some exposition feels slightly heavy-handed, particularly around the official response and legal consequences. The police statement feels perfunctory rather than dramatically necessary. The final sighting of Leon could be more subtly handled - it borders on unnecessary reassurance rather than letting tension remain. The chapter occasionally relies on familiar YA comfort beats (group chat banter, protective parental moment) that, while well-executed, don't surprise. **Overall assessment:** This is competent, engaging YA writing that delivers on its promises. The emotional core feels genuine, the characters remain consistent, and the resolution respects both the darkness and comedy established throughout. While not groundbreaking, it's solid storytelling that understands its genre and audience. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This is a substantial piece of British YA fiction that successfully executes its premise of starting from mysterious blood emoji texts. The story follows Imogen and her friends as they uncover a school "volunteer program" that's actually a front for harvesting student blood, with a vampire character trying to maintain ethical boundaries within an exploitative system.
