The strongest elements are the character voices and dialogue. Imogen's first-person narration is consistently sarcastic and engaging, with believable teenage perspective and humor. The friendship dynamic between Imogen, Callum (the anxious analytical one), and Aaliyah (the confident dramatic one) feels authentic, with each character maintaining distinct speech patterns and reactions throughout. Lines like "I'm not auditioning for your tragic heroine fan club" and "Season three: they recast me with someone taller" demonstrate the author's facility with age-appropriate humor and voice. The plot structure is solid, building logically from mysterious texts to school meetings to midnight confrontations. The vampire Leon is an interesting character - positioning him as an "ethical compliance officer" trying to regulate an exploitative system creates compelling moral complexity. The corporate bureaucracy angle on vampire society feels fresh. The British setting is well-established through cultural references, slang, and specific details like the seaside town atmosphere, chip shops, and school structure. The world-building integrates supernatural elements believably into contemporary reality. However, there are some weaknesses. The resolution feels somewhat rushed - the slideshow reveal and fire alarm sequence, while dramatic, glosses over technical details that strain credibility. The vampire world-building, while intriguing, could be more fully developed. Some plot threads (like the exact relationship between Leon's organization and the "buyers") remain vague. The ending with another unknown number feels like sequel-baiting rather than organic conclusion. Additionally, while the piece maintains consistent tone, some of the dramatic moments (particularly the final confrontation) occasionally tip toward melodrama. The prose is generally clean and engaging without being purple or overly stylized. The pacing works well for YA fiction, maintaining tension while allowing character development. The piece successfully fulfills its genre requirements and prompt constraints. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Pacing: 15 World Building: 14 Compelling Plot: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 7 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Unearned Transformations: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18
Avg Final Item Score: 74.6/100
+ Space Western — Cargo Unknown (Chapter Avg: 79.6 | Final: 82.6)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Space Western Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Captain, something's... moving in that crate we picked up.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Space Western Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Captain, something&#x27;s... moving in that crate we picked up. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming 1. Big-picture concepts and settings - Classic frontier-in-space vibe: - Dusty trading posts on asteroid belts. - A “railroad” route of freighters and smugglers. - Lawmen (“Marshals”) riding small interceptor craft instead of horses. - Saloons as dive bars at orbital stations, with synth whiskey and clacking holo-poker. - The ship: - A small hauler: patched, under-armed, fast when it must be. - Crew lives paycheck to paycheck via shady contracts. - The crate was taken on at a backwater outpost, no questions asked. - Political backdrop: - Megacorps vs. frontier colonies. - A weak central government; much is handled by local Marshals and private security. - Rumors of corporate black-ops bioweapons, alien relics, AI bans. - The “Space Western” tone: - Rugged individualism; loyalty, betrayal, law vs. justice. - Showdowns (with guns or ships). - Sparse, image-rich language; laconic dialogue. - Moral gray: characters forced into hard choices. 2. Possible contents of the moving crate - Option A: A dangerous creature - Engineered predator (corporate experiment) that can survive vacuum/harsh conditions. - Parasitic/shape-shifting organism. - Tension: creature loose on a confined ship; who’s predator, who’s prey. - Western analog: rattlesnake in the saddlebags / cougar in the barn. - Option B: A child or stowaway - Genetically engineered child/prototype psychic. - Escaped property of a megacorp or a cult. - Tension: crew caught between bounty/profit and protecting the kid. - Western analog: wagon train finds outlaw’s orphan / valuable runaway slave. - Option C: An outlaw/assassin in cryosleep - Legendary gunslinger marked for retrieval. - Wakes early; reluctant alliance against shared threat. - Western analog: prisoner transport goes wrong. - Option D: Ancient alien artifact - Semi-sentient; subtle movement, whispers. - Warps crew’s perceptions; maybe seeds lifeforms. - Western analog: cursed gold / mystical relic. - Option E: Rogue AI core - AI drives movement (mechanical shifting, drone assembly). - Possibly trying to build itself using ship’s systems. - Western analog: haunted stagecoach / demon in the mine machinery. 3. Core cast ideas - Captain: - Ex-Marshal or ex-corporate security turned independent hauler. - Stoic, pragmatic, carrying guilt over a past mission. - Values crew as surrogate family. - First Mate: - Veteran, cynical, voice of experience. - Knows the underworld; has a secret tie to the crate’s origin. - Mechanic/Engineer: - Young, scrappy, superstitious, good at improvisation. - Provides comic relief and heart; maybe first to suspect oddities. - Pilot: - Hotshot, cocky, ex-racer; skilled but impulsive. - Provides Western “cowboy” swagger. - Doctor/Medic: - Underqualified frontier doc; maybe with military background. - Understands biotech enough to see how bad it is. - Extra: - Passenger, hitchhiker, or paying client whose motives are unclear. - Could be undercover Marshal, corporate agent, or related to crate. 4. Plot directions (macro arcs) - Arc 1: Smuggling gone sideways - Crew takes a no-questions cargo run. - Something moves. They open it (or it breaks out). - They’re hunted by whoever wants it back (corporation/Marshal/pirates). - Must choose: profit vs. conscience. - Climax: showdown at remote frontier station; choose to free/protect/destroy cargo. - Arc 2: Creature-feature siege - Movement is a predator/bioweapon/alien. - Story focuses on survival on the ship. - Outside threat arrives later to contain or capture the creature. - Climax: Captain’s sacrifice / clever trap / burning it all down. - Arc 3: Runaway asset and redemption - Crate holds a runaway experimental kid (or AI core) afraid and dangerous. - Crew debates: ransom it or deliver to safety. - Antagonists: corporate retrieval team, bounty hunters, maybe old Marshal contact. - Themes: found family, personhood, frontier justice. - Arc 4: Artifact, corruption, and possession - Object influences crew, stoking paranoia. - “Moving” is shifting geometry, gravity anomalies. - Climax: Captain must destroy or exile artifact, risking crew. 5. Choosing a hybrid approach (still brainstorming) - Hybrid 1: Child + Bioweapon - Crate carries a young girl/boy who is bonded to a restrained organism. - Kid is empathetic and mostly innocent; organism is protective/violent. - Corporation wants both as weapon system. - Crew must accept/kill/protect both. - Hybrid 2: AI + physical threat - Rogue AI core controls ship systems, uses ship to build mechanical body. - Movement is rattling, self-assembling drones. - Meanwhile, corporate ship closes in. - Hybrid 3: Outlaw + Alien/Parasite - Crate holds notorious outlaw infected with alien parasite. - Outlaw partly sympathetic; parasite dangerous but maybe sentient. - Crew stuck with dual hostage-threat scenario. 6. Structural pacing over 8 chapters (1000 words each, ~8000 words total) - Chapter 1: Setup - Introduce ship, crew, frontier world. - Show them accepting shady cargo. - Final line: “Captain, something’s... moving in that crate we picked up.” - Chapter 2: First encounter - Debate: open or not. - Something small escapes; weird event or minor injury. - Hints about who shipped the crate. - Chapter 3: Complication - Reveal partial truth of crate contents. - Communique/incoming ship demanding inspection, or bounty notice. - Stakes clarified: legal, financial, existential. - Chapter 4: Escalation - Threat/presence grows: more movement, sabotage, psychological tension. - Crew conflict over what to do. - Chapter 5: Midpoint crisis - Full/clear reveal: what’s inside, and why it matters. - External antagonists close in. - Captain forced to pick a side (even if reluctantly). - Chapter 6: Siege / Chase - Running engagements: in corridors or in space. - Tough choices, casualties or near-misses. - Discovery of leverage/weakness of enemy or threat. - Chapter 7: Showdown - Western-style stand-off at frontier location or derelict. - Confrontation with main antagonist (Marshal, corporate rep, outlaw). - Moral decision tied to crate’s fate. - Chapter 8: Resolution - Fallout. Survivors choose path forward. - Pay off themes: frontier justice, chosen family, humanity vs. profit. - End with a bittersweet but satisfying note; possible hook for future tales. 7. Thematic beats to weave in - Frontier justice vs. formal law: - Is returning the crate “right” if it means torture/weaponization? - Personhood: - If contents are sentient (child/AI/alien), are they cargo or passenger? - Loyalty: - Crew’s loyalty tested by bribes, bounties, desperation. - Exploitation: - Megacorps see frontier life/people as resources. - The Western ruggedness: - Self-reliance, stubbornness, weathered humor. - Ships and stations feel like dusty ranches, lonely outposts. 8. Variations in tone - Option: Dark suspenseful horror - Focused on fear of the unknown; dim corridors, isolation. - Option: Pulpy adventure - Quippy dialogue; dangerous but fun; big hero moments. - Option: Somber moral drama - Emphasis on hard choices, compromised ideals. - Option: Blend - Start as pulpy/scrappy smuggler tale, drift into suspense, land in emotional Western drama. 9. Possible antagonists - Corporate agent: - Polite, ruthless; offers legal threats or big money. - Federal Marshal: - Sympathetic but bound to law; old history with Captain. - Bounty hunter gang: - “Posse” in fast ships; more brute threat. - The crate’s content itself: - Unstable, dangerous when frightened or used. - Forces conflicts but not simply evil. 10. Possible endings (broad) - Noble sacrifice: - Captain or crew member sacrifices their future/career/life to save crate-being. - Dirty deal: - They bargain a compromise that keeps them alive but costs their souls a bit. - Clean escape: - They outsmart everyone, keep their principles, but remain wanted. - Tragic: - Save the frontier by destroying the thing, losing any reward, and scarring themselves. # Reflection 1. On the crate’s contents - Creature-only (Option A): - Pros: Clear physical threat; easy suspense, ship-based horror. - Cons: Risks becoming “just” a monster story; less moral complexity. - Child or sentient asset (Option B): - Pros: Strong emotional core; natural Western resonance (protecting the innocent). - Cons: Requires careful handling to avoid clichés (mysterious kid, chosen one). - Outlaw in cryosleep (Option C): - Pros: Fun Western outlaw dynamic; snappy dialogue. - Cons: Might overshadow the “mysterious crate” aspect quickly; becomes buddy-outlaw story. - Artifact (Option D): - Pros: Weird, cosmic flavor; can mirror Western cursed object tropes. - Cons: Harder to resolve cleanly in 8k; subtlety might clash with desired pulpy immediacy. - Rogue AI (Option E): - Pros: Very space-sci-fi; integrates tension into the ship itself. - Cons: Less “Western” in feel unless grounded in personal stakes; AI themes could sprawl. Hybrid Child + Bioweapon/Experiment: - Pros: - Combines moral dilemma (protect a someone) with real danger (bio-thing). - Natural corporate villain motive. - Fits “runaway slave/asset” Western motif and frontier justice. - Cons: - Needs tight control not to overcomplicate (keep lore simple). - Must avoid making the kid purely a plot device. Overall: - The most compelling, “Space Western” aligned option seems to feature: - A sentient, vulnerable being (child or equivalent) in the crate. - Corporate or authority pursuit. - Some dangerous twist (powers, symbiote) to maintain genuine suspense. 2. On tone - Pure horror could work, but: - Might smother the Western charm (banter, dusty honor codes, showdowns). - Pure pulpy fun: - Risks trivializing the tension of “we’re carrying something truly dangerous/valuable.” - A blended tone: - Start with roguish smuggler energy. - Shift into tense, somewhat claustrophobic suspense as weird things happen. - Resolve in a moral Western showdown with heart. - This blend seems best: it keeps the narrative lean but emotionally engaging within 8k. 3. On structure/pacing for 8 chapters - 8 x ~1000 words is tight; must be economical: - Each chapter should pivot the situation: - Ch1: Setup/hook - Ch2: First incident - Ch3: Info/stakes - Ch4: Internal conflict escalates - Ch5: Full reveal/midpoint choice - Ch6: Action/siege - Ch7: Showdown - Ch8: Denouement - Need a strong central throughline: - “What is in the crate, who wants it, and what will our people do about it?” - Reflection: Concepts that add too many factions, subplots, or metaphysics won’t fit elegantly. Better to keep: - One main external antagonist group. - One internal secret or betrayal. - One clear emotional focal point (e.g., Captain’s choice). 4. On character dynamics - Strong Space Western feel comes from: - A Captain as reluctant sheriff/outlaw wrestling with past. - Loyal but opinionated crew (each with a distinct stance). - An antagonist who genuinely believes they’re right (law, order, greater good). - Good tensions to include: - First Mate with knowledge of the crate’s origin (adds betrayal/complication). - A Marshal or corporate agent with a history with the Captain. - Crew split: some want to sell/turn over contents; others want to protect/destroy. 5. On themes - Frontier justice vs law: - Resonates strongly if crate’s occupant is legally “property” but morally a person. - Found family: - Crew functions like a small, battered family; crate’s occupant tests that bond. - Exploitation: - Corporate villain aiming to weaponize living being. - These themes pair naturally with a child/engineered-being scenario plus corporate antagonists. 6. On what’s less promising - Super abstract alien/artifact weirdness: - Might be too diffuse for 8k and undercut the Western concreteness. - Overly convoluted conspiracies: - Would eat wordcount better spent on character and tension. - Making the crate’s contents purely evil: - Removes the key moral dilemma and narrows the story to “kill the monster.” 7. Overall direction (not final, just leaning) - The most promising approach appears to be: - A ragged cargo crew takes a hush-hush job. - Crate contains a young engineered empath/weapon (or similar) escaping a corporation. - The movement is both physical (panic, powers) and symbolic (disruption of status quo). - Corporate retrieval (or Marshal entangled with them) closes in. - The Captain, torn between survival, old loyalties, and conscience, must decide. - Final chapters: Western-style standoff at a seedy frontier station; they side with protecting the being, at cost. - This path: - Honors the prompt. - Emphasizes Space Western aesthetics. - Allows a satisfying full arc in 8 chapters. If you’d like, next I can lock in a concrete outline based on this reflection: defining the crate’s exact contents, naming the crew, and mapping precise beats for each of the 8 chapters.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention I’m locking in a focused, character-driven Space Western with a strong moral core and a clear, escalating plot. Key choices: - Setting and tone: - Space Western frontier: - Rusted-out haulers, dusty orbital truck stops, half-lawless routes. - Visual/tonal echoes of classic Westerns: lonely vistas (starfields), desolate towns (stations), saloons (dives), Marshals and posses (lawcraft and bounty crews). - Tone blend: - Start: roguish, laconic, slightly humorous smuggler vibe. - Middle: tense, claustrophobic suspense onboard; fear and mistrust. - End: Western-style moral showdown and bittersweet hope. - Avoid: - Overwrought technobabble. - Full-on cosmic horror or abstract weirdness that derails the Western feel. - Crate contents: - A genetically engineered teen girl (around 13–14), named “Lyra” (working name). - She is: - A corporate-made empath/psionic weapon bonded to a semi-organic defensive symbiote that reacts to her fear. - Legally classified as proprietary biotech equipment. - Morally, a scared kid who never had a choice. - The “movement” in the crate: - Her and the symbiote waking from sedation. - Occasional tendrils or growths thumping/reshaping the crate. - This combines: - Real danger (the symbiote can kill; things can get out of hand). - Intimate stakes (protecting a child; questions of personhood). - Clear antagonistic interest (megacorp wants its asset back). - Protagonists: - Captain Jax Rourke: - Mid-30s/40s, ex-Federal Marshal who quit after a dirty mission involving corporate atrocities. - Stoic, dry humor, rules-of-thumb morality, quietly burdened. - Arc: from “get the job done, stay alive” to actively defying the system to protect Lyra. - First Mate Mara Kade: - Ex-corporate logistics/security; took the job and knows more about the crate than she initially admits. - Tough, pragmatic; survival-first, but conscience underneath. - Arc: from compromised to redeemed via choice to help Lyra. - Mechanic “Stitch” Delgado: - Young, scrappy, superstitious; provides heart and nervous humor. - First to notice something wrong; bonds with Lyra. - Pilot Rian Cole: - Cocky, charming, ex-racer; likes risk until the stakes get too real. - Medic Dr. Imani Hale: - Older, calm, with battlefield trauma; recognizes Lyra as a weaponized child immediately. - Aim: Keep cast tight; each has a distinct stance and role. - Antagonists: - Primary: Aurelia Voss - A polished, ruthless corporate retrieval officer for HelioDyne Biotek. - Believes the asset is critical tech; frames retrieval as lawful and necessary. - Secondary: A Federal Marshal patrol - Led by Marshal Briggs, Jax’s former mentor. - Initially neutral/lawful; pressured into siding with HelioDyne. - Goal: - Present antagonists with understandable motives (law, order, tech security), not cartoon villains, while their actions are chillingly utilitarian. - Plot focus: - Throughline: - Crew takes shady “no scans, no questions” cargo. - Crate starts moving; they discover Lyra and what she is. - Corporate forces close in; law entangled. - Crew must choose: cash in/comply, abandon her, or protect her. - Ends with a Western-style standoff and a costly commitment to doing the right thing. - Keep it clean: - One primary external antagonist faction (HelioDyne, with law as lever). - One internal secret/betrayal (Mara’s prior knowledge). - No sprawling conspiracies or unrelated subplots. - Stylistic aims: - Voice: - Tight third-person, mostly from Captain Jax’s POV, with occasional close-ins on others when needed. - Lean, visual prose; short, grounded sensory details; purposeful but not flowery. - Dialogue-driven character moments; Western laconic wit. - Pacing: - Each chapter turns a corner: new reveal, escalation, or irreversible choice. - Maintain momentum; no filler exposition dumps. - Themes: - Frontier justice vs institutional law. - Personhood vs property; exploitation of the vulnerable. - Found family and loyalty under pressure. - The cost of doing the right thing when the system’s wrong. - Avoid: - Making Lyra a passive MacGuffin; she will have agency, growth, and emotional depth. - Making the symbiote just “evil goo”; it’s a protective extension of her trauma/fear. - Glorifying violence—show it as dangerous, consequential, and character-revealing. This setup should produce a tight, emotionally resonant, cinematic 8-chapter story that fully uses the prompt and length constraints. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1 – The Crate and the Captain - Purpose: - Establish the ship, crew, tone, and the shady job. - End on the hook: movement in the crate. - Beats: - Open on the freighter “Calamity Jane” docking at a rough-edge orbital outpost (“Waystation Calico”). - Introduce: - Jax: negotiating underpaid cargo contracts, wary of authorities. - Mara: closing the deal on a “priority sealed shipment” from a HelioDyne intermediary, insisting on no scans. - Stitch and Rian: bantering, showcasing the ship’s ramshackle nature. - A glimpse of Voss’s logo or agents in the periphery, but no direct interaction. - The deal: - Crate is large, reinforced; labeled biohazard with legalese that no one reads fully. - Payout is unusually good for a simple run to a distant mining station. - Early foreboding: - Dr. Hale mutters about corporate biotech and “bad stories.” - Jax senses something off but needs the money. - In transit: - Ship leaves Calico; crew relaxes. - Subtle sounds from the cargo bay: metal creaking, a dull thump. - End: - Stitch, doing a routine check, hears distinct movement and a muffled sound. - Calls it in: “Uh, Captain? Something’s… moving in that crate we picked up.” Chapter 2 – Scratches in the Dark - Purpose: - Increase suspense; tease danger without full reveal. - Show initial crew division: open it or not. - Beats: - Jax, Mara, Stitch in cargo bay examining the crate. - External sensors show slight heat spike, internal pressure changes. - Debate: - Mara: “We open it, we void the contract.” - Jax: torn between duty to crew vs. fear of carrying unknown threat. - Stitch: unnerved, hears what sounds like a small voice. - First incident: - Crate jolts violently; side panel buckles slightly. - A slick, dark tendril or vine-like growth tests a seam then withdraws. - Response: - They rig external restraints, patch cameras, motion sensors. - Hale reviews manifest tags, finds obfuscated HelioDyne codes linked to “Project Lyric” (hint only). - External complication: - An incoming message ping: a Federal Marshal patrol broadcasting routine inspection notice for all outbound ships from Calico due to “biotech theft.” - Jax chooses to burn hard and alter course slightly to avoid them, raising stakes. - End: - Ship shudders as internal systems glitch momentarily (symbiote interfacing unconsciously). - Whispered audio on cargo cam: a hoarse, frightened, very human “Please…” Chapter 3 – Opening the Box - Purpose: - Reveal Lyra. - Clarify core moral conflict and external threat. - Beats: - Confrontation: - The crew watches the replay of the “Please.” - Jax decides: they can’t ignore a voice. Orders a controlled opening despite Mara’s protests. - Opening: - They cut seals; Hale ready with med kit, Jax armed. - Inside: Lyra strapped in, IV lines, monitors, half-grown organic lattice around her (symbiote). - She’s weak, terrified; symbiote bristles when anyone approaches too fast. - Information: - Hale scans: engineered neuro-signatures, stress-linked psionic spikes; symbiote responds to her fear, capable of lashing out. - Lyra haltingly explains: - She was grown/trained by HelioDyne as a tactical asset. - She escaped with help from a sympathetic tech (we’ll hint this was connected to Mara’s past). - She thought she was being smuggled to safety, not back to HelioDyne. - External stakes sharpen: - Priority encrypted message reaches them, routed from the Marshals but clearly authored by HelioDyne’s Aurelia Voss: - Official recall notice: “Stolen corporate property identified. Surrender the specified crate for inspection at once.” - Legal threats; bounty posted on “Project Lyric.” - Internal tension: - Some crew (Rian) see the bounty as a way out of debt. - Stitch is horrified at calling her “property.” - Mara is visibly shaken by the project name, but hides full recognition. - End: - Jax quietly promises Lyra: “No one’s hurting you on my ship.” - While alone, Mara sends a conflicted, coded burst message—a breadcrumb of her secret tie. Chapter 4 – Lines in the Dust - Purpose: - Deepen relationships and moral conflict. - Escalate danger via Lyra’s powers and the approaching enemy. - Beats: - Character work: - Stitch befriends Lyra; shows her the engine room, reassures her. - Hale gently explains to Jax the full horror of weaponizing an empathic child. - Lyra reveals the symbiote responds to her fear/anger; she can sometimes calm it. - Mara’s guilt: - She confesses to Jax (partially): - Former HelioDyne logistics; she recognized the project codes. - Took this job because someone inside HelioDyne tipped her that “Project Lyric” needed extraction—she believed the crate was an escape route, not a return shipment. - The coded message she sent was to that contact, not to betray them. - Trust shaken, but she aligns firmly now with protecting Lyra. - External pressure: - Marshal Briggs’s patrol appears on long-range scanners, on intercept course. - Briggs hails Jax: plays on old bond, mentions HelioDyne theft, requests they hold position for inspection. - Lyra’s loss of control: - Stress spikes at HelioDyne mention; symbiote flares. - Short, intense incident: - Biotech tendrils lash out in medbay/corridor, damaging equipment, nearly injuring Rian. - Lyra horrified at what she did; fears she’s a monster. - Clarifies: she is dangerous if pushed, but not malicious. - End: - Jax chooses to run instead of submit to inspection, knowing it makes them fugitives. - Briggs quietly warns: “You’re making this mighty hard to explain away, son.” Chapter 5 – No Way Back - Purpose: - Midpoint: clear side chosen, costs locked in. - Expose Voss and heighten imminent threat. - Beats: - Pursuit: - Space chase evoking horse-and-posse: - The Calamity Jane ducks through a debris field/derelict ring. - Briggs’ patrol hesitates; HelioDyne gunship under Voss pushes through. - Direct contact with Voss: - Narrow-band comm: Voss is cold, composed: - Offers amnesty and a large payout if they stand down and hand over Lyra. - Frames it as returning hazardous property; implies Lyra cannot survive without HelioDyne’s tech. - Jax, seeing the manipulation, stalls then cuts the line. - Internal conflict spike: - Rian is tempted; nearly sends coordinates. - Mara confronts him; simmering argument about survival vs. conscience. - Lyra’s agency: - She overhears, believes she’s only a burden. - Offers to surrender herself to save them. - Jax refuses: “We ain’t that kind of outfit.” - Reveal: - Hale and Mara piece together data: - Lyra’s powers could disable fleets, rip minds if fully trained. - Symbiote is keyed to corporate control triggers; Voss plans to “fix” her disobedience. - Plan setup: - They aim for a forgotten frontier refuel/salvage station “Prospector’s Rest” to hide, repair, and maybe find help. - Knowing Voss will trace them, Jax starts framing it as the ground for a last stand/trade on their terms. - End: - Voss dispatches a message to Briggs: - Strongarms him with jurisdictional orders to assist in retrieval. - Briggs, conflicted, turns toward Prospector’s Rest too. Chapter 6 – Prospector’s Rest - Purpose: - Close in, set the stage, show mounting desperation and resolve. - Beats: - Arrival: - Prospector’s Rest: a half-abandoned ring station; rust, flickering neons, a few roughneck miners—classic frontier town in space. - Brief respite: - Refuel, patch hull, tense saloon-like encounter with locals. - Rumors about HelioDyne “ghosting” whole colonies with their projects. - Setting the trap: - Jax and Mara plan: - Use the station’s labyrinthine maintenance shafts to their advantage. - Rig EMP charges and environmental controls to weaken HelioDyne gear. - Evac route for Lyra planned with Stitch’s help. - Lyra’s growth: - She insists on helping; has sensed Voss’s mind at a distance—calculating, cold. - She works with Hale to regulate her fear; practices dialing back symbiote reactions. - Conflicted lawman: - Briggs arrives first, confronts Jax privately. - They argue: law vs. justice; Briggs says handing Lyra over could prevent greater chaos. - Jax shows him Lyra; humanizes her. - Briggs wavers, but Voss’s ship is already inbound; his hands are tied publicly. - End: - Voss’s gunship and escorts drop out of FTL. - Ultimatum broadcast to all: surrender the asset or be treated as hostile insurgents. - Station shutters; everyone bracing for a siege. Chapter 7 – High Noon in the Black - Purpose: - Climax: Western-style standoff and battle. - Force Jax and Lyra into defining choices. - Beats: - Confrontation: - Voss lands a contingent; sleek armored enforcers marching through dusty corridors. - Central concourse showdown: - Voss with legal warrants and overwhelming force. - Jax, Mara, crew, a few armed locals; Briggs caught between. - Negotiation turned duel: - Voss: - Offers last deal, addresses Lyra as “unit.” - Threatens station and crew lives. - Lyra’s panic rises; symbiote quivers. - Jax rejects the deal; calls Voss out for slavery and torture. - Kinetic break: - Orchestrated firefight: - EMP traps hit, dropping some HelioDyne tech. - Symbiote lash disables weapons aimed at Lyra. - Chaos in tight corridors—evokes saloon shootout and alley brawls. - Briggs’s choice: - Sees HelioDyne move to kill civilians. - Throws in with Jax, ordering his deputies to stand down Voss’s forces. - He cites an emergency clause: protecting sentient life from unlawful harm. - Lyra’s critical moment: - Cornered with Jax as Voss advances with kill-switch device. - Lyra focuses, turns her power inward: - Overrides her own control tags; severs symbiote’s corporate bindings. - Redirects its defense surgically: disarming, disabling—not slaughtering. - Exposes Voss’s mind to a flash of Lyra’s pain—shakes her, but Voss remains defiant. - Resolution of Voss: - In the final beat, Briggs arrests Voss under abuse of sentient-biotech statutes (thin legal cover, but enough). - Or, if that’s too clean: Voss goes down in the crossfire, symbolizing the system’s violence turning on itself. - End: - HelioDyne forces repelled/contained. Station damaged but standing. - Calamity Jane scarred, but alive. Chapter 8 – Trail’s End (For Now) - Purpose: - Tie off emotional and moral arcs. - Leave a sense of consequence and possibility. - Beats: - Aftermath: - Casualty count; quiet moments in the battered concourse. - Lyra shaken but free of corporate control triggers; symbiote now responsive to her choice, not fear alone. - Legal/political fallout: - Briggs: - Files a contested report framing Lyra as a person under protective custody, not property. - Knows he’s likely ending his career; does it anyway. - HelioDyne: - Temporarily thwarted; their public image dented; threat not gone, but pushed back. - Choices: - Lyra is offered possible relocation to an independent colony. - She instead asks to stay with the Calamity Jane crew, at least for a while. - Jax hesitates (danger, pursuit), but: - Recognizes they’ve already chosen her over safety. - Accepts, with conditions about training control. - Crew dynamics: - Mara fully on-side; past with HelioDyne now openly known. - Rian chastened but loyal. - Stitch thrilled but protective. - Hale wary but committed to helping Lyra. - Final note: - As they undock from Prospector’s Rest, Jax surveys the stars—the endless, law-thin frontier. - They’re more wanted and more broke than ever, but they’ve drawn their line. - Closing image: - The Calamity Jane gliding into the black. - Lyra at the viewport, symbiote curled like a shadow at her feet, choosing her own direction for the first time. - Tone: bittersweet, resolute, with a clear Space Western “riding off” feel. If you’d like, next I can turn this plan into the actual story, drafting Chapter 1 at around 1000 words in the chosen style.
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
Good question—and great timing to ask it before drafting. Let’s break this into three parts: 1) How a human might approach this specific prompt. 2) Common LLM tendencies that might hurt this story. 3) A deep dive critique of our current intention/plan: where it smells “LLM-ish” and how to humanize it. We won’t rewrite yet; we’re diagnosing and ideating. 1) How a human might approach this piece Given the prompt “Captain, something's... moving in that crate we picked up” and “Space Western,” a human writer—especially one comfortable with genre—might: - Start smaller: - Focus first on a voice: the captain’s attitude, the ship’s smell, the thickness of station dust. - Write a scene or two just living with the crew before locking in the full plot. - Let the crate’s contents emerge organically from those early pages rather than pre-deciding every beat. - Embrace uncertainty: - They might not immediately know what’s in the crate. - They’d play with multiple ideas and see which one generates the juiciest conflicts in actual prose. - They might allow the story’s direction to change after writing a strong scene that suggests a better path. - Prioritize specific, personal stakes: - Use the crate to expose something about the captain (past guilt, secret compromise). - Let the Space Western trappings sharpen a central emotional conflict (e.g., “What does this man owe to the law he left?”). - Be less symmetrical: - The structure wouldn’t necessarily be 1 clean beat per chapter like clockwork. - Some chapters might run long, some short; they’d respect the 8-chapter brief but flex for rhythm. - They’d allow one or two messy edges or dangling threads because life doesn’t fully resolve. - Be willing to leave bruises: - Possibly kill a character, or at least leave scars that don’t tidy up. - Let the “victory” feel compromised: they win something but lose status, safety, illusions. - Resist neat moral vindication; institutions might remain corrupt and powerful. - Let style serve story, not impressiveness: - They’d likely avoid constant “big moments” and let quiet beats do work. - Use some idiosyncratic turns of phrase, recurring images, or in-jokes among the crew. - Voice and rhythm would evolve with the draft, not from a checklist. That’s the human arc: discovery, imperfection, asymmetry, specific obsessions, and a willingness to let the story get away from the outline if it starts breathing. 2) Telltale LLM approaches (and how they’d hurt this piece) LLMs tend to: - Over-structure: - Clean 8-part arcs with act breaks that line up a bit too perfectly. - Every chapter with a neat mini-climax. - This can feel engineered more than lived-in. - Over-explain: - Spelling out themes, motivations, and worldbuilding instead of trusting subtext. - Characters are prone to say exactly what they feel or what the plot needs. - Play it safe: - Avoid leaving loose ends that might feel “messy.” - Favor morally upright protagonists, villains who are clearly in the wrong, tidy catharsis. - Rarely allow protagonists to make choices that are ugly, petty, or irredeemably selfish unless it’s redeemed by the end. - Aim for “cinematic” at the expense of intimacy: - Lots of dramatic comms, ultimatums, showdowns, explosions. - Less of the small, quiet, specific stuff that makes people feel real: awkward silences, stupid jokes, non-heroic fears. - Flatten character voices: - Everyone talks with similar cadence and clarity. - Quips, exposition, and moral statements sound like they’re from the same brain. - Protect “core concepts”: - Once the AI locks onto “child weapon with corporate pursuer,” it’s hesitant to really hurt or complicate that concept in surprising ways for fear of “breaking” the outline. - It tends toward archetype purity: the child is innocent, the corp is evil, the ex-lawman is honorable. - Tie with a bow: - Big villain defeated or neatly contained. - Law and justice reconciled in some clever loophole. - Epilogue that reassures the reader that things are okay or heading that way. For this Space Western, those tendencies can drain: - Grit, - Moral ambiguity, - The sense of a world that doesn’t care about your arc. 3) Deep dive: critiquing our current intention & plan Let’s interrogate where our plan already drifts toward “LLM-flavored” and brainstorm more human directions. a) The premise: engineered psychic girl + evil corp What works: - Strong emotional engine. - Clear alignment with Space Western themes: frontier vs. corporation, property vs. person. What feels LLM-ish: - “Genetically engineered empath weapon child with symbiote” is a very popular trope cocktail. - HelioDyne as a sleek evil biotech corp; Voss as the cold, legalistic antagonist. - Lyra as mostly innocent, mostly good, mostly scared: risk of “weaponized waif” archetype. More human directions to consider: - Make Lyra less cleanly sympathetic: - She’s not just gentle and traumatized; maybe she’s prickly, manipulative when scared, or disturbingly calm about violence. - She has opinions about ownership, pain, what people “deserve.” - Complicate HelioDyne/Voss: - Give Voss real convictions: maybe Lyra’s powers, if unmanaged, nearly wiped a station before. Maybe the project was a response to an external threat. - Voss might be right about some risks—and still resort to unacceptable methods. - Blur the line between “experiment” and “kid”: - Lyra has been rewarded for compliance; maybe part of her wants to go back because at least there she understands the rules. - That tension is messy and human. b) Character lineup: ex-Marshal captain, tough first mate, scrappy mechanic, cocky pilot, weary medic What works: - Clear, functional roles. - Easy to track in a short story. What feels LLM-ish: - Reads like a standard ensemble loadout. - Arcs are signposted: Mara’s redemption, Rian’s temptation, etc. - Risk: nobody has a truly inconvenient trait that derails plans or introduces genuine unpredictability. More human directions to consider: - Inject pettiness and mismatch: - Give someone a grudge that’s not narratively “useful” (e.g., Rian resents Jax for something dumb and it colors his choices). - Let a character be devout, superstitious, or politically naïve in a way that complicates the group dynamic. - Less schematic backstories: - Jax’s ex-Marshal status is fine, but maybe the inciting trauma is not noble—maybe he quit over cowardice or complicity, not a single clean moral stand. - Mara’s HelioDyne past could include her directly facilitating bad things, not just “cowardly clerk who looked away.” - Make at least one person an actual liability: - Someone freezes in combat, betrays them for reasons that are emotional rather than rational, or clings to law even when it’s clearly wrong. c) Structure: each chapter with a clear function, escalation, and turning point What works: - It’s solid. - Ensures the story covers needed ground within 8k words. What feels LLM-ish: - Every chapter is too mission-statement-y: “Purpose: escalate X, reveal Y.” - Feels like screenwriting beats rather than fiction that breathes. - The midpoints and beats are almost textbook. More human directions to consider: - Allow “wasted” space that’s not plot-efficient but is character-rich: - A chapter that opens on a card game, or a maintenance task, where tensions simmer under small talk. - A quiet moment with Lyra watching a sunrise through a viewport, not advancing plot, but deepening texture. - Mess up the symmetry: - Maybe the big reveal doesn’t happen right at Chapter 3; maybe suspicion lingers longer. - Maybe the confrontation with Voss comes sooner, and we live in the aftermath longer. - Allow failure: - A plan they set up in one chapter simply doesn’t work in the next. - Instead of each chapter moving neatly “forward,” have at least one that leaves them worse and more lost. d) Tone: blend of roguish fun, suspense, moral Western showdown What works: - Good mixture; fits genre. What feels LLM-ish: - The stated tone management is careful and safe. - Hints of ensuring the reader is never too uncomfortable for too long. - The end is already leaning toward “bittersweet but hopeful.” Familiar, tidy. More human directions to consider: - Take one emotional risk: - Kill or severely injure someone the narrative “needs” (e.g., Stitch) to underline stakes. - Let Jax or Mara make a choice that is not fully redeemed (e.g., spacing an innocent guard, lying to Briggs in a way that ruins his life). - Let some threads stay frayed: - Don’t fully resolve HelioDyne’s threat. - Let Briggs’ decision feel like it might ruin him without guarantee it “meant something” in the long run. - Be less deferential to likability: - Allow a main character to speak cruelly, selfishly, or with prejudice and then have to confront that. e) Resolution: Voss confronted, law invoked, Lyra semi-freed, crew rides off What works: - Genre-appropriate: ride into sunset/black. What feels LLM-ish: - Briggs invoking a specific statute to arrest or constrain Voss is suspiciously neat. - Lyra joining the crew as a found-family epilogue is emotionally appealing but very standard. - The sense that everyone’s arcs close in 1–2 pages. More human directions to consider: - Undermine institutional comfort: - If Briggs helps them, he might have to falsify his report, not find a clean legal clause. - His choice might be: betray the law or betray himself; no clever third option. - Complicate Lyra’s fate: - Maybe she doesn’t just neatly “join the crew.” Maybe she’s sent to a place that may or may not be safe, and we end on uncertainty. - Or she does join, but not as a cute mascot—she’s dangerous cargo they’ve chosen to love anyway, and everyone knows it. - Consider leaving one major unease: - Perhaps Lyra did something with her powers in the climax that quietly horrifies Jax—a hint of what she could become. - Don’t answer whether that’s going to be okay. f) Dialogue and interiority (implied from plan) Likely LLM tendencies: - Clean, functional, expository dialogue: - “We must protect her; she is a person, not property.” - Moral clarity spoken aloud instead of embodied in action and subtext. - Underuse of silence, subtext, miscommunication. More human directions: - Let people talk around things: - Jax jokes when he should apologize. - Lyra lies about what she remembers to test their reactions. - Briggs and Jax talk about an unrelated old case instead of directly saying “I’m disappointed in you.” - Let misunderstandings hang: - Rian might misread Lyra and treat her like a threat longer than is fair. - Mara’s “confession” might leave out key details we only sense from her discomfort. g) Worldbuilding Risk: - HelioDyne, Prospector’s Rest, Waystation Calico: solid but generic if not textured with specific cultural, economic, and sensory details. - World might exist only as thin set dressing for the plot. More human directions: - Invent small, throwaway specifics: - An old holosign that never got updated after a mining company collapsed. - A particular cheap drink Jax always buys on stations. - A legend the miners at Prospector’s Rest tell about a ship that never came back. - Show how people live: - The way crew manage oxygen debts, gambling, sending money home, sharing music. - These don’t have to be long scenes, just specific touches. Summary of key “make it more human” levers When we eventually revise the plan and draft, we should aim to: - Roughen the edges: - Loosen the hyper-clean act structure just enough to feel organic. - Add at least one unplanned-feeling complication or failure. - Complicate morality: - Give Lyra, Jax, Mara, Briggs, and Voss all at least one moment where their choices are understandable but not tidy. - Add specific, idiosyncratic detail: - Replace generic tropes with sensory, cultural, and emotional specifics. - Give characters personal tics, weird loyalties, and unglamorous flaws. - Resist the full bow: - Allow some ambiguity in the ending. - Don’t rely on a neat legal fix or pure moral vindication. - Let subtext do work: - Show values through behavior and implication, not speeches. If you’d like, next step we can systematically adjust the existing outline with these principles in mind—still staying within the 8-chapter / ~8k-word constraint, but steering away from those LLM tells.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention Core aim: Tell a tight, character-focused Space Western that feels specific, a bit rough around the edges, and emotionally honest—anchored in the moment someone says, “Captain, something’s… moving in that crate we picked up.” Key choices: - Premise and stakes: - The crate holds a teenage girl, Lyra, engineered as a psionic weapons platform and symbiotically bound to living biotech. - She is legally “property” of HelioDyne, morally a person, and practically dangerous. - The crew of the small freighter Calamity Jane must decide, under pressure, whether to treat her as cargo, bounty, or human. - This is a story about: - What people choose when “the law” and “what’s right” don’t match. - How far working-class nobodies on the frontier will go against a system stacked against them. - Characters (refined to feel less schematic): - Captain Jax Rourke: - Former Federal Marshal, quit not from noble outrage but from moral cowardice: he signed off on a HelioDyne operation he knew was wrong. - Wary, sardonic, practical. Tends to avoid direct moral statements; lets choices speak. - Arc: dragged, against his instinct for self-preservation, into finally not looking away. - First Mate Mara Kade: - Former HelioDyne logistics/security; directly facilitated shipments like Lyra. - Took this job to try to smuggle Lyra out as atonement; everything went sideways. - Arc: from secretive and compromised to someone who owns what she’s done. - Stitch Delgado (mechanic): - Young, overtalking, superstitious. Uses jokes to manage fear. - Soft spot for underdogs; bonds quickly with Lyra but also fears her. - Rian Cole (pilot): - Charming, debt-ridden, addicted to risk. Practical to a fault. - Arc: tempted to sell Lyra out, but his choice won’t be cleanly redeemed. - Dr. Imani Hale: - Underpaid medic with battlefield trauma; has seen biotech atrocities. - Quietly furious at what HelioDyne’s done; advocates for Lyra without sentimentality. - Marshal Briggs: - Jax’s former mentor. Believes in law as a bulwark against chaos. - Put in an impossible bind between orders and conscience. - Aurelia Voss: - HelioDyne retrieval officer. Intelligent, composed, utterly certain. - Not a cackling villain; believes Lyra is too dangerous to be “loose” and that control is justified. - Voice and style: - Tight third-person, leaning mostly on Jax’s POV, with occasional shifts to Mara or Lyra where necessary. - Language: - Clean, readable, image-heavy but not purple. - Western-flavored cadences, dry humor, some slang—varied per character. - Show, don’t sermonize: - Moral positions emerge through choices, not speeches. - Subtext, silences, and side-eye do work; avoid over-explaining. - Structural approach: - Eight chapters of roughly 1000 words: - Each chapter has a clear center (a choice, reveal, or turn), but not a perfectly symmetrical “screenwriting beat grid.” - Allow for a couple of small, “inefficient” moments—quiet character beats that deepen investment. - Constraints embraced: - No sprawling lore. Corporate evil, frontier desperation, and Lyra’s nature sketched with specific details, not infodumps. - One main external threat (HelioDyne + coerced Marshals), one crucial internal tension (crew divided, Mara’s secret). - Thematic and tonal commitments: - Themes: - Frontier justice vs. institutional law. - Personhood vs. property. - The cost, not the convenience, of doing the right thing. - Tone: - Start: rugged, wry, lived-in Space Western. - Middle: claustrophobic tension, mistrust, moral pressure. - End: messy, high-stakes standoff; not a power fantasy, but a costly line in the sand. - Avoid: - Too-tidy legal fixes. - Turning Lyra into a pure innocent or pure monster; she’s a kid who’s been used and can hurt people. - Giving everyone a clean redemption; some scars and compromises will remain. Above all, the piece will stay anchored to the crate: its mystery, its weight, its consequences, and that first moment of “something’s moving” echoing through every decision. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1 – Calico Dust Purpose: - Ground the reader in the world and crew. - Make the crate’s arrival feel like a natural, risky choice. - End on the unsettling movement that kicks it all off. Beats: - Open with Calamity Jane docking at Waystation Calico: a scabbed-together outpost with faded logos, slow-bleeding life support, mining crews, and crooked dockmasters. - Jax haggles for cargo; he’s tired, mildly hungover, counting every credit. He does not want trouble. - Mara secures a sealed HelioDyne crate run: high pay, no scans, strict schedule. She pushes for it harder than seems logical. - Stitch and Rian swap complaints and minor gossip about HelioDyne rumors—people going missing, black labs—half joking, half believing. - Hale spots the biohazard codes; warns Jax this smells like HelioDyne biotech. Jax rationalizes: “We haul it, we don’t open it.” - Load-in: crate is big, reinforced, hums faintly; a bored HelioDyne contractor signs off quickly, hands Mara an extra datachip she pockets quietly. - Departure: they burn away from Calico. Brief, humanizing beats: cramped bunks, cheap instant coffee, trashy holo serial playing in the galley. - End: - Stitch in the cargo bay, alone, hears a muted thump from inside the crate. - He freezes: hears a second, softer sound like fabric dragging. - Calls on comm: “Uh. Captain? Something’s… moving in that crate we picked up.” Chapter 2 – Don’t Look, Don’t Know Purpose: - Build tension around the crate. - Show initial fault lines within the crew. - Hint at human presence without confirming. Beats: - Jax, Mara, Hale join Stitch at the crate. - External scan shows anomalous heat; pressure inside has shifted. - Debate: - Hale: this could be live biotech; we need to know in case it’s contagious. - Mara: contract forbids tampering; penalty clauses are brutal. - Jax: stuck between money, safety, and his Marshal instincts that say “probable cause.” - Jax chooses, for now, not to open it: - Orders environmental monitors, motion sensors, extra restraints. - “We’re six souls and a rustbucket. We’re not a crusade.” - A quiet beat: - Stitch alone again hears faint scraping and—he thinks—a hoarse whisper. He doesn’t repeat that part; it sounds crazy. - External tension: - A system-wide bulletin pings: HelioDyne reports stolen property; Marshal ships to inspect outgoing vessels from Calico. - Rian argues they should dump the crate and run light; Jax refuses to toss a paying job on a “maybe.” - Night-cycle: - Ship creaks, minimal lighting. Jax can’t sleep; stares at old Marshal badge. - Cargo-cam glitch: a flash of something—like fingers—pressing from inside before static. - End: - Hale replays filtered audio from the crate for Jax: under the hum, a rasped, “Help.” - Jax doesn’t answer. That word lands like a weight. Chapter 3 – Breaking Seal Purpose: - Force the choice to open the crate. - Reveal Lyra, but keep some ambiguity about her and the symbiote. - Seed mistrust around Mara. Beats: - Morning-cycle argument in galley: - Stitch says plainly he heard a voice. - Rian: “Voices don’t pay docking fees. HelioDyne does.” - Hale backs Stitch; her readings suggest a human biosign. - Lyra forces the issue: - Sudden violent shudder from the crate. Restraints strain. - A crack splits; viscous, root-like matter seeps, grasping for purchase. - They make a call: - Jax, jaw set, orders it open: “If there’s a person in there, contract be damned.” - Opening: - Inside: Lyra—shaved patches, ports on her skin, IVs, inside a mesh of pale, pulsing biomass. - She flinches from light; the biomass stiffens, defensive. - Hale’s triage: - She disconnects corporate sedation carefully. The living lattice recoils but doesn’t attack when Lyra clings to Hale’s sleeve. - Lyra’s first clarity: - She’s disoriented, terrified. Names “HelioDyne” like a curse. - Knows she was cargo; thought she was being taken away, not back. - Mara’s tell: - When Lyra mentions a promised “out” arranged by someone inside HelioDyne, Mara’s reaction is too sharp. - Jax clocks it; says nothing yet. - External pressure: - Comms: Marshal Briggs’s patrol requesting approach, citing HelioDyne theft. - Jax lies—claims standard cargo, minor engine issue, requests to hold inspection. - End: - In private, Lyra, more lucid, warns Jax: if HelioDyne gets her back, they’ll crack her open and everyone like her. - The lattice twitches along her arm like a frightened animal. Chapter 4 – Fault Lines Purpose: - Deepen character tensions, complicate loyalties. - Show Lyra as both vulnerable and dangerous. - Make Jax’s avoidance untenable. Beats: - Short time jump: Lyra stabilized in medbay; Hale monitoring the symbiote like a coiled snake. - Lyra: - Not purely meek: she tests boundaries, asks sharp questions, notes exits. - Admits she’s been trained to feel minds, to disrupt, to make people stop breathing when ordered. - Symbiote incident: - Rian comes too close, hand on his sidearm; Lyra’s fear spikes. - Tendrils lash out, crack his wrist, shatter equipment. Very fast, very precise. - Lyra horrified, apologizes; Rian now sees her as a loaded gun. - Confessions: - Mara gives Jax a partial truth: - She knew Project Lyric existed. Someone inside asked her to get Lyra out. - The crate was supposed to be part of that extraction; then HelioDyne changed routing, and she grabbed it anyway. - She doesn’t say how many other “assets” she shipped before. - Jax doesn’t absolve her. “You don’t get clean because you finally grew a conscience.” - Briggs escalates: - Private comm with Jax: - Briggs leans on their history; wants to come aboard, check cargo. - Quietly warns: HelioDyne is leaning hard; they say the stolen asset is dangerous. - Jax stalls, guilt pulling both ways. - Lyra’s view: - Short POV slice: she senses Briggs’s ship, HelioDyne’s cold attention, crew’s fear. - Considers turning herself in to spare them; also remembers what “home” is. - End: - Jax orders a risky burn away from Briggs instead of submitting. - That’s the moment he crosses from “avoiding trouble” into “harboring stolen property” knowingly. Chapter 5 – No Clean Choices Purpose: - Lock in consequences. - Put real cracks in the crew. - Strip away any illusion of a safe or clever solution. Beats: - Flight: - The Jane ducks into a debris field. Tough flying; Rian shines, swearing the whole time. - Contact from Voss: - She comes on calm, not cartoon-evil: - Explains Lyra is experimentally unstable. - Claims they prevented a prior incident that nearly killed a station. - Offers legal absolution and a fat payout if they comply. - She calls Lyra “it” without malice, like she’s talking about a reactor core. - Crew reactions: - Rian: “We’re dead if we run. We’re set if we hand her over.” - Mara: shaken; recognizes Voss’s careful half-truths. - Hale: coldly notes Voss never says “alive” when referencing return. - Stitch: openly sides with Lyra, emotional and scared. - Jax’s non-grand speech: - He doesn’t say “We’re heroes.” He says: - “If we give her up knowing what they are, that’s on us forever.” - Admits he’s already done that once in his career, and he’s not sleeping well. - Lyra complicates it: - Confides in Stitch that there is truth in what Voss said: she lost control once; people died. - She’s not sure she should be free either. That doubt is real. - Plan: - Jax sets course for Prospector’s Rest, a fringe station where official reach is thin. - Not a “we’ll solve this there” plan—more a place to make a stand or disappear. - Quiet undercut: - Rian, in a panic, slips a low-power ping with their trajectory, hoping for a deal if it goes bad. - He hates himself even as he does it. - End: - Voss intercepts the ping; alters course. - Briggs receives stronger orders to assist HelioDyne directly. He’s visibly uneasy. Chapter 6 – Prospector’s Rest Purpose: - Compress pressure: place all players, secrets, and choices in one dusty arena. - Build toward confrontation while allowing last human beats. Beats: - Arrival: - Prospector’s Rest: flickering lights, dead docks, a handful of miners and drifters. - Smell of old oil, cheap liquor, recycled air growing thin. - Setup: - Jax and Mara arrange refuel, slip the stationmaster some credits and half-truths. - They quietly prep fallback routes through maintenance shafts. - Lyra among people: - Walks the station in an oversized jacket; people stare. - She senses a low constant hum of weariness and small cruelties; it’s overwhelming but also grounding. - Key conversations: - Jax and Briggs in a narrow corridor: - Briggs has arrived. Tells Jax bluntly: orders are to help HelioDyne. - Jax doesn’t try to charm him; just lets Lyra step into view. - Briggs sees her, sees the ports, the too-adult eyes. Something cracks. - Mara confesses more: - Tells Stitch she signed off on shipments of “units” before. No euphemisms. - He doesn’t forgive her immediately; it lands heavy. - External tightening: - HelioDyne gunship under Voss drops out of FTL, far too armed for this backwater. - Voss announces an “emergency quarantine action” over open comms. - End: - As Voss’s forces prep to board, Lyra admits to Jax: - “I can make them stop. I don’t know what that makes me.” - Jax: “It makes you someone they’re afraid of. That doesn’t mean they get to own you.” - No promise it’ll be okay—just that they’re not handing her over. Chapter 7 – The Stand Purpose: - Deliver the messy showdown. - Force decisive, compromised choices. - Let people act according to their truest selves. Beats: - Voss boards: - HelioDyne security in clean armor moves through rusted halls. - She attempts procedure: cites contracts, warrants, biohazard protocols. - Confrontation in the central concourse: - Jax, Mara, Lyra, some locals, and Briggs form an uneven line. - Rian is there, rattled, clearly guilty about the ping. - Negotiation that fails: - Voss offers on open channel: - Amnesty for crew (except Mara) if they surrender Lyra. - Surgical language: containment, decommissioning. - Lyra, hearing “decommission,” trembles; symbiote rises. - Choices: - Rian blurts out his earlier contact; expects rage. Instead gets a flat “We’ll live with that later” from Jax. No time. - Briggs, sweating, half lifts his badge, half his gun. Realizes there is no lawful way to both protect Lyra and follow orders. - Shootout / power struggle: - It’s quick, grubby, not balletic: - EMP charges flicker some HelioDyne gear. - Locals start shooting more out of hating corp than loving Jax. - Symbiote lashes when Lyra panics; a guard’s gun arm goes limp. - Lyra’s pivotal act: - She feels Voss’s mind: cold resolve, genuine fear of what Lyra could do. - Lyra could crush her. We see the temptation. - Instead she uses her power to scramble Voss’s comms and command net—sabotage, not murder. - Briggs’s break: - He steps in, gun on Voss’s second-in-command, and states: - He’s claiming jurisdiction to halt the operation pending review of HelioDyne’s abuses. - It’s thin, likely won’t stand. He does it anyway. - Outcome: - Voss is injured or disarmed; some of her team down. HelioDyne’s legal veneer cracked in front of witnesses. - But this is no rousing triumph: bodies on the deck, station holed, everyone now on someone’s blacklist. - End: - Silence after the last shot. Lyra shaking, staring at her hands. - Jax doesn’t tell her she did good. He just puts a hand on her shoulder and says, “It’s over for today.” Chapter 8 – What We Carry Purpose: - Show the cost, avoid neatness. - Land on a choice that feels earned, not safe. - Keep echo of the original prompt: the weight of what they picked up. Beats: - Aftermath on Prospector’s Rest: - Dead covered with thermal sheets. Locals arguing about repairs, reprisals. - Rian tending to wounded, trying to make himself useful. - Mara quietly helping Hale with the dead; no absolution, just work. - Briggs: - Files a deliberately incomplete report, omitting Lyra’s location, exaggerating HelioDyne’s overreach. - He knows it’s perjury. Hands Jax his badge—resignation or suspension incoming. - “You didn’t make this easy,” he tells Jax, but there’s a weary respect. - Voss: - Either evacuated, promising this isn’t over, or detained just long enough to buy time. - In either case, HelioDyne as a whole is not “defeated”—only checked. - Lyra’s choice: - Hale outlines options: a hidden colony that might take her, staying here, or going with Jane. - Lyra knows she’s dangerous. Doesn’t trust any promise of safety. - She asks Jax, “Will you throw me out an airlock if I become what they wanted?” - Long pause. Jax answers honestly: “If it comes to that, I won’t let them have you.” - It’s brutal, but truthful; she accepts that more than any soft lie. - Departure: - Lyra decides to go with the Jane for now—under no illusion it’s simple. - Mara openly commits to seeing this through, no more secrets. - Rian apologizes without excuses; Stitch half accepts it. - Final image: - Calamity Jane lifting off from the battered station. - In the cargo bay, the once-ominous crate sits open and empty. - Jax hears phantom echoes of that first thump and that first “Help,” knowing this one choice will haunt and define them. - They ride into the black, not triumphant, but decided. This final plan keeps the story lean and tensioned for 8k words, holds tight to the original prompt’s hook, and leans into human messiness: imperfect choices, unresolved threats, and people trying, in their small, stubborn way, to do better than they did last time.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Captain Jax Rourke Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Background: - Born on a refinery moon where you worked or starved. - Joined Federal Marshals young: loved the idea of being the man with the badge between people and the void. - Career soured as he was ordered to “stand down” on corporate atrocities. The breaking point was signing off on a sealed transfer he knew was human cargo—a HelioDyne contract. He didn’t stop it. That eats him. - Quit without a speech. Just turned in his badge and bought a half-ruined freighter on credit: the Calamity Jane. - Personality: - Dry, self-contained, thinks in costs and risks. - Not inherently noble; he hates bullies and liars, but he also hates losing. - Avoids moral grandstanding. When cornered, he’ll make a moral call, but he’d rather patch a leak than argue philosophy. - Surprisingly patient with incompetence, very impatient with cruelty. - Idiosyncrasies: - Drinks terrible station chicory instead of decent coffee; says it “tastes like consequence.” - Carries his old Marshal badge in a sock drawer, under a spare gun, never admits to checking it. - Hums old trail songs from his moon when tense, under his breath. - Has a habit of running his thumb along scars on the Jane’s bulkhead while talking, like he’s counting them. - Flaws: - Conflict-avoidant until the last possible second; lets problems smolder. - Emotionally constipated: apologizes through acts (fixing something, sharing a drink) rather than words. - When scared, defaults to command tone and stubbornness; can steamroll others. - Deep guilt sometimes comes out sideways as cutting remarks. Physicality: - Mid-40s, rangy, built from years of manual work rather than gym muscle. - Dark hair going silver at the temples; keeps it short because it’s practical. - Eyes a murky green-brown; tired but keen. - Crooked nose, old scar along his jaw from a bar fight or boarding mishap he never tells the same story about. - Moves like a man used to low ceilings and sudden shifts: economical, steady on his feet. - Rarely smiles wide; when he does, it’s slow, half-surprised, and makes him look younger. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Keep his crew alive and paid. - Quietly trying to prove (to himself, mostly) that he’s not the man who signed that transfer. - Avoid the notice of any government or corporate apparatus. - Allegiances: - Outward: to his crew, to the unspoken code of haulers. - Inward: to a worn-out idea of justice he doesn’t talk about. - Relationships: - Mara: values her competence; suspects she’s hiding things. Treats her almost like a co-captain. - Stitch: half-joking, half-protective big brother stance. - Rian: respects his skill, doesn’t trust his judgment. - Hale: listens when she talks; trusts her moral barometer more than he admits. - Briggs: loaded history; sees the man he might have become. - Lyra: sees the ghost of the cargo he failed once; that’s personal. Voice samples: - Dialogue: “If that crate’s just dry goods, I’m the Emperor of Europa. Lock it down and somebody get me the manifest HelioDyne doesn’t want us to read.” - Dialogue: “I don’t like heroes on my ship. Heroes die. We’re gonna try something harder: not being cowards.” - Internal: The law comes knocking and suddenly my teeth hurt. Like they remember how to smile for a badge. --- # Mara Kade Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Background: - Grew up in corporate housing: everything branded, everything logged. - Joined HelioDyne logistics/security; excelled at moving sensitive “materials” without questions. - Gradually realized some “materials” were people. Looked away—promotions, bonuses. - A particular case (connected to Lyra’s project) broke through her compartmentalization. She helped leak data, then ran. - Jax hired her for her competence and contacts; never pressed too hard on the past. - Personality: - Controlled, wry, meticulous. She preps three contingencies and expects two to fail. - Hard on herself; harsher on anyone who endangers the crew. - Can be kind, but it’s often disguised as snapping someone into shape. - Idiosyncrasies: - Keeps precise handwritten lists in a battered notebook, despite having digital systems. - Rolls her shoulders before every docking/undocking, like a soldier before a breach. - Swears quietly in corporate shorthand—strings of protocol numbers—when stressed. - Drinks her liquor in tiny measured sips, never visibly drunk. - Flaws: - Secretive to a fault; withholds info “for everyone’s good” until it blows up. - Self-loathing leads her to make reckless “atonement” plays that risk others. - Distrusts idealism; can crush someone’s hope out of fear it’s naïve. Physicality: - Late 30s, medium height, wiry-muscular. - Brown skin, closely cropped dark hair with a faint corporate tattoo at the base of her skull she hasn’t removed. - Sharp, observant eyes; tends to make unblinking direct eye contact. - Posture efficient, precise; stands like she expects to be audited. - Keeps her gear immaculate: holster oiled, knife sharpened, boots laced. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Make sure Lyra doesn’t go back to HelioDyne; this is her line in the sand. - Keep the crew alive enough to have a chance at some sort of redemption. - Allegiances: - No love for institutions; bitterly anti-corp now. - Loyal to Jax, but on the condition he’s honest about what they’re doing. - Relationships: - Jax: respects him; resents his instinct to avoid decisive lines. They argue like equals. - Stitch: fond tolerance; sees him like a kid brother she wishes she’d been. - Rian: doesn’t trust him with sensitive choices; his fear reads too loud. - Hale: respects her; Hale is one of the few she’ll take moral criticism from. - Lyra: protective, guilty; sees her as the living consequence of her old job. - She knows, dimly, that if Lyra turns monstrous, it will gut her more than anyone. Voice samples: - Dialogue: “If HelioDyne’s paying you this much to not ask questions, the only responsible move is to ask twice.” - Dialogue: “Redemption’s expensive. You don’t buy it with one good deed and a sad story.” - Internal: I built routes like this for years. The only difference now is I actually care what’s in the box. --- # Stitch Delgado Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Background: - Station rat from a decomissioned shipyard; learned to weld before he learned to read well. - Bounced between ships until Jax took him on after he patched a fuel leak with a spoon and prayer. - Personality: - Fast-talking, nervous humor. Fears silence—it lets his brain list every way things can go wrong. - Sentimental; hoards small worthless objects with stories. - Surprisingly brave when someone else is scared; folds when he’s alone. - Idiosyncrasies: - Names pieces of machinery (“Come on, Nadine,” to an oxygen pump). - Collects stickers and patches; slaps them on his toolbox, makes a collage of their travels. - Eats terrible dehydrated candy; leaves wrappers in his pockets until Mara glares. - Flaws: - Prone to blurt secrets when stressed. - Overpromises what he can fix on the fly; occasionally creates bigger problems. - Needs reassurance more than he admits. Physicality: - Early 20s, lean, restless. - Warm-brown skin, curly black hair usually pulled back with whatever’s at hand. - Ink-stained fingers, perpetually smudged with grease. - Constant fidgeter: spins tools, taps boots, chews on cable ties. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Keep this found family together; this ship is the only home that’s stuck. - Prove he’s indispensable and not just “the kid.” - Allegiances: - Fiercely loyal to Jax and Mara; would side with them over money. - Immediate soft spot for Lyra: recognizes another lab-rat-adjacent kid, even if her cage was fancier. - Relationships: - Jax: hero figure; any disapproval from him hits like a punch. - Mara: scary big sister who makes him better at his job. - Rian: older cool cousin; likes him, doesn’t rely on him. - Hale: “Doc” who yells at him to hydrate. - Lyra: he becomes her one-man welcoming committee; it terrifies and thrills him. - His fear of Lyra is real but doesn’t override his instinct to be kind. Voice samples: - Dialogue: “I’m just saying, crates don’t usually say ‘help’ unless we’re in a horror vid. And I hate horror vids.” - Dialogue: “If the corporation wanted it safe, they shouldn’t’ve put it on a ship held together by my good intentions.” - Internal: Don’t open it. Unless it’s a person. If it’s a person and we don’t open it, that’s on us. Shit. --- # Rian Cole Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Background: - Born on a luxury liner, actually—parents were staff. Learned to fly shuttles between rich habitats. - Got into illegal racing, gambling; debts piled up. - Ended up on the Jane because other captains wouldn’t touch him. - Personality: - Charming, flippant, likes danger when it’s abstract. - Values survival and a good exit more than ideals. - Hates being scared, so he masks it with swagger and jokes sharper than Stitch’s. - Idiosyncrasies: - Keeps a holopic of a racing ship he wrecked; calls it his “guardian idiot.” - Never straps in properly; says he needs “freedom of movement.” - Has elaborate pre-jump rituals: taps dashboard three times, mutters a nonsense mantra. - Flaws: - Cowardly in subtle, human ways: selling others out in hopes of mitigating fallout. - Rationalizes selfish choices as “logic.” - Envious of Jax’s moral gravity, but too defensive to admit it. Physicality: - Early 30s, lean, wiry, with pilot’s hands: deft, calloused. - Dark blond hair he styles like he’s still in a racing league. - Always in a half-zipped flight jacket, boots propped on consoles till Mara smacks them down. - Moves with relaxed cockiness, but his eyes dart when stressed. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Get out of debt and out of anyone’s crosshairs. - Stay alive without ending up as company property. - Allegiances: - To himself first. - To the crew second—he does care, but survival instinct cuts deep. - Relationships: - Jax: grudging respect; resents being judged. - Mara: she sees through him; it unnerves him. - Stitch: actually likes the kid; teaches him some bad habits. - Hale: she intimidates him; she sees his tells. - Lyra: scares him; sees her as a grenade with feelings. - His traitorous ping is a moment of weakness, not cartoon betrayal. He will carry it. Voice samples: - Dialogue: “Look, if the nice lady with the gunship wants her toy back, maybe we don’t volunteer to die about it?” - Dialogue: “You want a moral stand, Captain, paint it on the hull. Just don’t ask me to get spaced for free.” - Internal: They’ll all say they never would’ve cut a deal. Easy thing to swear when you haven’t heard the price. --- # Dr. Imani Hale Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Background: - Served as medic on a border war hospital ship; saw biotech weapons chew people into statistics. - Tried private clinics; couldn’t stomach turning away those who couldn’t pay. - Ended up on haulers where the ethics are simple: patch whoever’s bleeding. - Personality: - Calm, unsentimental, quietly compassionate. - Dark sense of humor; measured speech. - Believes in triage ethics applied to life: you can’t fix everything, so choose what matters and don’t flinch. - Idiosyncrasies: - Keeps a tiny, well-tended herb plant in the medbay; calls it “Nurse.” - Records audio notes instead of written ones; mutters diagnostics like prayers. - Has a stash of contraband real liquor “for sterilization” that somehow never runs out. - Flaws: - Blunt to the point of wounding. - Can write people off as “lost causes” faster than idealists are comfortable with. - Holds grudges quietly and for a long time. Physicality: - Early 50s, compact, solid. - Dark skin, close-cropped salt-and-pepper hair. - Slight limp from an old shrapnel injury. - Hands steady; gaze assessing, can make someone shut up with one look. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Minimize suffering. That’s the closest thing she has to a religion. - Prevent another Lyra from happening if she can. - Allegiances: - To patients first. Institutions barely rank. - Relationships: - Jax: uses him as a barometer: if he’s hesitating, she pushes. - Mara: respects her more after the truth comes out, oddly enough. - Stitch: fusses over his health; sees his heart, worries it’ll get him killed. - Rian: calls him on his bullshit with surgical precision. - Lyra: treats her as a patient and a person, neither saint nor monster. Voice samples: - Dialogue: “Corporate biohazard labels are like ‘wet floor’ signs. If they bothered to warn you, it’s already too late.” - Dialogue: “You don’t need a priest, Captain. You need to stop doing things you’d confess.” - Internal: Child weapon platforms. We give atrocities such neat, professional names. --- # Marshal Elias Briggs Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Background: - Lifelong Marshal; frontier postings, long hauls, slow work. - Believes in the idea of law as the only thing that keeps stations from becoming slaughterhouses. - Trained Jax; saw promise in him. - Personality: - Steady, formal, with a dry, worn-out patience. - Not naive about corruption, but tends to think rot is local; the core can be saved. - Hates being forced into rushed decisions. - Idiosyncrasies: - Polishes his badge when thinking. - Collects small rocks or metal scraps from each posting; carries one in his pocket. - Drinks tea like it’s a ritual. - Flaws: - Too slow to accept systemic corruption; clings to procedure. - Can be moralistic and paternalistic; underestimates how trapped others are. - When cornered, his instinct is still to follow the chain of command. Physicality: - Late 50s, thick through the middle, strong. - Gray hair, cropped; weathered face with creases from squinting at scanners. - Straight-backed in uniform; authoritative without trying. - Movements deliberate; doesn’t waste breath or steps. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Keep order. Prevent chaos he’s seen when law collapses. - Save Jax from what he sees as a slide into outlawry. - Allegiances: - To the Marshal Service and its ideals—strained. - Relationships: - Jax: like a stubborn son who left home angry. - Voss/HelioDyne: uneasy allies; he doesn’t like being their muscle. - Lyra: seeing her cracks something; forces him to admit the law is sheltering evil here. Voice samples: - Dialogue: “Son, if you run from me, I have to chase. Don’t make old men do more work than they need to.” - Dialogue: “I’ve seen what happens when everyone decides they’re their own law.
