It’s not justice; it’s just knives.” - Internal: If this is lawful, then I’ve been pointing this badge the wrong way a long time. --- # Aurelia Voss Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Background: - Fast-tracked through HelioDyne’s executive/security programs. - Intimately involved in “asset retrieval” and “risk management.” - Genuinely believes her work prevents greater catastrophes in a dangerous galaxy. - Personality: - Precise, icy, professional. Speaks in careful, non-inflammatory terms. - Sees herself as rational, ethical inside her framework. - Has empathy, but it’s strategic, rarely allowed to overrule objectives. - Idiosyncrasies: - Adjusts her cuffs when irritated, the only visible tell. - Never raises her voice; makes others feel childish if they do. - Refers to horrific things in sterile language, partly as armor. - Flaws: - Arrogant in her certainty; assumes others are emotional, she is not. - Dehumanizes Lyra as a way to function; can’t afford to see her as a child. - Underestimates “small” people: haulers, stationers, Marshals with a conscience. Physicality: - Late 30s, willowy, immaculate. - Pale or olive skin (we can decide in-text), smooth dark hair pinned back. - Wears subtle, high-grade body armor under tailored uniform. - Holds herself like a boardroom at all times, even in a firefight. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Retrieve Lyra; not just for bonus, but because she believes Lyra loose is a strategic catastrophe. - Maintain HelioDyne’s legal and political shield. - Allegiances: - HelioDyne first. - Her own sense of being the adult in a room of hysterics. - Relationships: - Jax: sees him as a predictable “fallen lawman” archetype; an obstacle, not an enemy. - Briggs: mildly respects him; leverages his duty against him. - Lyra: sees her as valuable tech gone feral, not a person; any flicker of doubt is suppressed. Voice samples: - Dialogue: “Captain Rourke, you’re hauling a volatile asset you cannot possibly understand. Let the adults handle it.” - Dialogue: “Marshal Briggs, failure to assist in retrieval makes you complicit. I don’t think that’s how you want your record to read.” - Internal: If they’d seen what she did to Outpost Twelve, they’d thank me for putting her back in a box. --- # Lyra Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Background: - Lab-grown and raised within HelioDyne facilities as “Lyric-3,” later “Lyra” as a training reward. - Subjected to empathetic conditioning, psionic amplification, symbiote bonding. - Was promised “graduation” if she performed well; that meant full deployment. - An internal dissenter (possibly Mara’s contact) arranged her transfer to be hijacked. - Personality: - Alert, observant; reads microexpressions without trying. - Mix of childlike and chillingly adult: can quote procedure numbers and also hoard small toys. - Testing: pushes people to see if kindness is real or tactical. - Idiosyncrasies: - Taps two fingers against her thigh when overwhelmed, matching her heartbeat. - Hums tunelessly to calm the symbiote, like singing to a skittish animal. - Stares out viewports for long stretches; space is new and huge to her. - Flaws: - Unstable control: fear or anger can cause involuntary psionic/symbiote surges. - Has internalized some HelioDyne logic: occasionally talks about herself as a thing. - Can be manipulative in small ways—testing loyalties, pushing guilt buttons. - Carries real capacity for violence; part of her thinks some people deserve it. Physicality: - About 14. - Thin, under-muscled, with the look of someone who grew in a lab more than on a playground. - Shaved patches with faint scars and ports; dark, close-cropped hair where it’s grown. - Pale or sallow from artificial lighting; eyes too intense for her age. - Symbiote: - Lattice of pale, vein-like material along one arm/side; can flex, harden, extend. - When calm, lies flat; when threatened, rises like hackles. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Not to go back. That’s the clearest one. - Figure out if she’s allowed to exist as more than a weapon. - Avoid hurting people she chooses not to hurt. - Allegiances: - To anyone who treats her like a person, but it’s conditional and fragile. - Relationships: - Jax: confusing; he feels guilty around her, doesn’t pretend well. She senses it. - Mara: complicated mirror; Lyra knows she signed the forms. - Stitch: easiest to trust; his fear is honest, his kindness clumsy but real. - Rian: she senses his temptation to sell her out; doesn’t forget. - Hale: respects her blunt truthfulness; Hale never lies about the danger. - Voss: a cold sun in her memory; emblem of the cage. - She worries—earnestly—that the safest thing for everyone is her death. That’s not melodrama to her. Voice samples: - Dialogue: “If you hand me back, they’ll thank you. They’ll write it in your files. ‘Cooperative. Responsible.’ You’ll sleep. For a while.” - Dialogue: “They taught me where to press to make a heart forget how to beat. I don’t want to use that. Don’t make me.” - Internal: They keep saying ‘we’ll protect you’ like a spell. In the labs, promises were the softest scalpel. If you’d like, next we can map how these character traits surface in key moments of each chapter, so they feel lived-in rather than described once and forgotten.

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Waystation Calico looked like it had been built drunk and maintained out of spite. Rust-brown girders crisscrossed under a skin of patched plating, corporate logos half-sanded off where leases had changed hands. Docking booms stuck out at ugly angles, as if the station were caught mid-explosion and never finished the job. Out beyond, the starfield lay flat and cold. The Calamity Jane slid in slow, thrusters spitting pale fire. Jax Rourke watched the approach on the forward screen, one boot braced on the console, coffee bulb hovering by his elbow. His eyes tracked the flicker of misaligned beacons, the numbers crawling green along the top of the display. “Port array’s two degrees off,” Rian said from the pilot’s chair. “Guarantee you they haven’t recalibrated since the last quake.” “That or someone stole the sensor suite,” Jax said. “Keep her gentle. I don’t want to explain a scrape to the dockmaster.” “Relax, Captain. I’ve kissed uglier ports.” “Yeah? Station too, or just people?” Jax took a swallow of lukewarm chicory. Bitter as sin. “Put us on three.” Rian muttered something profane but obeyed, easing the Jane into alignment. The freighter was all straight lines and stubborn welds, a long box with engines bolted on like an afterthought. She’d never be pretty, but she flew. Mag-clamps thudded through the hull. The console chimed acceptance. Docking successful: Waystation Calico, Berth 3. “Home sweet liability,” Stitch’s voice crackled over comms. “Pressure lock stable. No leaks yet. I’m writing it down; it’s a miracle.” “Write down you’re doing the hose checks,” Jax said. “Mara, you with me for the dance?” “Already at the hatch,” came Mara’s reply. Clipped, efficient. Jax set his bulb aside and scrubbed a hand over his jaw. Stubble rasped against his palm. Another job. Another station that smelled like recycled sweat and cheap antifungal. Get in, fill the hold, get out before someone asked for papers he didn’t want to show. He palmed the hatch and stepped into the umbilical. Calico’s air hit him like a damp towel: metallic, sour, faint undertone of fried protein. Lights flickered on a half-second delay. He walked with the low-grav lope of someone used to ships more than stations, boots clanking on grates. Dockmaster’s kiosk was a cramped glass box with a man inside who looked like he’d been pickled. “Calamity Jane,” the man said, squinting at his slate. “Behind on fees.” “Paid last stop at Ruston,” Jax said. “Check again.” Mara was there already, lean and straight-backed, a slate tucked under one arm. Her hair was cut close, the faint helix of an old corporate ID tattoo just visible at her nape. She slid a datachip across the counter before the dockmaster could grumble. “He means he was going to pay as soon as you remembered what a calendar is,” she said. “Here’s docking, waste, and your bribe. Any priority cargo looking for fast hands?” The dockmaster’s eyes sharpened at “bribe.” He slotted her chip, numbers flicked, his expression thawed. “Berth nine, HelioDyne rep’s been crying for lift since yesterday,” he said. “No scans, high pay, biohazard tags, all very hush. Sound like your kind of mess.” “Maybe,” Jax said carefully. Mara didn’t look at him, just gave the dockmaster a small smile. “We’ll take a walk.” They moved away from the kiosk into the slow eddy of station traffic. Miners in stained coveralls, two station security with stun batons, a cluster of kids chasing a rolling can. Screens on the wall blinked news from core worlds no one here would ever see. “Biohazard,” Jax said under his breath. Mara tilted her head. “Hazard’s where the money lives.” “Could be a bug. Could be some bastard’s pet war toy. Could be HelioDyne trash they don’t want questioned.” “They’re paying triple the usual rate for a straight run to Prospector’s Rest,” she said. “No inspection, sealed manifest. We need the fuel, Jax.” He did the math. Fuel, food blocks, parts. The Jane’s left aft thruster had been coughing on startup. The last job had barely covered interest. “Triple,” he said. “Triple,” Mara confirmed. “And a bonus for on-time delivery.” Jax’s jaw flexed. HelioDyne. He felt the ghost-weight of metal in his pocket: an old Marshal badge he hadn’t quite managed to throw away. “No scans?” he said. “That’s their stipulation. Ours is we don’t open it.” Mara met his eyes. “We’ve hauled worse.” That was true. They’d moved crates that rattled, hissed, leaked. They’d never asked too hard. “All right,” he said. “Let’s see the rep.” The HelioDyne man in Berth 9 was all smooth, forgettable edges. Slate-gray suit stamped with the spiral logo; neat hair; impatient fingers. Behind him, on a grav sled, sat the crate. It was big enough to hold a compact rover. Matte black, corner brackets reinforced, hazard sigils in sharp red: BIOLOGICAL RISK, AUTHORIZED PERSONNEL ONLY. Serial and legalese scrawled along the side. “You Rourke?” the rep said. “Captain of the Jane,” Jax said. “What’s the haul?” “Priority HelioDyne property to Prospector’s Rest. Sealed container, non-invasive transport only. No scans, no tampering.” The rep recited it like reading from a screen. “Payment upon confirmed delivery, amount pre-authorized.” “Manifest?” Jax said. The rep flicked him a file. Mara’s slate pinged; she read faster than Jax did. “Itemized as research equipment and bio-stabilization matrices,” she said. “All lawful under corporate charter.” “Any danger to my ship?” Jax asked. “None, provided you adhere to the handling protocols,” the rep said. “Do you accept?” Mara’s elbow brushed Jax’s, a small pressure. Triple, her body said. Jax glanced at the crate. Up close, the surface hummed faintly. Could be the grav clamps on the sled. He thought of the Jane’s coughing thruster, Stitch’s patchwork repairs, Hale’s dwindling stock, Rian’s muttered complaints. He thought of a different crate, years back, that he’d signed over in a similar dock. He had never seen what was inside that one. He had never asked. “We accept,” he said. The rep’s relief cracked his bland mask for a second. “Excellent. File signed. It is critical that the container remain sealed. Any deviation will void your payment and incur penalties.” “Yeah,” Jax said. “We’ve read contracts before.” Loading it was grunt work. Stitch guided the sled, muttering to the crate like it might behave better if it felt included. Jax watched Hale eye the hazard markings, her mouth a thin line. “HelioDyne,” she said. “That’s who’s under the label now?” “Pays in advance,” Jax said. “Mostly.” She snorted. “There’s a specific timbre to this kind of bad idea.” In the cargo bay, they set the crate down centerline. Mara anchored it with maglocks. Stitch ran extra tie-downs like he didn’t trust the locks. Jax stood with his hands on his hips. Up close, that hum under the skin felt stronger, a vibration he could almost hear. “Captain?” Stitch said. “You feel that?” “It’s powered,” Mara said. “Temperature control, probably. They don’t want their toys thawing.” “Seal it,” Jax said. “Stitch, rig external temp and pressure monitors. Hale, if anything spikes weird, you tell me.” “And if something growls?” Stitch offered. “Then we renegotiate,” Jax said. They lifted from Calico two hours later. Rian took them out with a bit more flourish than necessary, peeling away from the station’s gravity well and into cold open. The Jane settled into her burn toward Prospector’s Rest, engines a low steady thrum. Jax did the rounds—checked readouts, listened to Hale’s report (all boring), accepted a mug of something almost like coffee from Stitch. By shipnight, the lights dipped to a softer blue. Rian had gone to his bunk with a cheap holo game. Mara was at the small table in the galley, scribbling in her notebook. Hale inventoried med supplies. Jax found himself in the cargo bay one more time, alone with the crate. He watched the monitors: internal temperature steady, pressure steady, no motion alerts logged. Just a 2.1 hertz hum, background systems. He stood there longer than he needed to, thumb rubbing at the scar along his jaw. “Just a job,” he told the crate. It didn’t answer. He left. An hour later, Stitch’s voice cracked through the overhead speakers, thin with something he didn’t bother hiding. “Uh. Captain?” Jax sat up in his bunk, heart giving one solid kick. “Cargo bay,” Stitch said. “Something’s… moving in that crate we picked up.”
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully establishes the Space Western setting and tone while adhering closely to both the writing prompt and the planned beats. The opening effectively grounds readers in a lived-in universe through concrete details like Waystation Calico's "rust-brown girders" and "corporate logos half-sanded off," creating that quintessential frontier outpost atmosphere. The character work is particularly strong. Jax emerges as a complex protagonist - his internal conflict about his Marshal past adds depth without being overwrought. The brief glimpses of other crew members feel authentic and distinct: Rian's casual competence and mild insubordination, Mara's calculated efficiency, Stitch's nervous energy. Each character speaks with a believable voice that matches their established profiles. The dialogue maintains an appropriate Western cadence without feeling forced ("kissed uglier ports," "Home sweet liability"). The conversations feel natural while advancing plot and revealing character. The negotiation scene with the HelioDyne representative efficiently establishes stakes and tension. The pacing builds effectively from routine docking procedures to the mounting unease around the mysterious crate. The author resists the urge to oversell the mystery, letting details like the faint humming and hazard warnings speak for themselves. The final revelation delivers the exact prompt line naturally rather than feeling contrived. The prose style is clean and functional, avoiding purple flourishes while maintaining atmospheric detail. Descriptions like the station's air hitting "like a damp towel: metallic, sour, faint undertone of fried protein" efficiently establish mood and place. Minor weaknesses include some predictable beats (the mysterious corporate cargo is a familiar setup) and the chapter functioning more as setup than story in itself. However, the execution is professional and the foundation solid for what follows. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 19

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
By the time Jax hit the cargo bay ladder, Stitch was halfway up it, nearly colliding with him. “Whoa,” Jax said, catching his shoulder. “Breathe.” “I am breathing,” Stitch said, which was not technically true. His eyes were wide. “It’s— it’s moving.” “Back down,” Jax ordered. “Show me.” Stitch hesitated, then turned and clattered down the rungs, Jax close behind. The cargo bay light strips were at night-cycle dim, pale across the stacked containers. The HelioDyne crate sat hunched under its tie-downs, matte black, perfect edges. Nothing obviously out of place. “There,” Stitch whispered. A dull thump sounded from inside. Not structural creak. Not engine resonance. A single, heavy knock, like something testing its walls. Jax felt it in his toes more than his ears. “Could be internal stabilization,” Mara said from behind him. She was barefoot, braid snapped loose over one shoulder, sleep still in her eyes but her voice steady. She must have come in by the side hatch; Hale was with her, pulling on a med jacket, hair pinned back in a crooked hurry. “Or it’s a thing,” Stitch muttered. Jax stepped closer. The crate’s hazard sigils glared back: BIOLOGICAL RISK. DO NOT OPEN. PENALTIES APPLY. He laid his hand flat on the metal. It thrummed, a subtle vibration. Humming machinery, maybe. Then, under his palm, the faintest drag, as if something inside had brushed the wall. His stomach went cold. “Step back,” Hale said quietly. He did. She passed a handheld scanner over the crate. Numbers rolled in sickly green. She frowned, adjusted settings, passed it again. “Talk to me,” Jax said. “Temperature holding slightly above ambient,” Hale said. “Pressure variance… minimal. But that biosign—” “Biosign.” Stitch echoed. “As in life. As in alive.” “—is human.” Hale finished. “Approximately. Humanoid. That’s a pulse. Sluggish, sedated, but there.” As if on cue, something inside scraped softly along the wall. Fingernails on metal, or a tool. It made Jax’s teeth hurt. Rian’s voice buzzed over comms, thick with sleep. “We all enjoying the midnight concert?” “Stay in the cockpit,” Jax said. “Keep us on course.” “To where?” Rian asked. “We haven’t even—” “Prospector’s Rest,” Mara cut in. “As planned.” A second thump. The crate shifted a millimeter against its restraints. “Shit,” Stitch said. “Crates don’t just do that. Captain—” “Everyone shut it,” Jax said, too sharply. They fell silent. He stared at the hazard label. No scans. No tampering. No questions. “We are not equipped for live biotech containment,” Hale said. “If that’s infected, parasitic, unstable—” “HelioDyne,” Jax said. His voice came out flatter than he intended. “Exactly,” Hale said. “I have seen their work. They don’t label things biohazard to be cute.” Mara’s arms were crossed tight. “The contract is explicit. We open this, we get nothing. Worse, we get sued until this ship’s hull is corporate property.” “We might have a person in that box,” Stitch said. “Lawsuit’s kind of a side quest then, don’t you think?” The crate shuddered again, harder. One of the maglocks creaked. A hairline seam shone brighter as if strained. Jax’s impulse was simple and old: you hear someone in a box, you get them out. But that was Marshal thinking. Marshal thinking had gotten him burned. He dragged his gaze to Hale. “Odds it’s just some lab animal?” “Pattern looks human,” Hale said. “And if it’s not, it’s damn close.” “Could be a conscript,” Mara said. “Could be a volunteer. Could be a prisoner. It is not our jurisdiction to decide.” “You hear yourself?” Stitch snapped. “Jurisdiction?” Mara’s eyes flashed. “I’m hearing liabilities. You don’t want to end up on HelioDyne’s blacklist. They own half the rigs between here and—” The overhead pinged. Incoming transmission, long-range. Jax stabbed the acknowledgment. A flat, automated voice flooded the bay. “Notice: Federal Marshal Service inspection sweep in effect for all vessels departing Waystation Calico in the last twenty-four hours. Be advised: stolen corporate assets reported. Compliance with boarding requests is mandatory.” Rian whistled over comms. “That’s us.” Hale looked up at the speaker, then at Jax. “That timing is not a coincidence.” Mara’s jaw clenched. “HelioDyne’s pulling the Marshals’ leash. Great.” The message repeated, then cut. “So.” Stitch rubbed his hands on his coveralls. “We’ve got a maybe-person in a don’t-open box, plus Marshals coming to open all our boxes.” “Not yet,” Rian said. “They’re still a few hours out if they started at broadcast. We’ve got time to… I don’t know. Freak out constructively.” The crate gave a small, almost petulant bump. Jax took a breath. “All right. Here’s what we do. We are not opening it. Yet.” Stitch stared. “Yet?” “‘Yet’ means we watch,” Jax said. “External monitors. Vitals. If anything spikes bad, if there’s any sign that whatever’s in there is dying or breaking out, then we talk about cutting seals. Until then, that contract stands. We dump this crate in a Marshal’s lap, we at least aren’t the ones smuggling stolen goods.” “Captain,” Hale said. “If there is a conscious human in there, waiting for your permission to breathe, every minute counts.” “And if there’s a corporate black-ops bug in there designed to liquefy us from the inside,” Rian put in, “maybe we don’t just crack it like a party keg.” “Thank you for that image,” Stitch muttered. Mara nodded tightly. “This is the least bad choice. Follow protocol until we know more.” Jax heard the corporate cadence in that word—protocol. It scraped. He stepped closer again, not touching this time. “If you’re in there,” he said quietly, “we’re watching. Hang on.” There was no answer. He didn’t really expect one. He forced himself to turn away. “Stitch, hook up motion and audio to feed into the bridge,” Jax said. “Hale, keep that scanner running on a loop. Mara, run the contract again; find the fine print they don’t want us to see. Rian, plot us a slight detour around known Marshal sweep routes. Nothing obvious.” “On it,” Rian said. They scattered to tasks. The bay dimmed, leaving the crate sitting like an accusation. Two hours later, Jax sat in the Jane’s cockpit, elbows on his knees, watching four small windows on his display: crate temperature, crate pressure, biosign trace, motion. “All quiet,” Rian said. He’d kicked his boots up despite prior warnings. “Maybe it just… settled. Mechanical. Nothing.” “Crates don’t ask for help,” Hale’s voice came from behind them. She stood in the hatch, tablet in hand. The light from the screens sharpened the hollows under her eyes. Jax blinked. “We didn’t hear—” “You didn’t,” Hale said. She tapped her screen. “Stitch’s audio feed. He was right to log it. Listen.” She hit play. Static. The low hum. A faint scrape. Then, warped by the metal, almost lost in the noise, a single syllable: “Help.” It wasn’t much. Could have been interference, imagination. Except they all heard the shape of it. Rian swung his boots down. “Nope.” “Run it again,” Jax said. She did. “Help.” No mistaking it now. Mara appeared in the doorway, drawn by the repetition. Her face closed down as she listened. “Could be an echo,” she said, but her voice was too tight. Jax stared at the audio trace, the little spike where the word sat. Behind his ribs, something old and bitter moved. “Any change since then?” he asked. “Biosigns fluctuated up,” Hale said. “Whoever—or whatever—it is, their heart rate bumped. Then sedative levels climbed. Automated drip.” “So it woke up,” Stitch said from the hatch, leaning in, “said ‘help,’ and the box put it back to sleep.” “Standard containment,” Mara said automatically. Then she caught herself. “HelioDyne standard containment,” Hale said. “Close enough.” The comm pinged softly: another broad-beam from the Marshals’ sweep, closer now. Jax muted it without opening. Rian glanced at him. “You gonna invite them over for tea, Captain? Let them crack the mystery box? We hand over the crate, say ‘whoops, didn’t peek,’ walk away?” “That’s one option,” Jax said. “There another?” Stitch asked. “Not one I like better yet,” Jax said. Silence stretched. The ship’s engines thrummed. On the screen, the crate’s vitals pulsed in slow, sedated rhythm. A thin tremor ran through the Jane, a flicker of the lights. “Power dip?” Jax snapped. “Just a hiccup,” Stich said quickly. “I’ll check the junction.” Hale frowned. “Or our guest is making noise in ways we can’t hear.” “Enough,” Jax said. He stepped away from the displays, paced once in the cramped cockpit. He felt Mara watching him. She knew his tells. She’d seen him avoid decisions before. “I’m not opening it. Not yet,” he said. “We don’t know what’s in there. We throw it open, we own everything that comes out. The law, the liability, the lives.” “And if we don’t?” Stitch said quietly. He didn’t answer. He dropped back into his seat, fixer’s instinct snarling with something knottier. On his screen, a small alert blinked amber: a Federal Marshal patrol had adjusted course. Intercept vector triangulating. In the cargo bay, cameras watched the crate. For a long time, nothing moved. Then, as Jax stared, a shadow passed under the inner surface. A pressure from within, warping the matte skin just enough to show fingers. Five shapes pressing out, trailing a smear of something slick, before slipping away. The motion sensor pinged. No one spoke. Jax exhaled, slow. “Okay,” he said. “Put a pin in ‘not yet.’”
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively builds tension around the mysterious crate while revealing character dynamics and advancing the plot. The writing follows the established plan well, hitting most of the intended beats while maintaining good pacing and escalation. The chapter succeeds in creating an atmosphere of mounting dread through careful sensory details - the "dull thump," the vibration under Jax's palm, and especially the climactic image of fingers pressing against the inner surface. These moments feel genuinely unsettling rather than melodramatic. Character voices remain distinct and consistent with their established profiles. Jax's conflict between his former Marshal instincts and current practical concerns comes through clearly, particularly in his reluctance to make a decisive choice. Mara's corporate background emerges naturally through her language about "protocol" and liability concerns. Stitch's nervous energy and moral clarity provide good contrast to the adults' complications. The dialogue generally flows naturally, with characters speaking in ways that feel authentic to their backgrounds and personalities. Lines like "Lawsuit's kind of a side quest then, don't you think?" capture Stitch's voice well, while Mara's "It is not our jurisdiction to decide" reveals her ingrained corporate thinking. The chapter effectively uses the confined space of the ship to create claustrophobia and force character interactions. The technical details about biosigns and scanners feel grounded without becoming exposition-heavy. However, the setup is fairly familiar within the space western/sci-fi genre - the mysterious cargo, the corporate antagonist, the crew divided between pragmatism and conscience. While well-executed, it doesn't break particularly new ground. The moral stakes, while clear, hit expected beats rather than surprising ones. The ending with the handprint image is effective and appropriately unsettling, providing a strong hook while maintaining ambiguity about what exactly they're dealing with. The integration of the Marshal threat adds external pressure that complements the internal debate about the crate. The prose is clean and functional, avoiding both purple excess and clinical dryness. The pacing allows tension to build naturally without rushing to revelations. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The third time the fingers pushed at the crate wall, Jax was already halfway to the cargo bay. He didn’t bother with the ladder this time; he took the short drop, boots slamming onto the deck. The crate sat where they’d left it, tie-downs taut, hazard sigils screaming. On the nearest monitor, the biosign trace had climbed from sedated crawl to something nearer waking. The low hum of internal systems had a nervous edge. Mara was there, jaw tight, scanner in hand. Hale stood on the opposite side, watching numbers. Stitch hovered by a structural rib, spanner clutched like a weapon he knew was useless. “It’s getting more active,” Hale said. “Sedative drip just maxed itself without command from outside.” “HelioDyne doesn’t want their property chatting,” Stitch said. “Shock.” Jax stepped up to the crate. “You in there,” he said, voice flat. “Can you hear me?” Silence. Then a scraping, slower now, like someone turning their head against a pillow. “Heart rate spiking,” Hale said. “If we leave it, they’ll either overdose or break through.” Mara’s fingers drummed against her folded arms. “We aren’t equipped for a breach. We crack it, we void contract, we invite lawsuits and possibly death.” “Marshals will be on us inside of an hour,” Rian said over comms. “Their vector’s locked. Can’t dodge without looking guilty.” “We are guilty,” Stitch said. “We took the job.” “We’re guilty of shipping a box,” Mara snapped. “We don’t have to be guilty of theft.” “Cut the philosophy,” Jax said. The words surprised him with their harshness. His pulse was up. He could feel something pressing under his teeth, the urge to kick this decision farther down the road. Old habit. Hale didn’t give him space. “Captain. Human biosign, respiratory distress climbing. If this were a crew member, I’d have already cut them out.” “That’s not—” Mara started. Jax turned on her. “You brought this job.” Her eyes flashed. “You agreed.” “Because we’re broke,” Rian chimed in. “In case that slipped anyone’s mind.” The crate shuddered, harder. A seam along the side bulged outward a fraction, metal protesting. “Enough,” Hale said. “Standing here arguing while someone suffocates is a choice. I won’t watch it.” She reached for her medcutter. Jax grabbed her wrist. Not hard—just enough. Her gaze met his, cold as medbay steel. “You’re going to stop me?” she asked. He let go. The comm pinged: priority channel. The Marshal crest flashed on a side screen. “Rourke,” came Briggs’s voice, rough, familiar. “This is Patrol Cutter Nine. We’re on a sweep. Got flagged traffic from your departure station. Request permission to board for inspection. Standard protocols.” There it was. His past, asking politely. Mara looked between Jax and the speaker. “If we open it now—” “—you can tell him you didn’t know,” Stitch said. “Not how that works,” Jax muttered. Briggs’s voice came again, more measured. “Calamity Jane, copy?” Hale’s cutter hovered over the locking seam. “Decide,” she said. Jax heard his own breath, loud in his ears. He hit the comm. “Cutter Nine, this is Calamity Jane. We’re experiencing minor engine irregularities. Not safe to take on visitors until we stabilize. We’ll transmit diagnostics.” It wasn’t a refusal. Not exactly. A stall. A pause. “I know your voice, Rourke,” Briggs said. No rank. Just name. “I’ll take your diag, but I’m still coming. Don’t make this more work than it has to be.” The channel clicked off. Stitch let out a low whistle. “He sounds nice.” “Marshal Briggs,” Jax said. “My old boss.” “Perfect,” Rian said. “Add paternal disappointment to the pile.” The crate banged, sharp enough to rattle a loose panel. Hale’s scanner squealed. “That’s it,” she said. “We open. If this is HelioDyne biotech and they want it back, the last thing I’m doing is leaving it sealed for them.” Mara stepped in front of the seam, body between Hale and the lock. “You don’t understand what kind of hammer they’ll drop. They will own us. Our ship. Our organs.” “Move,” Hale said. Hale was not big, but something in her stance made Stitch edge away rather than closer. Mara stood her ground. “We can let Briggs take it and sleep at night. We stayed in our lane.” “Speak for yourself,” Stitch said. Jax had heard enough. “Mara.” She looked over, jaw clenched. “You got us into this,” he said. “Is there something you’re not telling me?” For a heartbeat, he saw it: the flicker of guilt. Then she smoothed it away. “I knew HelioDyne paid well for discretion,” she said. “That’s all.” Lie, he thought. Or half of one. The crate’s status light jumped from green to a pulsing amber. A thin line of something pale squeezed through a seam and retracted, like a feeler testing air. “Captain,” Hale said. “If we wait, we’re accomplices. To whatever they’re doing in there.” He thought of another dock, another crate, another moment he’d let pass because it wasn’t his jurisdiction. He’d never seen what came of it. That ignorance had never felt like innocence. “Stitch,” Jax said, voice steady now. “Get me the cutter.” Mara inhaled sharply. “Jax.” “Contract’s void the moment Briggs steps aboard and sees this,” he said. “We don’t get the money either way. Only choice we got left is who we can look in the eye after.” Silence. Then Mara stepped aside. “That’s a mistake,” she said, but there was something else in it now. Relief, maybe. Or resignation. Stitch thrust the handheld cutter into Jax’s palm. Hale positioned herself, med kit ready. Jax pressed the blade to the seam. “If something ugly jumps, you shoot it,” he told Mara. “Gladly,” she said. He triggered the cutter. The beam hissed along the seam, metal glowing, then parting. The crate vibrated like it wanted to buck itself free. “Almost,” Hale murmured. The last of the seal gave with a crack. A breath of colder, antiseptic air spilled out, tinged with something coppery and sweet, wrong. Jax took the edge of the panel, hauled it open. Inside, under harsh white internal strips, a girl stared back at him. She was strapped into a contoured frame by bands across chest, arms, legs. Skin too pale under a sheen of sweat. Hair in ragged tufts around implanted ports. Tubes threaded into her veins from an IV hub. Along her left side, something not-her clung: a lattice of pale, veined tissue fused to skin, pulsing slow, its filaments sunk into ports on the cradle. Her eyes blinked at the sudden change in light. They were dark and startlingly clear for a second before she flinched, pupils pinpricking. The lattice shivered, tendrils tightening. “Easy,” Hale said, already leaning in, fingers gentle but sure on the IV lines. “Hey there.” The girl’s gaze fixed on Jax. Her lips moved. Her voice came out a cracked whisper: “This… isn’t Prospector’s Rest.” No plea in it. Just fact and fear. Stitch cursed softly. Rian, watching on the bay cam, swore louder. Hale checked the monitors built into the cradle. “Sedation cycling too high,” she muttered. “Body’s fighting it. They’ve been keeping her under on automatic.” Mara hovered at Jax’s shoulder. “That,” she said tightly, “is HelioDyne proprietary biotech. Project-level. We close this now.” The lattice along the girl’s side rippled at Mara’s tone, a little forest of pale spines rising. “Back up,” Hale snapped. “You’re spooking the sym.” “The what?” Stitch asked. “The thing glued to her,” Hale said. “Biotech symbiote. Neural-linked. Marvel of science, abomination, pick your term. It thinks fast and it protects its host.” The girl swallowed. “Don’t… let it… touch you. If I… if I’m scared it…” She trailed off, breath hitching. The symbiote’s tendrils twitched. Jax felt the shape of HelioDyne’s plan settle like lead. Weapon in a box. Loyal if controlled. Disposable if not. He met the girl’s eyes. “Name?” There was a pause, like she was downloading the answer. “Lyric-Three,” she said. Then, after a beat, like she was trying on something else, “Lyra.” “Lyra,” Jax said. “You called for help.” Her throat worked. “Was supposed to… supposed to be gone. Out. They… they turned me back.” Mara went still. Hale’s glance cut sideways. Jax filed it. Overhead, the comm pinged again. Briggs, waiting. “Captain,” Rian said. “Marshal cutter is decelerating into intercept. I can’t pretend engine trouble forever.” Lyra’s fingers flexed against the restraints. The symbiote curled tighter, sensing tension. “I’m not going back,” Lyra whispered. “If they take me, they’ll open my head. Make more.” Mara took a slow step forward despite the symbiote’s wary bristle. “We don’t have time for story hour,” she said to Jax, but her voice had lost some of its edge. “Briggs boards and sees this, HelioDyne gets everything back with a Marshal escort.” Lyra’s eyes slid to her. “You were… on the manifests.” Mara flinched like slapped. Jax exhaled. Choices narrowed, hard as the walls. He hit the comm. “Briggs. We’ve had a containment issue with a piece of HelioDyne cargo. Biohazard. You board now, you’re in it with us. I suggest you hold position.” A long pause. “Rourke,” Briggs said slowly, “what did you sign for?” Jax looked at Lyra, at the living armor clinging to her side. “Something that calls itself Lyra,” he said. “And doesn’t want to go back in the box.”
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully executes the critical turning point of the story - the opening of the mysterious crate and the discovery of Lyra. The writing demonstrates strong character work and maintains tension throughout, though it has some minor technical weaknesses. The character voices are distinctly rendered and consistent with the established profiles. Jax's reluctant moral awakening feels authentic, particularly in his decision to stall Briggs and ultimately open the crate. Hale's medical pragmatism ("Standing here arguing while someone suffocates is a choice") rings true to her background. Mara's defensive guilt when confronted about the job she brought them creates effective dramatic tension. Stitch's nervous energy and Rian's self-preservation instincts both come through clearly. The dialogue is generally strong, with each character speaking in their established voice. Lines like "Contract's void the moment Briggs steps aboard anyway" and "We close this, we void contract, we invite lawsuits and possibly death" feel natural while advancing both plot and character development. The technical jargon (biosigns, sedative drip, etc.) integrates well without becoming expository. The reveal of Lyra is well-handled, avoiding melodrama while maintaining the horror of her situation. The description of her condition - the ports, restraints, and symbiotic lattice - creates visceral impact without becoming gratuitously detailed. Her first words ("This... isn't Prospector's Rest") immediately establish both her intelligence and her precarious situation. The plot mechanics work smoothly, with Briggs's arrival creating the necessary pressure to force the crew's hand. The escalating signs of life in the crate build tension effectively, and the final choice feels earned rather than arbitrary. However, the writing occasionally rushes through moments that could benefit from more development. The transition from debate to action feels slightly compressed, and some of the technical exposition (particularly about the symbiote) could be more elegantly integrated. A few descriptions border on workmanlike rather than vivid, though they remain functional. The chapter adheres closely to its planned structure and successfully sets up the story's central moral conflict. The space western tone remains consistent, and the corporate vs. frontier themes emerge naturally through the action rather than through heavy-handed exposition. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Lyra watched them like they were all part of the same experiment. Hale adjusted the IV drip, fingers sure. “I’m lowering the sedation,” she said. “Not off. I’m not an idiot. But enough that you’re not being drugged into heart failure by some idiot auto-reg.” Lyra’s gaze tracked her. “You’re not theirs.” “Not anymore,” Hale said. The symbiote—“sym,” Hale had called it—pulsed along Lyra’s ribs, faint bioluminescent veins winking under the skin. It flexed a stubby tendril toward Hale’s hands, then withdrew as Lyra exhaled slowly, deliberately. “She’s tied into that thing,” Hale said to Jax, without looking away. “Her nervous system, brainwave patterns. Fear response spikes, it activates. You saw what it did to the crate walls.” “So we keep her calm,” Stitch said from his post by the door. He sounded unconvinced that anything in this situation could be calm. Lyra’s eyes flicked past him, past Mara, and landed on Jax. “You told the Marshal my name,” she said. Her voice was still rasped raw, but gaining strength. “I told him there’s a person aboard who doesn’t want to go back in the box,” Jax said. “That’s accurate.” “You shouldn’t have told him anything,” Mara said. “We need less attention, not more.” Jax turned slowly. “The cutter was already pointed at our head. You wanted me to invite them aboard and giftwrap her?” “I wanted you to not admit to harboring stolen property over an open channel,” Mara snapped. Lyra flinched at “stolen property.” The sym tightened, a tremor running through it. “Hey,” Stitch said quickly. “Words. Let’s not use the words that make the murder jelly agitated, okay?” “It doesn’t murder,” Lyra said. There was a flash of something sharp behind the flatness. “It protects. They made it to protect me. Then made me… for it.” Hale murmured, “Neural bond. Mutually reinforcing. Lovely.” “Lyra,” Jax said, “what was the plan? You said you were supposed to be ‘gone.’” She blinked slowly, accessing memories like files. “A tech. Senior biometrician. He coded my transfer. Calico to… out beyond. Said there’s places they don’t own. Said they could hide me.” Her mouth twisted. “They traced him. Changed the routing. Put me back in cycle. I woke when the vector was wrong.” “And called for help,” Stitch said. “Good instincts.” “He… said someone on the outside would make sure,” Lyra said. “A Kade.” The name hit the bay like a dropped tool. Stitch’s gaze snapped to Mara. Hale’s followed. Jax didn’t move, but he didn’t have to. Mara’s face stayed carefully still, but color drained a shade. “HelioDyne logistics,” Lyra added softly. “You signed my outbound. And the others they didn’t get out.” Mara’s shoulders tightened. She made herself look at Lyra. “He trusted me to reroute you. I tried. They flagged it. I grabbed this crate the second I saw the code, hoped to outrun the recall. That is the only reason you’re on this ship and not in their lab.” “And before that?” Hale asked, voice mild as a scalpel. Mara didn’t look away. “Before that, I signed whatever they gave me.” Lyra stared at her, unreadable. The sym gave a faint bristle, then smoothed when Lyra let out another measured exhale. Jax watched it all, feeling like someone had peeled back a panel in his own hull. Over comms, Briggs’s voice came again. “Rourke. I need very clear language right now. Is there an unregistered biotech asset aboard your vessel?” Hale muttered, “Asset,” under her breath, like a curse. Jax toggled the channel but didn’t speak yet. Mara stepped closer. “Let me talk,” she said. “No,” Jax said. “He’ll trust you,” Mara said. “You can spin.” “I’m done spinning,” Jax said. He hit transmit. “Briggs, HelioDyne shipped us a sealed crate with a sedated, bonded psionic kid inside. She has a name. Lyra. They marked her property.” Silence. Then a long, weary breath across the speaker. “Of course they did,” Briggs said. Mara shut her eyes. “You understand,” Briggs went on, “if you’re holding stolen HelioDyne research, they’ll be on you with every writ they can print. They’re screaming already.” “Yeah,” Jax said. “We noticed the screaming.” “We can resolve this,” Briggs said. “Power down, let me dock. I’ll secure the asset. Make sure HelioDyne follows protocol. Take you out of the line of fire.” “‘Secure the asset,’” Lyra whispered. Jax saw her hands clench against her restraints. “Marshal,” Hale said sharply, cutting into the channel. “Imani Hale, licensed medic. What they’ve done to her is illegal under three different sentient-biotech codes if you actually read your law book.” “I know who you are, Doctor,” Briggs said. “And I know what accidents look like when they get uncontained. We do this above-board or people die.” “People already died,” Lyra said. She wasn’t on comm, but the room heard her. Jax muted his mic. “Options,” he said. “Now.” Rian’s voice piped in from the bridge. “Option one, we open the door, shake Briggs’s hand, hope he’s the kind of boy scout who can tell HelioDyne no. Option two, we run, in which case we are very loudly guilty.” “Option three,” Mara said, “is we hand Lyra directly to Briggs, fast, before corporate security catches up. We let the law try.” Hale gave her a look. “You trust the same law that let HelioDyne box her in the first place?” “I don’t trust anything,” Mara snapped. “I am counting how many guns we don’t have.” Stitch cleared his throat. “Is there an option where we don’t feed the kid back into the meat grinder?” “She is not a kid,” Mara said, too quick. Lyra’s eyes narrowed. “I’m fourteen.” Mara flinched again. “She’s also a bioweapon.” “Those statements are not mutually exclusive,” Hale said. The symbiote’s tendrils rose like hackles at the tension. Metal around Lyra’s cradle creaked faintly. “Everybody shut up,” Jax said. He turned to Lyra. “If we open those restraints, can you keep that thing from lashing anyone’s head off?” Lyra’s gaze didn’t waver. “If I’m not scared,” she said. “If you don’t point guns at me. If you don’t say I’m going back.” She said “back” like “buried.” “If you lose control?” Hale asked. Lyra considered this. Not flinching away from the possibility. “Then you should kill me,” she said simply. Stitch made a choking sound. “Okay. Let’s not make killing kids the default solution, yeah?” “It’s not default,” Lyra said. “It’s… contingency.” Jax felt something twist tight in his chest. The matter-of-fact way she laid out her own execution plan. “Marshal Briggs,” he said, reopening the channel. “You still there?” “I’m here,” Briggs said. “And officially, I’m hearing obstruction. Don’t make me log it that way.” “Officially,” Jax said, “HelioDyne shipped a sentient weapon in a crate through unregulated space with no safeguards except sedation. You want that on your manifest?” “I want it under control,” Briggs said. “If HelioDyne’s in violation, there are channels.” Hale snorted. “Those channels are owned.” “I’m not debating ethics over a comm line,” Briggs said. “You’re out of compliance. Stand down and let me board.” Jax muted again. He knew that tone. It was the sound of a man tightening a noose because the book said so. Mara spoke low. “If we run now, we are done. Outlaws. Forever.” “If we don’t,” Hale said, “we’re accessories.” Stitch looked at Jax. “Captain. Please.” Rian: “I’ll go where you point, but if we’re doing outlaw, I’d like to know how serious to be about it.” Lyra watched him like she already knew his answer and was only waiting to see if he disappointed her. Jax closed his eyes for half a second. He saw a different crate, a younger him, a crisp uniform, a signature on a pad. Thought: it’s above my pay grade. Let the system handle it. He opened his eyes. “We run,” he said. Rian swore, but he was grinning with something like terror. “Yes, sir.” Mara stared. “Jax—” “HelioDyne wants her,” Jax said. “The Marshals are their courier. I’m not handing a talking kid in a cage back to the people who stamped property on her skin.” “She is dangerous,” Mara said. “So are we,” Jax said. “When we’re scared.” Lyra inhaled, slow, and the symbiote calmed. Hale nodded once. “Finally.” Stitch’s shoulders sagged with shaky relief. Mara looked from Lyra to Jax, something desperate in her eyes. “You don’t know what they’ll do to us.” “I know what they’ll do to her,” he said. “And I’m tired of not knowing things because it’s easier.” He toggled comms. “Briggs. I respect you. I do. But you’re sitting between a corporation and a kid they built to kill on command. I’m not letting them have her back.” Long silence. When Briggs spoke, it was softer. “Rourke, don’t make me your enemy.” “Get off our vector,” Jax said. “I won’t fire on you. I also won’t open my doors.” “HelioDyne has issued binding orders,” Briggs said. A harder edge now. “You’re harboring stolen military-grade biotech.” “I’m harboring a girl,” Jax said. He cut the line before Briggs could answer. Rian whooped, half-hysterical. “Outlaw it is.” “Punch us off their intercept,” Jax said. “Keep it quiet. I don’t want a flashy burn.” “You got it.” The Jane shuddered as Rian eased more juice into the drives, sliding them off the cutter’s path. Mara put both hands over her face for a second, then dropped them. “We are so very, deeply screwed.” “Probably,” Jax said. He turned to Lyra. “We’re gonna get you somewhere HelioDyne doesn’t own. That’s the plan. You with us?” Lyra studied him. “You might die.” “Been on my to-do list a while,” Jax said. A tiny huff. Not quite a laugh. “If you keep me,” she said, “they’ll chase you.” “Yeah.” Jax felt the weight of it settle. The line he’d crossed wasn’t one he could stroll back. Her fingers flexed. The symbiote’s tendrils made a slow, curious wave in his direction. “I’ll try not to be scared,” Lyra said. “So I don’t hurt you by accident.” “That’d be appreciated,” Jax said. The ship’s lights flickered again as something in the power grid hiccuped. Stitch cursed. “I’ll check it.” Lyra watched the lights with a small, knowing tilt of her head. “They’re pinging the systems,” she said. “HelioDyne. Through the tags.” Mara swore in corporate code. Jax exhaled. “Right. Next problem. Let’s make sure our guest doesn’t come with a remote control.” No one said out loud that they’d just traded one kind of doom for another. They all knew. The Jane’s course arced away, off the path of law and into the thin places between.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively builds tension and forces crucial character decisions, serving as a pivotal turning point in the story. The writing successfully balances multiple character perspectives while maintaining narrative momentum. **Strengths:** The character work is particularly strong. Lyra's matter-of-fact statement "Then you should kill me" perfectly captures her disturbing blend of childlike vulnerability and weaponized conditioning. Jax's evolution from conflict-avoidant to decisive feels earned, culminating in his powerful line "I'm tired of not knowing things because it's easier" - this directly addresses his backstory guilt about previous moral cowardice. The revelation of Mara's connection to Lyra creates genuine dramatic tension without feeling contrived. Her defensive reaction and Lyra's calm acknowledgment of betrayal add moral complexity rather than simple villainizing. Dialogue generally serves character and plot well. Each voice feels distinct - from Stitch's nervous humor ("Let's not make killing kids the default solution") to Hale's clinical directness to Briggs's weary authority. The escalating comm exchanges with Briggs effectively ratchet up external pressure while Jax wrestles with his choice. The chapter successfully shows rather than tells character motivations and conflicts. Mara's flinching, Lyra's measured breathing to control the symbiote, and Jax's careful consideration all reveal character through action. **Weaknesses:** The planned symbiote incident with Rian is missing, which would have better demonstrated Lyra's dangerous unpredictability. While tension exists, a concrete example of her lashing out would have strengthened the "dangerous child" dynamic. Some dialogue exchanges feel slightly exposition-heavy, particularly around the biotech codes and legal implications. While necessary for plot, it occasionally reads more like information delivery than natural conversation. The pacing rushes somewhat through Mara's revelation and Jax's decision. More time lingering on the crew's reaction to learning Mara's role could have deepened the betrayal's impact. Minor technical issues include repetitive sentence structures in places and some awkward transitions between speakers in group scenes. **Overall Assessment:** This is solid genre fiction that delivers on character development and plot advancement. The moral complexity feels genuine rather than forced, and the chapter successfully moves characters past the point of no return. While not transcendent literature, it's competent storytelling that serves its space western premise effectively. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 14 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Three hours into running, the universe reminded them it was not impressed. The Calamity Jane threaded a broken chain of ice-rock and scrap metal—a dead ring from some abandoned mining project. Rian guided her through the clutter with twitchy precision, jaw tight. “Any word from Briggs?” Jax asked, leaning over his shoulder. “Radio silent,” Rian said. “But the cutter’s shadowing. He’s either waiting on orders or hoping you get smart.” “Smart is relative,” Stitch muttered from the doorway. On the other monitor, Hale had Lyra’s vitals up. Colors and lines, too many of them. The symbiote’s neural activity chart sat like a storm cloud. “Her levels?” Jax asked. “Stabilizing,” Hale said. “She’s metabolizing the sedative, keeping control. Smarter than anything that age has a right to be.” Lyra sat upright in the medbay feed now, unstrapped except for a single magnetic cuff on one ankle. The sym clung along her side like a pale, coiled animal, its tendrils resting. Mara stood beside Jax in the cockpit, arms folded, eyes on the forward screen. “HelioDyne isn’t going to let this go. They’ll file injunctions, freeze our accounts, spin a story about terrorists stealing their lifesaving research.” “They can freeze my debt,” Rian said. “Call it even.” “No,” Mara said. “They’ll triple it.” A soft ping cut through the chatter. Incoming narrow-beam transmission, encrypted. Origin: unknown. “Source?” Jax asked. “Off our port, long-range. That’s not Briggs,” Rian said. “Decrypting.” The logo resolved like a slap: HelioDyne’s spiral, pale against dark. Then a woman’s face—smooth, composed, framed by the sort of uniform you only got within the corporate core zones. “Captain Rourke,” she said. “I’m Aurelia Voss, Executive Retrieval for HelioDyne Biotek. I’m glad I caught you before this goes any further off course.” Jax didn’t answer immediately. He studied her. The calm, the careful lighting. No insignia of rank beyond a small silver helix at her collar. “Go ahead,” he said. “I’m aware you’ve discovered the contents of our crate,” Voss said. “I imagine that was… upsetting.” “‘Upsetting,’” Stitch repeated faintly. Mara shifted, spine stiffening. Voss’s eyes slid over something off-screen. “The asset in your possession is classified Project Lyric. It is extremely dangerous and critically important. It was unlawfully removed from our facility with the assistance of a traitor in our logistics division.” “Traitor,” Mara said under her breath. “That tracks.” “We have legal claim,” Voss continued. “As does the Federal government, under joint defense contracts. My concern, Captain, is not paperwork. It’s containment.” “Containment,” Hale said quietly, arms folding tighter. Jax kept his voice even. “You shipped a sedated girl in a crate.” Voss didn’t flinch. “We shipped a weapons platform that has already demonstrated catastrophic potential. You are not equipped to manage a psionic surge or a symbiotic breach. I am.” Lyra’s voice, small but clear, came from the medbay feed speaker. “I know that voice.” Jax muted his mic. “You do?” Lyra stared past the camera. “She watched our tests.” Hale’s mouth thinned. Voss’s lips moved on Jax’s screen. He unmuted mid-sentence. “—isn’t here to blame you. Mistakes were made on our end in transport security. I’m offering you a way out.” “I’m listening,” Jax said. “Change course to the beacon I’m transmitting,” Voss said. “Cut engines. I’ll dock, transfer the asset with proper safeguards, and log that you cooperated under duress. HelioDyne will compensate you above contract for the risk. No charges. No forfeiture of your vessel.” “Seems generous,” Rian said quietly. “You can’t believe her,” Hale said. “She’s not lying about us being out of our depth,” Mara murmured. “But that’s not the part that matters.” “What happens to Lyra?” Jax asked. He used the name deliberately. Voss’s eyes cooled a degree. “The asset will be assessed, stabilized, and returned to secure research conditions.” “In pieces,” Lyra whispered, unheard by Voss. “And if we don’t hand her over?” Jax asked. “Then you are in possession of stolen military-grade biotech,” Voss said. “And we will retrieve it by other means. The Marshal Service is… strongly encouraged to assist.” “‘Encouraged,’” Briggs’s voice echoed in Jax’s memory. Jax killed audio and leaned back. “Crew input,” he said. “Short.” Rian spoke first. “Captain, that woman has a gunship full of lawyers and actual guns. We’re a bucket with dreams. I hate it, I hate all of this, but walking away alive is a seductive little devil.” Stitch shook his head violently. “She is not taking Lyra back in a box. No.” “Objectively,” Hale said, “Voss is correct that Lyra is dangerous. Subjectively, I’d rather staple my own tongue to the hull than hand her to the people who did that.” She jerked her chin toward the med feed. Mara’s jaw worked. “HelioDyne will not let this go. If we refuse, we are choosing a war we can’t win.” Lyra’s voice crackled over internal. “If you give me back, they’ll say you did the right thing. That you helped keep everyone safe. That’s what they always say.” Everyone looked, for a second, at the little speaker as if she were standing there. Jax stared at Voss’s frozen face on the paused transmission. He saw confidence. He saw certainty. He’d worn a version of that once, badge on his chest. He unmuted. “Voss. Your asset has a name. Lyra. She says you’ll cut her apart and make more of her.” “I’m not going to litigate technical procedures with you, Captain,” Voss said. “What I can say is that uncontrolled, she is a threat on a scale you cannot imagine. Outpost Twelve.” Lyra flinched. The sym shuddered. “What happened at Outpost Twelve, Lyra?” Hale asked. Lyra stared down. “They told me to push. To make them stop shooting. I pushed. They all stopped.” Her hands shook. “He— the tech— he vomited. They sedated me for two days. After that they said I needed… adjustment.” Voss’s voice went on, calm. “That event should illustrate why we cannot allow her to wander the frontier in the care of smugglers.” “Smugglers,” Rian muttered. “Rude but not inaccurate.” “Your choices,” Voss said. “Face us as adversaries, or walk away with your lives and a very generous compensation. Consider your people, Captain.” She cut the link, giving them space to stew. The vector beacon lingered on the nav. “Marshal cutter’s shifting,” Rian said. “Voss just tugged their leash. They’re sliding onto the same intercept as that beacon.” “So if we hand her over, we do it blessed by law,” Mara said. Stitch turned on her. “You’re not seriously—” “I am seriously aware we are outgunned,” Mara snapped. “And that I have delivered children like her into their hands already.” Lyra’s voice over comm was quiet. “You don’t have to keep doing it.” Mara fell silent. Hale looked at Jax. “You already know what you’re going to say,” she said. “Just don’t dither it to death.” He did. It felt like a stone he’d picked up chapters ago and finally had to throw. He toggled transmit. “Voss. Appreciate the concern. We’ll pass on the pickup.” Silence, then: “Reconsider. That was your last polite invitation.” “Copy that,” Jax said, and cut her off. “Okay,” Rian said, half-laughing. “We are officially in the ‘very screwed’ quadrant of the chart.” “I had us there when we opened the box,” Hale said. Mara exhaled. “Prospector’s Rest,” she said. “It’s crap, but it’s off most official lanes. A few independent outfits there… We might find a ride or cover.” Jax nodded. “Plot it. Dirtier route, fewer eyes.” Rian’s fingers flew. “Got a thread through some old mining debris fields and a blind relay. It’ll cost fuel.” “We’ll owe later,” Jax said. “Right now, we arrive not dead.” In medbay, Lyra watched the ceiling as Hale adjusted her lines. Stitch sat cross-legged on a crate nearby, trying to look casual. “So, hey,” he said. “Prospector’s Rest. It’s, uh… scenic. In a rusted-out, don’t-touch-anything kind of way.” Lyra tilted her head. “You don’t want to be alone with me.” He blinked. “That’s… not… I mean, I’m very charming company, but also I watched you dent a crate with your brain goo.” The sym flexed one lazy tendril. Lyra looked at it, then back at him. “I’m trying to be safe,” she said. “It listens to me more now.” “That’s good,” Stitch said. “Be nice to have someone on this bucket who listens to somebody.” She almost smiled. “You’re afraid.” “Yep,” Stitch said. “Very. But I’m still here. So that’s either bravery or poor judgment. Jury’s out.” She watched him another long moment. “They built me so people would do what I want,” she said. “Feel what I push. It’s hard to tell when they’re real.” Stitch swallowed. “Well. Pro tip. I mostly feel hungry and anxious. If you’re stirring something, you’re doing it wrong.” A ghost of a smile, there and gone. In the cockpit, an alert flared red. “HelioDyne gunship dropping out of FTL at our ten o’clock,” Rian said. His voice went flat. “Fast one. They took a shortcut.” “Distance?” Jax asked. “Far enough not to shoot yet. Close enough to flex,” Rian said. As if on cue, Voss’s ship painted them with an active scan—a bright sweep that made the Jane’s console lights flicker. “Briggs’s cutter still trailing?” Jax asked. “Yeah,” Rian said. “Slower, more cautious. If he sides with her, we get a sandwich named after us.” Jax keyed shipwide. “Everyone strap in. HelioDyne just came knocking.” In medbay, Hale snugged Lyra’s cuff. “Don’t do anything yet,” she said. Lyra’s eyes unfocused for a second. “She’s angry,” she murmured. “Voss. But not scared. She thinks she’s the only adult.” “I hate that she’s not entirely wrong,” Hale said. Back in the cockpit, another ping: encrypted from Briggs. Jax opened audio only. “Rourke,” Briggs said, tight. “HelioDyne is invoking emergency defense statutes. They want me to assist in retrieving their asset. I’m ordering you to—” “To stand down,” Jax finished for him. “I figured.” “They’re saying if she’s loose, she’s a weapon of mass harm. You know what those words do on paper.” “I know what they do to people in crates,” Jax said. “Dammit, son,” Briggs said, and the “son” wasn’t formal. “You’re leaving me with bad choices.” “Welcome to the party,” Jax said. “We’re heading for Prospector’s Rest. You didn’t hear that.” “That gunship will beat you there,” Briggs said. “You think you can hold against that?” “No,” Jax said. “We’re not holding. We’re cheating.” He cut the line, not giving Briggs a chance to offer a last clean out. Mara leaned against the console, pinching the bridge of her nose. “So this is it. We’ve picked our hill.” “Feels more like a ditch,” Rian said. Jax looked at Lyra’s vitals, still pulsing steady on the peripheral screen. Looked at Voss’s ship icon, burning toward them. Looked at the faint blip of Briggs’s cutter trying to keep up with someone else’s orders. He thought, not for the first time, about turning the Jane around, about letting someone else decide. Then he remembered the muted “Help”—half-choked by sedation and metal. “Set us on the line to Prospector’s,” he said. “We’ll meet them there.” “And when they come down with writs and guns?” Mara asked. “We’ll make them work for it,” Jax said. “And we’ll make damn sure everyone sees what they’re trying to drag back into a box.” It wasn’t a strategy so much as a promise. But in the thin, quiet dark between stars, sometimes that was all you had.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively escalates the central conflict and delivers the promised moral pressure. The introduction of Aurelia Voss as the corporate antagonist is particularly well-handled - she's presented as a competent professional who genuinely believes in her mission rather than a mustache-twirling villain. Her calm, clinical language ("asset," referring to Lyra as "it") effectively conveys the dehumanizing corporate mindset without resorting to cartoonish evil. The character work is strong throughout. Each crew member's response to the dilemma feels authentic to their established personalities: Rian's pragmatic fear, Stitch's emotional investment in Lyra, Hale's medical perspective, and Mara's guilt-driven defensiveness. Jax's decision-making process feels genuinely weighty, especially his acknowledgment of past moral failures rather than positioning himself as a hero. Lyra's complexity is well-maintained through the Outpost Twelve revelation. The chapter avoids making her either pure victim or pure threat, instead presenting her as someone genuinely dangerous who's also been horrifically abused. Her quiet "You don't have to keep doing it" to Mara is particularly effective. The dialogue generally feels natural and character-appropriate, with good contrast between Voss's corporate speak and the crew's rougher vernacular. The pacing builds tension effectively as options narrow and external pressure mounts. However, the chapter has some notable gaps. The writing plan called for Rian to secretly transmit their location to HelioDyne, which would have added an important layer of internal betrayal and crew fracturing. This omission reduces the "cracks in the crew" element that was central to the chapter's purpose. The prose is clean and functional but occasionally feels workmanlike rather than inspired. While avoiding purple prose, it could benefit from more specific, sensory details to ground the reader in the ship's cramped environment and the characters' physical tension. Some dialogue exchanges, while competent, feel slightly mechanical - characters tend to speak in turns that advance plot rather than feeling like completely natural conversation. The chapter serves its structural purpose well but doesn't transcend into memorable writing. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 12 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Prospector’s Rest floated ahead of them like a forgotten thought. Once, it had been a refueling hub for a lucrative asteroid field. Now half its ring was dark, whole sections gutted, letters missing from the glowing sign. It read SPECTOR’S RE, flickering between colors. Rust blooms crawled along the spine. Only a few docking beacons still pulsed, slow and tired. Rian let out a low whistle. “Charming.” “Trashy,” Stitch said. “I like it.” “It has thin oversight and thick walls,” Mara said. “That’s what we like.” Jax watched the scans. Minimal traffic: a couple of ore tugs, a patched tugboat transport, a sphere that might have once been a pleasure yacht turned flophouse. No official Marshal beacon. No HelioDyne transponder—yet. “Get us on a quiet dock,” he said. “No parade.” Rian guided the Calamity Jane toward a half-lit berth. Mag-clamps bit with a dull thud. The station’s umbilical snaked out to meet their hatch like a hungry thing. “Life support’s patchy,” Stitch said, scrolling through the handshake data. “But we won’t suffocate fast.” “Reassuring,” Hale said. Jax keyed shipwide. “We’re down. We refuel, patch what we can, and see if there’s anyone here who doesn’t send reports to HelioDyne for pocket change. No one goes wandering off alone.” Stitch glanced toward medbay. “What about Lyra?” Hale answered before Jax could. “She stays.” Lyra, propped on the med cot, looked up. “They’ll find me.” “They’ll look,” Hale said. “But this place leaks. That’s good and bad.” Lyra’s fingers tapped her thigh in a steady rhythm. The symbiote along her side was subdued; its pale tendrils lay flat. “I can feel them,” Lyra said. “Like thunder that hasn’t started yet.” “Voss?” Jax asked. Lyra nodded. “Closer. And the Marshal. He’s… torn.” “Accurate,” Jax said. Mara leaned in the doorway, arms folded. “We’ll throw off as much of their trail as we can. You just keep that thing from chewing through my hull.” Lyra’s gaze flicked to her. “You’re angry at yourself,” she said. “It makes you sharp.” “Stay out of my head,” Mara said. “I’m not trying,” Lyra said softly. Hale put a hand on Lyra’s shoulder. “Rest. We’ll shout if the sky falls.” “Small sky,” Stitch muttered. “Fewer pieces to dodge.” On the station, Prospector’s Rest smelled like burnt oil, stale air, and the sour tang of recycled sweat. Lights buzzed. A vendor’s screen looped an ad for a mining outfit that had gone bust years ago. Jax, Mara, and Stitch stepped into this tired gravity with the gait of people who’d seen worse. A thin man with a station pass on a lanyard met them at the end of the umbilical. He wore two different boots and a harassed expression. “Dockmaster?” Jax asked. “One of them,” the man said. “Name’s Kell. You got credits?” “We’ve got enough,” Mara said. She flashed a balance on her slate that was technically true if no one counted upcoming fuel burn. “We charge extra for drama,” Kell said, eyeing their hull scars. “No drama,” Jax said. “Just gas and quiet.” Kell snorted. “You docked the wrong end of the galaxy.” They walked the ring: past shuttered storefronts, a flickering news screen replaying core-world politics nobody here cared about, a cramped bar with a neon sign that read SAL N in sputtering pink. A handful of miners hunched over drinks, shoulders like rocks. Jax clocked exits, cameras, the way people’s eyes slid off when they saw Mara’s old corporate tattoo. Word traveled even in forgotten places. In a corner booth, a lanky woman in a grease-stained flight suit played cards with a man whose arm was clearly printed steel. Mara murmured, “That’s Ada. Runs jobs no one writes down. Might sell us a route or a lie.” “Later,” Jax said. He needed information first. He ordered a cheap drink at the bar just to pay for loitering. The owner, a broad man with a biosculpted nose that had gone out of style decades ago, poured. “You seen any heavy corporate ships come through?” Jax asked casually. “HelioDyne spiral. All clean and shiny.” The barman’s lip lifted. “Ain’t yet. Hear one’s burning hard this way, though. Got a ping to reserve a berth. Noise ‘bout some stolen miracle gone wild.” “Yeah,” Jax said. “Miracles. Always trouble.” “You law?” the barman asked, eyeing Jax’s stance. “Not anymore,” Jax said. Mara drifted back from a quick circuit. “Station’s got blind spots,” she said quietly. “Service tunnels. Old ore ducts. If we need to move someone unseen, we can. We can also get shot in the spine and no one’ll find us for a month.” “Comforting,” Jax said. “Let’s get what we came for.” Fuel was arranged with Kell: too expensive, but they didn’t argue much. Cleaning out the Jane’s lines, rebalancing her reactors—Stitch hustled between ship and station with focused energy. On the second trip back, Stitch nearly ran into Marshal Briggs. Briggs looked wrong on Prospector’s Rest. His uniform was too clean, his bearing too straight. He filled the corridor with something that wasn’t quite threat, not quite safety. “Easy there,” Briggs said, grabbing Stitch by the shoulders before he could topple. Stitch froze. “Uh. Hi.” Jax arrived two breaths later, calm on the outside, thoughts tangling. “Marshal,” he said. “Rourke,” Briggs said. He released Stitch, looked Jax over. “This place suits you.” “Trashy?” Jax said. “Untidy,” Briggs said. A ghost of something like a smile. Mara appeared behind Jax, posture taut. “You got here fast,” Jax said. “Could’ve been faster if I’d jumped when HelioDyne yelled,” Briggs said. “I took my time. They didn’t like that.” “Appreciate it,” Jax said. Briggs’s eyes flicked toward the dock where the Jane lay. “She aboard?” Jax didn’t pretend. “Yeah.” “Hiding a classified asset,” Briggs said, voice low. “Obstructing an investigation. Harboring stolen corporate property. You’re stacking charges like cards.” “You going to play them?” Jax asked. Briggs sighed, rubbed the bridge of his nose. “I read the files they sent. The words they use for her. I also saw the unredacted report from Outpost Twelve. She’s dangerous, Jax.” “I know,” Jax said. “So’s HelioDyne.” “I should take her,” Briggs said. “Hand her to a neutral facility. Start an inquiry. Make a fuss.” “And when HelioDyne leans on the inquiry?” Hale’s voice cut in. She joined them, arms folded. “And on you?” Briggs looked at her. “Doc.” “Marshal.” He hesitated. There was a war behind his eyes: duty vs. the evidence in front of him. “I can’t endorse you running,” Briggs said finally. “But I’m not dragging your girl out by force so Voss can carve her up. I can put in a ‘jurisdictional dispute’ and stall. That’s the best I can give you.” “Sometimes stalling’s all we need,” Jax said. Briggs’s jaw tightened. “Voss is ten minutes out. She’s bringing her own enforcement. You hole up here, there’s going to be a fight.” “We’re not holing up,” Mara said. “We’re… staging.” “Staging what?” Briggs asked. “Something unsanctioned,” Jax said. Briggs shook his head. “You never were this much trouble in uniform.” “I was,” Jax said. “You just didn’t see it.” They parted with no promises. Back on the Jane, Jax pulled everyone into the cramped galley. “Voss is docking soon,” he said. “Briggs is going to slow-walk her, but she’ll throw papers and guns. We can’t match force. We can make a mess.” “Mess I can do,” Stitch said. “Here’s the play,” Jax said. “Prospector’s has old maintenance ducts tied into central power, atmosphere, security. Mara’s map-hacking. Stitch is going to plant some surprises. We make sure Voss’s toys glitch. We make her overreach in front of witnesses.” “Use her own arrogance,” Hale said. “I like it.” “We’ll route Lyra through the ducts to a secondary dock,” Mara said. “If things go bad in the main hall, we put her on a different hull and break contact.” “Whose hull?” Rian asked. “Ada’s, if she bites,” Mara said. “She’ll smuggle anything if the price is right.” “And if she sells Lyra to the highest bidder?” Hale asked. “Then we don’t let her,” Jax said. “This isn’t clean. No version of this is clean. But I’d rather gamble on smugglers and miners than hand Voss a quiet victory.” Stitch raised a hand. “Just checking: we are aware this is all half-baked and will probably explode in our faces?” “Yes,” Jax said. “Get your rigging. We don’t have long.” He found Lyra in medbay, curling the blanket in her fingers. “You’re moving me,” she said before he spoke. “You felt me decide?” Jax asked. She shrugged. “You think loud.” “We’re going to try to get you off this station before HelioDyne locks it down,” he said. “You’ll go with Stitch through the ducts. Hale, if she can. Mara’ll guide.” Lyra looked past him, through the bulkhead, like she could see the station’s guts. The sym stirred, intrigued. “She’ll come,” Lyra said. “Voss. With papers and soldiers. She thinks she’s right.” “Are you scared?” Jax asked. “Yes,” Lyra said. “But not of them.” “Of what, then?” “Of what I’ll do if you let them touch me,” she said simply. Jax held her gaze. “We’re not letting them touch you.” “You might die,” Lyra said again. “Occupational hazard,” he said. Lyra’s mouth twitched. “Stitch is afraid of ducts.” “He’s more afraid of leaving you,” Jax said. That got a full, brief smile. The station shuddered as Voss’s gunship locked on. You could feel the difference: HelioDyne metal kissing tired Prospector’s steel. The hum of richer power. The lights brightened for a heartbeat, compensating. “Showtime,” Rian said over comms. In the concourse, Aurelia Voss emerged flanked by armored security. Her uniform looked absurdly crisp against peeling paint. She moved like she owned the oxygen. Prospector’s locals watched from doorways and bar stools. Kell hovered, twisting his lanyard. “Station Administrator,” Voss said, inclining her head. “We are here under emergency authority. There is a stolen HelioDyne asset on these premises. We will retrieve it.” Kell swallowed. “We don’t want trouble.” “Then you’ll have none,” Voss said. “Unless someone causes it.” Briggs stepped forward, badge visible. “This station is under Marshal oversight. Any operation goes through me.” Voss smiled with half her mouth. “Of course, Marshal Briggs. You’ve been most cooperative. Shall we?” Up in a crawlspace above the concourse, Stitch lay on his stomach, fingers hovering over a jury-rigged switch wired into a maintenance panel. Beside him, Lyra crouched, symbiote pressed close, eyes wide. “Okay,” Stitch whispered. “When Mara says ‘cut,’ I flip this. Their fancy guns go hiccup. Then we move.” Lyra nodded. “I can feel their helmets. Buzzing.” “Please do not pop their brains,” Stitch whispered. “We’re going for embarrassing, not massacre.” Down below, Jax and Mara walked out to meet Voss with deliberate casualness. Hale stayed half a step back. “Captain Rourke,” Voss said. “I’m disappointed.” “I get that a lot,” Jax said. “Place is perfect, though,” Voss went on. “A dead station for dead ends.” Mara’s voice murmured over the crew channel, tight. “Positions set. On my mark.” Voss held out a slim packet. “Emergency writs. Authority to reclaim Project Lyric, lethal force authorized if necessary. You are all hereby ordered to stand down.” Her security fanned, visors down, rifles gleaming. The locals tensed. Jax didn’t take the papers. “You want her, you explain to all these good people what ‘reclaim’ looks like.” “Cut,” Mara whispered in Stitch’s ear. Stitch flipped the switch. Half the concourse lights died. Vents coughed. A sharp crack ran through the soundscape as HelioDyne rifles sparked, powered armor HUDs glitching. Voss’s security staggered, cursing. A murmur rippled through the crowd. Someone laughed. Voss’s jaw tightened. “Fix it,” she snapped to her tech. In the ducts, Lyra closed her eyes, breathing slow; the sym flexed, tasting the electromagnetic confusion like spice. “Go, go,” Stitch hissed. He wriggled forward; Lyra followed.
