maybe even pack a bag once. - Use her prior hospitalization as a threat in a fight. - Mara might: - Sabotage his attempts at getting external help because she fears being locked up again. - Say, “If you leave, it’ll go with you,” in a way that feels like emotional blackmail (even if she believes it). h) Reconsider the neat twist-echo ending Not to discard it, but to: - Make sure the last beat is: - Disturbing because of character insight (“this is what Ethan has become / what he’s capable of”), not only because “aha, mirrored line.” - Maybe: - The echo is more subtle, woven into his behavior, and the final image is Mara’s realization rather than his clever inner pun. - Or the echo is there, but undercut by something raw: an intrusive thought he has that’s viscerally wrong in a very human way. i) Infuse idiosyncratic, specific details - Choose: - A song they always put on at night that starts to feel tainted. - A domestic ritual (tea, meds, podcasts) that gets warped by the intrusion. - A particular stressor (money, moving away from her support network, his overwork) that we see play into their choices. - Those specific anchors: - Make the horror feel like it’s happening to these people, not archetypes. j) Lean into ambiguity of responsibility - Don’t let Ethan off the hook by making the entity 100% responsible at the end: - Seed suggestions that the Passenger amplifies what’s already there. - Some of the cruelest thoughts or impulses are his, merely given permission. - That moral smear is very human: “Was it me or the thing?” without a clean answer. In summary: The underlying plan is solid, but it leans toward “competently genre-savvy” in a way that can out itself as LLM-like: tidy structure, clean escalation, clear rules, elegant twist. To humanize it, we should: - Inject more emotional mess, contradiction, and bad decisions. - Loosen the mythos so it feels discovered, not diagrammed. - Let character dynamics dictate when and how horror beats land. - Be willing to end on a note that is unsettlingly unresolved in terms of blame, certainty, and inner corruption—even if the external story “makes sense.” Next step (later) will be to selectively roughen and deepen the plan with these ideas in mind, not destroy the structure, but un-prettify it where it feels too engineered.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention Core aim: Write a possession horror that feels intimate, specific, and human, centered on that first image: waking (or “waking”) to find someone you love staring at you, and realizing the gaze is no longer simple, or safe. The horror should come as much from the relationship and the characters’ choices as from anything supernatural. Key choices: - Protagonist: - Name: Ethan, early 30s. - Practical, mildly arrogant in his rationalism; tech/comms job he can do remotely. - Loves Mara but is tired and privately resentful of feeling like her caretaker. - Has his own vulnerabilities: insomnia, stress, avoidance, a few guilty secrets (e.g., an emotional near-affair, lying about money, pressuring the move). - Narration is first-person past tense, candid but not fully self-aware; small self-serving omissions and reframings. - “Her”: - Name: Mara. - Early 30s. Smart, funny when relaxed, but frayed. - History: one serious breakdown in her mid-20s after a previous, ambiguous “haunting” and a toxic relationship; brief hospitalization. - Moved with Ethan into a cheaper, older rental partially because she couldn’t afford her old life, partially because he pushed for “space.” - She is not just a victim or prophet: she lies sometimes, minimizes, and has sharp edges. She’s also the one who has seen something like this before. - Setting: - An old, slightly off rural rental house (converted farmhouse or hillside place). - Cheap, drafty; odd layout; too-quiet nights. - Isolation: they’re a drive from town, neighbors not right next door. - The setting matters only as a pressure-cooker: not “the haunted house,” but the wrong place for two strained people with a bad history. - Antagonistic force: - A presence that emerges around their sleep and their watching. - No big, formal name. Maybe a stray nickname (“passenger”) from an online post; maybe a phrase Mara once heard. It never becomes branded lore. - Behavior (implied, not fully codified): - It circles intimate pairs. - It’s interested in the border between sleep/wake, watcher/watched. - It likes when one pretends—to sleep, to trust, to be okay. - It studies faces. It presses against consciousness. It nudges cruelty. - It may have touched Mara before; it may have bled into Ethan long before he admits it. - There are patterns and guesses, but no authoritative rulebook. That uncertainty is part of the horror. - Plot and emotional spine: - Starting from: Ethan catches Mara staring when she thinks he’s sleeping. - Small repetitions and oddness accumulate. - Ethan toggles between concern and condescension; Mara toggles between apology, fear, irritation, and belief that this is “like last time.” - They both lie: to each other, to themselves, to the reader (via Ethan). - Gradually it becomes unclear who is watching and who is being watched. - By the end, something in Ethan has shifted. The closing image echoes the opening but is emotionally heavier and less neat: we understand both the supernatural implication and how Ethan’s own flaws made him a perfect host. - Voice and style: - First-person past tense, tight on Ethan’s perceptions, but: - Allow slips where his narration rewrites events more kindly than they likely were. - Occasionally let through a line of thought that feels a touch too cold or collective, hinting at an intrusion. - Style: direct, readable, concrete. Less “poetic horror monologue,” more lucid recollection that grows disturbed. - Use specific, mundane details (the space heater hum, her chipped mug, their recurring argument topics) as anchors to ground the surreal elements. - Tone: - Slow, creeping unease; never fully bombastic. - A few sharp, frightening moments, but mostly relational dread and the wrongness of being watched. - Leave some questions open (especially about the entity’s origin and exact mechanics), but make the emotional and narrative arc clear. - What to aim for: - Character-driven horror: every supernatural escalation also strains their relationship. - Messy, believable arguments; imperfect attempts at help; unheroic impulses. - Ambiguity where it hurts (who’s at fault? how much is illness vs. intrusion?). - A conclusion that’s chilling and thematically coherent, without a lore info-dump or moral sermon. - What to avoid: - Over-designed mythos with rules like a game manual. - Over-clean pacing where each chapter is a perfectly labeled “beat.” - Reliance on clichés: priests, Latin incantations, tech always capturing perfect evidence, cardboard “crazy exorcism survivor” backstory. - Overly neat twist; we’ll keep the echoed imagery but let it sit inside a complicated emotional reality. This is an 8-chapter piece (~1000 words each), so each chapter gets a focused move: one or two key developments and a shift in either the relationship, the haunting, or Ethan’s internal state. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1: The First Time (We Talk About) - Open with the line: “I caught her staring at me again. She thought I’d been sleeping.” - Present moment: - Night. New house. Ethan wakes in that half-way space. - Mara’s silhouette is propped on one elbow, eyes on his face. - He keeps still, watching her watch him for several seconds; she is very still, unblinking. - When he moves, she flops down, pretends to be asleep. - Morning: - He teases lightly. She shrugs it off: “Zoned out. Sorry. New place.” - Brief, human conversation: unpacking, shitty plumbing, her upcoming telehealth therapy. - Subtle tension: - Ethan internally: “I moved us out here so it’d be quiet for her,” but hints of resentment (commute, loneliness). - Mentions, obliquely, “the thing in her past” he doesn’t like to think about. - End beat: - That night he lies awake longer, facing her, curious if she’ll do it again. - Quiet admission: he doesn’t yet know if he’s more annoyed or unsettled. Chapter 2: Patterns, Fights, Avoidance - Time jump of days/weeks; we see: - Multiple instances of waking to her looking at him: from bed edge, from doorway, sometimes so close he feels her breath. - Sometimes she seems dazed; sometimes almost intent, as if checking for something. - Ethan’s reactions: - Starts with jokes; moves to mild frustration: “You’re freaking me out.” - Internal mix: guilt (is this her anxiety? meds?), irritation (“I need sleep”), faint fear he labels “irrational.” - Friction: - Small argument where he clumsily invokes her past hospitalization; she goes cold. - She insists she doesn’t remember watching him like that. - First slip in reality: - One morning she says, “You do it too sometimes,” and he laughs it off; he doesn’t remember, so he edits it in his mind as her defensiveness. - End beat: - Ethan, half in spite, sets his phone to record audio one night “just to show her she’s walking around.” - He tells himself it’s rational. It’s also surveillance. Chapter 3: Glitches and Confessions (Half) - Playback: - Mostly mundane night sounds. - Then: a faint whisper right near the mic, voice like Mara’s overlaid with something flat: “…he’s almost there.” - Ethan replays, convinces himself it’s audio pareidolia. Doesn’t show her. - Another episode: - He wakes “suddenly” in the doorway in the small hours, bare feet cold, looking back at the bed where Mara sleeps. - Tells himself he must’ve gotten up to pee and forgotten. - Day unease: - Mara, anxious, asks if he’s angry; says, “I feel like something’s waiting again.” - Hints of her past: - “There was… watching, before,” she says. “It got bad.” Won’t give details yet. - Tension rises: - He suggests increasing her meds or seeing a better doctor; she hears only “broken.” - They fight. He says something crueler than he reports verbatim. - End beat: - That night, as he pretends to be asleep, she murmurs: “Please don’t fake it. It notices.” - He doesn’t ask what she means. Chapter 4: The Night He Sees Himself - He sets up his old webcam on a shelf, angled at the bed. More serious now but frames it to himself as data-gathering. - The night: - Fragmented sleep. Sense of being watched. The weight of someone sitting on the mattress. - He forces himself to keep his eyes shut, counting breaths, petty determination to “catch her.” - A heavy pause right above his face. Cold fingertips almost touching his eyelids. - Hard cut: wakes at dawn, heart racing. - Reviewing footage: - The recording is short; it stopped around 2 a.m. - In the captured fragment: Mara sitting up abruptly, then both of them lying still. Then, just before the stop, Ethan himself sits up, turns his head toward the camera, eyes reflecting dim light—expression blankly hungry. - It’s only a second. It could be artifacts. He closes the file quickly. - Daytime: - Mara’s on edge, drinking too much coffee, says he “wasn’t you” last night. That he stood by the bed and said things she won’t repeat. - Ethan decides she’s mixing dream and memory. Also, he doesn’t fully want to know. - End beat: - Under strain, she blurts a more direct echo of her past: an ex who used to watch her sleep, then… something violent, then white rooms, doctors. - She says, “This feels the same. Like it’s waiting for you to leave your body open.” - Ethan’s narration: he’s unnerved, but also quietly offended to be dropped into her old script. Chapter 5: If You Pretend - We focus on one pivotal night. - Mara asks him: - “If you wake up and I’m standing there, just say my name. Don’t lie still and watch. Don’t pretend. That’s when it… uses you.” - She struggles to say “uses,” like it’s superstition she half-believes, half-fears. - Ethan’s mindset: - He both cares and is irritated by what sounds like magical thinking. - Tells himself testing it is rational; he can prove it’s just sleepwalking. - Night: - He wakes to the sense of her standing over him. Decides consciously to keep still, feign sleep. - Long, quiet moment. Her breath close. A whisper in his ear that doesn’t sound like a warning: “There you are.” - An intense, invasive sensation pressing at his awareness (described physically, not metaphysically explained). - Blackout—not dreamlike montage, just a jump. - Morning: - Scratches on the inside of his forearm he doesn’t recall making. - Mara’s got a bruise on her shoulder; she’s distant, won’t meet his eyes. - She flinches when he touches her. - Discrepancy: - She says he stood over her for “a long time” in the night; he denies it. - He discovers the webcam unplugged, cord on the floor. Neither of them “remembers” doing it. - End beat: - Ethan finally searches online; finds scattered posts describing partners staring, thresholds of sleep, something that “gets in when you pretend.” No consensus, some obviously delusional, but a phrase or two rings too true. - He’s unsettled enough not to show Mara what he found. Chapter 6: Past Bleeding In - Their relationship is fraying. - Little scenes: she won’t fall asleep first; he pretends everything’s fine, then snaps. - Money/job stress intrudes—emails, missed calls. Real-life pressure mixing with horror. - Mara opens up more (but not cleanly): - This comes out during a fight, not as a neat monologue. - She accuses him of repeating her ex’s patterns: doubting, filming, diagnosing. - Says: with her ex, it started with watching. Then words in his mouth that weren’t his. Then what he did to her (not described in gore, but clear and awful). - She says she thought it was her fault, or an illness, but now: “It likes people like you. People who think they’re above it.” - Ethan’s narration: - Defensive, half-cruel: he frames her story as “the script she knows,” suspects she’s fitting him into it. - Yet he can’t ignore the overlap with his own recent gaps. - Another night fragment: - He wakes in the hallway, just outside the bedroom, watching the dark for no clear reason. - He hears Mara whimper his name from bed—but feels no urgency. That lack of urgency is wrong. - End beat: - He proposes a practical solution: - Separate sleep for a bit. Routine. Light on. No more games of pretending. - It sounds reasonable. Underneath: an experiment, and an avoidance. Chapter 7: The Separation (That Isn’t) - They set rules: - Mara sleeps on the couch with a lamp on. - Ethan in the bedroom; doors open. - If either finds the other watching, wake them immediately. - Night, from Ethan’s perspective: - He struggles to sleep, mind racing, body heavy. - Feels watched even alone in the room. - Half-dreams of standing by the couch, studying the flutter of Mara’s eyelids. - There’s a disorienting back-and-forth: he’s in bed hearing floorboards creak; he’s on the floor beside the couch; he’s looking down at himself. - Important: keep it grounded in feeling, not labeled as “astral” or explained. - Mara’s terror: - We glimpse only through what Ethan records after the fact: - She says he came to her, stood over her, whispering things he shouldn’t know about her past. - She says his face “slipped” between his and the ex’s. - Ethan reports this like it’s crazy—yet the reader sees cracks in his denial. - Flash of violence: - A broken glass on the floor, a cut on Ethan’s bare foot. - His hazy recollection of Mara’s shoulder under his hand, too tight. - End beat: - He wakes back in bed near dawn, feeling oddly clear, as if a headache has finally broken. - Hears Mara crying quietly in the living room, saying, “It chose,” which he pretends not to hear. Chapter 8: After - Quiet tone; no big exorcism. The horror is in how settled things feel. - Morning: - Ethan is calm, efficient. He cleans up the broken glass, makes coffee. - He narrates Mara’s behavior: jumpy, watching him like he’s dangerous. He frames it as “her episode.” - Subtle shifts: - His thoughts are a shade colder, more detached. - He uses her past (and last night’s fear) to justify gently taking more control: - “Maybe we should talk to Dr. Haynes again.” - “You scared yourself, Mare.” - Gaslighting with concern. It feels practiced. - Mara confronts him: - Says, “It’s you. You know that, right?” - He recounts the conversation as if she’s fragile, but lets slip tiny tells: - He enjoys how her accusation proves she’s “not well,” which makes his narrative stronger. - Tie-back to the prompt: - That night, she finally falls asleep first, exhausted from crying. - He lies beside her, awake, watching her face in the dim light. - We recall the opening dynamic, but inverted. - Final turns (keep them lean, not over-clever): - He notes how peaceful she looks. How vulnerable. - She stirs once, opens her eyes to see him inches away, watching. - She flinches; he murmurs something soothing. She closes her eyes again—pretends to sleep, maybe. - Last lines (in spirit, not literal from this outline): - He admits he keeps watching even after she thinks he’s turned away. - A quiet, unsettling echo of the original prompt, without announcing the twist: - Something like: “She thinks I’m sleeping. It’s easier that way.” - Leave us with: - The sense that whatever was staring out of Mara is now comfortably behind Ethan’s eyes. - And also that Ethan—as he always was, rational, controlling, half-cruel—made a perfect place for it. This plan keeps the story tight, grounded, and emotionally driven, with the possession horror emerging from the very human dynamics of watching, doubting, resenting, and pretending—not from a tidy demon rulebook. The original prompt remains the spine: the wrongness of that stare between two people who share a bed, and what it lets in.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Ethan Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws - Age/History: - Early 30s. Grew up in a mid-sized town, oldest of two boys. - Parents: solidly middle class; father quiet and practical, mother anxious but efficient. Emotional stuff was managed through doing things, fixing things, planning, not talking. - Went into communications/IT—remote job in a marketing/tech-adjacent role. Good at systems, frameworks, “making sense of the mess” in other people’s projects. - Personality: - Competent, methodical, mildly controlling. The one who reads reviews for an hour before buying a toaster. - Thinks of himself as patient and logical, especially “compared to most people.” - Avoids emotional mess by reframing it as a problem to solve: scheduling therapy, researching meds, adjusting routines. - Needs to be the reasonable one; can’t stand feeling stupid or irrational. - Has a dry sense of humor. Uses it to defuse tension, then gets prickly when it doesn’t work. - Flaws (with anchored examples): - Emotional arrogance: - Believes he understands Mara’s issues better than she does because he’s read about them. - Example: During a real-life argument about her fear of the house, he catches himself thinking, “God, I should invoice for this session.” - Conflict avoidance: - Lets resentment fester instead of confronting early. - Example: Resents that the move to the cheap house was “for her,” but never explicitly negotiated it; it’s a silent tally mark. - Selective empathy: - Very kind when she’s fragile in “obvious” ways (panic attack), but impatient when her distress is complex or implicates him. - Dishonesty-lite: - Half-truths about money (he downplays debt), about how isolated the new place is (“It’s only 20 minutes,” it’s 40). - Once had an emotional flirtation with a coworker online; technically nothing “happened,” but he knows it’d hurt Mara. - Needs control: - The decision to record her is as much about owning the narrative as it is about helping. - Idiosyncrasies: - Over-explains tech stuff when nervous. - Keeps a mental to-do list constantly running; crossing things off calms him. - Mildly superstitious in private but hates himself for it: - If he reads about a haunting at 2 a.m., he’ll close the tab and immediately google a skeptical debunk, just to “balance it.” - Low-level insomnia: scrolls on his phone at night, checks email at inappropriate hours. - Eats standing at the counter; drinks too much coffee, forgets water. Physicality & how he moves - Appearance: - 5'10", runner’s build gone slightly soft from desk work. - Brown hair kept short because it’s less maintenance; stubble that hovers between “deliberate” and “forgot.” - Wears hoodies and T-shirts from tech conferences; jeans; practical sneakers. - How he carries himself: - Tends to lean in doorways, arms crossed—reads as defensive even when he thinks he’s being casual. - Hands often occupied: mug, phone, dish towel, something to avoid just standing there. - When agitated but trying to stay calm, he presses thumb to the bridge of his nose or rubs his eyelids. - Interaction with the world: - Talks to appliances under his breath when they malfunction. - Notices and mentally catalogs small defects in the house (drafts, warped doorframes), tells himself he’ll “get to it.” Motives, allegiances, relationships - Motives: - Wants to be a good partner and the stable center of the relationship. - Wants proof that things are manageable, definable, fixable. - Wants to not be “the bad guy” in anyone’s story. - Unconsciously: wants Mara’s issues to be solvable via his competence—validating his identity. - Allegiances: - To Mara, genuinely—but conditional in ways he won’t admit. - To his self-image as rational, reliable. He’ll protect that over uncomfortable truths. - Relationships: - With Mara: love plus caretaker dynamic. He partly chose her because loving her allows him to be necessary. - With family: calls his mom weekly, keeps things surface-level. Rarely discusses Mara’s mental health in detail; doesn’t want “interference.” - Few close friends; a work friend or two he messages more intimately than he should, but frames as banter. Voice: sample quotes / internal monologue - “I wasn’t spying. I was collecting information. That’s different. Spying is emotional.” - “She’s staring at me like I’ve already done something I need to apologize for.” - “We moved out here for quiet. That’s what I tell people. The rest—the cheaper rent, the way she flinched at sirens—I don’t put in the marketing copy.” - “If this is sleepwalking, there’s a protocol. If it’s not—well, there’s still probably a protocol. I just haven’t found the right PDF yet.” # Mara Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws - Age/History: - Early 30s. Grew up in a coastal city; moved around a lot in her 20s—roommates, partners, precarious creative gigs. - Formerly did freelance illustration and design; now does occasional commissions but struggles with consistency. - Mid-20s: bad relationship with an older guy (Nate) who became controlling. In that period: insomnia, feeling watched, weird incidents she half-remembers; ended with a violent episode. She was hospitalized afterward for what was labeled “a stress-induced psychotic break.” - Personality: - Warm when she feels safe; quick dry wit; makes weird little jokes in grocery store aisles. - Introspective to a fault. Overthinks her own motives, apologizes for existing. - Weather-sensitive mood: grey days sink her; bright winter sun can lift her for hours. - Uneasy truce with her brain chemistry; she’s done the therapy, read the books. - Flaws (with anchored examples): - Self-blame: - Reflexively assumes she’s the problem if someone’s unhappy. - Example: If Ethan is quiet because of work, she apologizes for “being too much lately.” - Withholding: - Hides symptoms or fears until they explode. - Example: She doesn’t tell Ethan the staring has started for her too—she wakes to him over her—because she’s terrified it sounds “crazy again.” - Passive sabotage: - Might “forget” to schedule an appointment or “lose” a prescription because she both fears and needs help. - Sharpened edges: - When cornered, can get cutting. She’ll bring up things Ethan said months ago with eerie precision. - Magical thinking: - Knows logically it doesn’t make sense, but clings to rules/rituals (like not pretending to sleep) because they feel like control. - Idiosyncrasies: - Collects ugly-cute mugs from thrift stores; has one chipped yellow one she clings to. - Draws in the margins of everything: receipts, junk mail, the moving box labels. - Hums tunelessly when anxious; stops mid-hum when she catches herself. - Sleeps with one foot out from under the blanket “to prove there’s nothing under the bed,” a leftover childhood habit. - Leaves lights on in hallways; Ethan goes around turning them off. Physicality & how she moves - Appearance: - 5'5", slight but with a bit of softness; has that underfed-artist look when stressed. - Dark hair, usually in a messy bun; strands escape and frame her face. - Pale easily; dark circles under eyes when she’s not sleeping. - Hoodie and leggings person at home; bare feet, chipped nail polish. - How she carries herself: - Shoulders slightly rounded, like she’s ready to make herself smaller. - When relaxed, moves with loose, distracted grace; when on edge, every sound flicks her gaze. - Runs fingers over doorframes and walls as she moves through the house, as if checking they’re solid. - Interaction with the world: - Notices textures: the grainy paint, the way air moves in a room. - Very attuned to other people’s micro-reactions; reads tension fast, often incorrectly to her own detriment. Motives, allegiances, relationships - Motives: - Wants proof she’s not “broken beyond repair.” - Wants Ethan to believe her without having to perform sanity or insanity. - Wants to feel safe in a home, a body, a relationship. - Wants whatever happened “before” to never repeat—and fears she might be recreating it. - Allegiances: - To Ethan, strongly; she’s grateful and guilty about that. - To her sense (however shaky) that something outside her is real and dangerous. - To the younger version of herself she failed to protect; she’s more stubborn now on her own behalf, sometimes in self-sabotaging ways. - Relationships: - With Ethan: love, dependency, gratitude, resentment. She knows he sees her as fragile sometimes and both hates and uses that. - With her family: strained. They were supportive but emphasize medication/compliance and “stability”; she feels watched by their worry. - Few close friends left; isolation amplifies her reliance on Ethan. Voice: sample quotes / internal monologue - “Please don’t make that face. The ‘I’m being reasonable about your brain’ face. It makes me want to set something on fire.” - “It’s not a ghost, Ethan. I’m not that basic. I just…I know what it feels like when someone’s looking at you and they’re not…home.” - “If I tell him I saw him by the bed again, he’ll hear ‘episode’ instead of ‘evidence.’ So I don’t tell him. And then I’m the one keeping secrets.” - “I remember everyone telling me last time that there was no one in the room. I also remember his eyes. Both things can’t be true.” # The Presence (as character, lightly sketched) Note: It won’t speak in big monologues; but to write it believably, we need a sense of its “personality.” Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws - It’s less a “demon with lore” than a recurring behavioral pattern in the dark. - What it does: - It lingers around intimate sleeping humans. - Drawn to watching, to pretending, to the tension between vulnerability and denial. - It doesn’t invent violence out of nowhere; it leans on what’s latent. - Personality-ish traits: - Curious, patient, clinical. - Amused by human rituals (rules, meds, cameras) that pretend to control it. - Preferential: likes minds with structure (Ethan), histories with fractures (Mara). - Flaws: - Not omnipotent; needs their choices. It can be thwarted or slowed. - A bit vain: repeats certain patterns because they’ve worked before. Physicality & interaction - Rarely directly visible; more felt: - The extra half-second of someone’s stare. - The way footsteps stop outside a door and stand too long. - The sensation of intent hovering just above a sleeping face. - When glimpsed, it’s always through someone’s eyes or behavior; no separate monster shot. Motives, allegiances, relationships - Motives: - To inhabit, to persist, to refine. - To push people to that edge where they can’t tell if they did it or “it” did. - Allegiances: - None. Though it tends to ride with whoever is most useful. - Relationship to Ethan/Mara: - With Mara: old familiarity. She’s seen what it does; that makes her both threat and lure. - With Ethan: project; admires his rational defenses, enjoys eroding them. Voice: sample “intrusions” (not spoken aloud, but as if it had a voice) - “You’re already halfway here. I’m only finishing the sentence.” - “She taught you the rules. You broke them. That’s not on me.” - “Look at how carefully he explains it away. I barely have to touch him.” If you’d like, next step I can do is write a brief “test scene” of Ethan and Mara arguing about the staring, to ensure their voices and dynamics feel grounded and human before we commit to drafting chapter-by-chapter.

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I caught her staring at me again. She thought I’d been sleeping. The thing that woke me wasn’t a sound so much as a pressure, like a thumb resting lightly between my eyebrows. My body had done the calculation before my head: dark, quiet, Mara’s slow breathing, the tick of the shitty baseboard heater in the corner. New house noises. Then that other thing—awareness. I kept my eyes mostly shut, lashes a thin curtain. The digital alarm clock on my side glowed 3:19 in radioactive red through the slit. Our bedroom was a rectangle of almost-black. The streetlamp down the hill threw up a faint, jaundiced wash through the thin curtains. Mara was on her side, propped on one elbow, facing me. I could make out the pale oval of her face, the tangle of dark hair falling forward. She wasn’t blinking. Her eyes were fixed right where mine would be if I were asleep. I stayed still. Counted three of her breaths. Four. Five. I’d been half dreaming when I woke, and my brain kept trying to paste pieces of that onto what I was seeing. In the dream I’d been underwater. In our actual bedroom, oxygen clung thick and stale. She didn’t move. Her fingers were curled near her mouth like she’d frozen halfway through biting a nail. The posture was wrong for sleep. Too precise. Too attentive. On the eighth breath I twitched my hand like I was just now waking, did an exaggerated little shift on the pillow. When I opened my eyes properly, she was on her back, arm flung over her face like she’d been that way all night. “Babe?” I croaked. My voice came out rough and too loud. She made a muzzy sound. “Mm. What time’sit?” “Three.” I watched her. She squinted at the ceiling, then rolled toward me, eyes gummy with pretend-sleep. “You okay?” she asked. “Yeah,” I said. My heart was beating too fast for yeah. “Did you… never mind.” “What?” “Nothing. Just… new house. Weird dreams.” She pushed a hand into my chest, a light shove. “Stop stealing my brand,” she mumbled, and tucked her face into my shoulder. I let it go. You have to pick the right moments with her. I wrapped an arm around her and listened to the quiet for a long time after that, until the heater clicked and groaned again and the feeling of her eyes on me finally faded. — In the morning Mara acted like someone halfway through a jet lag she hadn’t earned. She shuffled around the kitchen in my old college hoodie and socks, hair in a lopsided knot, staring down the empty coffee maker as if it had done something personal. “It’s broken,” she announced, after hitting the brew button twice. “It’s not plugged in,” I said. I reached past her and flipped the hidden switch on the outlet. “There’s a little switch, remember?” “This house is a maze of secrets,” she said. But it came out flat. She’d been quiet since we’d moved in a week ago. Not unhappy, exactly. Just… muted. Less of the little sideways comments, the stupid puns. More staring out the window at the black trees on the hill. The place was a bargain. Two bedrooms, crooked porch, sloping yard, old farmhouse bones with too many half-finished “updates.” Cheap because it was too far out for most people and the landlord didn’t want to fix the wiring properly. I’d framed it as “peaceful” when I found the listing. She’d said, “It looks like somewhere a missing poster starts,” but she’d smiled when she said it. She poured coffee and sat on the counter, bare legs swinging. The mug was one of hers—a chipped yellow thing with a faded cartoon possum. She always picked the ugliest mugs in any thrift store; she said it was a rescue operation. “You’re staring,” I said. She blinked. “At my savior? Yes. Thank you for electricity.” “No, earlier. In bed. You were… watching me.” Her hand tightened around the possum’s face. “When?” “Like three-something. I woke up. You were perched over me like a gargoyle.” She snorted, but it sounded forced. “Sexy.” “I’m serious. You looked… out of it.” “I don’t remember.” She took a sip. “Probably just woke up. I do that. I’ve done that. It’s not—” She cut herself off. Not like last time hung there, unsaid. “It was just weird,” I said, softer. “You kind of freaked me out.” “I said I don’t remember,” she said. The snap of it surprised both of us. Her shoulders hunched. “Sorry. I just… new bed, new sounds. I probably float in and out. You know.” I did know. I’d read about it. Parasomnias, micro-awakenings. Her history in neat bullet points on a patient portal. I reached out and brushed a crumb from her knee. “Okay,” I said. “No big deal.” She looked at me then, properly. Pupils large in the morning light. “Were my eyes open?” “Yeah.” “Creepy,” she said, with her old voice. “Sorry.” “There are worse things to wake up to.” She rolled her eyes, but the corner of her mouth twitched. — The rest of the day was normal in the small, slightly brittle way that our normal had become. I set up my laptop on the rickety dining table that tilted toward the window and tried to get through client emails. The cell service was spotty; the Wi-Fi modem blinked like it was pleading for forgiveness. Mara unpacked another box of kitchen stuff, moving slower than usual, stopping to inspect a spider in the corner and escort it outside in a mug. At lunch, she floated the idea of driving back into the city sometime to see her friend Lena. “Just for a day,” she said. “I don’t want to become a ghost.” “We just got here,” I said. “Maybe give it a month. Let your brain adjust.” “My brain isn’t a pet,” she said. Another flicker of spark. “You don’t have to talk about it like it just needs a new environment and enrichment toys.” “I didn’t—” “I know.” She kissed my cheek on her way past. “I know.” There was no dramatic thunderclap, no flock of crows. Just a long afternoon of loading passwords into my browser and listening to the house settle. Once, a door eased itself open down the hall and both of us froze. Mara laughed too loudly. “Slanty,” she said. “Charming slanty.” When the sun went down, it went fast. One minute the yard was just dull; the next it was gone, a rectangle of black pressed against the glass. The porch light the landlord had promised flickered and died when I tried it. “We can get a motion sensor,” I said. “We can get a different house,” Mara said, but she was leaning into me on the couch, feet tucked under my thigh. A streaming show played, all neon and quips. She wasn’t really watching. By ten-thirty she was yawning. “Old lady hour,” she said. “I’m going to try to sleep before my brain remembers it hates me.” “I’ll be in soon,” I said. “Just finishing this email thing.” She lingered a second, looking at me like she was about to say something else. Then she shook her head and padded down the hallway. The bedroom light came on, then off. I stared at my laptop screen until the words blurred, then closed it. In the dark reflection of the black screen I saw my own face, pale, tired, hollow-eyed. I knew better than to google anything about sleep disorders at night. It was like cutting my palms and sticking them in aquarium water. In bed, Mara was already on her side, facing away, breathing evenly. I slid in behind her. She made a small sound, backed into me. “You okay?” I asked. “Mm. It’s quiet,” she said. “That’s good.” “Too quiet,” she added, almost inaudible. I kissed the back of her neck. “I’m here.” She put her hand over mine. “I know.” Eventually her fingers slackened. Her breaths lengthened. I lay awake, listening past them. The heater ticked. The fridge hummed in the other room. Somewhere outside, something small moved through dry leaves. It wasn’t until my own thoughts had gone syrup-slow that I realized I was waiting to feel that pressure again, that sense of her eyes on me. Waiting, stupidly, to catch her. It didn’t come. Sometime after two, I slipped under. When I jolted awake at 3:19, heart punching my ribs for no reason I could name, my first instinct was not to move. Old habit: observe first. The room was dark. The alarm clock glowed. Mara’s breathing was steady beside me. I kept my lids low and watched her. She lay on her back now, face angled toward me. The faint light traced her features, making her eyes look like two black hollows. I couldn’t tell if they were open. I couldn’t tell if she was watching. I lay there, very still, and for a moment it felt like we were both faking sleep, each of us waiting to see what the other would do.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This opening chapter effectively establishes the psychological horror premise while grounding it in believable character dynamics. The writing follows both the prompt and the chapter plan faithfully, opening with the exact required line and building the unsettling atmosphere of nocturnal watching between intimate partners. The characterization is notably strong. Ethan emerges as rationally-minded but subtly controlling, demonstrated through small details like his condescending explanation of the coffee maker outlet and his framing of Mara's mental health needs ("Let your brain adjust"). His internal voice feels authentic - the mix of genuine concern and mild irritation rings true. Mara is portrayed with complexity beyond the "fragile girlfriend" trope; her sharp retorts ("My brain isn't a pet") and defensive humor reveal someone with agency despite her vulnerabilities. The prose generally maintains good tension and atmosphere. Concrete details anchor the supernatural unease in mundane reality - the "radioactive red" alarm clock, the chipped possum mug, the house's quirky electrical issues. The author resists overwrought horror clichés, instead building dread through subtle wrongness and relational tension. However, there are moments where the writing becomes unnecessarily ornate. The metaphor comparing late-night googling to "cutting my palms and sticking them in aquarium water" feels forced and draws attention to itself rather than serving the narrative. Some descriptions edge toward purple prose, particularly in the atmospheric passages. The dialogue feels natural and reveals character efficiently. The morning kitchen scene particularly succeeds in showing their dynamic through subtext - Ethan's gentle condescension, Mara's defensive deflection, and the unspoken weight of her "last time." The pacing effectively builds unease without rushing toward supernatural revelation. The chapter ends on an appropriately ambiguous note that mirrors the opening, maintaining uncertainty about who is watching whom. The writing demonstrates strong technical competence and psychological insight, though it occasionally overreaches with its metaphorical language. The characterization and relationship dynamics feel authentic and complex, providing a solid foundation for the horror to come. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 19

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The second time I caught her, it was almost worse because I’d been waiting for it. A few days had passed. We’d stacked more boxes in corners, hung two crooked prints in the hallway to pretend we lived here on purpose. I’d convinced myself I’d overreacted that first night. Hypnagogic hallucinations. Carryover from stress. My brain loves vocabulary; if I can name a thing, I can box it. Then at 4:06 a.m., unnamed, I woke with my tongue dry and my hands already in fists. The room was darker than it should’ve been. The red of the clock barely made a dent. I kept still. My eyes were almost, but not quite, closed. Mara was sitting up. She was on my side of the bed, body angled toward me. Her knees were drawn up, blanket pooled around her waist. Her spine straight, shoulders relaxed, like someone watching a slow movie. Her head tilted, eyes pointed at my face. I watched three of her breaths. Four. I counted up to ten. She didn’t move. My ribs started to ache. I twitched suddenly, a fake jerk awake. “Wha—?” I made my voice thick. Her head snapped away so fast her hair swung. In the same motion she let herself fall back to the pillow, back turned to me, like a marionette whose strings had been cut. It should’ve been funny. It wasn’t. “Mara.” No answer. “Mara.” She mumbled into the pillow, “Wha’s wrong?” “You were sitting up,” I said. “Staring at me.” “Don’t think so,” she slurred. “G’night, babe.” She sounded exactly like someone dragged from deep sleep. She also sounded like someone doing a bad impression of someone dragged from deep sleep. I lay there, heart tripping, looking at the curve of her back. There’s a threshold where you either wake your partner all the way and interrogate them at four in the morning or you decide to not be that guy. I let it go. Outside, the dark pressed up against the windows. The house made small arthritic pops. Eventually I drifted off again. — The next morning, the kitchen smelled like burnt toast. “I did not stare at you,” Mara said, before I’d said anything at all. I froze with my hand on the cupboard. “I didn’t say—” “You’re making the face,” she said. She stood at the counter in my T-shirt, barefoot, mauling a blackened slice of bread. “The little furrow right here.” She tapped between my eyes. “Like your brain’s building a case.” “I woke up,” I said. “You were sitting up. You dropped like a sniper called your name.” She chewed. “Dramatic.” “You scared the shit out of me.” “It’s probably—” She stopped. Flicked a crumb off the counter. “I’ve done weird sleep stuff before.” “Yeah,” I said carefully. “Don’t,” she said. “Don’t what?” “Don’t sound like a brochure.” “I’m just saying, it fits. People sit up. They talk. They stare. Parasomnias. You read the pamphlets.” “And you read all the supplementary material, I know.” She breathed out through her nose. “I don’t remember sitting up. I barely remember sleeping.” “That’s the point,” I said. “You don’t remember doing it.” “It’s not like last time,” she said, sharp. “I didn’t say it was.” “You thought it.” I opened the cupboard just to have something to do with my hands. “Two nights, that’s all. I’m just… watching.” “Cool,” she said. “That’s fun.” “Hey.” I reached for her, but she stepped sideways, out of reach. “I’m allowed to be weird in my sleep without it being a referendum on my sanity.” She grabbed her mug, the yellow possum, sloshed coffee. “I was trying not to make a thing of it. But if you want it to be a thing, we can make it a thing.” I should have backed off. Instead I said, “Pretending it’s nothing didn’t work out so great before.” Her jaw tightened. “Wow.” “I’m not attacking you,” I said. “I’m worried.” She knocked back coffee like it burned. “I know you are. You’re always worried. You’re very responsible.” She set the mug down too hard; coffee jumped. “Next time I’ll film myself drooling so you can review the tape.” “That’s not fair,” I said. It came out smaller than I wanted. “I’m going to shower,” she said. “If I levitate, I’ll yell.” She left me standing there with two slices of bread and the memory of her face when I said before. I watched her disappear down the hallway, shoulders hunched, and thought: great. Nailed it. — Work did not cooperate with my goal of Not Being Weird. The modem dropped the video call three times. A client wanted last-minute copy changes that made no sense. The second bedroom that was supposed to be my office still smelled faintly of dust and whatever the previous tenant cooked. I answered emails and, every so often, mentally replayed Mara upright in the dark. At noon, I found her at the dining table with her sketchbook, a cold mug by her elbow. She was drawing small, repeated eyes in the margin of a grocery list. “Hey,” I said too gently. She closed the sketchbook. “Hey.” “I’m sorry,” I said. “About before. I was an ass.” “You were a concerned ass.” She tried to smile. “I know you mean well. I just…” “Don’t want me keeping score,” I said. “Yeah.” She turned the mug slowly. “I don’t want to be a problem you’re managing.” “You’re not.” “Sometimes I am.” She met my eyes. “I’m trying really hard to only be myself.” “You are yourself,” I said. “The weird sleep is just…” “My brain doing circus tricks,” she said. “It’s fine.” She pushed hair off her forehead. “If it gets bad, I’ll tell you. Promise.” “Okay,” I said. I wanted to believe her. “If you ever feel… off. We can call Dr. Haynes.” “Yeah,” she said quickly. “Totally.” Quick yes. Noted. “You know,” she said, softer, “you stare too.” I laughed. “Do I?” “In the morning. Sometimes I wake up and you’re just looking at me, like a creep.” “I’m admiring,” I said. “That’s what all creeps say.” “What, I’m not allowed to look at my girlfriend?” “You’re allowed,” she said. “Just saying, maybe I’m mirroring.” She shrugged, but her eyes were on me, gauging. “I haven’t been sitting up at three a.m. like an exorcist extra,” I said. “Maybe you just don’t remember,” she said lightly. The words hung a beat too long. Then she shook her head. “Sorry. Dark joke.” “It was a little dark,” I said. She slid off the chair and came around to kiss my temple. “We’re okay,” she said. It sounded like she was trying to convince herself. — That night we went to bed earlier, both pretending not to be doing it for any reason. Mara curled on her side facing the wall. I lay on my back staring at the ceiling fan, which ticked every third rotation. The heater coughed. Somewhere under the house something scrabbled—mouse or pipes or the bones of the previous tenant, my brain suggested helpfully. “Ethan?” she said in the dark. “Yeah.” “Thank you for… moving here with me,” she said. “I know this place is—” She waved a hand; I heard air move. “It’s a lot.” “It’s fine,” I said. “Rent is cheap. We have a yard. I get to pretend I’m a rugged rural man.” She made a sleepy sound that might’ve been a laugh. “You’re not rugged.” “I am very rugged. I know how to reset a breaker.” “Mm. Hot,” she murmured. “Rugged.” “I’d move to a cave for you,” I said, half joking, half not. “Please don’t,” she said. “I’d draw on the walls and they’d medicate me for it.” “Go to sleep,” I said. She reached back blindly until she found my hand and squeezed it once. Then she settled. Later, when her breathing had gone slow and even, I rolled onto my side to look at her. The faint spill of light from the hallway made a soft line along her cheekbone. She looked younger, like the photos from before I met her. Less braced. I watched her for a while. Not in a creepy way, I told myself. Just… appreciating. Making sure she was really sleeping. That the shiver in her fingers was only a dream. I must have drifted, because the next thing I knew I was jerked awake by an absence. The heater had cut off mid-cycle. The fridge had gone quiet. It was a vacuum of sound. Mara lay on her back now. Her head was turned toward me. Her eyes were open. No blink. No shift. My lungs forgot how. I didn’t move. Neither did she. We lay there like that, maybe six inches apart, both of us pretending—at least I was—that we were still asleep. My vision prickled. My heartbeat was in my ears. I told myself: say her name. Just say it, wake her up for real. I didn’t. I lay there, and she lay there, and I thought: if I move first, I lose something. I don’t know what. I just know it feels like a game I didn’t agree to play. After a long, slow minute, her eyelids slid down. Her chest rose deeper. The heater ticked back on with a clunk. “Jesus,” I whispered, too quiet for her to hear. She didn’t react. In the morning, over cereal and burnt toast, she said, “See? No levitation. You can relax.” “I caught you staring again,” I said, before I could stop myself. She flinched, barely. “I told you,” she said. “I don’t remember.” And for the first time, I wondered if that was actually true. Or if we were both lying, equally, in different directions.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively builds on the established premise while deepening both character development and psychological tension. The writing demonstrates strong craft in several key areas. The character work is particularly strong. Ethan's voice remains consistent with his established profile - analytical, well-meaning but controlling, with subtle defensive mechanisms. His internal monologue ("My brain loves vocabulary; if I can name a thing, I can box it") perfectly captures his need to rationalize and control. Mara's responses feel authentic to someone who has experienced mental health stigma - her sharp defensiveness ("Don't sound like a brochure") and her attempt to deflect with humor show psychological realism. The dialogue is naturalistic and serves multiple purposes simultaneously, revealing character, advancing plot, and building tension. The argument feels like a real couple's fight, with both parties saying hurtful things they don't quite mean. Lines like "You're very responsible" land as both acknowledgment and subtle criticism. The horror elements are well-integrated into the relationship dynamics rather than feeling grafted on. The mutual staring creates genuine unease, and the ambiguity around who is lying or misremembering serves the possession theme effectively. The ending moment where both characters may be pretending to sleep while watching each other is genuinely creepy. The prose is clean and direct without being sparse. Concrete details like the burnt toast, the ticking ceiling fan, and the "yellow possum" mug ground the scene in believable domesticity. However, there are some weaknesses. Occasional phrases like "My vision prickled" lean toward telling rather than showing physical responses. Some transitions could be smoother - the jump between scenes sometimes feels slightly abrupt. The horror elements, while building well, could be pushed slightly further to create more visceral impact. The chapter follows its planned structure closely, hitting the key beats of escalating incidents, relationship friction, and growing ambiguity about who is the unreliable narrator. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 17 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 19

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I didn’t set out to spy on her. That’s what I kept telling myself. It was just that two nights in a row of the same wrongness was enough to bump this out of “quirky” and into “data required.” That’s my bias, I guess. Some people pray. I open apps. The third night, after she’d taken her meds and we’d brushed our teeth in the too-bright bathroom with its whining fan, I propped my phone on the nightstand, screen down, cord stretched to the outlet. I opened the voice memo app and hit record. “What are you doing?” Mara asked, watching my hands. “Nothing,” I said too fast. “Work note.” She snorted. “At eleven p.m.? Nerd.” “Client in London,” I lied. They were in Pittsburgh. She clicked off the lamp on her side. The room folded in. “No more staring contest tonight,” she said. It was light, but there was a question in it. “Deal,” I said. “Sleep.” This time, I fell under quick. No hour of vigilant ceiling-gazing, no mental inventory. The house hummed and cracked. Her breath next to me was an anchor. I sank. — I woke before the alarm, feeling like someone had reached into my chest and swapped my heart with something made of glass. Too fast, too fragile. The room was grey with early light. Mara was on her stomach, hair everywhere, one arm hanging over the side of the bed. An empty mug sat on the floor where she’d forgotten it. Normal. I reached for the phone. The recording icon still pulsed. Two hours, thirty-six minutes, twenty-nine seconds. I slipped out of bed, padded to the kitchen, and set the phone on the table. Mara hated listening to her own voice, so I figured I’d review it alone and delete it before she woke up. Save her the embarrassment. Save me the conversation. I hit play and made coffee while the first hour of white noise and mattress creaks and sleep-breath filled the room. Thirty minutes in, there was a rustle—the sound of someone shifting, maybe sitting up. A murmur I couldn’t make out. I turned up the volume. A minute of nothing. Then a whisper, right up close to the mic, so sudden I sloshed coffee onto my hand. “—he’s almost open.” My own breath in the kitchen went thin. I rewound ten seconds and played it again. “…he’s almost open.” It sounded like Mara and not like Mara. Her voice but with the warmth scooped out. Like someone doing an impression of her without understanding what people sound like. I paused the recording. The rational explanation came first, because that’s the track my mind runs on: auditory pareidolia. It’s like the thing where you hear Satan when you spin records backwards because you’re primed for it. Late-night noise plus expectation equals spooky whisper. I played it again. “Almost,” the not-Mara said, a little clearer this time because I knew to strain for it. A second, breathier thread under it—maybe just the room tone, maybe something else. “Fuck,” I said quietly. “Morning,” Mara mumbled from the doorway. I jumped. Slopped more coffee. Great. “Hey,” I said, casual as a heart attack. “You’re up early.” She was swaddled in the blanket, hair a halo of knots. She blinked at the phone. “What are you listening to?” “Nothing,” I said. “Sleep talk. You were, uh… chatty.” Her face closed a notch. “Delete it.” “I will. I just wanted to—” “Delete. It.” Her voice was sharper than the knife by the sink. I thumbed stop. “Okay. Sure.” “I don’t need evidence of me being weird on your phone,” she said. “That’s not— I don’t like that.” “I was just trying to figure out if you were sitting up,” I said. “It’s not—” “You don’t have to monitor me,” she said. There was fear behind the edge. Not anger, not really. Fear. “I’m worried, that’s all.” “Your worry sounds like a clipboard,” she said. She went to the cupboard, grabbed her favorite chipped mug, and slammed it down a little too hard. “You promised me we wouldn’t turn this into a case study again.” “I promised I’d help,” I said. “Sometimes helping is not making it a bigger deal.” She poured coffee with her left hand and spilled. “I’m tired. Please, Ethan.” She was right. She was also wrong. Both felt true. “I’ll delete it,” I said. I held the phone up, played the last seconds out loud—just a hiss of static now that I expected something. No words. I stared at the waveform like it had betrayed me. Then I hit delete. Gone. There was a small, perverse relief in not having to prove anything. She exhaled. Some tension left her shoulders. She stepped close enough that her blanket brushed my bare arm. “Thank you,” she said. Soft again. “I know you’re trying.” “I just don’t want to miss something if it’s… happening,” I said. “If what’s happening?” she asked, quick. “Nothing,” I lied. “Forget it.” She didn’t push. That was almost worse. — We tried to be normal after that. Or I tried; Mara seemed to be radiating a careful approximation of normal that you’d only notice was off if you knew her real version. She unpacked books and arranged them by color instead of author. “If anyone needs to find something, they can suffer,” she said. She started a painting of the hill behind the house, all charcoals and smeared greens. “To make friends with it,” she said, half joking. She called her therapist, or said she did. I didn’t double-check. I answered Slack messages. I ordered a new modem. I spent too much time thinking about one sentence on a recording I’d destroyed. He’s almost open. It snagged. Open to what? Open like a door? Or open like a wound? That night, I told myself I wouldn’t do the phone thing again. It had upset her. It had given me nothing but static and a phrase I might’ve imagined. We went to bed at midnight. Mara took her pill, curled up with her back to me. “Can you sleep?” I asked. “Trying,” she said into the pillow. “If you wake up weird or anxious, wake me, okay? Don’t just… sit there.” “I don’t,” she said. “Okay.” A beat passed. “If you wake up and I’m being creepy,” she added, “just nudge me. Don’t make movies on your phone.” “I’m not—” “I know,” she said quickly. “I know. Just. Don’t.” “Okay,” I said again. She reached back, found my thumb, squeezed once, then let go. It should’ve been reassuring. — I woke up on my feet. Cold wood under bare soles. Shadow stacked against my skin. My hand on the bedroom doorframe. For a moment I thought I was dreaming and that relief felt like a soft animal in my chest. Then I flexed my fingers and felt splintered paint under the pads. Awake, then. The hall was ink-dark, except for a bruised rectangle of streetlamp light at the far end. I was outside our bedroom looking in. Mara lay in the bed, alone, on her side facing the door. The beam of the alarm clock’s red numbers cut a slash across her cheek: 3:02. Her eyes were closed, lashes resting on her skin. Vulnerable. Soft. How long had I been standing there? The question came with no answer, only the hollow echo of my pulse. I backed away, slow, as if not to wake her. My limbs felt distant, like the lag on a glitchy video call. Back into the room. Into bed. Under covers. In the morning, I told myself I’d gotten up to pee and forgotten the walk back. It happens. Sleep inertia. People wake in weird places. “You were talking last night,” Mara said, pushing scrambled eggs around her plate. “Yeah?” “I think so,” she said. “Or dreaming. You were saying something, but it didn’t sound like you.” A tiny electric tick ran through me. “What’d I say?” “I don’t know.” She frowned. “It was like… two voices. Or a bad recording. Doesn’t matter.” “It matters,” I said more sharply than I meant. “If I’m the one doing weird shit—” “I didn’t mean it like—” She rubbed her temples. “Can we not dissect every second, please? I’m tired. I feel like we’re both on trial.” I shut my mouth. I didn’t tell her about waking in the doorway. I didn’t tell her about the whisper. I didn’t tell her because I didn’t want to add weight to anything, and I didn’t want to watch her face when she realized it wasn’t just her anymore. Later, on my lunch break, I tried to recreate the whisper in the kitchen, just to prove to myself it was nothing. I hunched over the mic and murmured garbled syllables, listened back, tried to hear, he’s almost open. It didn’t sound the same. That evening, Mara brought in the mail, flipping through glossy junk. “Hey,” she said, tossing a medical bill on the table. “Did you ask Dr. Haynes’ office to send records to your email? They left a voicemail earlier.” “No,” I said. I hadn’t. “Maybe they’re updating something.” She frowned. “I don’t like my brain file floating around.” “It’s secure,” I said automatically. “HIPAA, encryption, all that.” “You really trust systems,” she said. “Must be nice.” There was a hint of admiration in it. Or accusation. Maybe both. That night I did not set the phone to record. On principle. On respect. On fear of what I’d find. I lay awake longer than I meant to, staring at the wobbly circle of light from the hall bleeding under our door. Mara’s breaths were uneven; every hitch made me want to ask if she was awake, if she was okay. I didn’t. At some point I drifted. I woke to her hand on my chest. Not sweet; flat. Heavy. In the dark, her face was inches from mine. “I know you’re awake,” she whispered. Cold swept through me. “Mara?” She blinked, slow, like surfacing. Pulled her hand back. “What?” she said, genuinely confused. “You said—” “I was asleep,” she muttered, rolling away. I lay there, staring at the back of her head, pulse hammering. I didn’t have a recording. I didn’t have proof. I only had the distinct feeling that we weren’t on one side of this thing watching it. We were inside it, and something on the edge of our bed was taking notes.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively advances both the supernatural horror and relationship dynamics established in the previous chapters. The author demonstrates strong control over pacing, building tension through a series of escalating incidents that blur the line between psychological and paranormal horror. The technical execution is largely solid. The prose maintains a clean, readable style that suits Ethan's practical, analytical voice. The dialogue feels authentic to the characters' established relationship - Mara's sharp defensiveness about being "monitored" and Ethan's well-meaning but controlling attempts to gather data ring true to their dynamics. The author avoids excessive exposition, letting details emerge naturally through action and conversation. The horror elements work well within the story's established framework. The recorded whisper "he's almost open" is appropriately ambiguous - unsettling without over-explaining the supernatural mechanics. Ethan's sleepwalking incident is effectively creepy, particularly the image of him standing in the doorway watching Mara sleep. These incidents maintain the story's central theme of watching and being watched. Character consistency is strong. Ethan's rationalization of the whisper as auditory pareidolia fits his tech-oriented mindset, while his decision to record Mara aligns with his need for control disguised as concern. Mara's reaction to being recorded - her fear and anger at being made into a "case study" - reflects her established trauma around medical surveillance. However, the chapter has some weaknesses. Certain metaphors feel strained, particularly "feeling like someone had reached into my chest and swapped my heart with something made of glass." The ending line about "something on the edge of our bed was taking notes" ventures into purple prose territory, breaking from the otherwise grounded voice. The chapter follows the planned structure well, incorporating the recording device, the ambiguous whisper, signs of Ethan being affected, and escalating tension between the couple. It maintains the story's commitment to character-driven horror rather than relying on supernatural spectacle. While competently executed, the chapter doesn't surprise much beyond its planned beats. The progression feels inevitable rather than genuinely unsettling in unexpected ways. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 8 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 10 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The fourth time she did it, I didn’t pretend to be asleep. I’d been lying there for an hour already, watching the slit of hallway light under the door narrow and widen as the house shifted. Mara’s breathing had gone symphonic: soft inhales, tiny whistling exhale through the side of her mouth. We’d gone to bed pissed at each other in that quiet, drained way where you run out of synonyms for “I’m fine.” I was on my back, deliberately. No covert cameras, no phone recording this time. Just me, the dark, and a stubborn resolve to handle it like a person instead of a lab. At 2:43, the heater clunked off. At 2:44, Mara sat up. It wasn’t a normal sit-up. No sleepy roll, no groan. One second she was flat, the next she was upright, spine straight, head bowed. A glitch in between. “Mara,” I said immediately. She didn’t react. Her hair fell forward, a curtain hiding her face. Her shoulders rose once, slow, fell. She turned. Her head came up. Her gaze found my face. It was like being under a microscope. No flicker of recognition, no sleepy confusion. Just… assessment. My skin crawled. “Mara,” I said again, louder. “Hey. You’re doing it again.” She blinked. Once. The spell broke. Her shoulders slumped. “What?” she croaked. “You were sitting up,” I said. The words came out harsher than I meant. “Staring at me.” She looked down at her hands in her lap as if surprised to see them. Then she pulled her knees up and hugged them. “Don’t,” she whispered. “Don’t what?” “Don’t tell me that,” she said. “Please.” “You asked me to nudge you.” “I changed my mind,” she said. “I don’t want to know.” I sat up too, anger and fear tangling. “You don’t get to veto reality.” She flinched. “Okay, clipboard.” “I’m not your doctor.” “Sometimes you’re worse.” That landed. I looked at her in the weak blue light from the alarm clock. Her face was pinched, eyes shiny. She looked less haunted and more cornered. “I’m trying to help,” I said. It came out thin. “I’m trying not to lose my mind,” she said. “We’re both doing great.” We stared at each other, two exhausted people in a crooked bed, with something neither of us wanted to name breathing around us. “Tell me about before,” I said suddenly. She shook her head. “No.” “You said it’s not like last time, but you never told me what last time is, not really.” “It’s old shit,” she said. “It’s mine.” “We moved out here because of your old shit,” I said, more sharply than I should have. “I think I get to know the syllabus.” Instant regret. She recoiled. “Wow,” she said. “There it is.” I scrubbed my hands over my face. “I didn’t mean—” “Yes, you did,” she said. “It’s fine. You’re allowed to be tired of it.” “I’m tired of feeling shut out,” I said. “I’m here. I signed up. But I feel like there’s this… chapter I’m not allowed to read.” She stared at the wall. For a minute I thought the conversation was over. Then her shoulders dropped a fraction. “He watched me sleep,” she said. The way she said it made the hairs on my arms rise. “Who?” “You know who.” Nate. The ex whose name we didn’t use much. The one blurred in her stories. “He watched me sleep,” she repeated. “At first it was kind of—whatever. Boyfriend bullshit. ‘You look peaceful.’ Then it got… more. I’d wake up and he’d be sitting in the chair, just… staring. No phone. No book. Hours, he said.” “You’ve never told me that,” I said. “Because it sounds like a horror movie cliché,” she snapped. “Because I know how it sounds.” “What happened?” I kept my voice gentle. “I stopped sleeping,” she said. “I started feeling… wrong in my own skin. He’d say I talked in my sleep. Said I was saying fucked up things. Then I’d wake up and he’d be angry with me for… dreams. I’d catch him in doorways. In the bathroom. Watching.” She dug her nails into her calves. “Then there was a night I woke up and he was right here—” she tapped between my eyebrows, “—and he said ‘I know you’re awake,’ in this voice that wasn’t his. It sounded like a recording. Flat. Like he was putting on a person suit.” I swallowed. “And?” “And then things happened,” she said. “He hurt me. He hurt some other people. I had… an episode. They said I was stressed, paranoid. That I’d read too much online. That I misremembered.” Her laugh was more of a cough. “They said he was just a man. Which I’m sure is true. Men can be monsters all by themselves.” “I’m not him,” I said quickly. “I know you’re not,” she said. “I wouldn’t be here if I thought you were.” “But you think something… from that is here,” I said, trying out the shape of the thought. “I think I know what it feels like when the room is full of attention,” she said. “And I felt it tonight. And the last few nights. And in that other house. And I’m really fucking scared you’re importing my old ghost into your nice rational brain and you’re going to resent me for it.” I reached for her. She let me hold her knees. “Look at me,” I said. She did. Her eyes were wet but steady. “If this is just sleep stuff,” I said, “we get you better meds or a different doctor. If it’s stress, we deal with stress. If it’s something else…” I trailed off, because what? “If it’s something else?” she prompted. “We don’t pretend it isn’t,” I finished, surprising myself. She searched my face. “You believe me.” “I believe you believe what you’re saying,” I said. It was the terrible therapist answer and she flinched. I hated myself for it. “I believe something’s happening. I’m not ready to jump to poltergeist.” “I never said poltergeist,” she said. “I’m not that imaginative.” We sat in unhappy silence. Finally she said, “If you wake up and I’m staring at you like that, just say my name. Shake me. Don’t lie there like roadkill. Don’t… let it use you.” Let it use you. The words slotted too easily into the whisper in my memory: he’s almost open. “What is ‘it’?” I asked. “I don’t know,” she said, almost angry at the question. “A metaphor. A parasite. A bad habit that looks like a person. I don’t know.” She wiped her face. “I just know the patterns.” “Okay,” I said. “If I wake and you’re being creepy, I shake you.” “And don’t pretend to be asleep to ‘catch me,’” she added, watching me. “Promise.” I hesitated. That’s what doomed me. Not because of magic. Because she saw it. “Ethan,” she said. “I promise,” I lied. She lay down, turning away from me, pulling the blanket up over her shoulder like armor. I lay back too, staring at the ceiling, feeling like a kid who’d been told not to push the big red button. — The next morning she was soft, almost apologetic. She made pancakes, badly, burning the first batch and laughing at herself. She padded around in fuzzy socks, humming under her breath, making faces at the crooked cabinets. Between calls, I ordered a cheap little motion-activated nightlight online, so the hallway wouldn’t be a black tongue at two a.m. I also, out of habit, googled “parasomnia staring episodes harmless” and skimmed an article that told me everything was normal, and another that hinted at “violent behaviors during sleep” in rare cases. Mara texted me a photo of the hill painting she’d been working on, now with a smudge of a house at the bottom. under surveillance, she’d captioned it, followed by a ghost emoji. Then: kidding. Then: mostly. Mid-afternoon, a voicemail pinged from Dr. Haynes’ office about rescheduling, and I ignored it. The idea of inviting an outside authority into the house made my jaw clench. At dinner, I tried to be casual. “Maybe we should move your next appointment up,” I said. “Just to check in.” She stabbed a piece of overcooked broccoli. “Because I sat up weird?” “Because you’re scared,” I said. “And because last time—” “Last time they told me I invented a monster to excuse a man,” she said. “Forgive me if I’m not dying to get their take.” “I’m not trying to have you committed,” I said. “I just don’t want to miss something.” “You always think there’s a right thing to catch,” she said. “Like if we just document correctly the universe will hand us a diagnosis.” “What’s the alternative?” I snapped. “Just vibe it out while you watch me sleep?” She flinched. “Don’t say it like that.” “How am I supposed to say it?” “I don’t know.” Her voice wobbled. “Maybe don’t make it sound like I’m some kind of predator.” I sighed. “I’m sorry. That was shitty.” She nodded, jaw tight. “I know I’m… hard work. I’m trying.” She was. I knew she was. Guilt settled on me like dust. That night, she flicked on the lamp by her side and left it on low. “Is that okay?” she asked. “Of course,” I said. She crawled into bed and, after a second, reached for my hand. “We’re on the same side,” she said. It sounded like a reminder. “Yeah,” I said. “Of course.” When her breaths evened, I lay there and thought about promises. About red buttons. About how very much I wanted to be right, and how ugly it felt that a dark part of me wanted her to be wrong, if only so I didn’t have to believe in anything I couldn’t measure. If I woke up and she was staring, I told myself, I’d shake her. I wouldn’t play along. I fell asleep repeating it. — Around three, the lamp went out with a tiny pop. I came awake to the smell of hot metal and Mara’s hand, flat on my chest again. Her face above mine, eyes wide and unreadable in the sudden dark. For a second, I forgot the script. I stayed still.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong character work and relationship dynamics within the possession horror framework. The author effectively uses the supernatural elements as a lens to explore the complexity of Ethan and Mara's relationship, particularly around trust, belief, and control. The dialogue feels authentic and reveals character naturally. Exchanges like Mara calling Ethan "clipboard" and his defensive response show their dynamic through conflict. The conversation about her past with Nate is handled with appropriate weight - neither minimized nor over-dramatized. Mara's difficulty articulating her experience ("A metaphor. A parasite. A bad habit that looks like a person") rings true to someone trying to explain trauma that others have dismissed. The characterization remains consistent with the established profiles. Ethan's need for rational control is evident in his promise to "shake her" while simultaneously planning to surveil her. His internal contradiction - wanting to help while resenting being shut out - creates believable tension. Mara's wariness about sharing her trauma, combined with her specific warnings about "letting it use you," maintains her established voice. The horror builds effectively through domestic unease rather than overt supernatural events. The lamp going out and Mara's sudden presence creates genuine tension without relying on cheap scares. The author maintains ambiguity about whether events are supernatural or psychological, which serves the story's themes. However, the chapter significantly deviates from its stated plan. The webcam setup, footage review, and Ethan seeing himself in recordings - key plot elements - are entirely absent. While the emotional core remains intact, these missing elements may affect narrative continuity or character development arcs. The prose is clean and controlled, avoiding purple language while maintaining atmosphere. Descriptions like the "black tongue" of the hallway work without feeling forced. The pacing allows tension to build naturally through conversation and small details. The ending effectively sets up continued escalation while maintaining thematic consistency around watching, pretending, and the erosion of trust between intimate partners. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 8 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I should have shaken her. That’s the part that keeps looping when I think back on it: the tiny space where I could have done the simple, human thing she asked, and instead did the exact opposite. Her hand was on my chest. Fingers spread like she was lining up something beneath my ribs. The popped bulb left the room in a denser dark. My eyes adjusted enough to catch the glint of her pupils. “Mara,” I meant to say. Instead I closed my eyes halfway and went very, very still. It wasn’t a decision so much as a slide. The part of me that loves tests, loves knowing, stepped forward. If I pretended, if I watched her watching me, I’d know whether this was sleepwalking or something else. This was data; this was control. I slowed my breathing. Thought: sell it. Her fingers flexed. The air between our faces felt crowded. Then she spoke. “There you are,” she whispered. It was her voice, but wrong at the edges, like someone had laid tracing paper over it and gone over the lines with a too-fine pen. Affectionate, almost. Triumphant. A cold pressure grazed my closed eyelids, the ghost of a touch, as if she were measuring the weight of them. I had the insane thought that if I opened my eyes right then, something would slide in. My chest hurt. My instinct screamed: move. I didn’t. There was a moment—a stretchless, elastic second—where I felt unmoored from the bed. Not floating, not out of body. More like someone had nudged my sense of where “I” ended and the dark began, blurring the outline. Then: nothing. — I woke to sunlight knifing past the curtains, alarm beeping cheerfully at 7:30. My heart slammed like I’d sprinted. Mara was not in bed. My shirt was twisted. My mouth tasted like metal. A faint ache hummed along my forearms. In the kitchen, the coffee pot was on. Mara stood at the sink in her usual hoodie, back to me, mug in hand. “Morning,” I said, voice raw. She jumped. Really jumped. Coffee sloshed over her fingers. “Shit.” “Sorry,” I said. “Didn’t mean to—” “It’s fine.” She shook her hand, not looking at me. “You were out.
