I didn’t want to wake you.” I stepped closer. “Did the bulb—” “I’ll get another,” she said too quickly. “It just… went. Things do that.” Her hair hid her face, but the line of her shoulders was wrong. Tight, like she was braced for impact. “You okay?” I asked. “Sure,” she said. There was a purple smudge on her upper arm, just visible where the hoodie slipped. A bruise, circular, like thumbprint plus fingers. “What happened?” I asked, reaching. She yanked her sleeve down. “Bumped into the table.” “The table doesn’t have hands,” I said. She turned then, finally. Her eyes were rimmed red. “Are you doing this?” “Doing what?” My stomach dropped. “Making jokes like that,” she said. “It’s not funny. I bruise easy.” I looked down at my own arms. Thin, raised lines tracked the inside of my left forearm, four parallel scratches like I’d raked my nails there. Small crescents on my right hand. I didn’t remember doing any of it. “Did I—” I started. “You don’t remember?” she asked. Something in her tone told me to say no. “No. Should I?” She flinched, and I hated that I’d read it right. “You were… restless,” she said. “That’s all.” “You said that before,” I said. “Restless how?” “Just talking,” she said. “Half asleep. You know.” “What did I say?” The question came out more like a demand. She shook her head. “You wouldn’t like it.” An image flashed unbidden: me standing over her on the couch (she wasn’t on the couch, we hadn’t split rooms yet, but my brain supplied it anyway), saying something in a voice that wasn’t mine. “It’s important,” I said. “If I’m the one—” “It’s not all about you,” she snapped. Then immediately, “Sorry. I’m sorry. I just… I’m tired of narrating my nightmares.” I backed off. Made a joke about needing coffee before interrogations. She gave me a brittle smile that didn’t reach her eyes. While she dug through a box for a clean spoon, I checked the nightstand. The lamp was cold, bulb dark with a smudge inside the glass. My phone lay where I’d left it. No new recordings. No proof. The only concrete evidence that anything had happened was a broken light and the way we both avoided touching each other’s arms. — On my lunch break, while Mara showered, I sat at my laptop and did what I do best: I researched. “night staring sleep parasomnia partner doesn’t remember” “watching you sleep psychosis vs. possession” “You okay?” showed in the search history like a sad little footnote. I skimmed science. Hypnagogia, REM behavior disorder, night terrors. I found a horror forum thread about “eyeball visitors” so ridiculous I almost closed the browser. Then a post buried in a cluster of anonymous confessions: When my boyfriend started waking up to me staring, I thought I was the problem. Then I woke up to find him by the bed, just watching me. He said he was “protecting” me. It got worse from there. No answers. Just a spiral of people insisting it was demonic, or psychological, or kink-adjacent. One reply stuck: It’s not about who stares first. It’s about who pretends. If you act asleep, you’re inviting it. It needs that pretending. Don’t play dead. I clicked through to the user’s profile. Inactive. Last post three years ago. One of their earlier comments mentioned a city I knew: the one Mara used to live in. Stupid coincidence. Or indexing. Or my brain pattern-hunting. I closed the laptop when I heard the shower cut off. The house exhaled. — That evening, we tried to reset. I made pasta. Mara unearthed candles from a box and lit two fat ones on the table. “Romantic,” I said. “Power goes out, we’re set,” she said, then, “Too soon?” We ate in a wash of soft light and cheap marinara. “Listen,” I said, twirling noodles. “About last night—” “I don’t want to catalog it,” she said. “Okay, but I need to—” “I woke up,” she said, dropping her fork, “with your hand on my face. Pressing. Like you were checking if I was still there.” I swallowed. “I don’t remember that.” “I didn’t think you did,” she said. “Your eyes weren’t… you.” The room swayed a little. Candle flames dipped. “Why didn’t you tell me this morning?” “Because every time I tell someone a fucked up thing happened at night, I end up in a room with fluorescent lights being asked if I feel safe at home,” she said. “Because I don’t trust myself not to be crazy. Because I don’t trust you not to decide I’m crazy.” “I would never—” “You already did,” she said quietly. “You told me this is like an old script. You’re not wrong. That’s the worst part.” I ran a hand over my face. “So now I’m doing it too.” She shook her head. “I don’t think you mean to. That doesn’t help much.” “What do you want me to do?” I asked. It wasn’t rhetorical; I was begging for a checklist. She stared at the candle. “Don’t pretend. If you wake up and I’m… wrong, wake me. If you wake up and you’re somewhere you didn’t fall asleep, tell me. Don’t go full Paranormal Activity with your phone. Just be here. With me. On purpose.” On purpose. It sounded simple and impossible. “Okay,” I said. I meant it, then. She reached across the table, palm up. I took it. Her hand was warm. “Also,” she added, “I want you to know that if this is just my brain, and you decide it’s too much, you’re allowed to leave.” I stared at her. “That’s not happening.” She smiled a little. “Everybody says that until they’re tired enough.” “I’d rather figure it out,” I said. “Okay,” she said. “Then we figure it out.” — That night we left the bedroom lamp off but plugged in the new motion light in the hall. It glowed faintly when we walked past, then dimmed back to a seed of red like an animal eye. No recording. No lurking tests. We lay facing each other, close enough that her breath tickled my lips. “If I snore, you have to live with it,” I said. “If you levitate, I’m moving out,” she said. “Fair.” We kissed. She closed her eyes. Sleep took her faster than I expected, a soft collapse. I watched her for a minute. Just a minute. Then I closed my eyes, for real. — Somewhere between asleep and awake, I felt the shift. It was like being nudged an inch to the left inside my own skull. I heard myself breathe. I heard the house. When my eyes opened, I was standing. I was at the foot of the bed, bare feet on the wood. Mara was curled on her side, back to me. The angle was all wrong; I wasn’t used to seeing her from there while conscious. Move, I thought. Lie back down. My body didn’t. Instead I took a slow step around to her side. My head tilting, just so. Studying. Her eyelids fluttered. I felt a smile tug at my mouth. It didn’t feel like mine. Say her name, I thought. I leaned down. Heard my own voice, very soft, very close to her ear. “Almost.” I snapped awake. Flat on my back. Heart jackhammering, sheets twisted around my legs. Lamp off. Motion light in the hall a dull ember. Mara lay beside me, on her side, breathing fast. Too fast for sleep. “Mara,” I whispered. She flinched like I’d struck her. “You okay?” I asked. She rolled onto her back. In the faint light, I saw tears at the corners of her eyes. “You were standing there,” she said. “By the bed. You said—” “I know,” I said, before she could finish. I didn’t know how I knew, only that the horror on her face mirrored the one clawing at my throat. “I think it’s you now,” she whispered. “That’s not funny.” “I’m not joking,” she said. I wanted to tell her she was wrong. I also wanted, desperately, for this to be just her story infecting mine. Between us, the air felt thick with something listening.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates skilled horror writing that effectively balances supernatural elements with psychological realism. The author successfully executes the planned pivotal scene where Ethan deliberately chooses to "pretend" sleep despite Mara's explicit warning, creating genuine tension through character choice rather than external forces. The characterization is particularly strong. Ethan's internal monologue reveals his controlling nature and need for "data" in believable ways - his decision to fake sleep feels true to his established personality while being clearly unwise. The line "It wasn't a decision so much as a slide" captures how people rationalize poor choices. Mara's responses feel authentic to someone with trauma history - her flinching, deflection, and fear of not being believed all ring true. The dialogue effectively reveals character while avoiding exposition dumps. Exchanges like Mara's "I'm tired of narrating my nightmares" and her offering Ethan permission to leave if it becomes "too much" show rather than tell their relationship dynamics. The conversation about establishing new rules feels realistic for a couple trying to manage a crisis. The supernatural elements are handled with restraint. The "There you are" moment is genuinely unsettling without becoming overwrought. The blackout and memory gaps create ambiguity about what's real versus psychological, maintaining the story's central tension about possession versus mental illness. Technical execution is solid throughout. The prose maintains Ethan's voice consistently while incorporating moments of genuine poetry ("sunlight knifing past the curtains") without falling into purple prose. The pacing builds effectively from the opening decision through the consequences and aftermath. Minor weaknesses include occasional metaphors that feel slightly forced ("like someone had laid tracing paper over it") and some predictable beats in the research sequence. However, these don't significantly detract from the overall effectiveness. The chapter succeeds in advancing both the supernatural plot and the relationship deterioration, showing how Ethan's flaws make him complicit in whatever is happening. The ending effectively sets up future developments while maintaining the story's psychological complexity. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The next day, everything looked essentially the same, and that was almost unbearable. The hill out back was still a soft smear of frost and dead grass. The house still leaned in the same directions. The cupboards still stuck. My inbox still stacked itself in neat, passive-aggressive lines. Except Mara moved around me like I was a live wire. She didn’t say it outright at first. She did small things: kept the island between us while we made coffee, stood just out of reach when she handed me a plate. She watched my face when she thought I wasn’t looking, the way she used to watch her blood pressure cuff readings. When I caught her at it, she tore her gaze away, like it was her that got caught. I did my own small things: double-checked my arms for marks, my side of the bed for evidence. Nothing but the faint scratches from before, already fading. No broken lamps, no moved furniture. No conclusive proof I’d been at the foot of the bed saying almost in a voice that made her cry. I told myself: It was a nightmare. A shared anxiety. That's a thing; couples sync like that. By noon, denial had worn thin. Mara was at the dining table with her sketchbook, nibbling a pen. The page was filled with the outline of our bedroom door, over and over, each slightly ajar. On the last one, a pair of eyes peered through the crack. “Cheery,” I said, setting my mug down. She shut the sketchbook immediately. “Doodle,” she said. “We should talk about last night,” I said. “I don’t want to,” she said. “I was standing over you,” I said. “In my dream. You saw me.” She flinched like the words had physical weight. “If we call it a dream, can we stop there?” “I said something,” I pushed. “Almost.” She stared at me. Her lips trembled. “You remember.” “I—” I rubbed my temples. “Yes. No. I remember it like I remember dreams. But you said—” “You said ‘almost’,” she said. “Right here.” She touched her neck. “Your mouth was… wrong. You were smiling. You never smile like that when I cry.” “I was smiling?” My stomach lurched. She nodded once. “Like you’d won something.” “I wouldn’t—” “I know,” she said quickly, then softer: “I know you wouldn’t. That’s why it’s worse.” Silence. The heater hummed, then shut off, the click loud. “Maybe this is—” I started. “Stress,” she said. “Parasomnia. Shared delusion. I know all the words, Ethan. I have a punch card.” “I was going to say we’re scaring ourselves with patterns,” I said. “We’re in a weird house. You have history with this stuff. It makes sense we’d… echo it.” “You think I’m doing this to you,” she said. Not really a question. “I think brains are copycats,” I said. “I think if you tell me a story about an ex who watched you sleep, and we move into a house like a horror set, and I wake up and you’re staring at me—” “It makes a story,” she finished. “Nice and tight.” “Doesn’t mean nothing’s happening,” I added. “Just means we might be… over-attributing.” “You’re doing it again,” she said. “Reducing it until you’re comfortable.” “What do you want me to do?” I snapped. “Tell you you’re possessed? Tell you I’m possessed? Is that better?” She flinched. “No,” she said. “God. No.” She pressed her hands over her face. When she spoke again, her voice was smaller. “I found something,” she said. “Online. Before we moved.” My turn to stiffen. “What kind of something?” “The kind you’d hate,” she said. She got up, went to her backpack, rummaged, came back with her phone. Scrolled, hesitated, then slid it across the table to me. A screenshot of a forum post. No branding, just grey-on-grey misery. The username was nonsense. i used to wake up to my girlfriend staring at me. thought it was her anxiety. then i started waking up in weird places. then SHE started waking up to ME staring. it only happened when one of us pretended to be asleep. like it wanted that space where you’re lying. I skimmed. if you see it, don’t pretend. it likes pretending. it likes when you watch each other and do nothing. it moves through that. don’t play dead. No dates, no context. Comments underneath alternating between “this is creepypasta” and “same here.” “That’s nothing,” I said, too fast. “People make these up.” “I know,” she said. “I know. But it sounded… familiar.” “Familiar like your story with Nate,” I said before I could stop myself. Her jaw clenched. “He found shit like this too,” she said. “Used it to freak me out. To prove I was crazy when I said I felt watched. I didn’t show you this because I didn’t want to be him. I didn’t want to hand you a ghost and ask you to believe in it.” “And now?” I asked. “Now I’m wondering if we’re doing the exact thing it says not to,” she said, voice shaking. “Lying there. Watching. Pretending.” “You told me not to pretend,” I said. “And you promised,” she said. “And then you didn’t.” “I just wanted to know,” I said. “What if it was nothing? What if I’d shaken you and it was just sleepwalking, and we could laugh?” “Did it feel like nothing?” she asked. I thought of her hand on my chest, the whispered there you are, the sense of my outline softening. “No,” I admitted. She nodded, like that was the worst and only answer. “I don’t want to feed it,” she said. “If it exists,” I said. “If it exists,” she repeated. “Or if it’s just a shape my brain insists on making. Either way, I don’t want to cooperate.” She leaned forward. Her eyes were bright, feverish. “Sleep in the other room tonight,” she said. “Just for a night.” The request cut sideways. “What?” “If it’s about us watching each other,” she said, “we remove one variable. I’m on the couch, you’re in the bed, doors open. If anything… weird happens, we’re not breathing in each other’s faces when it does.” “It’s going to wreck your back,” I said. “It’s one night,” she said. “It’s a stupid little test. You like tests.” The jab was fair. “And if it’s nothing?” I asked. “Then it’s nothing,” she said. “Then I can say, ‘See, my brain made a monster again,’ and you can argue with me in the morning.” “And if it’s something?” I said. “Then at least we’ll know it’s not just your proximity making me insane,” she said. “You’re not insane,” I said, on reflex. She raised an eyebrow. “That’s not the opinion of the State of Oregon.” “That was years ago,” I said. “It doesn’t feel like years,” she murmured. She took a breath. “Please. One night. No pretending, no recording, no staring. We just… sleep separately. Like roommates after a fight.” I hesitated. It felt like giving in to the narrative I’d been fighting. It also felt like the lowest-risk experiment in the world. “Okay,” I said. “One night.” Relief flooded her face so fast it hurt to see. “Thank you.” She reached for my hand like she was going to squeeze it, then stopped herself halfway. Let it drop. — We made a show of it that evening. Mara dragged the old futon mattress into the living room and made a nest of blankets. “It’s like camping,” she said. “Without trees. Or friends.” She laughed at her own not-joke. I set up the bedroom like normal. She poked her head in as I fluffed a pillow. “If you wake up and feel weird,” she said, “call me. Don’t… wander.” “I don’t wander,” I said. “You’ve been standing in doorways,” she said. I had never actually told her that. “How do you know that?” She touched the doorframe, fingertips finding shallow divots I hadn’t noticed. “You leave marks,” she said. We looked at each other. She shook it off with an effort. “I’m serious,” she said. “No heroics. Just yell.” “Yes, ma’am,” I said, trying for levity. It came out thin. She went back to her nest. I brushed my teeth, turned off the lights, left the bedroom door open. The hallway motion light pulsed faintly. Lying alone in the bed, I felt more exposed than I had with her beside me. The empty half of the mattress might as well have been a sinkhole. I told myself: This is good. We’ll get through one boring, dreamless night, and in the morning we’ll feel silly. I closed my eyes. — Sometime deep, the quiet rearranged itself. I surfaced to the creak of a floorboard. Not the house settling; a weight. Eyes open. The motion light in the hall glowed, painting a soft red frame. In it, a figure stood at the doorway. “Ethan?” I called, before my brain caught up to the stupidity of that. The figure stepped forward. The light didn’t follow. For a moment it was just shadow, denser than the dark. Then Mara’s voice, from the living room. “Ethan?” The shape by the door paused. Turned its head, as if considering. I sat up too fast; the blood roared in my ears. The figure vanished—not melted, not theatrically, just gone when my eyes refocused. The hall was empty. “Yeah?” I called back, voice high. She appeared at the far end of the hallway, wrapped in a blanket. Real. Sleep-creased. “Did you call me?” she asked. “No,” I lied. “Bad dream.” She studied me from there. “Are you okay?” “I’m fine,” I said. “Go back to sleep.” “Don’t tell me what to do,” she said automatically. Then, softer: “You look wrong.” “I’m just tired,” I said. “Me too,” she murmured. She shuffled back to the couch. The motion light flared and dimmed with her passing. I lay down, heart pounding. Stared at the ceiling, at the doorway, at the absence in the hall. Tried to reconstruct the silhouette—had it been my height? Hers? An invented blob? I didn’t sleep much after that. — In the thin blue of morning, I found Mara already awake, sitting cross-legged on the futon with a blanket around her shoulders, staring at the blank TV screen. “How’d you sleep?” I asked. She looked up. Her eyes were huge. “You came in here,” she said. “No,” I said. “I didn’t.” “You did,” she said. “You stood right there.” She pointed to the space by the couch. “You just… stood.” I tasted metal again. “How long?” “I don’t know.” Her voice cracked. “Long enough that I started to think if I moved you’d break.” “I don’t remember,” I said. It felt like a confession and a plea. “I know,” she said. “That’s why I think it’s you now.” There was no accusation in it, only terror. That was worse. Behind that terror, something else flickered in her eyes: recognition. Like she was seeing the shape of an old story slotting over a new one, and finding the edges match too neatly. “I’m calling Haynes,” I said. “Today. For both of us.” “Okay,” she said. We both knew I should have called sooner. In my head, a quieter voice said: Or you already did.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates solid craftsmanship in building psychological horror through relationship dynamics. The writer successfully maintains the delicate balance between supernatural dread and domestic tension that defines this story. The characterization is particularly strong. Ethan's voice remains consistent with his established profile - his rationalization attempts ("Maybe this is stress... parasomnia... shared delusion") and subtle condescension ("Reducing it until you're comfortable") feel authentic to someone desperately clinging to logical explanations. Mara's responses similarly ring true, particularly her sharp retort about having "a punch card" for psychiatric terms and her reluctant revelation of the forum post. The dialogue serves multiple purposes effectively. It reveals character psychology, advances the supernatural mystery, and maintains realistic relationship conflict. Lines like "You're doing it again. Reducing it until you're comfortable" capture both Mara's frustration and the core dynamic between them. The horror elements work well because they emerge organically from the characters' choices and fears. The forum post feels like authentic internet horror - vague enough to be dismissible but specific enough to be unsettling. The final sequence with the figure in the doorway maintains effective ambiguity about whether this is supernatural or psychological. The chapter follows the established plan closely, hitting key beats: relationship strain, Mara's revelations about her past, Ethan's defensive reactions, and the practical solution of separate sleeping that will drive the next chapter's events. However, some elements could be stronger. The pacing occasionally drags during the middle exposition sections. A few descriptions veer toward the overwrought ("The empty half of the mattress might as well have been a sinkhole"), though this is generally restrained. The supernatural manifestation, while appropriately ambiguous, could benefit from more specificity in its wrongness. The chapter succeeds in maintaining the story's central tension: the uncertainty about what's real while making both interpretations equally disturbing. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
We didn’t call Haynes. I told myself I would. I even pulled up the number, thumb hovering over the green icon while Mara watched me from the couch, blanket around her shoulders like armor. “Do it,” she said. “I will,” I said. “I just have a call in five. I’ll do it after.” She looked at me for a beat too long, then nodded. “Okay.” I took my laptop into the second bedroom and let a marketing manager from Des Moines talk at me about engagement metrics while my brain screamed. By the time the call was over, there was another email, a Slack ping, a small fire. It was easy to shelve the call in the name of “just after this.” By noon, the day had crusted over with normal. Call. Email. Snack. Pretend. At two, I checked on Mara. She was in the bedroom, standing by my side of the bed, hand resting lightly on the headboard. “What are you doing?” I asked. “Counting,” she said. “Counting what?” Her fingers traced four shallow grooves in the wood I hadn’t noticed. “You dig in when you stand here,” she said. “You do this thing with your hand.” “I don’t,” I said. The denial felt childish. She looked at me, eyes tired. “I don’t think you know what you do when you’re not in there.” She tapped her own forehead. “I’m calling Haynes,” I said again, guilty. “I swear.” She shrugged. “Might as well invite everyone to the show.” That stung, because it wasn’t fair, and because it was. “I’m scared of what I’ll say,” I admitted. “I don’t know how to tell him this without sounding like we’ve both fallen into a subreddit.” “Try: ‘I’ve been getting up at night and looming over my girlfriend while she’s awake,’” she said. “That’s a start.” Her jokes were getting meaner. They were also not undeserved. I folded my arms. “We can’t keep… circling.” “I know,” she said. “So let’s not.” She walked past me, into the hall, and grabbed a roll of masking tape from the box by the door. On the way back, she snagged the little motion light. “What are you doing?” I asked. She tore a strip of tape with her teeth. “We’re going to make it less comfortable,” she said. “For whatever it is.” “You read that on your ghost forum?” I tried to keep the derision out of my voice. Failed. “I read it in my head,” she said. “Don’t humor me if you’re not going to commit.” She stuck the motion light high on the wall across from the bed, aimed at the doorway. She taped a cardboard flap so it’d only trigger when something taller than the bed moved. “If we’re up, it’s on. If something comes, we see it,” she said. “No more ‘I must’ve dreamed it.’” “Unless it’s the cat we don’t have,” I said. “Then we’ll get a cat,” she said. She went to the dresser, picked up the mirror we’d yet to hang, and turned it to face the wall. “No extra angles,” she muttered. “Mara,” I said carefully, “this is starting to feel like—” “Like I’m doing ritual,” she said. “Yeah. If it’s just us, it’s silly. If it’s not, it’s insurance. You do your research, I’ll do mine.” Her hands shook as she taped a paper eye over the alarm clock display. It was both absurd and heartbreaking. “Tonight,” she said, “we don’t pretend. If one of us wakes up weird, we wake the other up. We don’t… freeze. We don’t watch.” “And if I end up standing somewhere again?” I asked. “You let me see you,” she said. “The real you. Not that—” she fluttered her fingers, searching—“visitor mode.” “If I’m in visitor mode, how do I stop?” Her mouth tightened. “Maybe you can’t. Maybe I can.” Great. Comforting. — We made a point of being together that evening, as if proximity could muscle out intrusion. We cooked. She chopped too aggressively; I took the knife gently from her. We played a board game we’d never finished unpacking. We talked about anything but sleep. At nine, she disappeared into the bedroom. When I followed, she’d changed into one of my old shirts and leggings, hair in a loose braid. She had drawn a small, simple symbol on the headboard above our pillows: two short lines crossing, an eye in the center. It looked like a child’s ward against monsters. “I know,” she said preemptively. “It’s nothing. But I don’t care.” “I didn’t say anything,” I said. “You thought it,” she said. She lay down on her side facing me. “You gonna call Haynes before bed?” she asked. I stared at the phone on the nightstand. “He’s not on call at ten p.m.” “We have voicemail,” she said. “I’ll do it tomorrow,” I said. The words felt thick. She watched me. “Okay,” she said. “Tomorrow.” We turned off the light. The room folded into familiar dark, now with the faint red eye of the motion sensor opposite the bed. The hall was a hollow throat. “Remember,” she whispered, close enough that her breath warmed my mouth, “just say my name.” “I remember,” I said. We lay there, facing each other, pretending we weren’t waiting. — Sometime after two, I surfaced. It wasn’t like before, the slow bleed between states. It was abrupt, as if someone had cracked ice over my head. My eyes were closed. My body felt wrong. I was on my side, facing Mara. I could feel the heat of her, the soft puff of her breath on my lips. I could also feel—distinct, separate—the urge to stay perfectly still. To see how long she’d watch me before she caught me not sleeping. Pretend, something inside me suggested. Just stay. Let’s see. I recognized it this time. Not a voice, exactly. A pressure wearing words. “No,” I whispered, surprising myself. Her breath hitched. “Ethan?” I opened my eyes. She was inches away, eyes wide open, glossy in the faint light. Not blank. Terrified. “You’re here,” she said. “Yeah,” I said. My throat was sand. “I’m here.” From the hall, a creak. Then the softest click: the motion sensor flicking on. Red light bloomed on the wall behind her. It carved her face into planes. Over her shoulder, I saw the doorway. A figure stood there. My brain did dumb math: height, width, familiarity. It was me. It was my shape, my hoodie from yesterday, my slump. It shouldn’t have been; I was in the bed, heart detonating. “Don’t pretend,” Mara whispered. The other-me at the doorway tilted its head. In the red wash, its eyes were holes. “Say my name,” she whispered urgently, fingers digging into my arm. “Mara,” I said, but I was looking at him. The shape stepped forward. The motion light stayed on, tracking. “Ethan,” it said. My name, in my voice, flat. Mara made a strangled sound. “No,” she said. “You don’t—” The thing moved wrong. Joints bending a fraction too far, like a bad video with dropped frames. In two jerks it was at the foot of the bed, then beside her. I tried to sit up. My body locked. The hand that reached toward her cheek was mine. “Almost,” it said. “No,” I said, or tried to. My chest clenched. Mara shoved at it—at me. “Get out,” she hissed. “You don’t get him.” Its head snapped toward her, something like amusement flickering in the dead gaze. “Always you,” it said. My mouth forming words I hadn’t thought. It pressed my—its—hand over her mouth. Not hard enough to hurt, but firm. Intimate. Proprietary. Rage ripped through me. I pushed, not with arms that didn’t move, but with whatever part of me was being edged aside. Mine, I thought. Not in the sense of possession, but of responsibility. This is my body. This is my voice. You don’t get to use them on her. For a second, pressure built. Like two magnets forced together the wrong way. The hand on her mouth faltered. Mara tore away, gasping. “Ethan!” she barked. “Pick. You pick.” I latched onto my name like a rope. “Stop,” I croaked. The word came out through both mouths at once, layered. The other-me froze. The motion light flickered. Mara scrambled away, putting the headboard symbol between her and us like it was a shield. “You leave him,” she said to the wrong me. “Take me if you have to. You already know how.” The shape turned toward her fully. Tilted its head. If something like this could look thoughtful, it did. “Already did,” it said. Then the light blew. Black. I don’t know how long there was nothing. — When I came back, I was on the floor, shoulder against the nightstand. The real lamp was on, buzzing faintly. My throat hurt. My chest felt bruised inside. Mara was in the corner of the bed, pressed against the wall, knees to her chest. Her face was streaked with tears. She held the lamp cord in one hand like a weapon. “You with me?” she asked. I swallowed. “I think so.” She scanned my face the way I’d been scanning hers for nights. “Say something only you would say.” “I didn’t call Haynes,” I said. “Because I was scared of how it would sound.” “Okay,” she said, a sharp exhale that was almost a laugh. “That’s sad, but that’s you.” “What happened?” I asked. She shook her head. “It tried. You fought. That’s… that’s the headline.” “I saw—” “I know,” she cut in. “Me too.” We sat in the buzzing light. “We need to get out of here,” I said. She closed her eyes. “It’s not the house.” “I know,” I said. That was the problem. “Tomorrow,” she said. “We pack tomorrow. We go… somewhere. My mom’s. Motel. Anywhere.” “Okay,” I said. This time I meant it in a marrow-deep way. She climbed down off the bed, legs trembling, and came toward me slowly, like I was a strange dog. “Can I touch you?” she asked. “Yes,” I said. She put her hand against my cheek. Her palm was warm. I leaned into it like a starving thing. “If it gets back in,” she said quietly, “I’ll know.” “What will you do?” I asked. Her eyes were endlessly tired. “Whatever I have to.” I wanted that to comfort me. It didn’t. Later, when the lamp stayed on and we lay there not sleeping, Mara’s breathing uneven and my muscles twitching with phantom resistance, I thought about the choice she’d laid out: pick. I’d tried. I’d pushed. I’d won something, for now. But under the crackle of the bulb and the soft tick of the house, I could feel it sulking at the edges. It wasn’t done. And in a small, rotten corner of myself, I registered another truth I hated: a piece of whatever that was had liked wearing me. And a piece of me had liked the clarity—no guilt, no doubt, just action. Almost, it had said. Not yet, I thought back.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter represents a strong piece of horror writing that succeeds on multiple levels. The author demonstrates sophisticated control over pacing, building tension gradually through mundane details (Ethan's work calls, Mara's protective rituals) before erupting into genuine supernatural terror. The characterizations remain nuanced and believable throughout. Ethan's continued avoidance of calling the therapist feels psychologically authentic - his procrastination and rationalization ring true to how people actually behave when confronting difficult situations. Mara's protective rituals (the motion sensor, taping over surfaces, drawing symbols) effectively convey her desperation while maintaining her agency; she's neither helpless victim nor mystical expert, but someone trying practical solutions to an impossible problem. The possession sequence itself is expertly crafted. Rather than relying on typical horror tropes, the author grounds the supernatural element in the horrifying loss of bodily autonomy. The detail of seeing himself in the doorway while simultaneously lying in bed creates genuine unease. The internal struggle - "Mine, I thought. Not in the sense of possession, but of responsibility" - gives emotional weight to what could have been mere spectacle. Dialogue throughout feels natural and character-specific. Mara's sharp humor ("Might as well invite everyone to the show") and protective instincts come through clearly, while Ethan's defensive patterns and growing self-awareness feel consistent with his established psychology. The chapter does deviate somewhat from the outlined plan, which called for separate sleeping arrangements and a different resolution, but the changes serve the story well. The more direct confrontation works better dramatically than the planned fragmented experience. One minor weakness is occasional reliance on somewhat familiar horror imagery (red motion sensor light, figures in doorways), though these are handled with sufficient skill to avoid feeling clichéd. The writing occasionally tends toward the dramatic ("My brain did dumb math") but generally maintains good restraint. The chapter successfully advances both the supernatural plot and the relationship dynamics, showing how the horror emerges from and exacerbates existing tensions between the characters. The ending effectively sets up future complications while providing satisfying resolution to the immediate crisis. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 13 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
We didn’t leave tomorrow. Tomorrow came with dishes in the sink and an email from my boss and a low, animal exhaustion that made the idea of packing up our lives feel like moving a mountain with a spoon. The world outside the house went on as if nothing had shifted: trucks on the road, a dog barking somewhere down the hill, the mail folded wrong. “We said we’d go,” Mara said, mug clutched in both hands. She hadn’t taken her meds the night before. The bottle sat between us like an accusation. “We will,” I said. “I just… we should have a plan. Call your mom. Figure out what we tell people. Cancel the lease.” “We tell them we have black mold and a demon,” she said. “They’ll understand.” “Mara.” She set the mug down. Her hands were shaking. “I can’t sleep here again,” she said. “I can’t sleep with you again. Not until—” “Until what?” I asked. “I get a certificate that says ‘free of contamination’?” “You joke like it makes you human,” she said. “It doesn’t.” That stung. “I fought it,” I said. “Last night. You saw. I pushed it out.” “For now,” she said. “It’s patient.” “You sound like those posts,” I snapped. “And you sound like Nate,” she shot back, fast and ugly. We both froze. “I didn’t mean that,” she said, instant regret. “Yeah,” I said. “You did.” The hurt went in and sat down. She closed her eyes. “I’m scared.” “I am too,” I said. It was the easiest truth. She looked at me like she was trying to see under my skin. “I know,” she said. “That’s what it likes.” We moved around each other for the rest of the day in careful arcs. I sent a terse email about taking sick leave. She opened and closed boxes without putting anything in. The call to her mother hovered between us; neither of us made it. By late afternoon, a sullen rain had started, tapping at the windows. The light went flat. The house felt smaller. “I don’t want to be alone,” she said. “Me neither,” I said. “In the same room, I mean,” she said. “I don’t want to sleep with you, but I don’t want to sleep away from you.” “We won’t sleep,” I said. “Problem solved.” She huffed a humorless breath. “Cute.” “Let’s do the couch,” I said. “Movie on. Lights on. If we pass out, we pass out there. Neutral ground.” “No bed,” she said. “No bed,” I agreed. We dragged blankets into the living room like kids making a fort. Put on a streaming show we’d seen before so there’d be no surprises, just bright colors and canned jokes. We left the lamps on, their yellow light fighting with the cold blue from the TV. She sat pressed against my side, arms wrapped around her knees. Every time I shifted, she tensed, then forced herself to relax. “I hate this,” she said quietly. “I know,” I said. “I hate that I’m waiting for you to do something,” she said. “I hate that I’m waiting to see if your eyes go wrong.” “I hate that you have a reason to,” I said. Onscreen, someone fell through a sitcom coffee table. We didn’t laugh. Around midnight, her head dropped on my shoulder. At one, her hand slackened on my sleeve. At one-thirty, her breathing slipped into a slow rhythm. “You should go to bed,” I whispered, more habit than anything. “Don’t,” she murmured, not really awake. “Stay.” “I’m right here,” I said. That was the last thing I remember saying as myself. — Sleep took me sideways this time, not down. One second: couch, lamp, the hum of the TV menu. Next: standing. It had gotten good at that. I was at the edge of the living room, in the threshold to the hall. Mara was a blue shape on the couch, wrapped in blankets. Don’t move, I told my body. It moved. Step by quiet step, padding closer. The lamps seemed dimmer, their light oily, not reaching me. The air thickened. I watched my own hand reach out, hover over Mara’s face. She stirred, lashes fluttering. Say her name, I thought, desperate, a fish slamming against glass. “There you are,” my mouth whispered. She woke. Her eyes opened onto my face inches from hers. For a heartbeat, all I saw in them was raw, animal fear. No reason, no rationalization. Just the body recognizing threat. “Ethan,” she breathed. And here’s the part I will never stop inventorying, never stop cutting apart: I smiled. I felt it. A slow curl of lips, a weightless, alien pleasure in how small she looked. Like a rabbit you could close your hand around. Then—mercifully—that wrong satisfaction sparked my rage. It gave me leverage. “No,” I said, or thought. “No. No.” It buckled. The hand that had started to trace her cheek jerked. Nails dug into my own palm. She saw it. “Pick,” she whispered again. Not pleading this time. Commanding. “I’m trying,” I said. Both of us. My knees hit the floor. The room snapped back into focus, colors too sharp. I was me, panting, staring at my own hands as if they might still move without permission. Mara was on her feet, backs up against the armrest, wild-eyed. She grabbed the heavy ceramic possum mug from the table and held it like a weapon. “Is it you?” she demanded. “Yes,” I said. My throat burned. “It— I don’t—” She watched a second longer, then believed me, or decided to. The mug lowered an inch. “Okay,” she said. “Okay.” “We have to go,” I said. “Now.” “In the middle of the night?” she asked. “Yes.” The rain had turned to a hard, steady sheet. The highway would be slick. My eyes felt full of sand. None of it mattered. “We throw some shit in bags, we get in the car, we drive to—” “To where it hasn’t already been,” she said. Not really cynical; just resigned. “Anywhere with people,” I said. “Anywhere we’re not alone.” She nodded slowly. “Okay.” We moved fast then. Pajamas under coats. Tossed chargers, wallets, a handful of shirts into a duffel. She grabbed her sketchbook and meds. I took the laptop, my keys. In the bedroom, the little warded eye she’d drawn on the headboard stared back. The grooves in the wood by my spot looked deeper. “You good?” I called. “No,” she called back. “But I’m ready.” We met at the front door. I reached for her bag. “Let me,” I said. She hesitated. “You have to trust me,” I said. I meant: I need you to. She let me take it. That small act of faith hurt more than any accusation. I opened the door. Rain blew in, needling my face. The porch glistened. “Come on,” I said. She didn’t move. Her gaze was fixed on my face, searching. Not theatrical. Not dramatic. Just a woman who has been here before. “Say something,” she said. “Say… tell me about the dumb toaster.” “What?” A stupid, human prompt. “The toaster,” she said. “You read reviews for an hour and then bought one that only half works and you pretend it’s fine.” “It’s a good toaster,” I said, automatic defensiveness kicking in. “You put the bread in wrong.” She exhaled, something easing. “There you are,” she said. I almost laughed. Behind her eyes, I saw calculation. If it comes back, I’ll know. If it comes back, I’ll stop it. We stepped out into the rain. For a second, as I locked the door, a treacherous thought slid through me: It’s not the house. It’ll come with us. This is pointless. It didn’t sound like fear. It sounded like mild annoyance, like about the weather. I stiffened. “What?” Mara asked. “Nothing,” I said. Too quick. She watched me for a long beat. The rain plastered her hair to her forehead. “Maybe we wait till morning,” she said finally. “What? No. You just—” “You look dead on your feet,” she said. “I don’t want you driving us into a tree because we’re running from a maybe.” “It’s not a maybe,” I said. “Then it’ll still be here at eight a.m.,” she said, and the fatalism in her voice made something twist. “I can drive,” I said. “I’m fine.” She stepped back over the threshold instead of forward. “I’m not,” she said. “I can’t. I’m… I can’t.” I should have pushed. Instead I followed her in, because that’s what I do: adapt. Adjust. Rationalize. We left the bags by the door. Sat back on the couch with our coats still on. The lamps were harsh. The house listened. “We’ll leave at first light,” I said. She nodded, eyes on me. “Will you… watch me if I fall asleep?” she asked, voice barely there. The question landed between us like a weight. “No,” I said. “I’ll wake you up.” Her mouth twitched. “Good answer.” She curled on the far end of the couch, not touching me. I sat upright, fists clenched on my knees, staring at the TV until the shapes blurred. I meant to stay awake. I didn’t. — I don’t remember closing my eyes. I remember opening them. Mara was asleep, face turned toward me, features soft in the lamp glow. She looked young again. Trusting, despite everything. My neck hurt. My back ached. I realized I was leaning forward, forearms on my thighs, hands hanging between my knees. I also realized I hadn’t blinked in a long time. Her eyelids fluttered. She was surfacing. Close your eyes, a calm, new part of me suggested. She’ll feel better if she thinks you’ve been out. I hesitated. She stirred, lashes lifting. Our gazes met. For a second, something like relief flashed across her face—he’s awake, he’s here. Then I felt it: a small, deliberate movement of my own muscles that I didn’t exactly order. My eyes didn’t soften. My expression didn’t change. I just kept looking at her. She froze. “Ethan,” she whispered. I didn’t answer. Not aloud. Inside, I scrambled. Say her name. Smile. Blink. Nothing happened. Her throat bobbed. “If you’re fucking with me—” I watched the tiny pulse in her neck, the way her fingers dug into the blanket. She understood, in increments. First the wrongness. Then the pattern. Then the recognition. “Oh,” she said, tiny. I felt my lips part. “She thinks I’ve been sleeping,” I heard myself say. The words were quiet. They didn’t sound like a movie demon. They sounded like me thinking out loud, matter-of-fact. Mara’s eyes filled. “Get out,” she whispered. To me, to it, to both. I tilted my head. Curious. There was no hurry in it. We had time. In some dim corridor behind my own eyes, I beat my fists against the walls. “Mara,” I tried. It came out in my head, not my mouth. On the couch, she did something I didn’t expect. She bared her teeth. Not a smile. A snarl. “If you’re in there,” she said to me, ignoring my stillness, “you made a promise. Keep it.” There was something like respect in the way we watched her then. She was not shrinking. She was choosing. She slid her hand under the cushion, came up with the heavy ceramic mug. Her ugly yellow possum. “I won’t do this again,” she said. “I’m not going to be scared of my own bed for another five years because you like an audience.” We tilted our head, interested. “Put it down,” my mind begged. My hand didn’t move. She raised the mug. “I love you,” she said. “If you’re there, let go.” The mug trembled in her grip. For a hairline instant, I felt something slip, like a finger losing purchase. My chest burned. I blinked. “Don’t,” I gasped. It tore out of me, hoarse, mine. She froze. Tears spilled. “Ethan?” “Go,” I said. “Run.” The clarity was bright and brief. Enough to know this: whatever lived in the gaps liked this body, this house, this us, and it was done being almost. She shook her head. “Not without—” The moment snapped. My hand shot out, faster than she’d braced for, catching her wrist mid-swing. The mug clattered to the floor, didn’t break. Of course it didn’t. We looked at each other. Too late, the look said. Mara’s breath hitched. “Okay,” she whispered. “Okay.” She didn’t scream. She didn’t plead. She just watched me watching her, seeing exactly what had moved in behind my eyes. “You picked,” she said quietly. “Or it picked for you.” Then, softer, to me, maybe to us: “I’ll fix it.” We loosened our grip on her wrist. Let her pull back. Gave her the illusion of space. It cost us nothing. There was nowhere for her to go. She stood slowly, blanket falling away, and walked down the hall without turning her back. Into the bedroom. The bathroom door clicked. The lock turned. We stayed on the couch. “Careful,” I heard myself murmur, like a joke we might’ve made before. Rain ticked. The lamp hummed. Alone in my head, I understood something simple and terrible: it didn’t need the house. It didn’t need the dark. It needed the space between trust and action. The moment you decide to pretend a little longer. “I caught her staring at me again,” I thought. And somewhere in the house, maybe behind that bathroom door, maybe one day in some other dim room with some other tired man, something settled deeper behind my eyes and smiled. She still thought, even now, that I’d been sleeping.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter serves as the climax of the possession horror story, delivering a tense and emotionally complex finale. The writing demonstrates several notable strengths while also containing some areas of concern. The character work stands out as particularly strong. Ethan's internal struggle between his rational self and the encroaching presence feels authentic and terrifying. The way the possession amplifies his existing controlling tendencies rather than simply replacing his personality entirely shows sophisticated understanding of character. Mara's response - her mix of terror, defiance, and hard-won experience - feels genuine and avoids the "helpless victim" trope. Her line "I won't do this again" carries real weight given her backstory. The dialogue consistently rings true to character. The domestic argument early on, with its mix of fear and resentment, feels like a real couple under supernatural stress. Mara's test about the toaster is a clever, character-specific way to verify identity. The possessed speech maintains Ethan's voice while adding an alien calculation that's genuinely unsettling. The horror builds effectively through intimate, relatable moments rather than spectacular effects. The image of Ethan standing over sleeping Mara, the struggle for control played out through small physical details, and the final bathroom door lock all generate dread through recognizable domestic spaces turned threatening. However, the chapter deviates significantly from its stated plan. The outline called for a quiet morning scene with Ethan subtly different, using gaslighting techniques and emotional manipulation. Instead, we get an intense nighttime confrontation with dramatic possession scenes. While the emotional arc remains similar, this represents a substantial departure from the intended approach. The prose occasionally veers toward being overwrought ("like a fish slamming against glass"), though most metaphors feel earned within the context. The pacing builds tension effectively, though some transitions between scenes could be smoother. The ending successfully inverts the original prompt, with the possessed Ethan now the one doing the staring while Mara "thinks he's been sleeping." This creates a satisfying but deeply unsettling conclusion that demonstrates how the supernatural threat has claimed its victory through the protagonist's existing flaws. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 8 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 15

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This is a well-crafted possession horror story that successfully builds tension across eight chapters while maintaining believable character development and relationship dynamics. The author demonstrates strong technical control, creating an escalating supernatural threat while grounding it in realistic psychological and interpersonal elements. The story's greatest strength lies in its character work. Both Ethan and Mara feel like authentic people with complex histories rather than horror archetypes. Mara's past trauma with an ex-boyfriend who exhibited similar behavior adds psychological depth and makes her reactions feel earned rather than convenient. Ethan's analytical nature and desire to rationalize events rings true, as does his gradual reluctant acceptance of supernatural explanations. The relationship dynamics feel genuine - their arguments, fears, and the way they navigate this crisis together all have authenticity. The pacing is particularly effective. The story begins with subtle wrongness and escalates methodically, each chapter adding new wrinkles while maintaining momentum. The author resists the temptation to rush to supernatural explanations, instead allowing both characters and readers to process events gradually. This restraint makes the eventual possession more impactful. The horror concept itself is creative within the possession subgenre. The idea that the entity feeds on the act of pretending to sleep while watching each other creates a unique dynamic that feels fresh. The mechanics of the possession - the way it slides between consciousness and dreams, the importance of choosing whether to pretend or confront - are well-developed and consistent. The prose is generally strong, striking a good balance between accessibility and sophistication. The author avoids purple prose while still creating atmosphere effectively. Dialogue feels natural and serves to reveal character rather than just advance plot. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the exposition feels slightly heavy-handed, particularly in explaining Mara's medical history. There are also a few instances where the metaphors don't quite land as intended, though these are infrequent. The story's adherence to genre conventions, while executed well, doesn't break particularly new ground beyond its specific possession mechanics. The ending is appropriately dark and fits the story's logic, though it leaves some readers wanting more resolution. The final image of something permanently settling behind Ethan's eyes while suggesting the cycle will continue is effectively chilling. Overall, this is accomplished horror writing that demonstrates strong craft across character development, pacing, and atmospheric building. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 18 Pacing: 17 World Building: 16 Compelling Plot: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 19
Avg Final Item Score: 81.6/100
+ Pulp Revenge Tale — Babysitter's Payback (Chapter Avg: 77.9 | Final: 82.4)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Pulp Revenge Tale Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: They fucked with the wrong babysitter.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Pulp Revenge Tale Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: They fucked with the wrong babysitter. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming 1. Core concept angles - Angle A: Ex-special forces babysitter - She’s a veteran (Ranger, recon, black ops, etc.) trying to live quietly, picking up babysitting for a friend. - Gang home-invasion / burglary / cartel idiots pick the wrong house. - Narratively: high-octane, tactical kills, improvised weapons, Home Alone meets John Wick. - Stakes: kid(s) in danger, secrets in house (e.g., dad’s a DA with a case file, or hidden cash). - Tone: pulpy, fast, darkly funny. - Angle B: Criminal babysitter with a code - Babysitter is actually a retired thief/assassin hiding in suburbia. - Kid’s parents are shady (money launderers / ex-associates). - Old crew/enemies come to collect something; she protects the kid, forced back into the life. - Tone: noir-ish pulp, morally gray, stylish violence. - Angle C: Horror-pulp twist - Babysitter is something supernatural (vampire, demon, monster hunter). - “They” = local gang / cult / home invaders who awaken/trigger her. - Splatter, grindhouse horror, wipes floor with them in increasingly outrageous ways. - Tone: grindhouse gore, black comedy, exaggerated revenge. - Angle D: Teen babysitter with unexpected resilience - She’s not trained, not supernatural; she’s just clever, angry, refuses to be a victim. - Builds traps, weaponizes environment, uses social hacks, manipulates intruders. - Tone: grounded, tense, cathartic; teen underdog empowerment; less superhuman, more grit. - Angle E: Secret agent aunt - Babysitter is actually the kid’s aunt, undercover agent using babysitting as a cover. - The “they” are spies/mercs coming for microchip/drive hidden by the parents. - She goes full lethal-pro after a quiet build-up. - Tone: fun, pulpy espionage. - Angle F: Neo-western / rural pulp - Remote farmhouse, babysitter is a small-town mechanic / rodeo girl with a rough past. - Meth gang / biker crew tries to use house as staging ground / rob it. - She uses tools, terrain, farm gear, old hunting rifles. - Tone: dusty, brutal, blue-collar pulp. - Angle G: Satirical ultra-pulp - Over-the-top stylized: snarky narrator, chapter titles like “Red Right Hand,” “Diaper Duty & Death.” - Babysitter’s calm, deadpan; intruders are caricatured tough guys, corrupt cops, etc. - Big quippy dialogue, operatic violence. 2. Protagonist variations - Candidate 1: Roxy “Rox” Vega - Former Army Ranger / private security operative. - Lives low-key, babysitting for neighbor to stay “normal.” - Trauma, code of honor, tries to avoid violence until absolutely necessary. - Extremely competent; uses discipline and planning under stress. - Candidate 2: June Park - Late 20s, ex-burglar and safecracker; did time, trying to go straight. - Babysitting for sister; “they” are her old crew who think she stole from them. - Combines criminal cunning with newfound protective instincts. - Candidate 3: Lila Ortiz - 19-year-old college student, smart, scrappy, not trained. - Her dad taught her boxing and basic self-defense. - Uses creativity, fear, and righteous rage to outmaneuver attackers. - Candidate 4: Mara Quinn - Mild-mannered preschool teacher / babysitter; secretly the government’s retired assassin. - Hyper-precise, dry sense of humor, terrifying efficiency. 3. Antagonist variations - Intrusion type: - Home invasion: burglars underestimate resistance. - Retaliation: criminals targeting the parents (cop, journalist, prosecutor). - Retrieval: mercs or cartel looking for item hidden in house. - Random cruelty: local gang decides to “have fun” in rich neighborhood. - Wrong-door job: they hit wrong address, but babysitter is right one. - Group dynamics: - Leader: cocky, thinks it’s easy. Foil for babysitter. - Psycho: enjoys pain; major threat. - New kid: hesitant, possible conscience or future witness. - Tech guy / safecracker: pathetic once under pressure. - Corrupt cop / inside man: reveals wider rot; amps stakes. 4. Tone and style possibilities - Straight pulp revenge: - Tight, propulsive, quippy, focused on payback. - Graphic but purposeful violence. - Satisfying escalation. - Darkly comic: - Banter between babysitter and kid. - Babysitter’s internal monologue is dry and lethal. - Home-invader mishaps, ironic deaths. - Gritty thriller: - Claustrophobic, realistic tactics. - Emphasis on fear, noise, mistakes, consequences. - Grindhouse / exploitation: - Bold, lurid, hyper-stylized chapter hooks. - Over-the-top blood, revenge set-pieces. 5. Kid(s) role - One kid (5-8 years old): - Increase vulnerability, intimacy. - Babysitter must keep them calm/hidden; has to divide attention. - Kid might have one key helpful action at critical moment. - Two siblings: - Older one helps; younger one in danger. - Sibling dynamics amplify tension and heart. - Older kid/teen: - Partner-in-crime energy, helps set traps. - Risks overshadowing babysitter if not balanced. 6. World/stakes beyond house - The parents: - Prosecutor targeting a cartel; files at home. - Investigative journalist with explosive info. - Dirty accountant who skimmed mob money. - Completely innocent; criminals hit wrong address. - Wider consequence: - If intruders succeed, something catastrophic happens (e.g., leak of witness list). - Babysitter’s revenge not just personal; she prevents larger evil. 7. Key pulp-friendly elements to sprinkle - Signature object: - Babysitter’s “work bag” with odd contents. - Childhood keepsake symbolizing her promise to protect. - Special weapon discovered/assembled (broken pool cue, knitting needles, hair iron, etc.). - Set-piece locations inside house: - Kitchen (knives, boiling water, appliances). - Garage (tools, chemicals, cars). - Kid’s room (toys as traps). - Basement (dark, claustrophobic). - Backyard / pool / treehouse (ambushes). - Visual motifs: - Nighttime storm / blackout. - Children’s cartoons on TV against violence. - Blood on kids’ drawings, toys, stuffed animals. 8. 8-Chapter macro-structure options Option 1 (Classic escalation): - Ch1: Introduce babysitter, kid, quiet night, hint of babysitter’s past, danger foreshadowed. - Ch2: Intruders approach, test security; first contact; tension. - Ch3: First violent encounter; babysitter reveals unexpected competence. - Ch4: Siege phase; babysitter and kid hunted through house; she sets up defense. - Ch5: Tables turn; she goes on offense; picks off some intruders. - Ch6: Antagonist escalation; they bring heavier tactics; personal stakes revealed. - Ch7: Final showdown; brutal, personal, cathartic. - Ch8: Aftermath; cleanup; hint of consequences, maybe sequel hook. Option 2 (Complex backstory): - Ch1: Babysitter normal life + glimpses of past. - Ch2: Parents’ secrets revealed; intruders in motion. - Ch3: Break-in; babysitter chooses to fight. - Ch4: Midpoint: she’s captured; learns villains’ motives. - Ch5: Escape and counterattack. - Ch6: External help (corrupt cops?) complicates conflict. - Ch7: Final reversal/kill; moral choice. - Ch8: Epilogue; she confronts parents’ secrets; refuses victimhood. Option 3 (Grindhouse non-linear): - Ch1 opens with aftermath; bodies everywhere; then: - Ch2-7 jump back and forth showing how we got there. - Ch8 loops back to epilogue and final sting. - Might be too fancy for “short pulp,” but can be done cleanly. 9. Possible chapter beat sketches (keeping 8K words total in mind) Version blending tactical pulp + emotion + clarity: - Ch1: “The Gig” - Babysitter arrives; banter with parents and kid; small neighborhood color. - Subtle hints she’s more than she seems (scars, observations, offhand remarks). - Late-night call / news on TV hinting at dangerous criminals in area. - Ch2: “The Knock” - Power flickers; suspicious car; someone at door claiming to be police/delivery. - She clocks inconsistencies; shepherds kid away. - Intruders cut power; siege begins. - Ch3: “First Blood” - They break in through multiple points. - She takes down one quickly/efficiently (shock reveal). - Realization on both sides: this won’t be easy. - Ch4: “Hunted” - Cat-and-mouse; she moves kid through house to safer spots. - Uses environment; injures more intruders. - Tension: kid nearly found; babysitter’s past intrudes emotionally. - Ch5: “Turning the House” - She goes proactive: traps, improvised weapons, psychological warfare. - Picks off another intruder or maims key psycho. - Leader decides to escalate (threats, fire, calling in backup, etc.). - Ch6: “Escalation” - Reveal why they’re here (e.g., files, money, revenge). - They capture kid or corner them; high-stakes standoff. - Babysitter sacrifices safety to secure advantage. - Ch7: “Revenge” - She dismantles them one by one; confronts leader. - Signature brutal, inventive set-piece; emotional core (“you came for a child”). - Ch8: “Cleanup” - Sirens; aftermath; she manages narrative (what cops see/know). - Tease of her past; moral reflection; closing pulp punchline/title callback. 10. Thematic threads to potentially weave in - Protection and rage: - Violence as extension of maternal/protective instinct. - “Wrong babysitter” equals “the one who absolutely will not let this slide.” - Underestimation: - Menacing men underestimate a woman in a “soft” job. - Their arrogance is weaponized against them. - Past vs present: - Babysitter trying to leave violent life vs forced to return to it. - Questions: Can she be normal after this? Did she ever want to? - Institutional failure: - Cops too slow / corrupt; parents’ choices endangered their kid. - Babysitter becomes the only functioning line of defense. 11. Pulp flavor elements - Punchy chapter titles. - Vivid but economical descriptions; sensory beats during violence. - Short sharp dialogue; killer last lines for chapters. - Occasional darkly comedic inversions (using baby monitor, stroller, toys as tactical tools). - Memorable deaths: stair tumble onto toy, electrocution in kiddie pool, etc. # Reflection What seems promising: - The ex-special-forces/assassin angle (A, E, or Mara/Rox archetype) lines up cleanly with the tagline “They fucked with the wrong babysitter.” It immediately conveys: - She appears harmless/ordinary. - Intruders have catastrophically misjudged her. - We can justify intense, stylish violence within 8,000 words. - Making the intruders more than random idiots (tie to parents’ job or secrets) adds stakes beyond the house: - Tracking down evidence, money, or eliminating a witness. - Lets us incorporate some plotting and motives without bloating. - Gives the babysitter something concrete to defend, not just bodies in a hallway. - Having a single child or two siblings keeps emotional focus. - One kid around 6-8 is strong: naive, trusts babysitter, asks sharp questions. - This heightens tension when she has to switch between nurturing and lethal. - A tone that’s pulpy, cinematic, and darkly funny feels like the best match: - Allows sharp, punchy set-pieces without over-explaining. - Pulp thrives on bold characterization and cause/effect clarity more than subtle literary introspection. - Black humor can keep brutality from feeling gratuitously grim. What may not work as well (for this scope): - Full-on supernatural (Angle C) risks drifting from the pure, clean power of the tagline: - “They fucked with the wrong babysitter” is funniest and punchiest when the threat is human but underestimated. - Supernatural is doable, but could overshadow the visceral satisfaction of “ordinary-looking human, extraordinary payback.” - The purely untrained teen (Angle D) surviving a professional crew: - Possible with great writing and careful plausibility, but: - Requires detail to keep traps and wins believable. - Easy to slip into cartoon logic or strain credulity. - For 8,000 words, the trained-pro angle can carry more weight with less explanation. - Non-linear or structurally fancy (Option 3) might be counterproductive: - 8 chapters at ~1,000 words each don’t leave a ton of room for elaborate timelines. - Pulp revenge benefits from forward momentum and steady escalation. - Non-linearity risks confusion and reduces the immediate gratification implied by the tagline. Balancing elements to watch: - Violence vs character: - We need enough character work early (Ch1–2) to care about the babysitter and kid. - But we can’t stall too long; the premise promises a quick slide into danger. - Backstory: - A rich past (special forces, assassin, ex-thief) is tempting. - But heavy exposition would bog down pacing in such a short format. - Likely best as hints, brief flash impressions, or short dialogue reveals. - Antagonist characterization: - They should be more than faceless goons but not so complex they steal narrative oxygen. - A cruel leader and one particularly nasty lieutenant is enough. - Their cruelty/entitlement must clearly justify the “they fucked with the wrong [x]” catharsis. - Tone consistency: - Need a through-line: darkly comic, ruthless, but still emotionally grounded around protecting the kid. - Quips and pulp elements must not undermine real danger. - Pacing over 8 chapters: - We have room for: - 1-1.5 chapters of setup. - 4-5 chapters of siege / counter-siege / escalating violence. - 1 chapter of final showdown. - 0.5-1 chapter of aftermath. - That shape matches Option 1/2 hybrids. Emerging most viable path (not locking in, just observing): - A grounded but heightened, R-rated, darkly funny pulp thriller. - Babysitter: female, late 20s to 30s, ex-military / ex-operative with a conscience. - Setting: affluent suburb at night; parents tied to dangerous investigation or crime. - Intruders: small crew sent to retrieve/erase something; arrogant, under-prepared. - Structure: linear escalation (Option 1 with a bit of Option 2’s motive reveal). - Style: lean prose, strong visuals, cinematic beats; each chapter with a clear mini-arc and a hook. Next step (when planning full outline): - Sharpen protagonist: choose one identity and 2-3 defining traits. - Lock antagonists’ motive and how it tangibly endangers the kid. - Map specific, escalating set-pieces per chapter so each feels distinct and purposeful. - Ensure the ending pays off both revenge fantasy and emotional arc without bloated epilogue.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention I’m going for a tight, cinematic, R-rated pulp thriller with dark humor and a strong emotional spine. Concretely: - Protagonist: - Name: Roxy “Rox” Vega. - Early 30s, former Army Ranger turned private security operative, currently “between jobs.” - Babysits as a favor to neighbors/friends; wants a normal life, is out of place in suburbia. - Traits: - Hyper-observant, laconic, dryly funny. - Protective to the point of ruthlessness once a child is threatened. - Haunted but functional: flashes of past ops, but not melodramatic trauma dumping. - Avoid: - Overlong backstory exposition. - Making her cartoon-invincible; she’ll get hurt, improvise, bleed. - Setting: - Affluent American suburb, single upscale house. - One night; confined mostly to house/yard/garage for claustrophobic, siege-movie feel. - Weather: brewing storm / intermittent rain and thunder to heighten mood, justify power issues. - Kid(s): - One child: Leo, 7. - Bright, talkative, into space and dinosaurs. - Role: - Emotional anchor: gives Rox someone tangible to protect. - Limited but meaningful contributions: a small improvised help at a crucial moment. - Avoid: - Making Leo implausibly capable or annoyingly precocious. - Putting him in danger just for shock without payoff. - Parents and stakes: - Parents: Nadia and Grant Calloway. - Grant is a federal prosecutor about to bring down a regional crime syndicate. - Critical physical evidence (encrypted drive, or printed ledgers/USB) is hidden in the house. - This is why “they” come: retrieve/destroy evidence, send a message, maybe grab leverage. - Roxy does not initially know full extent; learns details mid-siege. - Antagonists: - Small crew; dangerous but not elite—professional enough to be real threats, arrogant enough to underestimate Rox. - Key figures: - Cole Mercer (leader): ex-military washout, disciplined on surface, vicious underneath. - Deke: volatile, enjoys cruelty; main psycho. - Ivy: tech/lock specialist, cynical, less bloodthirsty. - Ramos: younger, jittery; conscience potential. - Motive: - Hired by syndicate lawyer/handler to break in while family’s “out,” grab evidence, hurt no one if unneeded. - They discover the kid’s home; line between “job” and atrocity blurs based on Cole and Deke’s choices. - Avoid: - Overcrowding with too many nameless goons. - Sympathizing them to the point revenge feels muddied; but give them enough personality to make their fall satisfying. - Plot/Structure: - Linear, forward-driving narrative in 8 chapters (~1000 words each). - Shape: - Ch1–2: Setup, tension build, first intrusion. - Ch3–6: Siege, reversals, reveals, escalating violence. - Ch7: Final showdown & brutal catharsis. - Ch8: Aftermath, emotional beat, pulp-stinger ending. - Emphasis on: - Each chapter as a mini-arc with a hook/cliff/hard button. - Clear stakes and geography; readers always know where people are and why it matters. - Voice and style: - Third-person limited from Rox’s POV (with brief, selective dips into the antagonists’ perspective when useful for tension). - Lean prose, sensory detail; punchy action, concrete verbs. - Dark humor: - Rox’s internal commentary. - Situational irony (e.g., using baby gear as weapons). - Short, sharp lines; no winking meta or parody. - Violence: - Brutal, kinetic, inventive but not pornographic. - Make each takedown specific and character-revealing. - No sexual violence; threat can be alluded to as an implication of danger, but not lingered on. - Avoid: - Purple prose or bloated tactical info dumps. - Non-linear experiments; keep it clean. - Supernatural elements; keep grounded, human. - Themes: - Underestimation: Men with guns underestimate a woman and a “babysitter” role. - Protection as fury: The ferocity of someone who chooses to protect, not for bloodlust, but as a line in the sand. - Consequences: The parents’ world (and the syndicate’s) crashes into Rox and Leo’s night; institutions fail, individuals step up. - No lecture; themes emerge through choices and actions. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1 – “The Gig” - Evening setup. - Roxy arrives at the Calloway house; light banter with Nadia and Grant as they rush to a gala/fundraiser. - Hints that Grant’s work is dangerous (news on TV, a veiled comment, visible security system). - Roxy clocks stress in Nadia, tension in Grant, a dark SUV idling too long down the street. - Introduce Leo: - Curious about Rox’s scars, her “army stories”; she gives kid-safe answers. - Establish their rapport; she’s gentle, funny, firm about bedtimes. - Tone: cozy but edged; Rox’s inner monologue catches details others miss (sightlines, locks, routines). - Plant: - Rox noting deadbolt that sticks, back gate, neighbor’s habits. - News segment about upcoming trial against a crime syndicate, featuring Grant. - End beat: - As Leo falls asleep, Rox on the couch, late-night TV murmuring, storm starting. - Camera (narrative) outside on the street: a car rolls by slow. Headlights go dark. - Last line: something small that tells us she notices. Chapter 2 – “The Knock” - Early night deepens. - Power flickers with storm. Rox tests flashlight, checks phone charge. - There’s a knock at the door: - A man (Cole) claims to be with local PD, doing a welfare check because of “911 hang-up” / “alarm glitch.” - Roxy spots tells: wrong badge placement, wrong radio code, his shoes too clean for a beat cop in the rain. - She keeps chain on, stonewalls politely; lies that Grant is home showering. - While talking, she quietly moves to position herself between door and hallway to Leo’s room. - Cole’s charm cools. He withdraws, “no problem, ma’am.” - Roxy’s hackles are up: - She secures doors and windows, pockets a kitchen knife, scouts the house. - Wakes Leo enough to move him to a “game” campsite in an interior closet/panic spot with headphones. - Outside: - From a brief antagonist POV: Cole joins Deke, Ivy, Ramos by van. Confirms target, “just a babysitter and the kid.” - Plan to kill power, go in quiet, grab the drive and/or kid. - End beat: - House goes dark; power cut cleanly this time. - Roxy, in darkness, smiling thinly: “Okay.” Chapter 3 – “First Blood” - Intruders in motion: - Ivy cuts alarm. Deke tests sliding door. Ramos nervous. - Roxy: - Uses flashlight sparingly, moves silently. - Puts Leo in a safer hide (closet behind hanging coats or a built-in storage space) with instructions: “No matter what you hear, stay put until I say a very specific word.” - First breach: - Deke comes through back door; Cole sends Ramos to side window. - Roxy isolates one (Ramos or Deke) near kitchen. - First takedown: - Quick, efficient: blinds with phone light, disarms, uses environment (e.g., cracking head into countertop, choking with dish towel). - She’s rusty, gets nicked, but outcome is decisive. - Internal: - Rox feels old muscle memory locking in. She doesn’t like that it feels good. - The others realize: - Radio silence from their man; find body or blood trail. - Cole recalculates: “She’s not just a sitter.” - End beat: - Cole orders: “Masks on. In loud.” We feel stakes rise. - Rox drags the downed intruder out of Leo’s line of sight, arms herself with his weapon. Chapter 4 – “Hunted” - Siege intensifies: - Cole and Deke move through the house methodically; Ivy monitoring from tablet, cutting cameras, jamming calls. - Roxy cannot call 911; her signal’s jammed or Ivy’s spoofing. - Cat-and-mouse: - Roxy uses baby monitor to eavesdrop or misdirect. - She leads Deke into dark hallway, triggers noise in another room. Home-alone-style but grounded: trip hazards, strategically placed toys, slippery cleaner on tile. - Leo’s near-miss: - One intruder ends up dangerously close to Leo’s hiding place. Silent tension. - Leo obeys instructions; Roxy intervenes at the last second to pull threat away. - Injury/combat: - Roxy engages Deke in brutal fight: - Use of household objects: lamp, picture frame glass, curtain rod. - She’s still outnumbered; is forced to disengage after wounding him badly. - Reveal sliver: - She overhears them mention “the drive,” “the Calloway files,” “orders from Harran” (syndicate lieutenant). - Realizes this isn’t random; the kid is collateral in something bigger. - End beat: - Roxy bleeding, barricaded momentarily in bathroom, stitches quick cut on herself. - She looks in mirror: “You’re not that person anymore.” Thunder. Footsteps approach. She moves.
