Chapter 5 – “Turning the House” - Roxy shifts from pure defense to strategy: - Quickly canvases spaces she controls: garage, kids’ rooms, backyard with pool. - Improvised traps: - Tools on precarious hooks. - Bleach and cleaner mix (careful not to go too technical) for irritant. - Noise-makers to track movement. - Psychological warfare: - She uses walkie from fallen intruder to taunt Cole: - Calm, controlled; reminds him he walked into a house with a child. - Plants seeds of doubt among his crew. - Ivy’s doubt: - Short cutaway: Ivy is unnerved, didn’t sign up for dead teammate and possibly hurting a kid. - Cole strong-arms her into staying; Deke injured and enraged. - More takedowns: - One more intruder is eliminated or incapacitated via a trap + close-quarters fight in the garage (e.g., car rolling pin, wrench, nail gun). - Stakes twist: - Cole threatens over radio: if she doesn’t hand over what they want, he’ll set the house on fire with both her and the kid inside. - Roxy now knows they’ll escalate beyond a burglary; compromise impossible. - End beat: - She finds the evidence (Grant’s hidden drive/papers) during her movements. - Weighs: destroy vs use. Slips it into her pocket—a new layer of leverage. Chapter 6 – “Escalation” - Cole’s escalation: - Starts a small fire in the backyard or by the garage as demonstration. - Forces confrontation: “Give me the drive and the boy walks out.” - Moral bind: - Roxy can’t trust him; Leo’s safety vs massive criminal case. - Tense standoff: - She arranges a faux “trade” location inside the house. - Has to bring Leo closer, against her instincts, to maintain illusion. - Betrayal: - During the meet, Cole tries to double-cross: - Sniper angle (if they had backup), or Deke lunging for Leo. - Roxy partially expected it; counters, but chaos: - She’s injured more seriously (shot grazed or knife wound). - Leo is briefly grabbed or separated—moment of pure dread. - Ramos/complication: - Ramos hesitates with Leo; he’s clearly not okay with hurting a kid. - Roxy exploits this: - Fast talk, flash of humanity: “Walk away. Now.” - Leo’s small hero moment: - Distracts the man guarding him (e.g., bites his hand, jabs with dinosaur toy). - Creates opening for Roxy to reclaim him / disarm. - End beat: - Rox and Leo re-secured but cornered on upper floor. - Cole is down two people and humiliated; vows to kill her himself. - Fire spreading; time pressure introduced. Chapter 7 – “The Wrong Babysitter” - Full unleashing: - House partially on fire, alarms blaring, rain outside hissing on flames. - Roxy moves Leo to last fallback (roof access/attic/neighbor’s fence route) and sets final trap. - Ivy’s pivot: - Ivy, unnerved and seeing things blow up, tries to bail. - Cole turns a gun on her; Ivy either: - Tries to shoot him first and dies; or - Freezes, giving Rox a chance to intervene. - Showdowns: - Roxy vs Deke: - Savage fight, ends in symbolically fitting, ugly way (e.g., Deke thrown down stairs onto scattered toys/tools; neck snaps). - Roxy vs Cole: - More personal, tactical; Cole is skilled, mirrors a dark version of her. - Dialogue reveals he knows her file/background (they’ve worked same regions). - He mocks her “babysitter” life; she rejects his worldview. - Final kill: - Ingenious use of environment: - Perhaps in the kitchen or by the pool in storm. - Electrocution, drowning, or a clean close-range gunshot after she’s earned it. - Make it cathartic, not gleefully sadistic; punctuated with a sharp line tying to the title. - End beat: - Cole dead, rest neutralized. - Roxy staggers, finds Leo. He’s scared but trusting. - Sirens now in the distance; neighbors finally alerted by smoke/commotion. Chapter 8 – “Aftermath” - Immediate fallout: - Police and fire on scene. - Roxy controls the story: - Keeps her deeper past obscured. - Presents events as home invasion thwarted via “self-defense” and “luck.” - We hint some officers recognize technique, but there’s no proof. - The evidence: - She gives Grant the drive/docs (or a copy), with clear disgust: - “Lock this down. You don’t get to half-step protecting your kid.” - Implication: his carelessness/overconfidence drew this violence to his family. - Leo: - Reunited with parents. - Asks if Roxy will still babysit him. - Soft, wry moment: she promises, or hesitates with a meaningful glance. - Wider consequences: - News later mentions “botched attempt” by syndicate operatives. - Harran (off-page boss) sees Roxy on surveillance still; potential future trouble hinted. - Roxy’s choice: - She walks out into dawn, bruised, hands in pockets. - Considers disappearing vs staying in this “normal” life she clearly doesn’t fit. - Final line: - A hard, pulpy button that reclaims the tagline: - Something like: “Next time they might check who’s watching the kid. If they’re smart. If not—well. She’d be up.”
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
Good question—and a smart time to ask it. Let’s break this into three parts: - How a human might naturally approach this prompt. - Common LLM tendencies that work against this particular kind of story. - A deep critique of our current intention & plan, plus ideas to make it more human. I’ll aim to be direct and concrete, not abstract. 1. How a human might approach “They fucked with the wrong babysitter” What a good human writer often does with a prompt like this: - Starts from a feeling, not a structure. - They latch onto: - The anger of being underestimated. - The feral protectiveness of watching someone else’s kid. - The trashy joy of “oh, you idiots picked the wrong house.” - Tone is discovered while drafting, not pre-sanitized. - Zeroes in on 1–2 vivid, specific human hooks: - The weird intimacy of being in someone else’s house at night. - The glimpse into a couple’s life through their fridge magnets, their bedroom, their arguments overheard earlier. - The awkwardness of being the “help” in a rich house vs becoming its only real defense. - Indignities (being underpaid, condescended to) that make her later rage resonant. - Lets messiness in: - The babysitter might: - Swear a lot. - Make a mistake that costs something. - Freeze once; recover badly but realistically. - Feel very real flashes of pettiness, panic, shame, gallows humor. - The violence might be: - Clumsy in places; things don’t always go to plan. - A bit emotionally ugly, not purely “cool choreography.” - Uses specificity over “vibes”: - Human writers lean into: - Exact brands, songs, shows on TV. - The feel of cheap carpet under knees, the smell of someone else’s detergent, the kid’s sticky hands. - A single line of dialogue that encapsulates an entire relationship. - Isn’t afraid of jagged edges: - May not neatly tie up: - The legal/moral aftermath. - The MC’s emotional state. - The justice of the system vs the pulp revenge. - The last note might be ironic, uncertain, or bitter—not a clean mic drop. A strong human version of this story likely: - Has an attitude. - Shows some contempt for the invaders and maybe for the parents. - Knows the babysitter as a person before knowing her as a weapon. 2. Telltale LLM approaches (and why they’re dangerous here) LLM-pattern habits that can flatten this kind of story: - Over-structuring and over-clarity: - Tendency: - Rigid acts, evenly spaced “escalations,” tidy arcs for everyone. - Issue here: - Pulp revenge gets its energy from surprise and swing. - Too-coloring-book structure feels manufactured, not lived. - Safety and moralizing: - Tendency: - Avoid real ugliness. - Emphasize clear good vs evil, emphasize “justifiable” violence, reassure the reader. - Issue: - The prompt is literally “They fucked with the wrong babysitter.” - We want transgressive fun and catharsis, not corporate HR messaging. - Being squeamish about emotional or ethical ambiguity neuters the pulp. - Over-polished “cinematic” language: - Tendency: - Smoothly choreographed action; everything “fluid,” “seamless,” “she moves like a shadow.” - Describing competence at the expense of friction. - Issue: - Without grit, missteps, or awkwardness, the protagonist becomes generic John Wick clone. - Readers smell power fantasy that hasn’t earned its weight. - Neat “bow” endings: - Tendency: - Police show up, someone says “You’re a hero,” villain clearly defeated, seeds for sequel. - Issue: - Pulp can end on a punchline or downbeat. It doesn’t need everything explained. - Too tidy undercuts the feral energy and human cost. - Everyone is “competent in their lane”: - Tendency: - Pro is perfectly pro. Kid is perfectly kid. Villain is perfectly villain. - Issue: - Real-feeling people are inconsistent; they overshare, choke, misjudge. - Over-explaining motives: - Tendency: - Clearly articulate the villains’ employer, the file, the whole conspiracy, to show coherence. - Issue: - Mystery and partial ignorance can feel more real and be more frightening. - The babysitter doesn’t need a perfectly footnoted understanding of why they came. - Fear of tastelessness: - Tendency: - Avoid offensive details, avoid too-dark humor, sanitize dialogue. - Issue: - Good pulp here should feel a bit wrong. Criminals should say vile, casual shit. - The babysitter’s quips should sometimes be mean or bleak, not always “hero clever.” 3. Critique of our current plan: where it drifts into LLM tropes, and how to humanize it Let’s interrogate the specific choices we made. a) Roxy as hyper-competent ex-military professional Potential LLM pitfall: - The “mysterious hyper-competent woman” is a stock answer. - She risks feeling: - Like a trope delivery system. - Too competent, too composed. - Cool but emotionally weightless. What a more human approach might explore: - Her contradictions: - She’s good at violence but uncomfortable asking for a decent hourly rate. - She uses “babysitting” as an excuse to feel normal—and resents the people who can be normal. - She’s proud of her skills AND ashamed she still wants to use them. - Imperfections: - Maybe she misreads something early. Maybe she hesitates to shoot someone who isn’t clearly armed and gets hurt for it. - Maybe she panics once, snaps at Leo unfairly, then has to repair that. - Specific, not generic: - Instead of “former Army Ranger,” maybe it’s: - She did one ugly deployment, or worked private security for shady clients, and quit. - She’s not a hollywood commando, she’s someone who’s seen one or two horrible things and trained enough to be dangerous. b) The intruders and the syndicate “job” Potential LLM pitfall: - We went straight to: - “federal prosecutor” - “regional crime syndicate” - “encrypted drive”/“Calloway files” - This is standard thriller boilerplate: competent, clean, plausible, overfamiliar. What a more human, textured version might consider: - Make the motive sleazier, pettier, or more grounded: - The dad skimmed money. - Someone in the family is dirty. - It’s a mistaken-address job and they try to salvage it. - Mess with their professionalism: - Let them argue about money mid-job. - Someone’s high. Someone’s scared. Someone wants this to be quick and “clean”, someone wants to make it ugly. - Don’t explain all: - Roxy doesn’t need a full villain TED Talk; she can pick up fragments. - Let the reader feel there’s a bigger world without clarifying it like a Wikipedia entry. c) The kid, Leo Potential LLM pitfall: - Leo is at risk of being: - Generic “bright 7-year-old.” - Narrative prop; always brave, always obedient, always cute. - LLMs tend to make kids wise or plot-convenient, because that reads “touching” in training data. More human possibilities: - Let Leo be: - Inconveniently curious. Picks bad moments to ask questions. Needs the bathroom at the worst time. - Occasionally annoying, then suddenly heartbreakingly sweet. - Capable of panicking, going silent, or doing something foolish that Rox then has to handle. - One precise, grounding detail: - His obsession: space facts, dinosaur names, drawing comics, a specific cartoon. - His safe object (a stuffed toy, a plastic spaceship) plays into a crucial moment non-magically. d) Violence and competence Potential LLM pitfall: - Clean tactical beats: every trap works, every fight is intelligible, Roxy rarely missteps. - High competence fantasy with low emotional consequence. Humanizing adjustments to consider: - Let some stuff go wrong: - A trap backfires; she injures herself; the noise draws another intruder. - She miscounts assailants once. - Show aftermath in micro: - Her hand shaking when loading a magazine. - Her reaction to the first kill: maybe professional calm snapping into delayed nausea or anger. - Fight texture: - Clumsy grappling, furniture breaking, both parties gasping, weird sounds, compromised vision. - She fights dirty because scared, not just stylishly. e) Tone and quips Potential LLM pitfall: - Consistent, controlled dark humor and neat one-liners. - Ending on a super-tidy “title callback” line is very on-the-nose. More human-feeling approach: - Let some lines be messy: - She tries to quip and it comes out flat. Or she only thinks of the perfect line afterward. - Use humor as defense: - Jokes that undercut her own fear or pain. - Inappropriate laugh in a quiet moment. - Ending: - Resist the Instagrammable final line. - Possibly end on something ambiguous, tired, raw: a mundane question, a bureaucratic detail, Leo mispronouncing something, or a callback that hits emotionally, not slogan-like. f) Aftermath and morality Potential LLM pitfall: - We leaned toward: - Clean legal framing: she’s justified. - Handing the drive back, mild moral scolding for the dad, then she walks into dawn. - Clear lines: bad guys punished, good guys safe. More human complications to consider: - Cops might be suspicious; she may have to lie convincingly. - Forensics and questions: how many bodies, what weapons, how does she spin it? - Grant might: - Be angry at her for risking Leo, even though she saved him. - Downplay his role in attracting violence. - Rox’s internal: - Maybe she enjoyed parts of it and hates that about herself. - Maybe she feels used; maybe she charges them for overtime, or refuses payment in a way that isn’t simply noble. g) Structural neatness Potential LLM pitfall: - Every chapter currently has perfect escalation, a defined mini-climax, and a hook. - It’s good craft, but risks feeling like “screenwriting template #3.” Humanizing the structure: - Break the pattern slightly: - Have one chapter that lingers too long somewhere uncomfortable (e.g., trapped in a closet, listening). - Let one beat resolve anticlimactically (a plan that fizzles). - Allow some asymmetry: - Violence may cluster in one chapter, then a quieter, more psychological one after, not perfect alternation. h) Sanitized ugliness Potential LLM pitfall: - We carefully excluded sexual violence, sanitized villain depravity, kept it “network TV edgy.” Nuance: - We should absolutely avoid exploitative sexual violence. - But villains should feel dangerous in more than abstract terms: - Their language should be gross, misogynistic, racialized or classist (without reveling in it). - Their attitude to the kid should be viscerally upsetting, even if they never touch him. - This is about: - Letting their darkness be specific enough that Rox’s brutality is emotionally justified. - But handling that with restraint, not voyeurism. 4. Brainstorm: ways to make the piece more human (without rewriting yet) Some directions to consider integrating (later) to humanize, roughen, and deepen: - Make Roxy’s “normal” life sting: - She’s underpaid for this gig. - Earlier, Grant low-key patronizes her about “tough job, huh?” when she mentions service. - That irritation flavors her protectiveness later: they don’t deserve her, but the kid does. - Give Roxy one sharp private vulnerability: - Afraid of basements from something in her past. - Mild claustrophobia. - Bad knee that acts up at the worst time. - A sibling she failed to protect; never spelled out fully, just implied. - Let Leo cut through her armor: - Kid offers her a sticker “for being brave” early; later it’s on her hand/phone/gun in a fight. - He asks if she has kids. That lands, silently. - Make at least one intruder painfully human: - Ramos is genuinely scared, has a girlfriend texting during the job, something that complicates the “just a goon” image. - When Rox kills or spares him, it costs her something emotional. - Imperfect choices: - She chooses to shoot to kill when there might have been another option—and knows it. - She lies to Leo in a way that haunts her (“Everything’s okay”) while we know it’s not. - Let the house feel like a real place: - The weird artwork. - The cluttered drawers. - The unwashed mug in the sink with Grant’s lipstick-mark from Nadia. - These details become improvised tools; also a lens on the Calloways. - End on a more complicated note: - Maybe Grant tries to spin it for the press; Roxy sees he’s learned nothing. - Maybe she quietly pockets a copy of the drive. - Maybe she sits in her car, bloody, listening to some dumb pop song Leo likes, and finally shakes. If we do this right: - The story will still be fun, pulpy, and violent. - But it’ll feel like it came from a particular person with a particular attitude, not an AI pattern-engine smoothing all edges. Next step (when you’re ready): - We go through the existing chapter plan and thread in a few of these humanizing elements: - Less boilerplate conspiracy; more specific, messy motive. - More idiosyncratic Roxy. - A slightly rougher, less “screenplay-perfect” escalation. - A more ambiguous, emotionally resonant final beat.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention This is a lean, bloody, character-driven pulp story that feels like a specific, flawed human wrote it, not a template. Core commitments: - Premise first: - The story must fully deliver on: “They fucked with the wrong babysitter.” - That means: - The invaders’ mistake is clear and satisfying. - The babysitter’s retaliation is ferocious, inventive, and emotionally grounded. - We end with the sense that their fate is earned, not just stylized. - Protagonist: Roxy Vega - Early 30s, Latina, ex–private security contractor (not a superhero, not black-ops royalty). - Used to mid-level dirty work overseas for corporations and NGOs, saw enough to walk away. - Babysits for cash and quiet; trying to learn how to live in the world without a rifle. - Core traits: - Observant, dry, self-deprecating. - Protective and angry about bullies, especially where kids are concerned. - Competent but not infallible: bad knee from an IED, occasional panic spike, guilt about one job that went sideways. - Intent: - Show both her capability and her vulnerability. - Let her make mistakes; let her care too much; let her sometimes relish the violence and hate that in herself. - Kid: Leo Calloway - 7 years old. - Loves dinosaurs, cheap monster movies, and space; chatty and intense. - He’s: - Sometimes annoying, sometimes hilarious, occasionally heartbreaking. - Realistically scared and distractible under pressure. - He has one small but crucial act of bravery that feels like something a scared 7-year-old could do. - Parents and stakes: - Nadia and Grant Calloway: - Well-off, distracted, a bit condescending. - Grant is a local prosecutor; not noble paladin, not cartoon villain—ambitious, not cautious enough. - Motive: - Grant quietly held onto physical evidence (cash, ledger, USB) from a plea deal, planning to leverage it later. - A mid-tier crime boss wants it back; sends people while the Calloways are out at a charity gala. - The kid is not the goal, but quickly becomes a tool/pressure point. - Roxy has no full briefing; she pieces this together from overheard arguments earlier, subtle house details, and what the intruders say. - Antagonists: - Small, messy crew: dangerous but not elite. - Cole: - Self-styled professional, ex-military washout. - Controls the job, wants it clean, resents being in the suburbs. - Deke: - Volatile, cruel, uses ugly language. - Represents the real threat to Leo. - Ivy: - Tech/lock person. - Cynical, wants it “no one hurt,” but cowardly when it counts. - Ramos: - Young, nervous, in over his head. - Intention: - Give each a bit of personality quickly; enough to feel real when they bleed. - Avoid over-explaining the syndicate; keep it street-level and petty. - Tone and style: - Third-person close in Roxy’s POV almost all the time. - Very brief dips to an intruder’s POV only when it genuinely heightens tension or irony. - Language: - Clean, concrete, vivid. - Short, sharp sentences in action; more textured in quiet scenes. - Humor: - Dark, defensive, situational. - Roxy’s dry internal comments, Leo’s earnestness, the absurdity of using Fisher-Price toys in a fight. - Avoid Marvel-style constant quipping; some lines fall flat or stay in her head. - Violence: - R-rated, physical, sometimes clumsy. - No torture porn, no sexual violence. - Show fear, pain, and mess alongside cool moments. - Structure: - 8 chapters, ~1000 words each: tight, no filler. - Chronological, one night, one main location. - Each chapter is one or two key beats, not an overstuffed act. - Allow a few imperfect edges: not every chapter must end on a thunderous twist; some end on quiet dread. - Things to avoid: - No omniscient, exposition-heavy voice explaining motives in detail. - No invincible protagonist; no perfect tactics sequence. - No overly neat bow-tie ending or cheesy final slogan. - No sanitized villains who feel like TV bad guys; they’re specific and unpleasant, but not cartoon supervillains. - Thematic undercurrent: - People who treat other people (and their kids, and their labor) as expendable are wrong—and sometimes meet the wrong person. - The line between “protector” and “monster” is thin when you’re very good at hurting people. - Institutions are unreliable; care is personal and costly. Everything in the plan should support: - The emotional satisfaction of “wrong babysitter.” - A believable, specific woman’s long, nasty, human night. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1 – “Twenty Bucks an Hour” Purpose: Ground Roxy, Leo, and the house; plant tension; start from small human annoyances, not explosions. Beats: - Early evening. Roxy arrives a bit early; Nadia rushing with earrings half-on, Grant scrolling his phone. - Quick, telling interactions: - Nadia apologizes for the mess; the house is showroom-clean. - Grant jokes about Roxy’s “tactical skills” after hearing she “worked overseas,” but in a patronizing, jokey way. - They underpay her (or haggle) in a way that stings. - Leo: - Bombards Roxy with dino/space facts, shows her his toy T-rex and glow-in-the-dark stars. - Asks about her scars; she deflects with half-truths. - Roxy alone with Leo: - She notices details: deadbolt that sticks, side gate that doesn’t latch, cameras that aren’t actually on. - Overheard pre-departure argument snippet between Nadia and Grant about “the deal,” “holding onto it,” “they won’t come here.” - She files that away as “rich people drama.” - Leo to bed: - They watch a dumb monster movie while he falls asleep; he lends her his plastic T-rex “to guard you.” - Plant unease: - News on TV about local crime boss, plea deals, break-ins. - Roxy on the couch, half-dozing, senses a car idling too long outside. - She turns volume down, listens. - End with her noting something off (lights sweeping the curtains, then cutting), not full alarm yet. Chapter 2 – “The Welfare Check” Purpose: Shift from mundane to wrongness; let Roxy smell danger early and act in a grounded way. Beats: - A knock at the door: Cole posing as a cop doing a “welfare check” due to “an alarm ping.” - Roxy cracks door on chain, kid asleep behind her in hallway glow. - She quizzes him lightly; small inconsistencies: wrong call sign, calls Nadia “Natalie,” uniform off. - She plays dumb: - Claims Grant is showering, dog is “mean.” - Closes door gently; heart rate open but controlled. - Immediate, practical reactions: - Checks on Leo: he’s half-asleep; she quietly moves him, turns it into a camping “fort” in an interior closet. - Makes him pee now (“part of the game”) so that’s not a crisis later. - Locks: - Goes systematically through doors/windows; notes that some can’t be secured well; improvises (chair under handle, knife in frame). - Roxy’s inner life: - Brief flicker of past checkpoint bullshit. Old instincts humming, which she both trusts and resents. - Outside: - From van POV: Cole drops the cop act; Deke irritated, Ivy on tablet, Ramos jittery. - Confirm they saw a babysitter, kid, no parents. - Plan: cut power, in and out fast. Cole wants clean; Deke talks about “fun.” - Power goes out: - Not storm-flicker, but a hard cut. Roxy clocks the difference. - She tells Leo, quietly in the dark, “We’re playing the quiet game now. You remember what I said?” - End on her taking a breath, picking up Leo’s plastic T-rex and a kitchen knife. Chapter 3 – “First Stupid Mistake” Purpose: The first kill; reveal Roxy’s edge, but keep it messy and human. Beats: - House breathing in the dark; rain starting. - Ivy bypasses alarm; Deke comes in through back; Ramos through side. - Roxy: - Moves low, slow. Bad knee twinges. - Leaves Leo hidden behind hanging coats, with strict code word only she would use. - Ramos: - Youngest, most nervous, moving through kitchen whispering to himself. - Roxy ambush: - Uses noise from fridge or toy to draw him; blinds him briefly with phone screen, bashes hand with heavy mug, scuffle. - It’s close, ugly; he grabs her, they crash into counter, knives clatter. - She chokes him with dish towel or cuts him by accident; he panics, she finishes it almost reflexively. - She’s breathing hard, shaken: this felt too much like “then,” and also too easy. - Emotional beat: - She mutters “I told you to go home” to his body—he’s clearly just some kid in over his head. - Quick, guilty inventory: she had other options. No time. - Cole and Deke realize: - Radio silence. Cole annoyed; Deke pleased it’s “interesting.” - End with: - Roxy dragging Ramos’s body out of Leo’s path, taking his gun even though she hates how natural it feels. - She’s in it now. Chapter 4 – “Games in the Dark” Purpose: Cat-and-mouse; near-miss with Leo; deepen tension and humanity. Beats: - Deke and Cole sweep the house, Ivy feeding them layout from hacked blueprint app and cameras. - Roxy uses baby monitor: - Plants one in hall to listen. - Whispers small lies to throw them off about where she is. - Leo’s perspective: - Brief, close moment: in the closet, listening to footsteps and muffled thumps. - He almost calls out; clamps hand over his mouth because she told him to. - Deke: - Says gross, threatening things casually; we see clearly he’s the true danger to Leo. - First trap: - Cleaning spray on tile + marbles or toy cars. - Deke slips, crashes; not a cartoon pratfall, but enough to enrage him. - Confrontation: - Roxy engages Deke in hallway: low light, close quarters. - Ugly brawl: he’s bigger, she’s rustier; she uses banister, lamp, a framed photo that shatters. - She hurts him but can’t finish him; knee gives, she’s forced to retreat. - Overheard info: - Cole on radio mentions “the ledger,” “Grant’s little stash,” “boss wants it tonight.” - Roxy puts together that this is about something Grant held back. - End beat: - She’s in the bathroom, patching a slice on her arm with a kids’ cartoon bandage. - Leo whispers on baby monitor, “Roxy?” She has to swallow panic so her voice sounds steady: “Still the game, Leo. You’re winning.” Chapter 5 – “House Rules” Purpose: Roxy takes initiative; we see her intelligence and anger; intruders fracture. Beats: - Roxy moves through rooms to “weaponize” the house: - Tools from garage (wrench, duct tape, nails). - Hairdryer and water near an outlet (potential). - Heavy baby gate positioned for a trip. - Personality details: - She notices Nadia’s untouched treadmill draped in clothes, Grant’s gun safe—empty or stupidly unlocked without ammo. - Builds resentment: these people are careless; their kid is paying. - Ivy: - At van arguing with Cole via radio. - She’s rattled by Ramos’s silence, wants to bail; Cole threatens her cut. - Roxy on radio: - Uses Ramos’s earpiece to talk: - Calm, not action-movie clever. “You came into a house with a kid. You can leave now.” - Cole scoffs; Deke eggs him on. - Second takedown: - One intruder (Deke or Ivy if she enters) caught by trap in garage: - Struggle with tools, car rolling, something breaking bone. - It’s improvised and partially misfires, forcing Roxy to get closer than she planned. - Stakes sharpen: - Cole, furious, threatens to burn them out. - Roxy has now seen enough to know: they won’t leave without blood or the evidence. - She finds the stash: - Behind laundry detergent, inside toy chest, etc.: cash bands, USB, small ledger. - She’s disgusted; it explains the job. - End: - She pockets USB; considers tossing it. - Leo’s soft voice from vent: “Can I come out now?” Her “No” is sharper than she means. Chapter 6 – “Trade” Purpose: Forced standoff; moral pressure; things go wrong; Leo’s small moment. Beats: - Fire: - Cole starts a fire in trash cans by the back door or curtains; smoke creeping. - They’re on a clock now; Roxy coughs, eyes sting. - Cole’s offer: - Over radio: “USB for the kid. You walk.” - It sounds almost reasonable; we know, she knows, it’s a lie. - Internal: - Roxy weighs it honestly: if she believed Leo walked, would she trade? She doesn’t trust them. - The “trade”: - She stages it in foyer: - Leo hidden barely out of sight. - USB in hand (real or decoy). - Deke lunges off-script toward where he suspects Leo is. - Chaos: - Roxy anticipated some betrayal but not this angle. - Short-range fight; she gets a worse injury (gun graze along ribs or knife to shoulder). - Leo is briefly grabbed by Ramos-equivalent or Deke, but: - Leo bites hard, jabs with plastic T-rex horn or kicks shins. - Gives Roxy half a second to yank him free. - Crucial choice: - Roxy could chase Cole as he bolts deeper for more evidence—or scoop Leo and retreat. - She chooses Leo, and knows it gives Cole room. - End: - Smoke worsening, alarms finally wailing. - Roxy barricades them upstairs; whispers, genuinely shaken, “I’m sorry” to Leo for snapping earlier. - He presses the T-rex into her bloody hand: “He bites the bad guys.” - She laughs once, harsh, then pulls herself up. Chapter 7 – “Wrong House” Purpose: Final reckoning; brutal and specific; less choreography, more desperation. Beats: - House partially on fire, rain hammering windows. - Roxy stashes Leo in attic crawlspace with stricter instructions: - Code word only she would ever say (something to do with their monster movie). - He begs her not to go; she goes anyway. - Ivy’s end: - Ivy trying to flee with van; Cole uses her as bait or shoots her in frustration. - We glimpse the boss’s ruthlessness via Cole, not a monologue. - Deke vs Roxy: - Deke, injured, high on adrenaline, hunts. - They clash on staircase: - He taunts; she doesn’t have a snappy reply, just focus. - Fight ends with him going over banister onto something sharp or hard (tools, broken furniture). - It’s grim, not gloriously balletic. - Cole vs Roxy: - Last man. She’s limping, bleeding; he’s scorched, furious. - In the kitchen or by the pool doors: - They circle, both knowing this is it. - He tries to needle her: - “You could’ve walked. He’s not even yours.” - That lands; she admits, “That’s why you’re still talking.” - Fight: - He’s trained, not a slob; it’s ugly, even match. - She uses his arrogance: lures him onto wet floor wired near an outlet, or uses the stove gas/ignition, or just gets hold of his own gun. - Kill: - She doesn’t sermonize; maybe one short, human line. - Then pulls the trigger, or lets him fry/drown because she’s out of strength. - Immediate after: - She staggers, finds Leo where he’s supposed to be, sobs once into his hair before stuffing it down. - Sirens in distance, neighbors yelling outside; fire bigger now. Chapter 8 – “What They Deserve” Purpose: Aftermath that’s not too neat; focus on consequences, emotion, and a grounded final note. Beats: - Police, fire, paramedics flood scene. - Roxy on porch blanket, EMT trying to stitch her; Leo asleep against Nadia. - The story: - Cops asking what happened. - Roxy gives clipped, believable version: - Men broke in, she hid Leo, got lucky, used a gun she “found.” - Leaves out radio games, her speed, her comfort with killing. - One detective eyes her, not buying the “just lucky,” but bags it for later. - Grant: - Tries to explain: “These men… my case… they were after me.” - Roxy looks at him with tired contempt; doesn’t blow up, but implication is clear. - The evidence: - She returns USB/ledger (or says where it is) but: - Maybe she kept a hidden copy or left some money missing. We don’t spell it out fully. - Human moments: - Nadia thanks Roxy too effusively; Leo insists Roxy gets his T-rex “forever.” - Roxy deflects, clearly uncomfortable with “hero” talk. - No bow: - Cops aren’t sure what to do with four dead criminals and a lethal babysitter, but public narrative favors her. - The crime boss may be angry; that threat lingers off-page. - Final beat: - Later, alone in her dented car: - She notices Leo’s T-rex on the passenger seat. - Hands trembling a little now that it’s over. - She laughs once at the absurdity that babysitting turned into this; laughter snags on something like a sob. - Phone buzzes: an unknown number, maybe Grant asking if she’s “available again,” or a new family referral. - She looks at the T-rex, at her bandaged hands. - Final line is quiet, human, not slogan: - Something like: she puts the phone face down, starts the car, and thinks, “Next time, they should pay up front.” - Suggests: - She’s still herself. - She’s dangerous. - The world will keep underestimating her—and that’s their problem.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Roxy Vega Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - 32. Grew up in a working-class neighborhood outside El Paso. Dad was a mechanic, mom cleaned houses. No one in her orbit had a safety net. - Enlisted at 18. Deployed once to Afghanistan; later drifted into private security contracting because it paid stupidly well and she didn’t know how else to monetize “I’m good at not dying.” - Quit after a job guarding a mining site where “deterrence” got blurry. She followed orders, someone else paid, but a kid lost a father. That stayed. - Now lives in a bland rental a few suburbs away from the Calloways. Drives an ’05 Corolla that always needs something, fixes it herself. - Does part-time security consulting and unglamorous gigs: night shifts, warehouse checks, and babysitting for extra cash. Babysitting started as a favor to a neighbor who called her “the safest pair of hands I know.” The line embarrassed her and stuck with her. - Personality: - Dry, wry, low-key. Slow to volunteer anything about herself. - Patient with kids, impatient with performative adults. - Keeps score silently when people are careless with others’ safety. - Doesn’t perceive herself as a hero; more like a tool that sometimes points the right direction. - Idiosyncrasies: - Hates leaving dishes in the sink; will clean other people’s kitchens when they’re out. It calms her. - Counts exits automatically. In restaurants, grocery stores, playrooms. - Hums tunelessly when nervous, then stops as soon as she notices. - Sleeps on top of the covers with one foot on the floor, habit from shared barracks and bad contracts. - Low pain tolerance for small things (paper cuts, hangnails) but weirdly calm with big injuries. - Flaws: - Over-responsible: picks up blame that isn’t hers. - Defensive sarcasm; can come off cold or bitchy. - Quick to judge people with money and safe lives; sometimes unfairly. - Has a latent appetite for confrontation she doesn’t like to admit; there’s a part of her that lights up when things go sideways. Physicality and presence: - 5’6”, compact, strong. Not a superhero build; more like someone who lifts because it’s practical. - Brown skin, dark eyes, nose broken once (never set right), hair usually in a no-nonsense braid or bun. - Clothes: worn black jeans, boots, T-shirts, flannel or hoodie; nothing that screams “operator.” - Scar along left forearm from shrapnel; faint one near her ribs. She doesn’t hide them, doesn’t discuss unless pushed. - Carries herself like someone who’s always bracing for a loud noise: attentive, never fully slouched, back to walls when possible. - Expresses herself in small ways: one eyebrow up instead of an argument; a half-smile that means “you’re full of shit but I’m not fighting you on it.” Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Baseline: pay rent, stay out of the sort of work that rots you, avoid becoming someone who only exists in violence. - Reflexive: protect kids, underdogs, anyone being cornered. - In the story: keep Leo alive; make very sure the men who walked into this house don’t get to try again. - Allegiances: - No organizational loyalty; skeptical of institutions. - Soft spot for working-class people doing their best. - Resentful of people like Grant who gamble with others from safe positions. - Existing relationships: - Cordial with Nadia (who treats her like a capable professional). - Strained politeness with Grant; she sees through his charm. - Neighbor-friend “Tina” who first hired her as a sitter; only person who’s seen her break down once, late at night. - No current romantic partner; a couple of former colleagues she texts memes with, nothing deeper. Sample lines: - To Leo, early: “I’ve seen worse monsters than that guy. Different channel, though.” - Watching Grant joke about her “combat babysitting”: “Yeah, nothing braver than trusting a stranger with your kid because you’re late for shrimp cocktails.” - Mid-siege, internal: “You wanted quiet, Vega. Instead you got a live-fire exercise with a seven-year-old audience. Great career pivot.” - To Cole, on radio: “Listen. You walk away right now, you go home with all the holes you came with. Or you keep talking. Up to you.” --- # Leo Calloway Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - 7 years old, only child. - Lives in a nice house full of rules, white furniture he’s not supposed to touch, and a schedule of piano lessons, soccer, and “enrichment.” - Personality: - Chatty, intensely curious, interrupts himself mid-sentence to add another fact. - Slightly lonely: his parents are busy; he latches onto adults who actually listen. - Likes being taken seriously, hates being called “buddy” by strangers. - Idiosyncrasies: - Obsessed with dinosaurs and outer space; mispronounces complex scientific terms with confidence. - Gives his toys jobs (“This T-rex guards the pillows, this one guards the snacks”). - Picks at the labels in his shirts until they fray. - Hides uneaten vegetables in very obvious places; genuinely believes no one notices. - Flaws: - Bad at whispering; “whispers” full volume. - Will ask relentless questions at exactly the wrong time. - Defiant when scared; might say “no” instead of “okay” just because. Physicality and presence: - Small for his age. Knobby knees, bedhead that never fully flattens. - Missing one front tooth; lisp just fading. - Pajamas with rockets or dinos. Wears the same socks two days in a row if they have his favorite pattern. - Physical confidence in his own home; runs, climbs furniture; gets shy outside his territory. - Expressive face; fear is obvious, but he tries hard to “be brave” when Roxy tells him a game depends on it. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Wants attention that isn’t rushed or half-on-the-phone. - Wants to impress Roxy; senses she’s “for real.” - In crisis: wants to follow the rules she gives him and keep his T-rex safe. - Allegiances: - To his parents, but their authority is abstract; Roxy’s is immediate, practical. - Instinctively sides with whoever is down on the floor playing or listening to him (which is usually Roxy, not Grant). - Relationships: - Thinks his mom smells nice and feels soft when she’s not hurrying. - Thinks his dad is “busy with bad guys,” concept half-TV-half-reality. - Sees Roxy as cool and steady; he likes that she doesn’t talk to him like a baby. Sample lines: - Early, to Roxy: “If a T-rex came in here, I’d punch it in the ankle. That’s its weak spot. Probably.” - Whispered in closet, to himself: “Okay. Astronauts don’t cry. Maybe a little. Quiet cry.” - After it’s over, drowsy against her: “You’re better than a security system. Don’t tell my dad I said that.” --- # Nadia Calloway Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Mid-30s. Marketing/communications consultant; handles brand strategy for wellness startups and nonprofits. - From a middle-class family. Self-made, but also acclimated fast to comfort. - Personality: - High-functioning, anxious under the surface. - Wants to do the right thing but avoids ugly details. - Socially smooth: fills silences, diffuses tension, apologizes for things not her fault. - Idiosyncrasies: - Always almost late; does eyeliner in ride shares. - Organizes the fridge by color; fridge looks perfect, pantry chaotic. - Hates voicemail; leaves 2-minute rambling texts instead. - Flaws: - Conflict-avoidant, especially with Grant; lets things slide she shouldn’t. - Outsources worry: assumes babysitters, schools, systems will catch what she doesn’t want to look at. - Defensive if someone implies she’s a bad mom. Physicality and presence: - Stylish without overdoing it. Jumpsuits, blazers, good shoes. - Keeps her hair and nails done; takes pride in “presentable.” - Physically affectionate with Leo when focused on him; distracted hugs otherwise. - Quick movements, lots of small adjustments—earring, hair, phone—classic nervous energy. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Wants a safe, impressive life: good school, good house, “impactful” job. - Wants Grant’s career to rise; their stability depends on it. - Does care about Leo deeply; just believes danger is something that happens to other people. - Allegiances: - To her curated version of stability. - To Grant, but with eroding trust; she clocked he’s hiding something about the case. - Relationships: - Warm but shallow rapport with Roxy so far; she likes that Roxy seems capable, hasn’t thought about what that entails. - In private, she’s the one who insisted they pay Roxy decently; Grant bargained down. Sample lines: - At the door, rushing: “Snacks are labeled, Wi-Fi is on the fridge, and please, if he says he brushed? He didn’t.” - Under her breath to Grant, thinking Roxy doesn’t hear: “You should have given it to them. We have a child, Grant.” - After the siege, to Roxy: “I don’t know how to say thank you in a way that isn’t… stupid.” --- # Grant Calloway Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Late 30s. Assistant DA with political ambitions. - Came from modest means, worked hard; sees himself as the hero of his own narrative. - Personality: - Charming, articulate, likes being The Guy Who Handles Things. - Rationalizes gray choices as “strategic.” - Believes he understands danger from reading case files and watching press conferences. - Idiosyncrasies: - Keeps whiskey in a decanter but drinks cheap stuff. - Obsessive about his suits and watches; scuffs annoy him more than moral compromise. - Leaves open kitchen cabinets wherever he goes. - Flaws: - Arrogant. Overestimates his control, underestimates other people’s risk. - Treats Roxy like friendly staff, not a person with a past. - Chose to hide evidence/cash thinking he could time its use for career leverage; told himself it was “to secure a better deal.” Physicality and presence: - Tall enough, gym-toned enough; reads as “put together.” - Good haircut, whitened teeth, handshake guy. - Carries himself with courtroom confidence; likes to take up space in a room. - His smile tightens slightly when challenged; hates losing face. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Advancement. Wants to be seen as the man who took down organized crime. - Provide for his family—but in a way that also feeds his ego. - Cover his ass once his choices put them at risk. - Allegiances: - To himself first; to “the system” as long as it suits him. - To Nadia and Leo, but filtered through his sense of being their protector in theory, not practice. - Relationships: - With Roxy: thinks she’s a good find—“our badass sitter”—without curiosity about what that means. - With Nadia: loves her, but hides things “for her own good.” Sample lines: - To Roxy at the start: “If he gives you any trouble, tell him I said you can deploy non-lethal force.” - Irritated, after: “You have to understand, I couldn’t just hand that ledger over to—” (cuts off when he sees her expression.) - Thinking, quietly shaken: “I brought courtrooms to their door. She brought a warzone to mine.” --- # Cole Mercer Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Late 30s. Did a short, undistinguished stint in the Army; discharged for “attitude issues.” - Drifted through private security, minor merc work; burned bridges by being too volatile for real professionals, too disciplined for outright psychos. - Now freelance fixer/enforcer for local organized crime: the guy you send when you want seriousness without headlines. - Personality: - Controlled surface: speaks calmly, likes plans, hates being surprised. - Underneath: resentment at anyone who has it easier; believes fear is respect. - Likes thinking of himself as “necessary.” - Idiosyncrasies: - Overly neat: wipes prints, aligns tools, hates cluttered vans. - Uses military jargon incorrectly to sound impressive. - Catalogues the quality of suburban houses like he’s on a real-estate tour. - Flaws: - Ego. Cannot tolerate being underestimated or outsmarted by someone he deems “lesser.” - Misjudges Roxy because she’s a woman, a sitter, and not signaling “threat” in his usual ways. - Underestimates how much his crew resents his control. Physicality and presence: - Lean, ropy muscle. Tattoos peeking from collar. - Short hair; eyes always scanning, rarely meeting yours for long. - Moves with a predator’s measured pace, until he snaps. - Voice low, often condescending; rarely yells—saves that for when he’s lost control. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Get the ledger/cash; prove to employer he’s still the guy to call. - Reassert control once things go sideways; revenge against whoever made him look stupid. - Allegiances: - To money and professional reputation more than ideology. - Minimal loyalty to crew; they’re assets. - Relationships: - Sees Ivy as useful tool; sees Deke as a blunt instrument; sees Ramos as dead weight. - Briefly amused by Roxy, then personally offended by her competence. Sample lines: - At the door, fake-cop charm: “Just a quick check, ma’am. Storm’s got the alarms chatty tonight.” - On radio, after first body: “Okay. So our babysitter bites. Good. I was getting bored.” - Final confrontation: “You killed my people for a kid that isn’t yours. You know how stupid that is?” --- # Deke Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Early 30s. String of petty crimes, short stints locked up, violence is his one consistent skill. - Grew up in chaos; treats cruelty as both entertainment and currency. - Personality: - Mean for fun. Always testing boundaries. - Enjoys scaring people more than killing them. - Idiosyncrasies: - Talks to himself; repeats phrases he likes under his breath. - Collects cheap knives; names them. - Laughs at wrong moments, too loud. - Flaws: - Impulsive, can’t follow a plan if there’s a chance to do something nastier. - Underestimates anyone who doesn’t posture. - Thinks suburbia means no real danger. Physicality and presence: - Solid, a bit thick around the middle but strong. - Patchy beard, prison tattoos, restless legs. - Smells faintly of sweat and cheap cologne. - Always invading personal space, puffing up. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Likes jobs where he’s allowed to hurt people. - Wants Cole’s respect but also likes pushing him. - Allegiances: - Mostly to his own pleasure; nominally to their employer. - Relationships: - Sees Ramos as chew toy. - Flirts with Ivy in a way that’s more threat than charm. - Sees Roxy as prey until she proves otherwise; then takes it personally. Sample lines: - Before break-in: “Babysitter’s probably drunk on the couch. In and out.” - Stalking hallways: “Come on, Mary Poppins. Let’s talk about childcare.” - When his trap injury hits: a stream of vicious, ugly cursing that makes his eventual fall satisfying. --- # Ivy Tran Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Late 20s. Community college dropout; good with code and locks; bored by legal IT work, lured into crime by better pay. - Personality: - Smart, sarcastic, emotionally detached as a shield. - Tells herself she’s “nonviolent”—she just opens doors. - Idiosyncrasies: - Vapes flavored nicotine constantly. - Names her hacking rigs; hates when people touch her gear. - Has a mental catalog of every password pattern she’s ever broken. - Flaws: - Cowardice. Folds when things get physical. - Willfully blind: pretends she’s above the ugliness she enables. - Panics when faced with genuine horror; no stomach for it. Physicality and presence: - Small, hoodie-and-leggings, messy dyed hair. - Thick glasses or contacts; squints at screens. - Slouches, rarely makes eye contact; comes alive only when talking tech. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Get paid, stay out of the paperwork of violence. - Prove to herself she’s clever enough to game a rigged world. - Allegiances: - To her own survival. - Loosely to whoever’s funding her life at the moment. - Relationships: - Mildly intimidated by Cole, disgusted by Deke. - Pities Ramos a bit. - Underestimates the babysitter as “some ex-military side hustle girl.” Sample lines: - In van, scoffing: “Gated communities are just higher-res illusions.” - When things go bad: “This is not what I signed up for, Cole. This is not ‘no witnesses’ clean.” - To herself, seeing Roxy on a camera feed: “How is she still standing?” --- # Ramos Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Early 20s. Did some time as a lookout, low-level runner; this is one of his first “serious” jobs inside a house. - Personality: - Nervous, eager to prove himself. - Not inherently sadistic; more scared of being seen as weak. - Idiosyncrasies: - Texts his girlfriend/mom constantly; phone buzzing even on jobs. - Overexplains small lies (“Traffic was crazy, like, three accidents”). - Flaws: - Naive about what this line of work really demands. - Not good under pressure; hands shake. - When challenged, picks the worst option instead of backing out. Physicality and presence: - Skinny, cheap sneakers, hoodie under ill-fitting jacket. - Chews his lip, bounces on heels. - Tries to look tough; doesn’t. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Needs money; thinks this will be quick. - Wants Cole’s approval, fears Deke’s mockery. - Allegiances: - To whoever keeps him fed and semi-safe; there’s a version of him that could’ve gone straight. - Relationships: - Exasperated pet to Cole and Deke. - Barely registers Ivy, aside from thinking she’s “cool.” Sample lines: - Before entry: “So it’s like, nobody home-home, right? Just in and out?” - When confronted by Roxy (if we show it): “Lady, I don’t wanna—” (cut off by the mess he’s in.) - In Roxy’s head after: “He was a kid. And you killed him, because he came where the kid sleeps.”

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Calloways were already ten minutes late when Roxy Vega rang the bell. Nadia opened the door with one earring in and the other clamped between her teeth. “You’re an angel,” she mumbled around the gold hoop, stepping back to let Roxy in. “I’m not doing crafts,” Roxy said. “Full disclosure.” “You won’t have to,” Nadia said, snapping the earring in. “He’s already in pajamas. Dinner’s… let’s call it ‘flexible.’” The house smelled like lemon cleaner and expensive candles. Hardwood floors without scuffs. White sofa. Big framed photos from ski trips where nobody looked cold. Grant came down the stairs in a tailored navy suit, knotting his tie like he was auditioning for something. “Roxy. Our tactical asset,” he said. “You sure you’re okay on short notice?” “I’m here,” she said. “That’s the job.” He grinned, the kind of grin that had won juries. “Couldn’t be safer,” he told Nadia, with a little gesture at Roxy, like she was a security system he’d installed. Roxy filed that away. The sound of his voice saying couldn’t be safer in this house, with those headlines on the kitchen TV. Nadia was migrating through rooms gathering clutch, lipstick, charger. “Okay, fridge: leftover pasta, dinosaur nuggets, yogurt. He can have one juice box, no YouTube after eight, he’ll ask. His inhaler is on the counter, he hasn’t needed it in months, but—” “I see it,” Roxy said. Blue inhaler by the knife block. She noted the knives automatically: decent chef’s, paring, bread, all in easy reach. Side door with a deadbolt that stuck a little when Nadia shoved it; she had to put a hip into it. “It does that,” Nadia said. “You have to—yeah. Like that.” “Got it.” Grant clicked off the TV with the remote. Right before the screen went black, Roxy clocked a crawl: LOCAL DA TO LEAD CASE AGAINST HARRAN CREW. His own face had been in the promo earlier. Harran: Roxy remembered the name from radio chatter overseas. Coincidence. Or not. “Phone numbers by the fridge,” Grant said. “Alarm panel’s by the front door—code is, uh—” “We should change that,” Nadia cut in. “It’s fine.” He waved it off. To Roxy: “If anything trips it by mistake, just answer and say you’re the sitter. They’ve got our file.” She glanced at the panel. Older model, green digits. “Who installed it?” “Some guy the firm uses,” Grant said. “State-of-the-art… six years ago?” He checked his watch instead of her expression. Leo barreled in, sock-squeaking on the wood. Rocket ship pajamas, hair in chaotic tufts. “Roxy!” he said, flinging himself at her with zero braking distance. She caught him easily. “You planning to take me out at the knees, dude?” “I’m practicing,” he said. “If a T-rex comes.” “Ankles,” she said. “You go for the ankles.” His eyes went wide. “I knew it.” “Bed by eight-thirty,” Nadia said, kissing the top of his head. He wriggled away. “Brush teeth. None of that pretend-brushing.” “I brush,” Leo protested. “I do it twice.” “He does it once,” Nadia told Roxy. “He lies. He lies about teeth.” “I contain multitudes,” Leo whispered, then grinned when Roxy snorted. Grant slid his arms into his coat. “If he gives you any trouble, tell him I said you can deploy non-lethal force.” “Uh-huh,” Roxy said. Her rate sat folded on the counter where she’d texted it earlier. Nadia grabbed an envelope from her purse, tucked in some cash, handed it over like contraband. “This should cover tonight,” Nadia said. “Plus Uber if you need.” Roxy felt the thickness. Thinner than it should have been. She didn’t count it; she knew the weight of twenties. “Thanks,” she said anyway. They left in a swirl of perfume and cologne and “Call if anything, seriously, anything,” and then the door thunked shut and the house exhaled. Silence. Then Leo’s voice at her elbow: “Wanna see my meteor?” He held up a gray rock. It was driveway gravel. “Wow,” she said. “I feel safer already.” He studied her, solemn. His gaze snagged on the pale line along her forearm. “How’d you get that?” “Fell off a bike,” she lied. “My dad says you were in a war.” “He shouldn’t say that.” She ruffled his hair. “You hungry?” He was. Roxy microwaved dinosaur nuggets, set out ketchup, cut carrot sticks smaller than any sniper she’d ever seen. She washed the one dirty pan in the sink because she couldn’t not. While he chewed, he talked: about an Allosaurus versus T-rex debate in his class, about space camp he wanted to go to, about how the new kid at school said his dad was a cop but he didn’t believe him because “he doesn’t know any gun facts.” “You know gun facts?” Roxy asked. “A couple,” he said, trying to sound casual. She laughed, a small, rusty sound. “Eat your carrots, weapons expert.” After, they watched a monster movie on some streaming service, the sound low. Leo narrated the plot to her as if she might miss it. When the creature appeared—a guy in a rubber suit, obvious zipper—Leo leaned closer. “It’s not really scary,” he said. “I’ve seen worse monsters than that guy,” she said. “Different channel.” He accepted that without understanding. By eight-thirty, he was yawning. She shepherded him through teeth-brushing (watched him this time) and into bed. Glow-in-the-dark stars peppered his ceiling, constellations almost right. “Leave the door open,” he said. “Done.” He frowned. “If there’s a fire, you come get me, okay? Mommy says always listen to the babysitter, but if there’s a fire—” “If there’s a fire, I’m carrying you out like a sack of potatoes,” she said. “Nothing’s gonna burn without me noticing.” “What if a T-rex—” “I’ll punch it in the ankle,” she said. He considered, nodded, settled. “You can borrow Rex,” he added, reaching to his nightstand and handing her a plastic T-rex with one missing arm. “To guard you.” “I appreciate the backup.” Light off, door cracked. Cartoon nightlight humming. She paced the house once. Habit. Checked the slider to the yard: latched, but the stick in the track was too short to matter. The side gate visible through the glass hung a little open. Front deadbolt: the turn felt soft; she worked it until it seated. Living room: she muted the TV, flipped through channels until the local news came back around to Grant’s case. “Assistant District Attorney Grant Calloway is expected to present new evidence—” She turned the sound off entirely. If it was important, it was already here. Somewhere. And apparently not locked in a vault like it should be. She set her phone on the coffee table, screen up. Text from Tina—You alive?—from earlier in the day, left unanswered. She should get a normal job, Tina kept saying. Something with HR trainings. Roxy stretched out on the end of the white sofa like she was afraid to crease it, one boot toe barely touching the floor. The house ticked and hummed. Rain started, a patter against the windows. Half an hour later, a car rolled slow past the front window. Headlights slid along the wall, catching framed ski photos, then vanished as the engine idled. Roxy’s eyes opened. She watched the glow seep around the curtain edge. Counted: one, two, three. The motor cut. The sudden quiet was heavier than the rain. She sat up, the plastic T-rex still in her hand, and listened.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This opening chapter effectively establishes the story's foundation while building tension through mundane details rather than spectacular action. The writing demonstrates solid craft in character establishment and atmospheric building. The chapter faithfully follows its planned structure, hitting key beats: Roxy's arrival, the Calloways' condescending treatment, Leo's dinosaur obsession, security observations, and the ominous ending with the idling car. The pacing moves naturally from domestic routine to creeping unease. Character work is particularly strong. Roxy emerges as competent but guarded, with her observations about security weaknesses establishing her background without exposition dumps. Her dry humor ("I'm not doing crafts") and practical responses feel authentic. Leo reads as a genuinely precocious seven-year-old rather than a miniature adult - his "I contain multitudes" line is exactly the kind of thing a bright kid might parrot without fully understanding. Grant's "tactical asset" comment perfectly captures his patronizing charm, while Nadia's frantic efficiency rings true. The dialogue flows naturally and serves character development. Conversations feel lived-in rather than constructed, from Leo's earnest dinosaur facts to Roxy's terse responses to the Calloways' casual condescension. The prose strikes an appropriate balance - clean and direct without being bland. Observational details like noting knife placement and security weaknesses feel organic to Roxy's mindset. The "house exhaled" moment works without feeling forced. However, some elements feel slightly predictable - the underpayment, the condescending parents, the security vulnerabilities all telegraph where the story is heading. While the execution is solid, the setup doesn't offer many surprises beyond competent genre work. The emotional engagement builds effectively through small moments - Leo lending his T-rex for protection, Roxy's automatic cleaning of dishes, the weight of the underpayment envelope. These details create investment in the characters before danger arrives. The chapter successfully plants multiple tension elements: Grant's high-profile case, the faulty security, overheard arguments about "the deal," and finally the idling car. The escalation feels natural rather than manufactured. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 11 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The knock came soft but wrong. Three quick taps, pause, two more. Not the fumbling of a neighbor, not the confident double-thump of someone who lived here. Hesitant, like they were trying out being polite. Roxy stood, set Leo’s T-rex on the coffee table, and moved to the door with her weight on the balls of her feet. Through the peephole: uniform. Tall, broad, hat brim throwing his face into shadow. Rain slicked the shoulders of his jacket. “Ma’am?” he called. “Police. Everything alright this evening?” Her thumb hovered near the deadbolt. No alarm beeping, no call from the company. She hadn’t touched the panel. She turned the chain instead, slowly unlocked the deadbolt, and opened the door three inches. The brass chain stretched between them. “Yes, officer?” He stepped back just enough to be nonthreatening. The porch light caught his face: square jaw, close-cut hair, the kind of clean that advertises itself. His badge flashed at his chest; too shiny, wrong font on the patch. Roxy’s neck prickled. “Evening,” he said easily. “We got a ping from your alarm company. Power flicker on the grid, sometimes sets off a fault. They had trouble reaching the homeowners. Mind if I take a quick look at the panel, make sure it’s not throwing a silent?” Behind her, down the hall, Leo’s room let out a faint cartoon sound effect. She’d forgotten to turn the TV all the way off. “The panel’s fine,” Roxy said. “We didn’t arm it.” He smiled, sympathetic. “Yeah, I get it, they’re a pain. Wouldn’t be doing my job if I didn’t check, though. Five seconds. You can watch me.” His eyes flicked past her shoulder as he said it, quick and sharp, inventorying. Roxy followed that glance. Behind her was an empty hall, a strip of light from Leo’s room. She shifted her stance, filling the gap. “You alone tonight?” he asked, too casual. She let herself blink slow, like she was weighing whether to be embarrassed. “Just me and Netflix.” He looked at her again. Took in worn boots, tattoos, the faint military set to her shoulders. Something in his jaw tightened a millimeter. “I’m Cole,” he said, like it was supposed to mean something. “You can call the station if you want to confirm I’m here.” “That’s alright, Cole.” She tasted the name. “We’re good.” His smile thinned. “You got ID, miss…?” “You do,” she said. “Why don’t you hold it up one more time?” The ID card clipped to his chest had a barcode, a photo, the word POLICE in big letters, and no department. It was the costume-shop version. He saw her see it. A fraction too long of a pause. Rain drummed on the porch roof. “My mistake,” he said, voice smoothing out again. “Must’ve been the wrong address. You have a good night, ma’am.” He stepped back, down off the porch. Roxy closed the door, slid the chain free, threw the deadbolt, and turned the knob to be sure it seated. It didn’t, not cleanly. She worked it until she felt metal catch. Her heart was beating faster now, but not high. A low, steady drum. Old rhythm. In the hallway, Leo padded out, rubbing one eye. “Who was that?” “Wrong house,” she said. “Hey. Didn’t we say campers stay in their tent?” “I had to pee.” “Good call.” She glanced past him into the bathroom, checked the window latch without thinking. “Pee, then back to base. New game. Special round.” He squinted. “What game?” “Hide-and-seek where only we know the rules,” she said. “Go on.” He shuffled off. She listened to water run, toothbrush swirl. Then she steered him toward the big walk-in closet off the master bedroom. “New fort,” she said. “Best one yet.” He blinked at the hanging dresses and Grant’s suits. “This is Mom’s clothes.” “Exactly. Maximum stealth.” She grabbed pillows and a blanket from the bed, made a low nest in the back corner, behind a row of long dresses. “See? Secret cave. You get the flashlight.” He brightened. “What are the rules?” “You stay in here, no matter what you hear, until I come get you,” she said. “You don’t come out for anyone else. Not Mom, not Dad, not if somebody says the house is full of candy. Only me.” His smile faltered. “That’s not… how do I pee in the game?” “You already did. You win.” “Oh.” He frowned, thinking. “What if you forget the password?” “I won’t. But just so it’s extra fair: the password is ‘Gamera.’” “Who?” “Gamera. Big turtle. Flies around. Your monster education is lacking.” He made a face. “That’s a dumb name.” “Exactly. So if you don’t hear that dumb name, you stay put. You put the blanket over you and you listen to your rocket noises. Okay?” He swallowed. Nodded. “Is this a drill?” “Sure,” she lied. “Drill.” He crawled into the nest with the seriousness of a cosmonaut. She tucked the blanket around him, put the flashlight in his hand. “Quiet game champion. Don’t open the door unless it’s me and I say it. Say it back to me.” “Gamera,” he whispered. “Good.” She closed the closet door gently, leaving a slim wedge for air. Her stomach tightened at shutting him in, the echo of another door, sand and shouting. She pushed that memory down until it was flat. In the kitchen, her phone sat where she’d left it, screen dark. No missed calls. No alarm company checking in. The panel by the door was calm, little green diode steady. She picked up her phone. Signal bars full. She thought about calling the non-emergency number, saying: Hey, guy with fake badge just probed your DA’s house. But she knew the odds. Instead she opened the side door Nadia had hip-bumped earlier. The deadbolt needed a shove; it groaned too loud in the quiet house. She checked the small rectangle of glass: no cracks. Beyond, the side yard lay slick and dark, the wooden gate not quite latched, swaying a half-inch with each gust. She slid the bolt home, then pulled a chair under the knob anyway. Habit and distrust. Back door: locked, but the stick in the track was wrong. She dumped it, grabbed a broom handle from the pantry, cut it down with a serrated knife until it wedged tight. Improvised, but better than nothing. Living room: she moved to the window, parted the curtain a hair. The street looked normal. A couple porch lights, a recycling bin, rain in the cones of light. No car directly in front now, but a dark van sat half a block down, tucked behind an oak. No plates visible from this angle. Roxy let the curtain fall. She took a slow breath. Old training, new house. Scan, secure, communicate. Only she didn’t have anyone to communicate with now. She grabbed the plastic T-rex from the coffee table, carried it into the kitchen, and set it beside the blue inhaler. The absurdity steadied her more than the glass of water she drank. The overhead lights flickered. She froze, glass halfway to the sink. They steadied. Went out. Came back. “Storm,” she said under her breath. The third time, they didn’t come back. The kitchen dropped into black, the faint glow from Leo’s nightlight down the hall suddenly distant. The hum of the fridge died. So did the quiet whirr of the HVAC. Roxy stayed still for two seconds, listening. No neighbors opening doors. No thunder right on top of them. Just rain, and in the rain, faint movement. She set the glass in the sink by feel, reached for her phone. Screen bright in her hand, a little rectangle of blue-white. She hit the side button: battery at seventy-two percent. Signal bars still there. She killed the screen. Too bright. Outside, something thunked softly near where the power meter sat on the side of the house. Storm, she thought again, and her own brain answered: Bullshit. She opened the silverware drawer, slid a paring knife into her back pocket, took the chef’s knife in her right hand. The weight was familiar. Too familiar. “Okay,” she whispered. To herself, not to anyone else. She padded down the hall toward Leo’s closet, letting her eyes adjust to the dark.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively executes the classic home invasion setup while establishing the competent-but-human protagonist that pulp fiction demands. The writing demonstrates strong craft fundamentals with clean prose, natural dialogue, and well-paced tension escalation. The characterization is particularly strong. Roxy reads as genuinely experienced without being superhuman - she spots the fake badge details (wrong font, no department) through observation rather than omniscience, and her reactions blend professional competence with human concern for Leo. Her brief internal reference to "another door, sand and shouting" efficiently hints at her military background without exposition dumping. Leo behaves authentically as a seven-year-old, asking practical questions about peeing during the "game" while accepting the adults' explanations. The dialogue serves multiple purposes effectively. Cole's attempts at authoritative charm ("Five seconds. You can watch me") reveal both his strategy and its limitations, while Roxy's responses ("That's alright, Cole") show her reading the situation without telegraphing her suspicions. The password exchange with Leo demonstrates both her tactical thinking and ability to work within a child's framework. The chapter follows classic thriller structure competently - initial contact, growing suspicion, confirmation of threat, defensive preparation. The power outage provides a strong ending beat that raises stakes without feeling overly convenient given the setup. However, the execution, while solid, doesn't transcend its genre constraints. The fake cop routine and systematic preparation follow familiar patterns without significant innovation. The writing is functional rather than distinctive, missing opportunities for the kind of voice that elevates pulp above mere competence. The chapter adheres closely to its stated plan, establishing threat while maintaining realism in both the antagonist's approach and protagonist's response. It successfully sets up the promised "wrong babysitter" scenario by demonstrating Roxy's capabilities without revealing their full extent. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 17 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The dark came down like a hood. Roxy let her eyes adjust and let her ears do the work. Rain ticking. The soft whine of wind in the vents. Leo’s wheezy, muffled sleep-breath from the closet if she strained for it. And underneath, a new sound: the scrape of something against glass. She moved to the sliding door, staying off the strip where she knew the outside light spilled, and crouched. The stick she’d jammed in the track was still firm from this side. Beyond the glass, a shadow hunched by the meter. A penlight flicked, quick and precise; the kind of beam people used when they wanted to see without being seen. Then the house finished dying. Whatever residual hum had been there—the fridge cycling, a server buried somewhere—quit. Her phone stayed lit. Not power, then. They’d cut it. “Just a drill,” she muttered. The words tasted stale. She backed away from the glass, knowing anyone out there could see motion against the faint reflection. Knife low in her hand, she went to the master bedroom, eased the closet door a fraction. Leo’s flashlight was a muted glow under the blanket. His voice barely audible. “Roxy?” “Still the game,” she whispered. “You’re winning. Don’t come out.” “What if—” “Gamera,” she said. “Remember?” He swallowed loud enough she heard it. “Okay.” She closed him back in. The squeeze in her chest was worse than the ache in her knee. Living room. She clicked her phone screen on for half a second, long enough to orient, long enough to pick up the baby monitor camera from a shelf. Clunky white plastic, cheap but effective. She flicked it on and set it facing the hallway. The other unit she pocketed. They’d expect panic. People in nice houses called 911, clustered in the most open, visible room, waited for uniforms. She had no guarantee 911 would pick up before whoever cut the power came inside. She ducked into the hall bathroom, slid the shower curtain aside, checked the frosted window. Latched but flimsy. She twisted the lock until it squealed softly and stepped back. Make it look like a weak spot. In the kitchen again, she listened. There. A soft pop from the back door latch. Someone working it. Her pulse picked up. Not fear exactly. Something more focused, narrower. She exhaled once, deep, let her shoulders drop. Her body remembered the ritual even if she’d spent years pretending it didn’t. Boot on tile. A silhouette in the back doorway, bigger than the fake cop. No mask yet. Deke, though she didn’t know his name. Baseball cap, hoodie, grin that thought it owned the room. “Hello, suburbia,” he whispered, stepping inside. She watched from the shadow between fridge and pantry, invisible so long as he didn’t look straight at her. He didn’t. He turned toward the counter, away from her, to look at the powered-down alarm keypad. “Clear,” he breathed into the mic at his collar. An answering crackle: “Keep it that way.” Roxy moved. It wasn’t smooth. She’d never been a movie. But it was fast. Two steps and she was at his shoulder. Knife up, left hand grabbing a fistful of hoodie to yank him off balance. He half-turned, surprised grunt, and the chef’s knife kissed his forearm instead of his neck, shallow and ugly. He howled, reflexively flinging his arm, catching her across the face with his elbow. Pain bloomed at her cheekbone. She stumbled, knife clattering to the tile. “Fuck—” he started, reaching for something at his belt. Her heel hit one of Leo’s abandoned Hot Wheels. Instinct snapped her weight sideways instead of down. She went with the skid, dropped to a knee that screamed protest, and lunged into him low, shoulder in his gut. They hit the counter together. A glass tumbled, shattered. His breath woofed out. He grabbed for her hair; she’d braided it for a reason. His fingers slid off, caught her ear instead. Pain. White spark. She slammed her forehead into his chin. The crack was satisfying. His grip loosened. Something metallic clanged to the floor by his feet—gun. Her hand found the paring knife in her back pocket before his did. She drove it up, under his ribs, too far left. He shrieked, shoved her hard. The blade tore free with a wet sound. Wrong spot. Too shallow. He wasn’t going down. He bolted backward, stumbling, leaving a smear on the cabinet. Out of range before she could follow. He crashed into the table, cursed, then lurched toward the sliding door he’d forced. “Cole!” he yelled, voice exploding the quiet. “Bitch is armed—” Roxy dove for the gun at his feet. Her fingers brushed cold metal as his boot came down. He kicked it away on instinct, not seeing where it went, only wanting it not in her hands. It skittered under the lower cabinets, out of their immediate reach. He staggered out the way he came, one hand clamped to his side. The door yawned open, rain blowing in. “Cole!” he bellowed again, disappearing into the yard. She let him go. Chasing a bleeding, screaming man into the dark while she had a kid in a closet and at least one more hostile outside? Stupid. The part of her that wanted to finish it was not the part that got to drive. She shut the slider, rammed the broom handle back into place, heart thudding. Blood smeared along her fingers where she’d gripped him. Some of it hers; most of it his. The adrenaline tremor hit late, a fine shake in her hands. She pressed them to the cool countertop. One breath. Two. “Status,” crackled a tinny voice from Deke’s collar mic, abandoned on the kitchen floor. She snatched it up, clicked the side. “We’re fine,” she said, flattening her voice into something male, nasal. “Tripped. She’s nothing.” Silence. Then Cole’s voice, distorted but calm. “Say again.” She hesitated half a second too long. The channel popped off. Well. So much for that.
