Their alliance uncovers trafficking/blackmail ring targeting queer folk. - Romance: soft, slow-burn; Rowan allergic to Nico’s chaos but drawn in. - Noir: techno-neon, highway chases, clandestine nightclubs. - Direction C: Corrupt cop x criminal informant - Protagonist: closeted detective (Alex). - Love interest: Gabe/Cass, informant with a smoking problem and a death wish. - Plot: Serial killings of queer men made to look like hookups gone wrong; tie into someone Alex works with. - Romance: forbidden, addictive, both liable to betray each other. - Themes: institutional rot, complicity, coming out, choosing a side. - Direction D: Ensemble at a queer bar - Protagonist: Eli, bartender. - Love interest: Cass, who uses bar as meeting point for shady deals. - Bar is threatened by developers, protection rackets, and political crusade. - A murder occurs in the alley; everyone’s implicated. - Romance: Eli and Cass reluctantly team up; sexual tension, banter, conflicting loyalties. Story beats/pacing over 8 chapters (multiple variant possibilities) Variant 1 (Direction A-style PI noir) - Ch 1: Introduction to MC and city - Open with prompt sentence: “He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas.” - MC first encounters love interest (LI) at a seedy bar or office. - LI brings a case: a friend/lover is dead; police call it overdose/suicide, feels wrong. - Establish: MC’s reputation, financial desperation, personal rule not to get involved with clients. - End: MC takes case despite better judgment. - Ch 2: Digging in - MC explores victim’s world: queer club, DIY venue, activist circle. - Meets supporting cast: drag queen informant, elder queer bar owner. - Finds first clue: something off in police report; missing evidence; hint of a blackmail ring. - LI appears again: evasive, flirty, suspicious. - End: MC realizes case ties to a bigger, riskier operation. - Ch 3: Deeper entanglement - MC and LI forced to team up. - Tension: MC questions LI’s involvement in victim’s life and death. - Reveal: powerful developer/politician/caporegime connected to both victim and LI. - Intimate moment: a near-kiss; confession; small gesture (lighting cigarette, bandaging wound). - End: MC caught between attraction and red flags about LI’s secrets. - Ch 4: Escalation and betrayal - MC discovers damning lead (payoff, ledger, footage). - Someone intimidates them; break-in at MC’s office/apartment. - MC suspects LI might be playing both sides. - Community stakes emphasized: victims are queer, targeted; police apathetic or complicit. - End: big complication (ally found dead, or MC framed). - Ch 5: Fallout and revelation - MC on the run in their own city; forced to lean on LI. - Emotional deepening: MC learns LI’s backstory; why he’s in this mess. - Reveal: central antagonist’s scheme clear now (land grab, cover-up, killing witnesses). - Separation: MC pushes LI away, citing “you’re bad for me,” underlying fear/trust issues. - End: twist: someone close to MC (cop, mentor, ex) is working for antagonist. - Ch 6: Choosing sides - MC at lowest point; can walk away. - LI makes reckless move, gets captured or cornered. - MC must decide: self-preservation vs rescuing LI and exposing truth. - Build towards alliance with marginalized allies in the community. - End: MC commits to a dangerous plan, knowing it might doom romance or life. - Ch 7: Confrontation - Setpiece: warehouse, dock, rooftop, or derelict theater. - Evidence, guns, lies; antagonist monologue but undercut with noir wit. - MC and LI working in sync, despite history of deception. - Someone gets shot/seriously hurt; sacrifice or near-sacrifice. - End: immediate danger resolved; consequences looming (media, cops, reprisals). - Ch 8: Aftermath and resolution - Public fallout: scandal breaks, but justice is partial, imperfect. - Community impact: bar saved or lost; some safety regained, but scars remain. - Romance resolution: - Either: MC and LI choose to try, acknowledging they’re bad ideas for each other but better together than alone. - Or bittersweet: part ways for now, unresolved but meaningful. - Final noir image: city at dawn, last cigarette, last wry line tying back to prompt. Variant 2 (Direction C-style cop/informant) - Ch 1: Detective narrates meeting LI informant; prompt line as initial judgment. - Ch 2: First murder case; informant hints at cop corruption. - Ch 3: Emotional entanglement; both complicit in bending law. - Ch 4: Discover murders tied to anti-queer politician; LI implicated. - Ch 5: Department turns on detective; internal affairs closing in. - Ch 6: Detective must choose between badge and LI. - Ch 7: Bring down corrupt network using illicit evidence and public leak. - Ch 8: Detective exiled from force; possibly leaves town with LI or watches him walk away. Variant 3 (Direction D-style bar ensemble) - Ch 1: Eli describes Cass’s entrance with prompt line. - Ch 2: Murder outside bar; cops blame queer patrons. - Ch 3: Eli/Cass dig; find connection to rent hikes, drug route. - Ch 4: Cass’s lies surface; Eli hurt; bar raided. - Ch 5: Eli rallies community; Cass cuts a dangerous deal. - Ch 6: Everything converges at Pride night or a fundraiser. - Ch 7: Plot thwarted, but at cost: bar damaged, villain exposed. - Ch 8: Reconstruction; Cass/Eli negotiation: is there a future? Queer romance dynamics (sampling) - Angsty: - One has internalized belief they ruin people; resists relationship. - The other sees through performance; pushes for vulnerability. - Tender: - Quiet scenes: sharing cigarettes under an awning; patching bullet grazes; exchanging keys. - Love expressed as: “I’ll help you burn this down if it keeps you alive.” - Conflict: - Secrets: one lies by omission about their role in crime/conspiracy. - Power: cop vs criminal; PI vs client; bartender vs fixer. - Trust: slow, grudging, set back by half-truths, then re-earned. Structural considerations - 8 x ~1000 words: - Each chapter needs a clean arc: clear objective, complication, small shift in relationship. - Minimal filler; scenes must both advance plot and deepen romance. - Start mid-action or mid-conversation to keep pace brisk. - Noir voice consistent; keep exposition lean, embed worldbuilding in dialogue and sensory detail. Possible twists/secrets to deploy - LI helped set in motion events that caused central victim’s death (knowingly or unknowingly). - MC once wrote an article or made a choice that empowered current antagonist. - Murder/blackmail targets queer folks in power who stayed closeted and compromised others. - “Bad ideas”: LI repeatedly offers risky shortcuts; one finally works, turning the case. - At least one betrayal feels genuine (not just fake-out) to keep stakes real. Endings (a few flavors to consider) - Hopeful noir: - Villain exposed; systemic issues remain; romance survives with eyes open. - Bittersweet: - Truth out, but costs are high; lovers separate for safety or conscience. - Subversive: - They choose each other and the community over formal justice systems. - Ending line reframes “bad ideas” as deliberate rebellion instead of accidents. # Reflection What feels strong: - Using a PI or similarly liminal protagonist: - Fits noir tradition and makes it easy to plug into corruption/murder plotlines. - Allows internal monologue rich with hardboiled, wry, lyrical observations. - A queer PI is archetypal-but-fresh in a neo-noir frame; identity/outsider status maps smoothly. - The “cigarette smoke and bad ideas” love interest: - Archetype works: a charming, dangerous man whose charisma masks damage. - Great for banter, sexual tension, push-pull dynamic. - Noir thrives on morally ambiguous lovers who may betray or save the MC. - Central case tied to queer community: - Raises stakes beyond individual romance. - Leverages noir’s systemic critique: corruption, policing, gentrification, targeted violence. - Allows exploration of found family and community defense, not just individual heroics. - Compact 8-chapter structure: - Encourages tight plotting: set up (1-2), spiral (3-5), climax (6-7), fall-out (8). - Each chapter can reliably carry one strong plot beat plus one relational beat. - Good match for noir’s momentum and for a short story scope. - Tone: - Neo-noir urban setting, rain and neon, suits and smudged eyeliner feels natural here. - The prompt line primes for a stylish, slightly heightened, cinematic narrative voice. Potential pitfalls / what doesn’t work as well: - Overcomplication: - Too many conspirators or twists could choke 8k words. - Risk: trying to include both giant political plot, multi-layered crime ring, and huge ensemble might leave romance undercooked. - Need to limit antagonist/plot elements so emotional beats have space. - Romance overshadowed or undercooked: - Noir can lean heavily into plot and vibes, sidelining emotional intimacy. - Need a clear plan for progression: attraction → guarded alliance → first real vulnerability → fracture → conscious choice to trust or walk away. - Physical intimacy should feel earned, not tacked on for genre. - Making queerness only a source of suffering: - Traditional noir themes (marginalization, violence, corruption) risk making queer characters only victims. - The story should balance threat with joy, solidarity, competence, and agency. - Glorifying the “bad idea”: - It’s fun to romanticize self-destructive men; but it can flatten him into a trope. - Better if his “bad ideas” emerge from survival strategies, trauma, and a skewed moral logic we understand, not just “sexy chaos.” - Gives room for growth: he can recognize damage he causes without losing edge. Trade-offs I’m weighing: - POV: - First-person from the PI/cop/bartender: - Pros: classic noir, immediate intimacy, strong voice. - Cons: love interest is filtered through suspicion; must work harder to reveal his inner life convincingly. - Close third: - Pros: slightly more flexibility, but less iconic noir flavor. - Likely: first-person, to lean into “He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas” as an inner monologue echo/refrain. - Occupations: - PI vs bartender vs cop: - PI: maximally noir, ethically flexible, believable access to both street and suits. - Bartender: strong hub/salon setting; more stationary, but everyone passes through. - Cop: bakes in institutional conflict and corruption, but risks copaganda if not handled carefully. - PI or bartender seem strongest for a lean 8-chapter story. - Ending tone: - Full happy ending might feel off-tone for noir but can work as neo-noir (hope in the ruins). - Fully tragic might undercut the “romance” expectation. - A tempered, hard-won hope or bittersweet-but-meaningful choice suits both noir and queer storytelling traditions. What seems most promising overall: - A focused Direction A-type structure: - Queer PI narrator. - Cigarette-smoke LI tied to the central case, morally compromised but not irredeemable. - Single strong throughline antagonist (e.g., developer/politician targeting queer spaces). - Plot: suspicious “suicide” → wider conspiracy → betrayal → alliance → partial justice. - Romance: central and intimately woven into choices about the case. - The city and queer community are characters; the romance is both personal and political. This path: - Delivers on “queer neo-noir romance” explicitly. - Keeps scope manageable for 8 x ~1000 words. - Allows rich mood without sacrificing clarity or relationship depth. - Creates a natural arc from the prompt line to a resonant concluding image. (Next step, after this reflection, will be to lock in the specific character set, POV, antagonist, and detailed chapter-by-chapter outline aligned with that chosen direction.)
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention Here’s what I’m committing to for the story. Core concept: - A queer neo-noir romance centered on: - Jace Morrow, a queer/trans-masc PI with a tarnished past. - Cass Vale, “all cigarette smoke and bad ideas”: a charming, morally gray fixer. - Plot: A single, coherent case: - Suspicious “suicide” of a young queer man. - The trail leads into a conspiracy involving a corrupt developer and a political campaign targeting the queer neighborhood. - Cass is tangled in it from the start; Jace must figure out if Cass is a liability, a weapon, or something dangerously like home. - Scale: Tight and focused to fit ~8,000 words: - Minimal but vivid cast. - One main antagonist: a smooth, ambitious developer-politician with police ties. - Stakes that are clearly personal (romance, guilt, survival) and communal (threat to queer spaces and lives). Voice and POV: - First-person past tense from Jace’s perspective. - Rationale: classic noir feel; lets the opening line be his thought. - Tools: wry, concise, sensory-rich narration; cynical on the surface, vulnerable underneath. - Style: - Noir-leaning but contemporary: neon, phones, social media, security cameras. - Hardboiled metaphors and dry humor, but not pastiche; keep it sharp and emotionally grounded. - Show queerness as intrinsic and normalized in this world; no explanatory asides, just lived reality. Romance: - Central, not decorative: - The relationship impacts choices in the case and vice versa. - Arc: - Chapter 1–2: Attraction + suspicion. - 3–4: Forced partnership and escalating chemistry. - 5: Fracture via betrayal/secret revealed. - 6–7: Conscious choice to trust (or at least stand together) in the climax. - 8: Hard-won, imperfect hope; choosing each other with eyes open. - Cass: - Not a flat “bad boy” stereotype. - His “bad ideas” arise from: - Survival under systemic pressure. - Loyalty to the wrong people. - Belief he’s already damned, so why not burn. - He has agency and moral texture; he can harm and protect, and he evolves. - Jace: - Haunted by a past investigative piece that exposed corruption but got a source killed. - Terrified of repeating that harm; this shapes his reluctance and his ferocity. Things to aim for: - A strong thematic spine: - Trust vs. self-preservation. - Systemic violence vs. community defense. - Love as both risk and resistance. - Vivid atmosphere: - Rain, neon, cheap motels, narrow stairwells, late-night diners, back rooms of queer bars. - Queer spaces feel alive: drag shows, bartenders, elders, kids, all with texture. - Every chapter: - Moves the case forward. - Deepens or complicates the relationship. - Ends with a hook, reversal, or emotional jolt. Things to avoid: - Overstuffed conspiracy: - Keep antagonism centered: one developer-politician (and his hired muscle + cop allies). - Trauma exploitation: - We show danger and harm, but avoid wallowing in queer suffering. - The community has resilience and competence; they are not just victims. - Copaganda: - Police presence is largely apathetic, hostile, or compromised. - Justice comes from exposure, community action, and strategic use of evidence, not heroic cops. - A magically neat ending: - The win is partial, costs are real. - But we end with enough light to honor the “romance” in “queer neo-noir romance.” # Chapter Planning Chapter 1 – He Was All Cigarette Smoke and Bad Ideas - Goal: - Introduce Jace, Cass, the city, and the central case. - Beats: - Opening line: Jace, late-night in his shabby office above a neon-lit laundromat, watching Cass lean in his doorway, smoking. - Cass: smooth, cocky, known in the underworld as someone who “makes things happen.” - Cass’s pitch: - A kid named Luka Rivera, early 20s, queer, found dead. - Ruled suicide/overdose; Cass insists it’s wrong. - Cass says Luka waited tables at The Palimpsest (queer bar/venue) and did errands for people; hints Luka was scared before he died. - Jace initially refuses: - It smells like trouble, Cass is cagey about his connection and motives. - Jace’s inner rule: no more cases that get kids killed. - Hook: - Cass drops a detail only the killer or someone close would know (e.g., angle of the body, missing ring). - Leaves a retainer that Jace badly needs and a photo of Luka with “For when your conscience beats your common sense.” - Jace, alone at the window, watching Cass’s red taillights vanish in the rain, decides to take the case against his better judgment. Chapter 2 – Neon Ghosts - Goal: - Immerse Jace in Luka’s world; hint at conspiracy; deepen Cass’s enigma. - Beats: - Jace visits The Palimpsest: - Talk with Iris, the owner, a sharp elder dyke; she’s wary but cares about Luka. - We glimpse chosen family, drag show in the background, the bar as sanctuary. - Clues: - Luka was organizing tenants against evictions in their building. - The building is marked for “revitalization” by Halden Rowe, polished developer mounting a “clean up downtown” council campaign. - Security footage from the night of Luka’s death is “missing.” - Cass reappears: - Watching from the edge of the room, trading barbed banter with Jace. - We see offhand proof he actually cared about Luka. - Jace learns: - Police closed the case in 24 hours. - Luka had bruises inconsistent with a simple overdose. - End beat: - Outside the bar, someone in a dark car photographs Jace and Cass together. - Jace clocks it, feels the net starting to weave. Chapter 3 – Lines in the Rain - Goal: - Force Jace and Cass into a working partnership; show friction and chemistry. - Beats: - Jace tracks Luka’s last movements: - A cheap motel, a call log (unknown burner), a cash deposit. - Cass tails Jace “to keep him from stepping on landmines.” - They clash over methods: Jace patient, methodical; Cass impulsive, favors shortcuts and threats. - They hit a dead end at a campaign office linked to Halden Rowe: - Sanitized, polite stonewalling. - Jace spots Luka’s name in volunteer logs; implies contact between Luka and the campaign. - Intimacy: - After a near-run-in with a cop who recognizes Jace from an old scandal, Cass pulls him into an alley to hide. - Close physical proximity, shared breath/smoke—tension spikes. - Cass jokes Jace thinks too much; Jace retorts Cass doesn’t think enough. - Concrete escalation: - Jace acquires a partial police report showing a witness statement from someone who has since “moved away.” - Note: report is doctored; pages missing. - End beat: - Jace finds his office door slightly ajar, file cabinet rifled. - Nothing obvious taken—except Luka’s photo. Chapter 4 – Smoke Screens - Goal: - Raise stakes; reveal Cass’s deeper involvement; first rupture of trust. - Beats: - Break-in aftermath: - Jace confronts Cass: who else knew about the case? - Cass admits: - He used to run errands for Halden Rowe’s people. - He connected Luka to that circle, thinking it’d mean money and safety. - Jace realizes Cass’s guilt is driving him. - New clue: - From Iris and another patron, Jace hears about a black SUV seen near Luka’s building multiple nights; plates tied to a security firm on Rowe’s payroll. - Threat: - Jace and Cass followed; a message is delivered: - Men “suggest” Jace drop the case; casually mention Jace’s old source who died. - Cass’s name studiously not mentioned—implies he’s known to them. - Emotional beat: - Jace, furious, accuses Cass of using him to clean up his mess. - Cass doesn’t deny it fully; says Luka mattered, this is how he can make amends. - End beat: - Jace finds an anonymous envelope slid under his door: - Grainy photos of Cass with Rowe’s fixer, plus Luka present in the background. - Implicit: Cass was there on a night crucial to Luka’s fate. - Trust fractures further. Chapter 5 – Bad Ideas - Goal: - Lowest point: betrayal crystallizes; Jace isolated but closer to truth. - Beats: - Confrontation: - Jace shoves the photos at Cass: “What else didn’t you tell me?” - Cass’s side: - He brought Luka to one of Rowe’s “fundraisers,” thought it was just donors. - Overheard talk about “collateral displacement” and “examples.” - Tried to pull Luka out once he realized; Luka refused, wanting to expose them. - Cass panicked, fed Luka a partial warning, then ghosted to avoid Rowe’s retaliation. - Jace’s reaction: - Sees his own past mistake reflected: warning too little, too late. - But he can’t shake the sense Cass is still holding back. - New intel: - Jace tracks down the “moved away” witness: - They’re terrified, reveal: - Luka met with someone from Rowe’s team (the fixer). - Luka had proof that Rowe used overdoses/“random” violence to clear buildings. - Shortly after, cops leaned on the witness to shut up; they fled. - Cass gets an offer: - The fixer approaches him: - Deliver Jace’s notes and he walks; otherwise, Cass’s past and queer spaces he loves get targeted. - Cass doesn’t tell Jace (key choice). - End beat: - Jace returns to his office to find his files copied, not taken. - Realizes someone close had to have had access. - Cass shows up at the door, rain-soaked, asking to talk. - Jace, hurt and suspicious, tells him to get out. Chapter 6 – Terms of Surrender - Goal: - Jace must decide whether to abandon the case; Cass makes a dangerous choice; they align for the climax. - Beats: - Jace’s low: - Alone in his office, considering walking away: memories of his dead source, the futility of fighting city-wide rot. - Sees Luka’s face (copy of the photo he’d scanned), sees the neighborhood slipping away. - Cass’s low: - Short scene from Jace’s POV when Cass forces his way back in: - Cass has been roughed up; he refused to hand over Jace’s files. - Confesses the fixer’s ultimatum; admits he almost considered it. - He is brutally honest: - “I am bad ideas, Morrow. But not that one. Not you.” - Decision: - Jace realizes: - The fact Cass didn’t betray him is the only leverage they have: the enemy thinks Cass is still pliable. - They strike a deal: - Use Cass as bait with a wire/recording; get the fixer admitting to arranging “overdoses” and police cooperation. - Simultaneously, pass evidence to Iris and a community journalist willing to go public fast. - Emotional beat: - Shared vulnerability; Jace tends Cass’s injuries. - Intimacy without full sex scene; maybe a near-kiss or a brief one that feels like a promise and a risk. - End beat: - Plan set: meet the fixer at an abandoned theater Rowe’s about to demolish. - Jace’s final thought: “If this was a bad idea, it was at least ours.” Chapter 7 – The Theater of Ruins - Goal: - Climax: confrontation with fixer/Rowe’s machine; evidence secured; real danger; Jace and Cass fight together. - Beats: - Setting: - Abandoned art deco theater at night; rain hammering the warped marquee; city buzzing beyond. - Meet: - Cass meets the fixer under the pretense of taking the deal. - Jace, hidden, recording via a cheap setup; Iris’s people nearby ready to blast footage online and to an honest (or cornered) DA/journalist. - Turn: - The fixer is not fooled; reveals: - A cop contact tipped them Jace’s been sniffing. - They know about Cass’s “crisis of conscience.” - Rowe’s presence: - Either physically arrives or on a call; cold, banal evil about “regrettable necessities.” - Escalation: - Guns drawn; Cass grabbed; Jace breaks cover. - Tense standoff: - Jace bluffs: the feed is already live (half-true). - Fixer hesitates; monologues just enough to damn themselves. - Violence: - A struggle, a shot fired: - Cass takes a bullet/grazing wound meant for Jace, or vice versa. - In the chaos, Iris’s crew kills power, sirens in the distance (but unclear whose). - Outcome: - Fixer incapacitated or forced to flee as audio/video pings out to multiple recipients. - Enough clear evidence captured: - Links between Rowe, fixer, staged overdoses, corrupt cops. - End beat: - Jace on the floor beside a bleeding Cass as red and blue lights paint the ruined walls. - He squeezes Cass’s hand, says: “Don’t you dare make this your last bad idea.” Chapter 8 – Ashes and Morning Light - Goal: - Resolve fallout; show imperfect justice; land the romance on a bittersweet-hopeful note. - Beats: - Aftermath (time jump: days/weeks): - News cycle: - Footage and documents leaked; Rowe’s campaign implodes; investigations opened. - One or two cops indicted; fixer facing charges. - Some charges “under review”—hinting the machine is hurt, not dead. - The Palimpsest: - Crowded again; community rallied; Rowe’s development on hold. - Still boarded windows next door, reminders of losses. - Jace: - Bruised, exhausted, mildly more reputable. - Offered a chance to “consult” officially; he declines, preferring independence. - Cass: - Recovering; marked man. - He’s cut ties with Rowe’s network, but knows the city won’t forget. - Romance resolution: - Quiet scene: rooftop or sidewalk at dawn outside the bar. - Cass lights a cigarette; Jace takes it, stubs it out; small symbolic gesture. - They talk about leaving vs. staying: - Cass jokes he’s poison; Jace says, “You’re also the guy who didn’t sell me out.” - No grand promises, just: - “Stay. See what happens.” - Or, “If we burn, we burn on our own terms.” - A brief, unhurried kiss or shared lean; tenderness amidst sirens and gulls. - Final image/line: - City in early light, neon signs flickering off. - Jace watching Cass, thinking: - He’s still cigarette smoke and bad ideas. - “But this time, I’m choosing the fire.” - Close on that conscious, defiant choice.
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
Good question, and great timing to ask it here instead of after the draft is written. I’ll break this into three parts: - How a human might approach this piece from the prompt. - Common LLM habits that don’t serve this kind of story. - A deep critique of our current intention/plan: where it smells like “AI,” and how to humanize it. Note: I’ll keep this craft-focused, concrete, and as candid as possible. -------------------- 1. How a human might approach this piece Prompt: “He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas.” Queer Neo-Noir Romance. ~8 chapters. A human writer (especially one living the culture or emotionally invested in it) might: - Start from a feeling, not a structure: - The exact ache of wanting someone you know is trouble. - The sensory memory of a specific bar, a specific rainstorm. - The tension between queer desire and danger—emotional, physical, social. - The frustration and love they feel for their own city. - Start small, then spiral out: - Maybe with an image: a guy leaning in a doorframe, smoke curling, eyes tired. - A line of banter that tells you everything about their dynamic. - Then: why is this person bad news? Why does the narrator care anyway? - Draw heavily from lived or closely observed queer experience: - The micro-calculations: where to stand, who gets trusted, how cops actually feel. - The textures of chosen family, in-jokes, petty drama, people who’ve known each other for years. - The way desire is threaded with vigilance; the way community notices when one of their own goes missing. - Be willing to: - Linger in messy scenes with no immediate plot “ payoff.” - Let characters contradict themselves and make ugly choices. - Leave loose ends in the plot, or moral ambiguity in the ending, if that feels true. - Voice first, “genre” second: - The noir elements emerge organically from voice/setting, not from checking off tropes. - Genre beats are bent to fit the characters, instead of characters shaped to hit beats. In short: a human is more likely to begin from idiosyncratic obsessions, specific memories, and emotional knots, then construct the plot around that, rather than start from “queer noir outline” and slot people into it. -------------------- 2. Telltale LLM approaches and why they’re risky here Some common LLM tendencies (including ones visible in our plan) that are dangerous for this story: 1) Over-structuring and over-competence - LLMs are good at outlines and classic arcs. That’s helpful, but: - It can produce a story that feels “screenwritten” rather than lived. - Every chapter has a neat beat and hook; there’s little genuine meander or surprise. - In noir and romance, a bit of “wasted” space—awkward conversations, bad decisions, delays, digressions—is where characters feel real. 2) Safety and moral tidiness - LLMs often: - Avoid having characters do something truly indefensible unless it’s clearly condemned. - Prefer clean moral lines: the corrupt are punished, the leads are flawed-but-good. - Default to cops/bureaucracy working once “the truth” is exposed. - For this piece: - A too-neat takedown of the villain or too-strong faith in institutions will feel false. - Queer neo-noir should be suspicious of “official” justice and comfortable with moral compromise. 3) Pretty-but-empty language - LLMs like: - Stacked metaphors, elevated phrasing, evocative but vague visuals. - The risk: - You get paragraphs that sound noir-ish but don’t say much. - Feels like cosplay instead of a specific city, specific bodies, specific histories. - For this story: - We need precise, concrete details, and a voice that chooses images like a person, not like a style guide. 4) Over-explanatory psychology - LLMs tend to: - Spell out why each character is the way they are. - Label emotions instead of letting subtext or behavior carry them. - That kills noir tension: - Desire and fear are more compelling when not fully articulated. - Cass is more interesting when we’re not constantly told his motivations in neat sentences. 5) Overprotectiveness of protagonists - Leads end up: - Competent, fundamentally kind, their worst impulses clamped down. - They don’t hurt each other in ways that might alienate readers. - For this piece: - They should be capable of being cruel, selfish, or very wrong. - The romance matters more if they earn it through real conflict, not just “gruff banter.” 6) Always wrapping with a bow - LLMs love: - Epilogues where everything is explained and symbolically tied up. - On-the-nose closing lines that echo the opening. - In noir: - A slightly raw ending, with unanswered questions and no full catharsis, often hits harder. - We can nod to themes without underlining them twice. These tendencies don’t mean the outline is wrong; they’re warnings about how easily it could feel synthetic. -------------------- 3. Deep dive: critiquing this specific plan Now let’s interrogate the current intention/chapters and flag “AI-flavored” pitfalls, plus brainstorm more human directions. A. The core premise What we have: - Queer PI Jace. - Smoky fixer Cass. - Dead queer kid Luka. - Corrupt developer-politician Rowe. - Evidence gathering > confrontation > partial justice. What feels LLM-ish: - It’s extremely archetypal. Nothing is wrong with archetypes—but: - “PI + fixer + dead kid + evil developer” is straight out of genre scaffolding. - It risks reading like a remix of familiar plots without a weirder, more personal slant. - Rowe is a little too cleanly “the villain.” - Wealthy, polished, gentrifier, uses cops: true-to-life, but currently flat. - Feels selected because “neo-noir needs systemic corruption,” not because Jace has a particular history with Rowe. More human tweaks to consider: - Anchor Rowe to a specific personal betrayal: - Maybe Jace’s ruined source was tied to Rowe. - Or Rowe used to be a closeted regular at the bar; the community has dirt on him, and he knows it. - Make Luka feel like an actual person: - Not just an inciting incident. - Seed distinctive details (art, jokes, a bad haircut, a crush, a playlist) that haunt Jace and Cass. - Consider a slightly off-center twist: - Maybe it’s not just gentrification; it’s also about leverage over queer people in power. - Or the conspiracy is smaller, pettier, more human—no huge ring, just a handful of ugly, plausible decisions. B. Chapter-by-chapter tropes Chapter 1: - Very solid structurally—but very “screenplay cold open.” - Risks: - Cass’s entrance and retainer are almost too smooth. - Jace taking the case “against his better judgment” is tropey. Humanizing ideas: - Let Jace have a more complicated reason: - Maybe he knew Luka. - Maybe Luka once emailed him, and he ignored it. - Maybe Cass is an ex, and this is loaded from second one. - Let the meeting be slightly messy: - Cass shows up drunk. Or panicked. Or asking for help without a neat retainer. - The case is not clearly a “case” at first, just Cass insisting “it doesn’t add up.” Chapter 2: - Bar, drag show, missing footage, SUV. Clean, functional, noir 101. Risks: - The Palimpsest and Iris feel designed to “represent community” instead of being weird, specific people. - Convenient clue pathways (security footage missing, plates → Rowe) can feel over-engineered. Humanizing ideas: - Give Iris one sharp, unflattering truth about Jace. - Let the bar have banal problems too: clogged toilets, a fight over the jukebox, drama between staff. - Make a clue come from an offhand comment, not obviously Chekhov’d evidence. - E.g., someone complaining about “those clipboard assholes from the campaign blocking the smoking patio” the night Luka vanished. Chapter 3: - Forced partnership, alleyway close call, missing pages. Fine beats. Risks: - The alleyway “pressed together to hide” is extremely fanfic/LLM-coded. - Characters’ competence and banter may feel too polished. Humanizing ideas: - If they’re crammed together, let it be awkward and unsexy: someone’s elbow, the reek of trash. - Desire can flicker amid the discomfort; that reads more real. - They should occasionally misread each other in non-dramatic ways. - Cass thinks Jace is scared of him; Jace is actually scared of his own pattern of obsession. Chapter 4: - Revelation of Cass’s past with Rowe; threat from heavies; envelope of incriminating photos. Risks: - Photographs as a blackmail/reveal device: a very standard trope. - The heavies delivering a direct warning is on-the-nose. - Cass’s connection to Rowe feels like a clean info-drop. Humanizing ideas: - Maybe there’s no neat envelope; Jace stumbles on something messy: an old post, a voicemail, a casual namedrop. - Have the threat be more insidious: - A cop “friend” who turns weird. - Someone leaving a dead rat at the bar, not a monologue. - Cass’s guilt should leak out earlier, in small, defensively sarcastic ways, so this chapter’s confession feels earned. Chapter 5: - This is the emotional low; structurally strong (confrontation, witness, ultimatum). Risks: - Cass’s backstory confession is clean and exculpatory: “I meant well, it went bad.” - The witness conveniently confirms the plot. - Cass is given an ultimatum and heroically refuses; very trope-aligned. Humanizing ideas: - Let Cass have done something worse: - Maybe he actively vouched for Luka to dangerous people for a payout. - Or he once fed Rowe info on activists, then backed out too late. - Let the witness be partial, contradictory, traumatized. - Some details don’t line up. - Jace has to decide what to believe; not everything gets verified. - Cass should seriously waver on the ultimatum: - Maybe he almost betrays Jace and pulls back at the last second. - Maybe he does one halfway shitty thing he has to own. Chapter 6: - Confession, patching up, alliance. Nice beats; also, very “romantic thriller.” Risks: - The conversation risks turning into a neat “I almost betrayed you but didn’t; please trust me” speech. - The plan to use Cass as wired bait is genre-standard. Humanizing ideas: - Make the reconciliation more awkward, less eloquent: - Interruptions, wrong words, anger that doesn’t resolve in one talk. - Emotional stakes: - Jace isn’t just scared Cass will betray him—he’s scared he needs Cass. - The plan could feel more improvised: - Less Ocean’s Eleven, more “this is a bad plan, but it’s all we’ve got.” Chapter 7: - Abandoned theater, wire, monologue, struggle, bullet, upload. Very cinematic. Risks: - Villain monologue exposition. - “Evidence goes live, villain hoisted by own petard”: satisfying but predictable. - Bullet-as-love-sacrifice is cliché. Humanizing ideas: - Make Rowe/fixer understated: - No speechifying; just a few banal, chilling lines. - Let something about the plan go wrong in a way they can’t slickly fix. - The upload fails. The recording is partial. Someone unrelated gets hurt. - If there’s a bullet, make it messy: - No slow-motion heroics; more stupid, chaotic velocity of violence. Chapter 8: - Fallout, partial justice, rooftop scene, “I’m choosing the fire” ending. Risks: - Very clean theme-echo. - Slightly “wrapped with a bow”: exposure works, bar is saved, romance is tentatively on. Humanizing ideas: - Soften the neatness of consequences: - Rowe might dodge some charges or rebrand himself. - The bar survives but is under new constant scrutiny. - Don’t over-script the final line: - Let the last beat be quieter, more specific: - A shared joke. - A small gesture (sharing a lighter, passing a flask, texting first). - Consider leaving one unresolved tension: - Cass might still leave; Jace might choose the city over him, or vice versa. - Even if they’re together, let doubt coexist with hope. C. The intention section: what to watch We’ve already tried to avoid some pitfalls (copaganda, neat HEA, faceless villains), which is good. But: - “Love as resistance,” “partial justice,” “eyes open”: - These are smart talking points, but if we lean on them too hard, it reads like theme essay, not story. - “Every chapter must do X and Y”: - Good discipline, but can create mechanical pacing. - The balance of style: - We say “not pastiche,” but the outline leans heavily into classic noir iconography (rain, neon, theaters, docks). - Without specific, idiosyncratic details, it’ll feel like a collage of noir stock photos. More human aims we can add: - Build one or two running jokes or petty conflicts that have nothing to do with the case. - Let characters be horny, tired, or petty in ways that interfere with the plot. - Allow some political/queer specificity: - Local ordinances, real-feeling activist strategies, housing court bullshit. - A sense of economic reality: who pays rent, how. - Embrace imperfect language: - Sentences that are choppy, blunt, or too honest. - Internal monologue that doesn’t always resolve into aphorisms. -------------------- Summary The existing plan is strong structurally and conceptually, but: - It leans into “competent genre outline” in a way that risks feeling like an LLM product: - Clean beats, archetypal characters, neat reveals, a symbolically resonant ending. - To make it feel more human: - Inject specificity, contradiction, and mess. - Let some things stay unresolved or morally muddy. - Make Cass’s bad ideas genuinely bad, and Jace’s attachment genuinely questionable. - Loosen the grip of structure just enough to allow surprising, character-driven detours. If you’d like, next step I can: - Annotate the existing chapter plan with specific “make-this-messier/more-human” notes before any rewriting. - Or propose 2–3 variants of key moments (meet-cute, betrayal, finale) that deliberately break away from the neat version.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention Core commitment: - Write a tight, character-driven queer neo-noir romance that feels lived-in, not templated. - Honor the prompt—“He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas.”—as the emotional thesis: - The story is about wanting someone you know is wrong for you, and choosing them anyway (or choosing yourself instead), in a city that’s also built on bad decisions. - 8 chapters, ~1000 words each: - So: focused, lean, with carefully chosen moments. - We’ll privilege specificity and emotional truth over elaborate plotting. Key choices: 1. Protagonist and POV - Protagonist: Jace Morrow - Late 20s/early 30s. - Trans masc, bi. - Ex-investigative journalist turned underpaid PI after one of his exposes got a source killed and his own career burned. - Semi-sober, insomnia, carries guilt like a second wallet. - POV: - First-person past tense from Jace. - Style: sharp, observational, occasionally poetic but grounded; lets subtext carry weight. - He’s not fully reliable; he edits his own story, avoids his own soft spots. - Intent: - Voice feels like a specific guy in a specific city, not like “generic noir narrator.” - Readers know him through what he fixates on: Cass’s hands, flickering signs, rent overdue. 2. Love interest - Cass Vale - Early 30s. Bisexual. Works as a fixer/middleman for people who don’t want their names on contracts. - Smokes too much, drinks too much, jokes too much. - Loyal in twisted ways. Genuinely dangerous, mostly to himself. - Ties to both queer community and the city’s underbelly. - “All cigarette smoke and bad ideas”: - Not just an aesthetic; he drags trouble with him. - He’s made choices that did real harm. The story doesn’t sand that down. - Intent: - Complex, not a redemption caricature. - Sometimes charming, sometimes pathetic, sometimes cruel, sometimes soft. - At no point is he fully explained; some of his choices remain ambiguous. 3. Setting and conflict - City: - Contemporary, unnamed but concrete: coastal, damp, gentrifying fast. - Queer bar district on the edge of new developments; community under pressure. - Central conflict: - Luka Rivera, a queer kid known around the bar scene, is found dead—ruled overdose/suicide. - Jace knew Luka slightly (a source that never panned out, or a kid who hovered around with questions). - Cass shows up insisting it doesn’t add up. - The investigation leads to: - Halden Rowe, a developer/council candidate pushing “cleanup” and “revitalization.” - Quiet cooperation from certain cops. - Small but real acts of violence aimed at clearing properties and silencing people. - Scale: - Not a vast conspiracy with ten layers. - A handful of people making ruthless cost-benefit decisions that crush vulnerable lives. - Intent: - Plausible, ugly corruption instead of operatic villainy. - The system doesn’t fall; a few people get singed. 4. Tone and themes - Noir, but: - More human than operatic. - Uses classic visuals (rain, neon) but always anchored in concrete, new details. - Themes: - Desire vs. self-preservation. - Guilt, complicity, and who gets to walk away. - Queer community as both tender and fractious; not just noble victims. - Bad ideas: when you know better and go anyway; when survival and betrayal blur. - Ending: - No tidy bow. - Partial justice, lingering unease. - The romance lands in a space of conscious risk: something like “We are bad ideas and we might wreck this, but let’s not lie about who we are.” 5. Craft rules (to avoid LLM-ish pitfalls) - Keep it: - Specific: brands of cigarettes, the exact shape of Luka’s chipped nail polish, the smell of the bar at 2 a.m. - Imperfect: silences, interruptions, awkward sex/affection, people saying the wrong thing. - Economical: no villain monologues, no long thematic speeches. - Avoid: - Over-explaining motives; let actions and slips of tongue do work. - Hyper-neat plot mechanics; allow some loose ends. - Overly “quoted” final line; aim for resonance, not slogan. - Every chapter: - One clear external move in the case. - One real emotional movement (even small) between Jace and Cass. - At least one detail that grounds us in a lived queer world (not just aesthetic). # Chapter Planning Chapter 1 – Cigarette Smoke Purpose: Introduce Jace’s voice, Cass’s entrance, Luka’s death, and the emotional hook, rooted in the prompt. Beats: - Late rain. Jace alone in his tiny office above a laundromat, half-working, half-avoiding a drink. - Cass appears in the doorway: wet leather, cigarette halo, that familiar ache of history. - Not a stranger: they’ve hooked up before, on and off, always disastrously timed. - Prompt lands as Jace’s internal line: “He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas,” laced with irritation and longing. - Cass’s ask: - Luka “jumped” or “OD’d.” Cass says he doesn’t buy it. - Luka used to crash on Cass’s couch sometimes, hung at the bar, talked about “something big.” - Cass thinks someone nudged him off the edge. - Jace refuses at first: - Burned by past. Broke but stubborn. - Also, Cass is a trigger: cases with Cass attached end with blood. - Two turns: - Cass leaves a folder with Luka’s photo and some scraps (text screenshots, a flyer for Halden Rowe’s campaign, a scribbled note: “they’re clearing us out”). - Jace recognizes Luka from a half-remembered request for help he never returned. - End: - Alone, Jace looks at Luka’s photo, remembers the unread message. - “I already owed one ghost too many.” He goes after Cass to say yes. Chapter 2 – The Palimpsest Purpose: Enter Luka’s world; meet community; get first off-key notes; complicate Cass. Beats: - Jace at The Palimpsest: - Not a glam neon cliché; cramped, mismatched chairs, drag posters, cheap gin, Christmas lights that never come down. - Iris, owner: mid-50s, no patience for Jace’s late guilt; she remembers his article that got someone hurt. - Information, messy not neat: - Luka: sweet, flaky, political when drunk; had been talking about “Rowe’s people” and “evidence.” - Rowe’s canvassers had been around constantly, buying drinks, getting numbers. - Luka’s death is already old news to cops. - Brief Cass/Jace interaction: - Cass at the bar, flirting and deflecting. - Iris pointedly ignores him; hints at his own past betrayals. - Clue seeds: - Luka was behind on rent but suddenly paid in full before he died. - He’d argued in the alley with someone in a suit—no one got a name. - End: - On his way out, Jace notices a “Rowe for Renewal” billboard looming over a block with eviction notices. - Rain starts; Cass falls into step with him, offering a cigarette he doesn’t take. - Jace agrees to let Cass in—for now. Chapter 3 – Bad Company Purpose: Start the investigation proper; force Jace and Cass into a shaky team; hint at Cass’s complicity. Beats: - Morning after grimed with hangover light. - Jace goes through Luka’s folder: prepaid card receipts, Rowe campaign flyer with an address circled. - Jace and Cass check that address: - Supposed to be a campaign satellite office; actually a nearly empty space and a bored guy who says Luka “volunteered a couple nights.” - Jace catches Cass lying casually to the receptionist, realizes how practiced he is. - Interpersonal friction: - Jace presses: how did Cass know Luka? - Cass dodges with jokes; Jace spots guilt but gets no specifics. - Real-world ugly detail: - They swing by Luka’s apartment: boxes packed, landlord already showing it. - A neighbor mentions security guys hassling building residents about “trespassers” in the stairwells. - Human moment: - Jace sees Luka’s old mug on a counter, takes it without thinking. - Cass sees and laughs, calls him sentimental; Jace tells him to shut up. - End: - A car idles too long outside as they leave. - Jace is paranoid; Cass is too blasé. - Unclear if they’re actually being tailed or Jace is seeing patterns. Chapter 4 – Open Wounds Purpose: Raise stakes; expose part of Cass’s involvement; show community tension; no clean villain speeches. Beats: - At the bar’s back room: - An argument: Iris and some regulars angry that Jace is stirring this back up; they’ve seen what happens to people who poke at power. - They don’t trust Cass; he’s done “errands” for landlords and dealers. - Confrontation: - Jace corners Cass after hearing this. - Cass admits: - He’s worked for Rowe-adjacent people as a go-between. - He introduced Luka to them—“for side work,” he says—but didn’t ask questions. - When he realized it was about pushing out tenants, he backed off. too late. - No neat absolution: he owns that he liked the money. - Threat comes sideways: - Jace’s door at home jammed; nothing stolen, but Luka’s file moved. - A casual text from an unknown number: “You’re chasing ghosts, Morrow.” - Friction: - Jace lashes out at Cass: “This is your mess.” - Cass doesn’t argue; just says, “Then help me clean it.” - End: - Jace alone, rereading Luka’s last unsent draft email to him (hinting at Rowe). - The guilt pulls him deeper in despite growing danger. Chapter 5 – Bad Ideas Purpose: Hit emotional and ethical low; expose more of Cass’s guilt; blur lines of trust. Beats: - Jace finds a small-time organizer who knew Luka: - Confirms Luka was scared, thought he had proof—texts, maybe a recording—tying harassment and overdoses near slated properties to one of Rowe’s people. - Luka boasted he had “insurance”; no one has seen it. - Cass’s breaking point: - He shows up drunk at Jace’s place. - Admits: - The “side work” he arranged for Luka was security/crowd work at Rowe events and “talking to tenants” about moving. - Cass once passed along names of “troublemakers” for extra cash. - Luka was on those lists. - He’s not sure if that directly led to Luka’s death, but he believes it’s all connected. - Ugly argument: - Jace calls him out: “You sold him.” - Cass hits back: “Like you never left anyone hanging for a story?” - Both are right and wrong. - Quiet cruelty: - Jace, devastated by resemblance to his own past, kicks Cass out. - Instantly regrets it; doesn’t call him back. - End: - Cass gets a DM from Rowe’s fixer offering him cash and safety if he helps “calm our overeager detective friend.” - We only see Jace later glimpse a hint of this (a text preview over Cass’s shoulder), not the full deal. Chapter 6 – Terms Purpose: Decision point; forge uneasy alliance without saccharine reconciliation; sketch the final move. Beats: - Jace spiraling: - Researching Rowe: sanitized news, polished speeches about “safety.” - Deletes and retypes messages to Cass. - Visits Luka’s now-empty room; landlord scraping off stickers. - Cass returns, not dramatically: - Bruised. Claims he “fell.” - Jace doesn’t fully buy it. - Half-confession: - Cass admits the fixer approached him. - He says he stalled, didn’t say yes—“I am a bad idea, but I’m not that predictable.” - He does not swear total innocence; instead: “If I’d wanted to sell you out, I would’ve.” - A plan, but frayed: - Use Cass’s meeting with the fixer to grab something concrete: - Names, instructions, money changing hands. - Stream/record it and route it to an independent local journo and Iris simultaneously. - Human beats: - Jace patches Cass up. - They share one unguarded moment—foreheads nearly touching, neither quite apologizing. - The attraction is there, but so is the knowledge it might ruin them. - End: - Jace sets up a very imperfect recording plan (cheap mic, unstable connection). - Cass texts the fixer: “We should talk.” Chapter 7 – The Meeting Purpose: Climax with tension and mess; no operatic villain, but real risk; partial win earned, not gifted. Beats: - Location: - Not some Gothic ruin; a half-demolished parking structure slated for Rowe’s condos. - Rebar, puddles, the city humming beyond. - The meet: - Cass with the fixer; Jace listening in from a shitty old sedan nearby. - Conversation low-key, transactional, chilling: - Fixer offers cash, maybe hints at past favors for Cass. - Cass nudges for clarity: “Like Luka?” - Fixer’s slip: “Luka got himself killed. We just removed temptations.” - Things go wrong: - The mic crackles; some of the key line drops. - A second car boxes Jace in: they did expect him. - Chaos: - Short, panicked confrontation. - No melodramatic speech, just terse threats, a gun, Cass shoving someone, a shot mis-aimed. - Jace manages to get a fragment of video and audio out to Iris/the journo before his phone is kicked away. - Intervention: - Iris and a couple of regulars show up—they’d insisted on backup. - Not action heroes; just angry, scared people who create enough confusion for Jace and Cass to get loose. - End: - The fixer retreats, injured or exposed; one license plate and a half-caught phrase tie him to Rowe. - Cass shaking, Jace furious and relieved. - Sirens near, unclear if that’s good or bad. Chapter 8 – After Purpose: Land on a human, unresolved-but-honest note; case dented the machine; Jace and Cass choose something knowing it’s a risk. Beats: - Short time jump (days/weeks). - Fallout: - Local journo runs a piece using Jace’s fragments plus community testimonies: - Shows pattern of harassment, forced moves, overdoses near Rowe properties. - Names the fixer; raises real questions. - Rowe: - Denies, distances, pauses his campaign. - No perp walk. Just a stain that might or might not end him. - The fixer: - Under investigation, maybe flees. - Police: - Make noises about an internal probe; no one believes them fully. - The Palimpsest: - Still open. Legal fund tip jar by the register. - Quiet memorial corner for Luka—a photo, a candle melted onto an old coaster. - Jace: - Still broke, still in that office. - Slight uptick in clients who “heard he gives a damn.” - More aware of his limits; less interested in pretending one story fixes anything. - Cass: - Lurking at the edges, work scarcer, people wary. - He didn’t sell Jace out. But he can’t undo what he did to Luka. - Final scene: - Outside the bar near dawn, after chairs are stacked. - Cass offers a cigarette. Jace takes it, doesn’t smoke; just holds it. - Brief, unsentimental talk: - Acknowledging Luka, the mess, the fact that neither of them are clean. - Cass: “You sure you want to be seen with all my bad ideas?” - Jace: “I’m not sure about anything. That’s the point.” - They don’t promise forever. - Maybe Jace leans in, kisses him once, tastes smoke and rain and regret. - Last note: - Jace walks with Cass back toward the noise and light, aware this could go wrong. - The thought is less aphorism than admission: - He keeps moving anyway. - We end on that movement—a choice into uncertainty, not a framed quote.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Jace Morrow Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Age: 29–32. - Grew up in the same city, lower-middle-class side of town. Catholic family; came out as trans in late teens, things went “complicated,” not catastrophic but strained enough he keeps his distance. - Ex-investigative journalist: - Wrote a big corruption story in his mid-20s that exposed cozy ties between a council member’s office and a construction firm. - His main source was outed despite Jace’s attempts to protect them; the source later died in what was ruled an accident. Jace believes his own sloppiness and hunger for the scoop helped kill them. - Blacklisted by local papers for being “difficult” and “reckless,” quietly smeared as unreliable. - Now a PI: - Business is mostly cheating spouses, background checks, the occasional missing dog. - He tells himself he’s chosen quiet work; he knows it’s exile. - Personality: - Dry, sardonic, self-deprecating. - Observant bordering on intrusive: he clocked a man’s whole morning from the scuffs on his shoes once and has never let himself forget how good that felt. - Avoidant when it comes to intimacy; deflects with jokes or work talk. - Idiosyncrasies: - Drinks too much coffee. Has a favorite chipped mug he stole from a diner closing down (logo half-scraped off, reads: “EAT HERE AND GET GAS”). - Always carries a notebook, but half his notes are metaphor fragments he’ll never use and bus route numbers. - Cuts the filters off cigarettes when he’s really stressed but rarely lights them; he likes the ritual more than the smoke. - Hates voicemail; lets them pile up unheard. - Flaws: - Guilt-driven to the point of paralysis: would rather do nothing than risk doing harm again—until something pushes him, and then he can overcorrect. - Self-righteous streak: he believes he sees through bullshit, which blinds him to his own. - Jealous of people who still have uncomplicated ideals; he can be cruel about it. - Drawn to chaos (see: Cass) and then resents it. Physicality: - Build: lean, wiry, more endurance than bulk. - Appearance: - Short, practical haircut he trims himself. - Keeps stubble when he can; it matters to him in ways he’d never explain out loud. - Clothes: thrift-store button-downs, dark jeans, one halfway decent jacket reserved for clients and court. - Old top surgery scars, a few faint cigarette burns, one more serious scar at his ribs from a night he doesn’t talk about. - How he carries himself: - Slight hunch, like he’s apologizing for taking up hallway space. - But when focused, he gets very still: weight balanced, gaze direct, pen hovering. - In crowds, always with his back to a wall or facing the door. - Expressions/interactions: - Tight little half-smiles; takes a lot to get a real laugh out of him. - Flicks his gaze to people’s hands when they talk. - On bad days, chews his thumbnail until it bleeds without noticing. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - To feel like he’s not a net harm. - To make things add up; he’s allergic to unanswered questions when someone’s dead. - In this story: he owes Luka; he owes his dead source; he wants to know if Cass can be anything but damage. - Allegiances: - Suspicious of institutions. - Loyal to Iris and the bar in a sideways way: buys drinks he can’t afford, watches the door when there’s trouble. - Strong internal code: don’t out people, don’t give the cops more than you have to, don’t use someone’s pain for your own redemption arc. - Relationships: - Iris: part-time ally, part-time moral check; she doesn’t fully forgive him, but she trusts his intentions more than his judgment. - Cass: history of on-again hookups and off-again cooperation; attraction salted with resentment. - Family: occasional texts with a younger sister; parents mostly off-page, a sore tooth he won’t poke. Voice samples: - (Internal) “He looked like a PSA about lung cancer dressed itself in a leather jacket and learned to smirk.” - (Dialogue) “No, I’m not a cop. If I were a cop, I’d have better shoes and less of a sense of humor.” - (Internal) “You’d think after getting one man killed I’d have learned to mind my own business. Turns out I’m a slow learner.” - (To Cass) “You don’t get to confess like it’s foreplay and expect a gold star.” --- # Cass Vale Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Age: 31–34. - Grew up one neighborhood over from Jace; foster system kid for a while. - Learned early that rules are for other people and so are safety nets. - Occupation: - “Fixer” in the small-time sense: sets up jobs, connects people who want things done off the books, arranges muscle, transport, hush money. - Not a mastermind; a middleman with a good Rolodex and worse boundaries. - Personality: - Charismatic, quick with a line, good at reading what people want to hear. - Practices detachment, but catches feelings more than he admits. - Self-sabotaging: will turn left into the fire even when the exit is clearly marked. - Idiosyncrasies: - Smokes a specific brand because a long-ago boyfriend did; never changed, never admits why. - Keeps matchbooks from every bar he’s ever made a deal in; never uses them, just collects. - Likes bad reality TV, claims it’s “research.” - Carries loose change and always over-tips bartenders he likes. - Flaws: - Compartmentalizes to the point of cruelty: “It’s just business” has justified a lot. - Cowardice in slow motion: not the kind to pull a trigger, but the kind to walk away when someone’s dangling. - Lies by reflex: about big things, small things, the weather. - Enjoys feeling needed; will create crises where he can ride in with a smoke and a solution. Physicality: - Build: rangy, slightly underfed look; looks better in clothes than out of them, but pulls it off. - Appearance: - Dark hair, too long at the front, finger-combed back. - Permanent hint of stubble, crow’s feet from squinting through smoke. - Tattoos: amateurish black ink; a little saint on his forearm, a date on his ribs he won’t explain. - Clothes: leather jacket that’s seen things, black jeans, some surprisingly nice shirts from deals gone right. - How he carries himself: - Loose-hipped, lazy confidence, leans more than he stands. - Always occupying doorways, thresholds; rarely the center of a room. - Expressions/interactions: - Talks with his cigarette; uses it to point, to underline sarcasm. - Slow grin when he’s lying; quicker, crooked one when he’s actually pleased. - Hovers close in conversations—invades personal space on purpose. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Survival, first. - Money, but less than people assume; half of it goes to keeping others afloat. - To not think too hard about whether he’s a villain. - For Luka: guilt and anger; he pulled him into circles that turned lethal. - For Jace: the stubborn, humiliating desire to be seen as more than a walking red flag. - Allegiances: - To certain people, not causes: - Iris, in his messy way. Some of his money kept the bar’s lights on once. - A couple of younger queers he unofficially looks out for. - Used to Rowe’s orbit; no real loyalty, just habit, perks, fear. - Relationships: - Jace: ex-hookup, half-partner sometimes, the one person whose opinion can actually wound him. - Iris: she doesn’t trust him, but she knows he’s useful; strained mutual dependence. - Luka: starts as “kid I got jobs for,” turns into a ghost that won’t leave him alone. Voice samples: - (Dialogue) “Relax, Morrow. If they were going to kill you, they wouldn’t text first. Probably.” - (Internal, if we ever heard it) “He looks at me like I’m the end of the world and still stands close enough to smell the smoke. Who’s the idiot here?” - (To Iris) “I’m not saying I’m a good person. I’m saying I’m the asshole you’ve got.” - (To Jace, bitter) “You write one story and the city burns, you’re a martyr. I introduce one idiot to the wrong suit, I’m a murderer. Funny math.” --- # Iris Navarro Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Age: mid-50s. - Mexican-American, butch lesbian, has been running The Palimpsest for close to twenty years. - History: - Watched waves of raids, moral panics, and gentrification try to erase her bar. - Has buried friends. Has outlasted three landlords and two city councilmen. - Personality: - Sharp, unsentimental, quietly kind when it counts. - Doesn’t forgive easily; holds grudges like others collect keychains. - Prides herself on knowing everybody’s business and rarely being wrong. - Idiosyncrasies: - Names her bar equipment (the espresso machine is “Lola,” the jukebox is “Santiago”). - Keeps a notebook under the bar; looks like a ledger, is half gossip. - Pretends to hate karaoke night; knows all the words. - Flaws: - Overprotective in a way that can shade into controlling. - Assumes she knows what’s best for “the kids,” which isn’t always true. - Distrusts any “cause” that isn’t directly paying the bar’s water bill. Physicality: - Build: solid, ex-softball or ex-bouncer shoulders, strong hands. - Appearance: - Salt-and-pepper hair cut close. - Wears crisp button-ups, dark jeans, boots meant for standing. - Wears a ring on a chain under her shirt; doesn’t talk about it. - How she carries herself: - Commanding behind the bar; everything within reach, like a cockpit. - Moves slower than she used to but with certainty. - Expressions/interactions: - One eyebrow does half her talking. - Calls most regulars “kid” regardless of age. - When she’s worried, she polishes a clean glass. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Keep the bar open: it’s home, archive, shelter. - Keep her people alive, even from their own stunts. - Allegiances: - To her patrons before politics. - Deep suspicion of cops and developers; learned the hard way. - Relationships: - Jace: sees him as well-meaning but dangerous; his last big story got someone from “their side” killed. - Cass: a walking liability, but he’s hauled in kegs at 3 a.m. and handed over envelopes when the bar was behind. - Luka: one of her kids; his death sits on her like a stone. Voice samples: - (To Jace) “You chasing this because you care, or because you miss seeing your name in headlines?” - (To Cass) “If you’re here to ask me to vouch for you, try another bar. Maybe one you haven’t almost gotten shut down.” - (Internal-ish) “I’ve been promised protection by better liars than Rowe.” --- # Luka Rivera (Though dead, Luka’s presence matters; he can’t just be “the body.”) Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Age: 22. - Worked part-time at The Palimpsest bussing tables, sometimes did door on busy nights. - Also loosely involved in tenant organizing; frustrated by how slow everything was. - Personality: - Earnest to a fault, loved big gestures. - Posted long Instagram captions about community and joy; also subtweeted exes. - Alternated between idealism and exhausted cynicism. - Idiosyncrasies: - Collected enamel pins, filled his jacket with them. - Kept changing his hair; last time Jace saw him, it was bleached and fried. - Always humming under his breath when he thought no one was listening. - Flaws: - Impulsive; trusted the wrong people if they flattered his sense of purpose. - Liked the thrill of “having dirt” on powerful men; underestimated consequences. Physicality: - Only seen in memory/photos: - Slender, sharp cheekbones, dark eyes too old for his age. - Hoodie and pins, chipped black nail polish. - Presence: - In the story, he’s a ghost in the social sense: everyone has a different Luka. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives (when alive): - Make things better, fast. - Be seen, taken seriously. - Allegiances: - To his building’s tenants. - To Iris’s bar, which felt like home. - Relationships: - Friendly with Jace; had once asked for advice about “going public” with some info. - Looked up to Cass’s apparent power; that went badly. Voice samples: - (From an old text Jace rereads) “You know how to do this without getting people killed, right?” - (From Iris’ memory) “Come on, let me run the playlist, I swear it’ll be good tonight.” --- # Halden Rowe Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws: - Age: early 40s. - Polished developer and council candidate. - History: - Family money, rebranded as “self-made.” - Owns or manages several “revitalization” projects. - Personality: - Measured, blandly charming, says “we” a lot. - Believes he’s net positive: “some displacement is inevitable.” - Idiosyncrasies: - Collects local art but only hangs pieces that match his color schemes. - Uses people’s first names constantly. - Flaws: - Morally anesthetized; doesn’t want to see the blood on the numbers. - Surrounds himself with fixers so he can keep his hands technically clean. Physicality: - Always well-tailored, neutral tones. - Fit in a way that says personal trainer. - Rarely raises his voice; rarely looks anyone “beneath him” fully in the eye. Motives, allegiances, relationships: - Motives: - Win the election; protect and grow his portfolio. - Avoid scandal by any means “legal enough.” - Allegiances: - To donors, not neighborhoods. - Relationships: - Doesn’t know Jace personally at first; becomes aware when noise starts. - Cass is a former tool via intermediaries. Voice samples: - (Public) “We’re not just building condos; we’re building community.” - (Private, clipped) “Handle it. I don’t want names. I want results.” --- If you’d like, next we can do a very tight secondary pass on a couple of side characters (the fixer, one or two regulars) or jump into drafting Chapter 1 with these voices guiding choices.

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
He was all cigarette smoke and bad ideas. Standing in my doorway like he’d been conjured by a headache, Cass leaned one shoulder against the frame, leather jacket slick with rain, cigarette cupped in his hand against the draft. Secondhand smoke curled into my office, tangling with the detergent fug from the laundromat downstairs. “Place still smells like Tide and regret,” he said. “It’s part of the brand,” I said. “You’re letting the heat out.” He stepped in anyway. The hall light behind him went out, sensor timing out, so for a second it was just the orange coal of his cigarette and the pale blur of his face. Then my shitty desk lamp remembered its job and washed everything in nicotine yellow. Cass looked the same as the last time I’d told him to fuck off, just more tired around the eyes. Hair too long in front, pushed back with his fingers. Stubble he’d call a beard if he was drunk enough. The jacket, the boots, the practiced slouch. He carried himself like the building should be paying him rent for the privilege. “Hey, Jace,” he said. “Cass.” I made his name flat as possible. “No offense, but it’s after midnight and I didn’t wish hard enough on a cursed object to see you tonight.” He smiled. The left corner of his mouth never quite caught up with the right; I’d been stupid about that smile, once. “You working?” he asked, glancing at the mess on my desk. Three manila folders, two empty coffee cups, a half-filled notebook open to a page of phone numbers and a doodle of a dead plant. Nothing worth the rent. “Trying not to,” I said. “What do you want?” He didn’t answer right away. He came closer, close enough for me to smell the wet leather and cheap tobacco under the detergent. He tapped ash into an empty mug without asking. That mug had once belonged to a diner that didn’t exist anymore. “A kid’s dead,” he said. I waited. You hang a statement like that in front of me, you know what it does. “Lot of those,” I said. “It’s a city.” “Luka,” he said. “Luka Rivera.” The name flashed. Skinny kid, bleach-fried hair, too many enamel pins on his jacket. Bussing tables at The Palimpsest, trying on different versions of himself under the Christmas lights. Cornering me once by the bathroom to ask about “how you make people listen.” I hadn’t emailed him back. “When?” I asked. “Couple nights ago,” Cass said. “Cops are calling it an overdose. Or a jump. Depends which asshole you ask.” He said it like the words tasted wrong. I swiveled my chair so I didn’t have to look straight at him. The blinds rattled in the draft; outside, rain smeared the red laundromat sign into bleeding shapes. “Condolences,” I said. “That your PSA?” “This isn’t a joke.” His voice sharpened. “They’ve already closed it. Paper said ‘troubled youth, history of substance use.’ You know the template.” “And you’re here because…?” “Because it’s bullshit.” I let the silence stretch. He took another drag, watched me through it. “I know bullshit,” he said. “I shovel it for a living. This isn’t that.” There were ten good reasons not to get within a block of anything Cass considered interesting. I knew most of them firsthand. So I went for the obvious one. “Cops don’t reopen cases because a guy who smells like an ashtray gets a bad feeling.” “I’m not asking the cops,” he said. Of course he wasn’t. I rubbed my jaw. The stubble bit my fingers. “This your guilt talking? Or did the kid actually say something?” Cass’s gaze slipped off mine. He stubbed out the cigarette in the mug, filter crushed against faded lettering. “He was scared,” he said. “Last time I saw him. Kept going on about having something. ‘Proof,’ he said. ‘Receipts.’ He was flashing his damn phone like a target. Said he was going to come talk to you, actually.” “He didn’t,” I said. “He texted you,” Cass said. “You don’t check your messages?” My stomach did a slow, cold turn. I thumbed my screen awake, scrolled through the graveyard of unread notifications. There it was, buried under spam and debt: Luka Rivera, two weeks ago. hey, you still do that dig up shit on people thing? got something sketchy. need advice. No follow-up. My thumb hovered over the text, too late in the wrong century. “Must’ve missed it,” I said. Cass watched my face, and something in his relaxed. Not relief. Resentment bleeding into vindication, maybe. “Yeah. Well. He’s dead now.” “That’s not on me,” I said, too fast. “Didn’t say it was.” But it was in the air, with the detergent and the smoke and whatever mold lived in the ceiling tiles. I closed my eyes for a second, saw another message on another screen, another dead man’s name. Different story, same gut punch. “What do you actually have?” I asked. Cass reached inside his jacket. For a moment my muscles tightened, old instinct that never made sense in this city where guns were rare and paperwork was lethal. He pulled out a dog-eared folder instead and dropped it on top of my own sad pile. It wasn’t much. A printout of the article about Luka’s death—stock photo of police tape, lines about “suspected narcotics.” A flyer for HALDEN ROWE FOR COUNCIL in glossy blue, corner circled in red. A screenshot of a text thread where Luka bragged to someone about “real shit on Rowe’s guys.” A rent receipt—three months paid in cash the week before he died. “And?” I asked. “And that’s not a kid on tips and part-time shifts,” Cass said, tapping the receipt. “That’s someone with sudden friends. Or sudden leverage.” “You his accountant now?” “You know how people like Rowe clean up,” Cass said. His voice had gone flat. “Bad optics disappear. Nuisances OD.” I flipped the flyer over. Someone had scrawled an address on the back, then crossed it out. Luka’s handwriting, maybe. I didn’t know him well enough to be sure. That stung. “What’s your angle?” I said. “You suddenly doing pro bono justice work?” He smirked, but it didn’t reach his eyes. “Maybe I liked the kid. Maybe I pointed him at the wrong people. Maybe I don’t want that on my conscience.” “You have a conscience now?” “Upgrades all the time.” He leaned forward, palms on my desk. His knuckles were scarred, one fresh bruise blooming. “Look, Jace. You dig. You ask questions. People talk to you. I’m asking you to look at this and tell me if it smells wrong.” “It all smells wrong,” I said. “That’s your cologne.” He huffed a laugh. “Take the damn case.” I should’ve said no. Too messy. Too familiar. Too late. I should’ve pointed him at some activist lawyer with better funding and less baggage. Instead I looked at the rent receipt again. Luka, who’d been forever bumming smokes, suddenly three months ahead. Luka texting me for help I hadn’t given. The neat period at the end of the sentence: found dead. Case closed. “How much are you paying?” I asked. Cass’s smile flickered. “You’ll take money from me?” “I’ll wash it first.” He slid an envelope across. It wasn’t thick, but it was more than my last three adultery jobs combined. I didn’t ask where it came from. From him, it was all the same. “This everything?” I asked. “For now.” He straightened up, rolled his shoulders like the conversation had weighed more than the cash. “I’ll find you if I remember anything else.” “That’s not a comfort.” He was already at the door. Paused, half-turned. “You check your messages from now on, yeah?” he said. “Kids like Luka, they think people like you are bulletproof.” “People like me are underinsured,” I said. He gave me that almost-smile. “Don’t make me regret thinking you might do the right thing.” “You always regret thinking,” I said, but he was gone. The hallway sensor clicked, light buzzing on, then off again. Rain chewed at the window. I stared at the envelope, at Luka’s name on the newsprint, at the unread text glowing on my phone. I didn’t open the envelope. I opened a new page in my notebook, wrote the date, wrote LUKA RIVERA in block letters. Underlined it twice. I’d already let one man die for a story. I picked up the phone, thumb hovering over Iris Navarro’s number, and told myself this was different.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates strong craft in establishing the noir atmosphere and character dynamics. The opening line delivers exactly what was promised in the prompt, and the writing maintains a consistent voice throughout that feels authentically hardboiled while avoiding pastiche. The characterization is particularly effective. Jace emerges as a fully realized protagonist - bitter, observant, carrying guilt from his past as a journalist whose source died. His voice combines dry wit with genuine pain, and his responses to Cass feel psychologically authentic. Cass is well-rendered as charming but damaged, someone who deflects serious topics with humor while clearly harboring his own guilt about Luka's death. The dialogue crackles with subtext and history. Lines like "You're letting the heat out" and "Upgrades all the time" reveal character efficiently while maintaining naturalistic speech patterns. The banter between Jace and Cass establishes their complicated relationship - attraction mixed with wariness, shared history of poor decisions. The plot mechanics work smoothly. The discovery of Luka's unread message provides genuine emotional impact and serves as an effective hook, making Jace's decision to take the case feel earned rather than perfunctory. The evidence Cass presents (rent receipt, campaign flyer, text screenshots) feels appropriately fragmentary for an opening chapter. The atmospheric details serve the narrative well - the detergent smell from the laundromat, the failing sensor light, the rain against windows. These ground the story in a specific place without becoming purple or overwrought. However, the setup treads familiar noir territory. While the queer angle and specific details provide freshness, the basic premise of the damaged PI reluctantly taking a case from a morally compromised ex-lover is well-worn ground. The writing is skillful enough to make this work, but doesn't transcend genre expectations. The prose occasionally leans slightly heavy on atmosphere, though it generally avoids purple excess. The metaphors feel mostly earned, particularly the central "cigarette smoke and bad ideas" concept that permeates the characterization.
