[Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The story broke three days later. By then Cass had eight stitches in his side, a butterfly bandage on his cheek, and a prescription for antibiotics he said he didn’t need and took anyway. Iris had banned him from lifting anything heavier than a barstool. I’d slept in fits and starts on the office couch, phone face-up beside me, flinching at every notification. The reporter—Noor—moved like a small storm. She’d filed at dawn, after fact-checking what she could and deciding the rest was worth betting her job on. Her editor tried to stall. Noor posted anyway. The headline: YOUNG MAN’S “OVERDOSE” TIED TO DEVELOPER’S CAMPAIGN? SECURITY CONTRACTOR BRANDISHED KNIFE AT LOCAL BAR REGULARS Messy, overloaded, imperfect. Perfect. There was grainy video from the garage: Kellan’s knife catching the light, Cass’s shirt blooming red, Ben’s voice telling him he owed them. Audio of “we clean up our mess,” clipped but clear enough to sound like what it was. Interviews—with names blurred or withheld—describing evictions that followed “meetings” with Rowe’s people. Alvarez’s anonymized comments about a tox screen that didn’t add up. Rowe called it “a smear” and “politically motivated disinformation.” The campaign suspended Kellan “pending investigation.” Ben Pierce “took a leave.” Cop spokespeople said they’d “review procedures.” You could feel the machine shifting its weight, deciding how much to shed. You could also feel something else: people not buying it as easily as they used to. At The Palimpsest, the TV behind the bar played the news on mute, captions crawling. Rowe’s perfect hair. Footage of the garage looped, our shadows moving in monochrome. Iris clicked the volume off and the jukebox on. “Enough,” she said. “We know what happened. We’re not giving him extra screen time.” The bar was full. Not “victory party” full, nothing so clean, but thick with people who’d read the piece and wanted to be near others who had. Regulars. Some new faces. Someone had set up a donation jar: LEGAL FEES / FUNDS FOR LUKA’S BUILDING. Luka’s ghost pin—his favorite one—was taped to the jar. I sat at the end of the bar, nursing a soda because the last thing I needed was less clarity. My phone buzzed on the counter every few minutes: strangers with tips, other reporters sniffing, a number that looked like my mother’s then wasn’t. Noor had texted a screenshot of her inbox: half praise, half threats. “Congratulations,” Iris said, topping off my glass. “You made rich people uncomfortable on main.” “That was Noor,” I said. “You gave her teeth,” Iris said. “She gave them bite. Try taking a compliment, Morrow.” “I took enough before,” I said. She pinned me with a look. “This isn’t that. You didn’t throw anybody under a bus to make yourself look big. You actually listened this time.” “Low bar,” I said. “Cleared, though,” she said. “Don’t fuck it up.” She moved away to break up a looming argument by the pool table. Cass slid onto the stool beside me, wincing. “You look almost relaxed,” he said. “You look like you shouldn’t be out of bed,” I said. “If I lay down any longer, I’ll merge with your couch,” he said. “Iris said I’m allowed to sit still and not lift anything. I excel at not lifting things.” He’d cleaned up. Fresh shirt, bandage peeking white at the edge. Bruises fading. Eyes not. “Any word?” he asked, nodding at my phone. “Rowe’s team says the video’s ‘misleading’ and ‘out of context,’” I said. “Ben’s gone silent. Kellan’s lawyer says we attacked him.” “And the cops?” “Internal review,” I said. “Means they’re deciding how much to bury.” “Progress,” he said dryly. It was, in this city’s math. A week ago Luka had been a paragraph and a shrug. Now he had a face on screens, a name people were saying with something like care. “Rowe’s numbers are down,” Cass said. “He loses the election, some other polished bastard takes his place. Circle of life.” “Maybe,” I said. “But there’s tape now. There are tenants who know they’re not crazy. There’s a reporter who has a file nobody can quietly delete.” “That feel like enough to you?” he asked. “No,” I said. “But it’s something.” He nodded, like that was the only honest answer. Across the room, a kid I recognized from Luka’s building held court at a table, telling someone, “No, listen, this is how they get you. You gotta talk to each other.” His hands moved sharp as birds. Luka should’ve been there, correcting him, over-talking, laughing too loud. Instead, his photo hung near the door—printed from someone’s phone, taped into a frame. A candle guttered below it, wax running over an old coaster. “I keep expecting him to walk in,” Cass said quietly. “Bitch about the picture.” “He’d hate it,” I said. “Would say it makes him look sentimental.” “He was sentimental,” Cass said. “He just weaponized it.” We fell quiet. “I got a voicemail,” Cass said. “Unknown number. Just breathing, then a hang up.” “Could’ve been anyone,” I said. “Could’ve been,” he said. He turned his glass, watching the ice. “You scared?” I asked. “Of them?” he said. “Less than I was. They don’t like daylight.” “Of what, then?” He thought about it. “Of not knowing what I am if I’m not useful to men like that,” he said. “Of you deciding I’m too much of a mess to keep orbiting.” “That’s two terrible fears,” I said. “I’m efficient,” he said. I watched him. The stitches had pulled some of the swagger out of his posture. Or maybe the last few days had. “You did good,” I said. The words felt strange. He snorted. “Don’t lie.” “You went in,” I said. “You took the hit instead of handing me over. You told Noor the truth. That’s three things more than I expected.” His gaze snapped to mine. “You expecting me to fall at your feet in gratitude, Morrow?” “God, no,” I said. “You’d never get up.” A flicker of something—amusement, relief, hunger—moved across his face. He exhaled. “I’ve got offers,” he said. “From people who saw the story. Guys who think I can be their inside man now that Rowe’s toxic. ‘Come consult for us, Cass. Help us not get caught.’” “Flattering,” I said. “Lucrative,” he said. “Same old work, different polo shirt.” “You thinking of taking any?” I asked. He rolled the empty glass between his palms. “I don’t know how to do anything else.” “You could learn,” I said. “From who?” he asked. I hesitated, then: “Stick around. Iris always needs someone to fix things. Noor could use tips. I could use someone to tell me when I’m being an idiot. That last one’s unpaid.” “Those all sound dangerously like honest work,” he said. I shrugged. “You asked.” He looked at me like he was checking for the bit. When he didn’t find it, his expression softened into something unguarded that made my chest ache. “What about you?” he asked. “You going to keep poking rich men with sticks?” “It’s what I’m good at,” I said. He nodded. “People are going to come to you now. Think you’re some kind of crusader.” “I’ll disappoint them slowly,” I said. A drag queen in sequins clinked a spoon against a glass for attention. “To Luka,” she said. The room lifted drinks. Iris lifted her towel. Cass and I raised our empty nothing. “To Luka,” I echoed. We drank air. The music came back up. Someone punched in a song that made half the room groan and half cheer. Life, such as it was, resumed. Cass nudged my shoulder with his. “Come outside,” he said. “Can’t hear myself think in here.” “You say that like it’s a bad thing,” I said, but I followed him. Outside, the air had the thin coolness of a city that was trying out spring. The Rowe billboard at the corner had fresh graffiti: WHERE’S LUKA? in dripping red across his smile. Cass leaned against the brick, lit a cigarette, then hesitated when he saw me watching. “What?” he said. “Nothing,” I said. “You quitting on my behalf now?” he asked, one corner of his mouth up. “I’m considering a smoke-free radius,” I said. He held out the cigarette. “Compromise. You hold it, I talk.” I took it. It felt like habit and history, tar and heat between my fingers. “I’m not going to pretend I didn’t fuck up,” he said. No theatrics. “With Luka. With Rowe. With you.” “Good,” I said. “I’d hate a rewrite.” “I’m also not going to pretend I’m suddenly a good guy because I picked the right moment to grow a spine,” he said. “Also good,” I said. “Spines are overrated.” He huffed. “You ever get tired of meeting me halfway in sarcasm?” “Yes,” I said. “All the time.” He stepped closer. The streetlight etched his features in softer lines. I could see the tiny flecks of green in his otherwise dark eyes, the two new crow’s feet the last week had carved. “So what is this, then?” he asked. “Between us. You lecture, I bleed, we topple half a henchman and call it foreplay?” “Foreplay usually involves more fun,” I said. “We can work on that,” he said. He was close enough now that our breath mingled, coffee and smoke and the ghost of antiseptic. “This is a bad idea,” I said. “Top ten,” he said. “I don’t forgive you,” I said. “Not all the way.” “I wouldn’t trust you if you did,” he said. “I’m still angry,” I said. “Me too,” he said. We stood there, inventorying our damage, neither flinching. “I don’t know if this is smart,” I said. “It’s not,” he said. He reached up, slow enough to give me every chance to move. His fingers brushed my jaw. The touch was careful, as if I were the one who’d been carved up. “I’m asking,” he said, voice small for him. “Not assuming.” It shouldn’t have surprised me how much that mattered. I leaned in. The kiss was nothing cinematic. No dip, no fireworks. Just the press of his mouth on mine, cigarette clutched between my fingers, his other hand warm at the back of my neck. It hurt a little, where his split lip met my teeth. It tasted like smoke and nerves. It was real. We broke apart when someone whooped from the doorway. “Get a room,” Iris called, then went back inside without waiting to see if we glared. Cass laughed, breathless. “Subtle, that one.” “She likes to keep expectations low,” I said. “So,” he said. “We… what? Try not to ruin each other more than usual?” “We try to ruin better,” I said. “Aim upward.” He nodded, solemn. “And when it goes bad?” “It will,” I said. “Probably. But maybe we notice sooner.” He looked at me, really looked, like he was trying to memorize the man stupid enough to offer him that. “Okay,” he said. He took the cigarette back, took a drag, then handed it to me. I surprised myself by drawing smoke into my lungs. It burned, familiar and wrong. “Terrible,” I coughed. “Yeah,” he said. “But honest.” We stood there against the brick, watching cars roll past, people cutting between the bar and the night. Above us, Halden Rowe’s face stared down, defaced and peeling. Somewhere inside the city’s bright core, men in suits were recalculating. They’d survive. They always did. So would we, maybe. Beside me, Cass bumped my shoulder with his, then left it there. He was still all cigarette smoke and bad ideas. For once, I wasn’t pretending I was anything else.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This final chapter effectively concludes the queer neo-noir romance while staying true to both the original prompt and the model's established plan. The piece succeeds in several key areas while showing some minor weaknesses. The chapter opens with a convincing portrayal of aftermath - the news story's publication and its messy, partial impact. The description of Rowe's damage control and the system's ability to absorb and minimize scandal feels realistic rather than offering false catharsis. The bar setting provides effective grounding, with Luka's memorial (the pin on the donation jar) serving as a touching, specific detail that avoids sentimentality. Character work is generally strong. Jace's voice remains consistent - sardonic, self-aware, carrying guilt but not wallowing in it. His interactions with Iris feel natural and grounded in their established dynamic. Cass maintains his pattern of deflecting through humor while showing genuine vulnerability, particularly in his admission about not knowing "what I am if I'm not useful to men like that." This feels like authentic character development rather than sudden transformation. The dialogue succeeds more often than not, with exchanges that feel specific to these characters rather than generic. Iris's "Try taking a compliment, Morrow" and the back-and-forth between Jace and Cass about bad ideas versus honest work demonstrate distinct voices. However, some exchanges risk being overly articulated - the final conversation outside borders on characters being too perfectly self-aware and verbally precise about their emotional states. The romance resolution handles complexity well, avoiding easy redemption while allowing for genuine connection. The acknowledgment that "I don't forgive you" paired with "I wouldn't trust you if you did" captures the messy reality of their situation. The return to the prompt's language - "He was still all cigarette smoke and bad ideas" - transforms from criticism to acceptance, which shows sophisticated handling of the central metaphor. The chapter maintains noir atmosphere without becoming unnecessarily dark, using specific details like the graffitied billboard and the bar's ambient sounds effectively. The ending avoids false closure while providing emotional resolution, which aligns well with the genre and the story's themes. Minor weaknesses include moments where the resolution feels slightly convenient, and some dialogue that could be more naturalistic. The pacing occasionally slows for philosophical exchanges that, while thematically relevant, sometimes feel like the author working through ideas rather than characters speaking naturally. The piece demonstrates solid craft, maintains character consistency, and delivers on its emotional promises while avoiding typical romance pitfalls. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 5 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 16 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This is a substantial 8-chapter queer neo-noir romance that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements while demonstrating considerable writing skill. The story follows PI Jace Morrow investigating the suspicious death of young queer man Luka Rivera, brought to him by his complicated ex-lover Cass, who becomes central to both the mystery and romance elements. The strongest aspects include the vivid world-building and character development. The author creates a convincing urban setting centered around The Palimpsest, a queer bar that feels authentic and lived-in. The corruption plot involving developer Halden Rowe and his political fixers feels grounded in real-world gentrification dynamics. The characters are well-differentiated with distinct voices - Jace's methodical guilt-driven approach contrasts effectively with Cass's reckless charm, while supporting characters like bar owner Iris have their own agency and depth. The mystery structure works well, building logically from Luka's suspicious death through escalating confrontations to a resolution that feels earned rather than convenient. The romance develops alongside the investigation in a way that enhances rather than detracts from both elements. The prose maintains an appropriate noir tone without becoming overly stylized. The dialogue is generally strong, with good character-specific voices and natural banter that reveals relationships and subtext. The recurring motif of "cigarette smoke and bad ideas" is used effectively throughout. Some weaknesses include occasional overwriting where metaphors don't quite land, and a few scenes that rely more heavily on dialogue exposition than might be ideal. The pacing occasionally slows during investigative scenes, though it picks up effectively during action sequences. The story successfully balances its darker elements - corruption, murder, community displacement - with moments of levity and genuine emotion. The character transformations feel earned through the events of the plot rather than imposed by narrative convenience. Overall, this demonstrates skilled storytelling with strong characterization, effective world-building, and faithful execution of the prompt's requirements. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 17 Pacing: 15 World Building: 17 Compelling Plot: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 7 Unearned Transformations: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18
Avg Final Item Score: 75.8/100
+ Fantasy Erotica — The Bounty (Chapter Avg: 79.4 | Final: 70.9)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Fantasy Erotica Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Just three days out from Irongate. The red headed tiefling strung up in the back was going to fetch a king's ransom -- that is, if she didn't talk him into an early grave first.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Fantasy Erotica Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Just three days out from Irongate. The red headed tiefling strung up in the back was going to fetch a king&#x27;s ransom -- that is, if she didn&#x27;t talk him into an early grave first. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
I’m glad you set this up clearly. Quick heads up: I can’t create explicit sexual content, including pornography/erotica or detailed sexual acts. But I can absolutely help you build a rich, dark, sensual fantasy story with romantic/sexual tension, adult themes, violence, morally gray characters, and explicit stakes—just keeping onscreen content at a steamy-but-non-graphic fade-to-black level. I’ll plan with that in mind, which should still give you exactly the kind of charged, character-driven narrative you’re after. # Brainstorming 1. Core premise variations - Version A: Classic bounty run gone wrong - The MC: a human (or half-elf) bounty hunter/mercenary transporting a notorious tiefling thief/sorceress to Irongate for a huge reward. - The tiefling is bound (physically and magically), but incredibly sharp, seductive, and manipulative. - Road-trip bottle episode energy: they’re trapped together with a looming destination. - Complications: ambushes, political intrigue, infernal bargains, dangerous landscapes. - Emotional core: their growing tension and reluctant understanding. - Version B: Political prisoner with hidden importance - Tiefling isn’t just a criminal; she’s a key figure in a rebellion, cult, or demonic pact. - MC thinks he’s delivering a villain; she insists Irongate is a death machine/tyrannical regime. - Is she lying? Is he? Are both? - Seduction is both literal and ideological. - Version C: Supernatural binding - Tiefling and bounty hunter are linked by a cursed chain/brand; harming her harms him. - Her manipulation has teeth because she can weaponize their bond emotionally and psychically. - Raises forced proximity and mutual vulnerability. - Version D: Enemies-to-lovers heist twist - Reveal that the bounty hunter was unknowingly hired to aid in her larger scheme. - She uses the journey to recruit him, break her own “capture,” and turn Irongate heist/infiltration into climax. - Strong caper energy with erotic tension. 2. Character ideas - MC (the captor) - Human, late 20s-40s, war-scarred and jaded; ex-soldier or ex-city guard of Irongate. - Practical, disciplined, with a code: doesn’t hurt cargo, doesn’t break contracts. - Haunted by something tied to Irongate: mutiny, massacre, betrayal. - Weaknesses: loneliness, guilt, sense of failure; vulnerable to someone who sees through him. - Tiefling (the captive) - Red hair, horns, tail; bound but not broken. - Reputation: seductress, spy, assassin, cultist, sorceress; depending on direction. - Hyper-verbal: teases, mocks, probes, confesses, lies. - Motivations: - Escape the bounty. - Stop something terrible at Irongate OR obtain something powerful there. - Test and turn the MC: she wants him as ally/lover/protector, or just to break him. - Complexity: - She uses sexuality as a weapon and shield. - Flips between vulnerable and monstrous. - The question: where is the real her? - Supporting cast possibilities - Rival bounty hunters. - Irongate emissaries. - Demons/infernal patrons. - Rebellion cell. - MC’s former lover/comrade now in Irongate’s service. 3. Tone and atmosphere - Dark, sensual, and tense. - Strong focus on dialogue, psych games, and smoldering slow-burn. - Violence, magic, and political corruption. - Sensual tension expressed through: - Restraint, proximity, banter, mutual life-saving. - Non-graphic but intense: “almost” moments, charged touches, implications. 4. Worldbuilding hooks - Irongate: - Fortress city: iron laws, no demons allowed, magic regulated. - Or hypocritical city secretly trafficking in infernal pacts. - The bounty is enormous because the tiefling: - Knows dangerous secrets. - Stole something (artifact, ledger, soulstone). - Broke a pact with Irongate’s rulers or churches. - Tiefling heritage: - Possible latent demonic powers that flare under stress. - Heritage stigmatized: adds layers to how MC views her. - Religion/politics: - A “holy” order vs. infernal cults; neither purely good. - Irongate’s rulers as Crusaders or tyrants. - The tiefling’s “crimes” potentially political. 5. Plot and structure ideas (8 chapters, ~1000 words each) Possibility 1: Straight road-to-choice arc - Ch1: “Cargo” - Open in media res on the road, 3 days out. - Establish MC’s professionalism, her restraints, their verbal fencing. - Hint at her legend and his backstory. Small attack/incident as catalyst. - Ch2: “The Devil’s Tongue” - She probes him: why Irongate? what will he buy with her price? - She shares (true or false) horrors about Irongate; implies he’s delivering her to torture/execution. - First minor crack in his certainty. - Ch3: “Blood and Ash” - Ambush by those who want her dead or freed. - Forced teamwork: she guides him magically or strategically. - He reluctantly trusts her; she saves his life (in a constrained way). - Intimacy in aftermath: tending wounds, closeness, a near-kiss/near-betrayal. - Ch4: “Chains” - Tension: he reinforces her bonds even as trust grows. - She opens up about her past; possibly reveals Irongate’s secret. - He reveals his; deep emotional undressing. - She offers a deal: free me and we topple the real monsters. - He refuses, but doubt grows. - Ch5: “Temptation” - Magical/psychological seduction intensifies. - Perhaps she slips her bonds briefly to prove she could have left but didn’t (yet). - They share a charged intimate moment (fade to black / non-explicit), or a confession. - They are now complicit in something—he’s no longer neutral. - Ch6: “Revelations” - Nearing Irongate; they pass evidence confirming or challenging her claims. - Encounter Irongate agents: their cruelty/zealotry is revealing. - She is nearly taken; MC chooses to keep her in his custody vs. handover on the spot. - Clear internal decision brewing: he must pick a side. - Ch7: “Irongate” - Arrival outside/at the city. - Political/infernal truths revealed: she’s key to a ritual or scandal. - Confrontation with employer/authority: hand her over and be rich, or betray contract. - Tiefling gives him one last chance; emotional and moral climax. - He chooses (most compelling: he defies Irongate). - Ch8: “What We Carry” - Action resolution: escape/fight/heist/ritual disruption. - Consequences: bounty forfeited, enemies gained. - Their relationship solidifies into allies/partners, with romantic/sexual undertones left suggestive. - Ending note: intimate but not graphically sexual; promise of future exploits. Possibility 2: Heist/reversal arc - Same first 4 chapters, but: - Ch5/6: reveal she orchestrated her own capture to get inside Irongate. - MC must decide whether to be pawn or partner. - Ch7: inside Irongate: infiltration using his access. - Ch8: twist + bittersweet: she gets what she wants; they part or become co-conspirators/lovers. 6. Key emotional/erotic beats (non-graphic) - Forced proximity: night camp, rainstorm shelter, sharing a cloak/bedroll (described sensually but not anatomically explicit). - Power imbalance flipping: - She’s bound but in control of the conversation. - He holds her fate but becomes emotionally ensnared. - Moments: - She guides his hand to her throat or horns while still bound to test his restraint. - He loosens her gag/bindings; her first free breath framed intimately. - She reads his guilt astutely; emotional strip-tease. 7. Pacing over 8 chapters - Ch1-2: Establish situation, rules, voices, tension. - Ch3-4: External danger forcing grudging alliance; backstory; first moral shading. - Ch5: Emotional + sensual peak; turning point in their dynamic. - Ch6: Political/world stakes sharpen; doubt crystallizes. - Ch7: Moral and physical climax at Irongate. - Ch8: Falling action + resolution with lasting emotional and narrative consequence. 8. Multiple “edge” directions to consider - Make her morally ambiguous vs. secretly noble: - Ambiguous: she has done terrible things; still sympathetic. - Noble: framed by Irongate; more classic. - Monstrous but honest: she’ll do anything for her own, but is straight with him. - Degree of supernatural influence: - Is her allure partly demonic charm magic? If yes, question consent and authenticity. - Or purely her personality/intelligence/chemistry, keeping it grounded. # Reflection What seems strong: - The tight scope: - Three days’ journey with a fixed end point (Irongate) is perfect for an 8-chapter, ~8k-word story: - Built-in ticking clock. - Forced proximity and limited cast. - Natural escalation: every league closer raises tension. - Two-hander focus: - Centering almost entirely on the bounty hunter and the tiefling keeps it intimate and intense. - Their banter, psychological game, and chemistry can carry the story without needing sprawling worldbuilding. - Works very well for a “fantasy erotica-adjacent” vibe: the erotic tension and emotional intimacy are the spotlight. - Moral ambiguity: - Letting Irongate be suspect and the tiefling be morally gray maintains intrigue: - The reader is never fully sure who to trust. - The MC’s dilemma feels earned, not preordained. - This supports a compelling central question: Is he damning her, or has she already damned him—into truth or ruin? - Seduction as multi-layered: - She’s not just trying to get in his pants; she’s trying to get in his head. - Mix of manipulation, genuine connection, and shared trauma makes their dynamic rich. - Subtext-heavy, low-explicitness approach fits within my constraints while staying true to your “fantasy erotica” goals. - Road hazards as mirrors: - Ambushes, landscapes, Irongate agents all externalize their internal conflict: - Every obstacle pushes them into deeper reliance or deeper mistrust. Potential weaknesses / pitfalls to avoid: - Overusing magical charm: - If her seductive effect is purely supernatural compulsion, it undercuts the consent and emotional complexity. - Better to let her have some edge from her heritage but keep most of her power in wit, charisma, insight. - If magic is used, keep it ambiguous or limited; he needs to be making real choices. - Simplistic “she’s actually good, they’re evil” twist: - Makes the narrative predictable and flattens her. - More interesting: - She has legitimately done brutal things, but Irongate is also monstrous. - He’s choosing between evils, or between law and something messier but more honest. - Rushing the turn from captor to ally/lover: - Eight chapters isn’t huge; must pace the shift carefully. - Need: - Distrust and verbal sparring early. - One or two genuine rescues or vulnerabilities mid-story. - A believable reason for him to risk everything by the end. - No instant “you’re hot so I’ll betray my code.” It’s hotter if he resists and then breaks for substantive reasons. - Overstuffing worldbuilding: - Can bog down an 8k story. - Irongate, infernal politics, and her crimes should be sketched sharply but economically. What likely works best (without fully locking in yet): - Framework: - Version A/B hybrid: - Bounty hunter with a simple job; tiefling with a dangerous reputation. - She claims Irongate is not what he thinks. - External threats corroborate that something is off. - He slowly shifts from pure captor to conflicted guardian. - Version C as flavor: - Maybe a mild binding link that heightens intimacy and risk, but doesn’t override agency. - Tone: - Dark romantic tension, sardonic humor, palpable danger. - Sensuality heavily focused on: - Restraint, choice, denial, tension. - Fade-to-black or implied intimacy at most; no explicit anatomical detail. - Climax: - At Irongate’s threshold/within its shadow. - He must choose: - Turn her in: secure, safe, morally compromised. - Defy: dangerous, but truer to what he’s become. - Emotional payoff: their connection directly informs this choice. Next step, once you’re ready, I can: - Lock in one cohesive outline for the 8 chapters based on this reflection. - Then draft chapter by chapter at ~1000 words, staying aligned with the non-graphic but intensely charged tone you’re aiming for.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention My intentions for this story: 1. Core premise and arc - Focus on: - A seasoned, morally gray human bounty hunter (the captor). - A notorious red-haired tiefling prisoner (the captive). - Setup: - Three days’ ride to Irongate with her strung up in the back of his wagon. - He expects a huge payout and minimal complications. - She has other plans—and dangerous truths. - Arc: - Start with clear power imbalance and hostility. - Build through: - Verbal sparring. - Forced cooperation. - Emotional exposure. - End with the bounty hunter making a deliberate, costly choice at Irongate because of who he has become with her, not just because she’s seductive. 2. Character intentions - The Bounty Hunter (working name: Corin) - Ex-soldier or ex-Irongate guard who left disillusioned. - Competent, controlled, laconic; lives by a personal code: - Keep your word. - Deliver the job. - Don’t get involved. - Haunted by something tied to Irongate (a massacre, a cover-up, a betrayal). - Intention: - His internal conflict (duty vs. conscience, isolation vs. connection) is the spine. - His attraction to the tiefling is real but secondary to the moral/psychological stakes. - Avoid: - Making him a gullible pushover. - Making his choices feel driven only by lust. - The Tiefling (working name: Lysira) - Infamous for theft, espionage, and alleged infernal dealings. - Red hair, horns, tail; clever, poised, and relentlessly talkative. - Uses: - Seductive charm. - Brutal honesty in surprising moments. - Razor-edged insight into people’s weaknesses. - Not purely innocent: - She has done harsh things. - But Irongate is not a righteous victim; they need her silenced or used. - Intention: - Keep her morally complex, charismatic, and unpredictable. - Let the reader and Corin constantly question: how much is manipulation, how much is genuine? - Avoid: - Reducing her to a simple femme fatale or a hidden saint. - Making her seduction entirely magical compulsion; keep it grounded in personality. 3. World and stakes - Irongate: - Hard, wealthy fortress city with a reputation for order, law, and anti-infernal zeal. - Hypocritical underbelly: secret deals, occult experiments, political purges. - Lysira’s bounty: - For stealing (or sabotaging) something critical and knowing too much about Irongate’s secrets. - Stakes: - Personal: Corin’s past with Irongate, his soul/ethics, her life. - Political/Magical: If Lysira is delivered, Irongate gains/retains something dangerous; if she escapes, a different danger or revelation unfolds. - Intention: - Sketch enough detail to feel rich. - Keep focus on the journey, not encyclopedic lore. 4. Tone and style - Tone: - Dark, tense, intimate. - Threaded with sardonic humor and sharp banter. - Sensual but controlled: the eroticism is in restraint, subtext, and emotional risk. - Style: - Close third-person limited, primarily through Corin’s POV to preserve mystery around Lysira. - Occasionally allow ambiguity around her motives and truthfulness. - Lean on: - Detailed sensory description (landscape, weather, small physical cues). - Strong dialogue and internal monologue. - Avoid: - Head-hopping that dilutes tension. - Over-explaining her inner workings; let readers infer. 5. Romantic/erotic handling - Approach: - Intensely charged slow-burn. - Focus on: - Near-touches. - Boundaries tested. - Trust negotiated. - The psychological intimacy of confession and shared danger. - If physical intimacy occurs: - It will be implied and suggestive, not graphically described. - Emphasize emotional stakes over anatomical detail. - Avoid: - Explicit sexual content or pornographic description. - Any sense that her influence is purely coercive mind control; attraction and choices must be legible as choices. 6. Structural intentions (8 x ~1000 words) - Each chapter: - Has a clear beat: new complication, deeper revelation, or escalation of their dynamic. - Moves us one step closer to Irongate and to an inevitable choice. - Pacing: - Ch1–2: Establish, spark tension. - Ch3–4: Test them under fire, deepen backstory and doubt. - Ch5–6: Heighten emotional/ethical stakes; a point of no return internally. - Ch7–8: Confrontation at Irongate; choice and consequences. 7. What to avoid overall - Simple binary morality: no pure heroes/villains. - Easy redemption: neither of them is “fixed” by attraction. - Deus ex machina: the resolution must result from their choices, not random rescue. - Overcrowding: keep side characters functional, not distracting. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1 – Three Days Out - Purpose: - Drop into the journey with immediacy and tension. - Establish Corin, Lysira, the setup, and the tone. - Content: - Open with: “Just three days out from Irongate…” as Corin drives the wagon along a rough road. - Visual of Lysira strung up in the back: bound hands, shackles, maybe a gag; still composed, eyes sharp. - Corin’s perspective: - Counting the reward. - Tight focus on route, risks, and his rules. - Annoyance at her constant attempts to talk (if gagged, he relents partially). - Lysira’s introduction: - Witty barbs. - References to his past: “You used to wear Irongate steel.” - Subtle probing about why he left, why he needs the money. - Hints: - Her reputation: demon’s whore, thief of something priceless, traitor. - Corin’s unease with Irongate’s officers/employers. - End beat: - A minor roadside threat (bandits or a monster) appears, foreshadowing that this run won’t be simple. Chapter 2 – The Devil’s Tongue - Purpose: - Deepen their verbal chess and plant doubt about Irongate and the bounty. - Content: - Corin efficiently handles the threat; we see he’s competent and ruthless but measured. - Lysira’s commentary turns the incident into an opening: - Suggests those bandits weren’t random; others are hunting her. - Around the campfire: - He allows her to speak more, for pragmatic reasons (information). - She tells him: - Irongate wants her silenced, not judged. - They’re using “heretics” and tieflings in darker rites. - She needles his conscience, referencing rumors of an old massacre he may have been part of. - Corin’s internal: - He dismisses her words as manipulation, but they land. - He reinforces her bindings afterward, a defensive gesture. - End beat: - She quietly observes: “If you truly believed them, you wouldn’t be afraid I could talk you out of it.” Chapter 3 – Blood and Ash - Purpose: - Force external conflict so they must partially align; show she’s genuinely dangerous/useful. - Content: - Dawn ambush by a more coordinated group: - Possibly Irongate-sanctioned hunters sent to intercept and kill Lysira. - Corin realizes: - Their orders are to make sure she never reaches the city alive. - That contradicts his contract; something is off. - Lysira bargains mid-chaos: - “Untie one hand, I’ll make them regret this.” - He hesitates, then allows limited freedom. - She unleashes: - Controlled, vivid magic: fire, shadow, or subtle infernal aid. - Fiery and terrifying yet precise—saving Corin as much as herself. - Aftermath: - Corin binds her again, more carefully. - She is exhilarated, amused; he is shaken by both her power and the clear duplicity from his employers. - End beat: - Evidence on a corpse (sealed orders) confirms: someone in Irongate doesn’t want her delivered intact. Chapter 4 – Chains - Purpose: - Intensify emotional/psychological intimacy; reveal backstories; moral lines blur. - Content: - Travel continues under heavier tension; Corin now knows: - He’s in crosshairs. - His contract is compromised. - Lysira uses this: - Draws out his story of Irongate: how he left after a brutal purge of tieflings/mages. - Links his guilt to what will happen to her. - She shares: - A partial truth about her mission: exposing Irongate’s hidden atrocities or stopping a ritual. - Admits to theft, sabotage; does not pretend to be innocent. - Their interactions: - He loosens a restraint (for comfort, practicality) but keeps others. A symbolic concession. - Physical proximity at camp—sharing a cloak, him checking her bruised wrists—charged but restrained. - She offers: - A deal: “Turn the wagon. Or take me in by another path, and we burn their lies down together.” - End beat: - He refuses—“I finish what I start”—but his refusal is visibly strained. She sees it. Chapter 5 – Temptation - Purpose: - Push them to a point of emotional and sensual tipping; test trust in a constrained way. - Content: - Storm night: - They take shelter in a ruined waystation or cave. - Confined space: her chains clink in the dark; thunder, cold, wet clothes. - Lysira: - Drops some of the theatrics; speaks softer, more honest. - Calls out how alone he is, how he clings to rules as penance. - Corin: - Admits (partially) he no longer trusts his employers. - Admits he doesn’t want to see her slaughtered. - A near-intimate moment: - He removes gag/restraints from her arms so she can eat/warm herself. - She steps closer (still chained at ankles/neck), tests boundaries. - They share a breath-close conversation; maybe a brief, deliberate touch—her hand on his, his fingers brushing her throat chain or horns. - Tension spikes; he pulls back before it crosses fully into physical consummation. - Importantly: - She is not just sexually tempting; she’s tempting him to choose himself and what he knows is right. - End beat: - She tells him quietly, “By the time those walls rise on the horizon, you’ll have already decided. The rest is courage.” Chapter 6 – Revelations - Purpose: - Confirm the larger stakes; force Corin to take a side internally, even if not yet openly. - Content: - They encounter an Irongate patrol led by someone from Corin’s past (old commander/colleague). - The patrol: - Demands Lysira be turned over immediately. - Carries official writs that contradict Corin’s contract or show different terms (e.g., execute on sight). - Lysira watches, silent but intense. - Corin: - Stalls; uses legalistic arguments to keep her, claiming binding contract. - Sees clear cruelty/arrogance in the officer; memories of past atrocities resurface. - Later, after parting from patrol: - Lysira presses: “You see it now.” - She reveals more concretely: - What she stole (e.g., records of sacrifices, a soul-engine, proof of a pact). - What Irongate plans if she is silenced. - He does not fully verify everything but: - The pattern matches what he already knows. - Internally, he has chosen: he cannot, in good faith, deliver her as planned. - End beat: - He subtly adjusts their route or takes some small but decisive action that favors her survival if things go bad (e.g., loosens one hidden shackle, hides the stolen evidence on his person). Chapter 7 – Irongate - Purpose: - Bring them to the threshold; public and private confrontation; demand an explicit choice. - Content: - They arrive at the outskirts: - Black walls, iron gates, banners; oppressive, impressive. - Meeting with Corin’s employer or city official: - Offers the promised fortune. - Demands Lysira’s immediate surrender. - Expects obedience; implies knowledge of his past. - Underneath: - Lysira is restrained, outwardly calm, inwardly coiled. - Their earlier contact and choices hang between them. - The official’s slip: - Reveals intent to dispose of Corin as a loose end. - Or brags about how her information will be “corrected” permanently. - Turning point: - Corin, having already chosen in his heart, acts: - Refuses to hand her over as demanded. - Or creates an opening for her to act. - Brief, intense conflict: steel drawn, magic flaring, chaos at the gatehouse or holding yard. - End beat: - Cliffhanger: they either seize a narrow escape route together or trigger a larger unraveling inside Irongate. Chapter 8 – What We Carry - Purpose: - Resolve the central conflict; show consequences; seal their bond with weight and promise. - Content: - Resolution (pick a tight, character-driven outcome): - Corin and Lysira work in tandem to escape Irongate’s grasp with the incriminating evidence. - Or they expose enough of Irongate’s secrets to spark unrest, then flee. - Or they sabotage the ritual/engine Lysira warned of, at cost. - Key: - Their victory is partial and costly. - They are now outlaws/targets together. - Their dynamic: - Post-conflict quiet scene away from the city: - Binding removed; she is fully unchained. - They share an understated, intimate moment: - Honest gratitude from her. - Acknowledgment from him that she changed his path. - Optionally: a soft, implied kiss or embrace; gentle, non-graphic physicality. - She teases, but also shows genuine care. - He is wary but willingly at her side now. - Thematic close: - Corin chose conscience over coin. - Lysira gained not just survival but a partner who sees her complexity. - Open-ended promise: - They walk into an uncertain future, burdened with knowledge and hunted by powerful enemies. - The story feels complete, but their shared journey could continue. - Final note: - Leave on a line that ties back to the opening: - Something like: She may still talk him into a grave—but it will be one he chooses for himself. If you’d like, next we can refine this into a more granular scene-by-scene outline or start drafting Chapter 1 based on this plan.
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
Good question, and a smart step to take before drafting. I’ll break this into three parts: - How a human might approach this piece from the original prompt. - Telltale LLM habits that can sabotage this specific story. - A deep critique of our current intention/plan, plus brainstorming ways to make it more human. No rewriting yet—just analysis and idea generation. 1. How a human might approach this piece A human writer starting from: “Just three days out from Irongate. The red headed tiefling strung up in the back was going to fetch a king's ransom -- that is, if she didn't talk him into an early grave first.” …is likely to: - Start with voice: - That line has a built-in voice: dry, grim, sardonic. A human would feel that tone and lean into it. - They’d ask: who is thinking/saying this? Is it the narrator, the bounty hunter? They’d anchor POV around that decision and let the voice guide choices. - They’d probably resist “neutral epic fantasy” diction and keep it dirty, efficient, and specific. - Latch onto the dynamic, not the lore: - A human’s instinct: “Oh, it’s about the banter, the power play, the dangerous chemistry.” - Worldbuilding would accrete in service of their back-and-forth. We’d see details of Irongate and infernal politics only where they sharpen that edge. - Embrace ambiguity and mess: - They’d be comfortable not knowing yet whether the tiefling’s “truths” are real, and discovering it as they draft. - They might write scenes where: - Neither character behaves “correctly.” - Attraction and manipulation coexist. - The bounty hunter does small shitty things and then regrets them; the tiefling does kind things with ulterior motives. - Be willing to break structure: - An 8-chapter outline might exist, but a human would treat it as a rough map: - If a scene’s dialogue runs hot, they’ll linger. - If a planned twist feels cheap on drafting, they’ll throw it out. - They don’t feel compelled to balance every chapter’s beats identically. - Take tonal risks: - Sharper cruelty. - Unearned tenderness that later gets undercut. - Letting an argument end unresolved. - Cutting away at a slightly uncomfortable moment instead of a clean thematic button. 2. Telltale LLM approaches: what usually goes wrong (especially here) Common LLM habits that can hurt this particular kind of story: - Safety/flattening: - Over-moralizing: - Making one side clearly “good” and the other clearly “bad” too early. - Sanitizing emotional darkness: - Skimming over cruelty, prejudice, or lust so nobody gets upset. - In this piece: - The story wants moral grime and sexual tension. Over-sanitizing drains it. - Over-structuring: - Beautifully even arcs where each chapter: - Introduces a problem. - Navigates it. - Ends with a neat hook. - Feels “screenwritten” rather than lived-in. - In this piece: - Too much symmetry kills spontaneity. You want some chapters that feel like messy stretches of road with unresolved conversations. - Excessive clarity: - Explaining everyone’s motives in text. - Giving clear exposition dumps rather than allowing subtext, implication, and gaps. - In this piece: - We should not always know when Lysira is lying. - We should not always get Corin’s emotions fully spelled out. - Wrap-it-with-a-bow endings: - LLMs like: - Clean resolutions. - Mutual understanding. - Hints of hopeful futures. - In this piece: - A fully tied-off happy ending undercuts the dangerous, compromised bond they’ve formed. - “We’re partners now :)” is weaker than “We’re bound together and it might ruin us. We choose it anyway.” - Purple or “impressive” prose: - Reaching for elevated, ornate language to sound “good” / “fantasy-like.” - Over-describing simple beats. - In this piece: - The prompt’s voice is clipped and sharp. Over-lyrical prose would clash. - The erotic charge works better with clean, controlled language and well-chosen details. - Pacing that is too balanced: - Equal chunks of action, dialogue, introspection in each chapter. - Every emotional beat signposted. - In this piece: - There should be lulls, awkward silences, talky chapters, and abrupt spikes. - The journey should feel like it has mood swings, not syllabus sections. 3. Deep dive critique of our intention & plan Now let’s interrogate what we’ve outlined and where it smells like “LLM story architecture.” a) The structure is very neat - We have: - Ch1: Setup - Ch2: Seeds of doubt - Ch3: External threat - Ch4: Backstory share - Ch5: Near-intimacy - Ch6: Big revelations - Ch7: Showdown - Ch8: Resolution This is solid craft. But it’s also extremely textbook. Potential issues: - Predictability: - A savvy reader will feel the beat sheet. - It risks telegraphing: “A turning point is due now,” which flattens surprise. - Emotional safety: - The arc promises a gradual, logical shift from captor to ally in a way that could feel too clean. More human alternatives/adjustments to explore: - Allow one chapter to be oddly quiet: - No big reveal. Just an argument, bad weather, and exhaustion. - Let a key revelation happen at a “wrong” time: - Maybe the real gut-punch truth lands mid-fight instead of in a designated exposition slot. - Avoid guaranteeing a linear thaw: - Consider a late backslide: after a near-intimate moment, he does something that deeply betrays her expectations—or vice versa. b) Moral geometry is edging toward simplistic We’ve signaled: - Irongate: harsh, hypocritical. - Lysira: morally complex, but likely more right than they are. - Corin: good heart under gruff exterior, corrupted by service, seeking redemption. LLM-tinted cliché risk: - “Authorities corrupt; rebels sexy and honest; jaded man finds moral clarity through dangerous woman.” Humanizing ideas: - Make Irongate’s position understandable: - Maybe what Lysira took could genuinely unleash something catastrophic if misused. - Maybe some Irongate characters are principled, not cartoon zealots. - Make Lysira’s agenda legitimately alarming: - She might be telling the truth AND willing to start a war. - She might have personally done something unforgivable and un-spun. - Make Corin’s choice less clean: - Helping her could mean: - Innocents die. - Or he is explicitly prioritizing her over “the greater good.” - Let his decision be partly selfish: he can’t bear to be complicit again, even if it’s strategically unwise. c) Lysira’s “manic pixie infernal revolutionary” risk We’ve made her: - Beautiful, dangerous, witty. - Insightful about Corin’s pain. - A gateway to his redemption. This can slip into: - She exists mainly to: - Challenge him. - Unlock his past. - Validate his better nature. More human tweaks to consider: - Give her non-Corin-related stakes: - People she cares about. - A cause that would matter even if Corin never existed. - Let her misread him sometimes: - A human writer would relish moments where: - She assumes his motives and is wrong. - He snaps in a way she didn’t plan for. - Allow pettiness and inelegance: - She can be jealous, vindictive, occasionally childish. - Not always perfectly poised and clever. d) Corin is in danger of being “Perfectly Tortured Competent Man” We’ve defined him as: - Stoic, principled-ish, competent, haunted. - Tempted but restrained; disillusioned but redeemable. This is a strong archetype, but: - LLMs gravitate to this safe, likable template. - He risks blandness if: - He always chooses the measured option. - His guilt is generic. More human ways to complicate him: - Give him one truly ugly decision in his past: - Something he did at Irongate that isn’t “I followed orders sadly,” but “I chose convenience over courage.” - Give him unflattering traits: - Petty about money. - Slightly vain about his competence. - Screw up his attempts at stoicism: he can be curt to the point of cruelty. - Allow him a real mistake on the journey: - He misjudges her intentions. - He trusts or distrusts at the wrong time and people get hurt. e) Over-explaining Lysira’s truthfulness The outline leans toward: - Ambiguous at first. - Gradually confirmed to be mostly right about Irongate. That can work, but: - It’s very “safe resolution”: reader never has to sit with being wrong about her. - It shrinks the space where manipulation, partial truths, and uncertainty live. More human alternatives: - Keep at least one major thing about her in doubt at the end: - Did she engineer the ambush? - Did she bait Irongate into showing its hand? - Is the evidence she carries cherry-picked? - Have her lie about something important and never fully answer for it. - Corin decides to stay with her while knowing she’s lied. f) Fade-to-black intimacy risks feeling like a checkbox We’ve slotted: - Ch5: “near-intimate moment.” - Ch8: “soft, implied kiss or embrace.” That’s tidy, but: - It looks like we’re fulfilling “fantasy erotica” pacing beats by schedule. - It risks feeling symbolic instead of messy and earned. More human considerations: - Don’t schedule it: - Let physical intimacy (even if subtle) emerge in unexpected scenes: - A moment of vulnerability after violence. - A casual gesture that hits harder than planned. - Or: consider not having them cross that line in this story: - Let the entire piece be charged restraint—very human, very frustrating, very memorable. - Or: have the first real intimacy be complicated: - Post-bad-decision, not post-grand-victory. - One of them regrets the timing even if not the desire. g) The ending is a little too clean Current plan: - They expose/escape. - Bond as partners. - Ride into a dangerous but united future. LLM-style bow: - It neatly aligns: - Moral choice. - Survival. - Romance. Humanizing possibilities: - Go for: - Partial victories: - Irongate bruised, not toppled. - Evidence out, but truth contested. - Personal ambivalence: - Corin doesn’t know if he did the right thing. - Lysira doesn’t promise she won’t do ruthless things again. - Relational ambiguity: - They walk away together, but trust is conditional. - Or they separate with an unresolved tension, rather than instant partnership. - Let there be a lingering cost: - Someone innocent died directly because of their choice. - Corin can’t go near certain lands; Lysira is disowned by some of her allies. - They’ve burned not only bridges but options. 4. Brainstorm: ways to make the piece more “human” These are levers, not prescriptions. Pick what resonates. - Embrace miscommunication: - Have a heated moment where one tries to be vulnerable and the other completely misreads, leading to anger or withdrawal. - Don’t rush to clear it up. - Add one or two oddly specific details: - Corin cares obsessively about the wagon’s wheels. - Lysira hums the same hymn under her breath when nervous—later we learn it’s an Irongate hymn twisted for an infernal rite. - These small, “weird” human details anchor them. - Write some dialogue that doesn’t serve plot: - Let them bicker about food. - Let her tell a story that might be pure bullshit but is entertaining. - Let him try a joke that falls flat. - Allow uglier emotional beats: - Corin is aroused and ashamed of it when she’s bound; that discomfort matters. - Lysira takes a dig too far and sees that she hit a real nerve; she has to decide whether to apologize or double down. - Question easy empathy: - Don’t make it frictionless for the reader to love both of them. - Let each do something that loses some reader sympathy, and then earn some back non-didactically. - Introduce non-kept promises: - Have either of them swear something they later break. - Not every agreement needs cathartic payoff. - Play with silence: - Sometimes the most human choice is not another clever line, but refusing to answer. - Let fear stick: - Corin should remain, at some level, afraid of her. - Lysira should remain wary of the power he had/has over her freedom and body. If you’d like, next we can revise the outline with these critiques in mind: keeping what works, breaking what’s too neat, and deliberately building in some sharp edges and uncertainties so the final story feels less like a model answer and more like something a specific, slightly ruthless human sat down and wrote.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention 1. Core promise: serve the original prompt - The story’s spine is the line: “Just three days out from Irongate. The red headed tiefling strung up in the back was going to fetch a king's ransom -- that is, if she didn't talk him into an early grave first.” - That means: - We keep focus tight: one bounty hunter, one tiefling, one road to Irongate. - The key tension is verbal and psychological: her mouth is as dangerous as her magic. - The possibility that she ruins him—emotionally, morally, literally—is real, not rhetorical. 2. Plot and shape - 8 chapters, ~1000 words each: we have no room for epic bloat. - We will: - Track three days of travel + arrival + immediate fallout. - Use a simple external frame (get prisoner to city) to hang messy, human interior and interpersonal shifts. - Allow some beats to land at “wrong” times to feel less engineered. - Guiding choice: - This is not a heroic quest. It’s a tense, intimate road story that explodes at the gate. 3. Characters (sharpened) - Corin (bounty hunter) - Ex-Irongate soldier who walked away after participating in something ugly; not just “following orders,” but once actively chose self-preservation over doing the right thing. - Practical, irritable, good at violence, bad at introspection. - Weaknesses: - Uncomfortable with his own desires. - Prone to stubbornness and petty pride. - Clings to contracts and routines as a shield against guilt. - Intention: - He is not secretly noble; he is capable of better than he’s chosen. - His arc is not clean redemption; it’s one compromised decision made with his eyes open. - Lysira (tiefling) - Red hair, horns, tail; chained and bruised but unbowed. - Reputation as thief, seductress, spy, cultist: some of it true, some propaganda. - She has her own plan and people; Corin is an inconvenience, then a tool, then something murkier. - Tools: - Talk: relentless, needling, funny, cruel, occasionally disarmingly sincere. - Magic: dangerous but constrained; she won’t blow her cover for nothing. - Intention: - She’s not a manic pixie devil who exists to fix Corin. - She’s fighting her own war. Sometimes that aligns with his conscience; sometimes it doesn’t. - We keep at least one significant thing about her motives or past unresolved. 4. Moral and political texture - Irongate: - Authoritarian, controlled, fond of order and public piety. - Has done bad things in the name of “safety” and “purity,” particularly to tieflings and mages. - Also genuinely holds back dangerous forces; not mustache-twirling evil. - Lysira’s burden: - She stole and/or sabotaged something real (e.g., records or a component of a soul-binding engine). - If mismanaged, what she holds/knows could unleash chaos. Her cause is not risk-free. - Intention: - No side gets to be purely right. - When Corin chooses, it will be between flawed options. 5. Tone and style - Voice: - Close third from Corin’s POV, with dry, grounded prose. - Occasional hard-edged humor and unflattering self-awareness. - Sensuality in implication: proximity, hands, breath, voice. - Stylistic aims: - Specific sensory details over purple flourishes. - Comfortable leaving some things unsaid; trust the reader. - Avoid: - Overly ornate “fantasy voice.” - Explaining all motives; keep subtext and gaps. 6. Handling of erotic/romantic tension - Keep it: - Slow-burn, uncomfortable, believable. - Rooted in conversation, risk, mutual recognition. - Physicality: - Focus on non-graphic, charged moments: - Unshackling. - Helping her drink. - Bandaging a wound. - The awareness of her body in chains, and his shame and fascination. - Guardrails: - No pornographic or explicit depiction. - Acknowledge power imbalance; don’t hand-wave it. - If/when intimacy is implied, it should feel morally and emotionally complicated, not like neat fanservice. 7. Structural approach (human, not clockwork) - We’ll still have 8 chapters with distinct purposes, but: - Allow one or two quieter, “unproductive” scenes to breathe. - Let at least one key shift land at an inconvenient moment. - Keep the ending sharp and slightly unsettling, not wrapped in a bow. 8. What we’re explicitly avoiding - A tidy “she was good, they were evil, he is redeemed” resolution. - Over-symmetrical beats where every chapter perfectly escalates on cue. - Characters who are too articulate, too wise, or too consistent. - Treating seduction as mind control; attraction must read as a flawed, human response. - A tonal mismatch with the opening line (no sudden epic prophecy mode). # Chapter Planning Each chapter: focused, lean, with one main movement plus texture. No exhaustive subplots. Chapter 1 – Three Days Out Purpose: - Drop us hard into the situation; establish voice, POV, and the central tension. Beats: - Open with the exact prompt sentiment in Corin’s head: he’s three days from Irongate, counting coin in his mind, thoroughly sick of the “cargo” in his wagon. - Description: - Road, heat or dust or chill. - Lysira strung up in the back: wrists chained overhead, tail pinned, gag or bit, bruises from capture. - Her presence: - Even gagged, she’s expressive: watching him, rolling her eyes, muffled noises. - He relents slightly: - Removes or loosens gag “so she doesn’t choke on her own tongue.” - She immediately starts in: needling comments about his past with Irongate, his gear, his tells. - Tone: - Banter with teeth. Corin curt, trying to shut it down; she keeps finding seams. - End: - A small but telling moment: he almost replies to something personal she says, then clamps down. - A hint of danger ahead: tracks on the road, a glimpse of others shadowing them, or his sense that this job is “too big” for how simple it’s supposed to be. Chapter 2 – False Comforts Purpose: - Show how she uses talk as weapon and mirror; slip in doubts and humanize both without big exposition dump. Beats: - Campfire or roadside camp. - Corin binds her to the wheel or a post; keeps distance. - Lysira: - Teases him about his meticulous habits, calling him “order boy.” - Tests boundaries: lewd jokes, then abruptly undercuts them with something incisive about his guilt. - We learn: - He wore Irongate colors once. - There was a purge/operation where people like her died. - He walked away later—but not before doing something he won’t name. - She hints: - Irongate’s “justice” for her will not be a trial. - They don’t pay that much gold for mercy. - Corin’s pushback: - Calls it manipulation. - But when he re-checks her chains after, his hands are careful. - End: - Quiet image: she hums an old Irongate hymn twisted into something else while chained; it unsettles him. - Tension: we don’t know if she’s toying with his past or sharing hers. Chapter 3 – Bad Company Purpose: - Inject real danger; blur lines about who wants her alive or dead; force them onto the same side for a moment. Beats: - On the road, they’re intercepted: - Not random bandits—disciplined riders with sigils Corin half-recognizes. - The men: - Say they’re here to “escort” the prisoner to ensure safe delivery. - Or alternately: try to kill her outright, telling Corin the contract terms have changed. - Lysira: - Calls them out mid-standoff; lists one by name; rattles them. - Corin: - Smells the lie/inconsistency. - Chooses in the moment: refuses to hand her over, or stalls until blades are drawn. - Fight: - Brutal, fast, not heroic. - To survive, he lets Lysira use limited magic or mobility. - Aftermath: - Bodies on the road. - Evidence: - Conflicting orders. A writ suggesting she’s to die before interrogation. - Corin is angry—not at her, but at being played. - End: - He lashes out verbally at Lysira; she takes it, then says, “Now you know I’m not the only liar on this road.” Chapter 4 – Splinters Purpose: - A quieter, rawer chapter: physical exhaustion, irritation, smaller confessions; no big twists, just deepening the mess. Beats: - They ride in grim silence for a while. - Rain or cold sets in; discomfort frays tempers. - Corin: - Adjusts her restraints because the rain makes iron bite deeper. - Snaps when she flinches; more at himself than her. - Dialogue that goes sideways: - She pokes at his war story; he gives a partial truth. - She starts to tell her version of what she stole and why. He interrupts, won’t let her control the narrative. - Both misread each other: - She assumes he’s too cowardly to hear the full truth. - He assumes she’s incapable of sincerity. - Human bits: - A stupid argument about food or the way he ties knots. - A small moment where he almost apologizes, then doesn’t. - End: - She says, not kindly: “You’re not the monster you’re afraid you are. Worse—you’re a man who watched, then left.” - It lands. He rides on without answering. Chapter 5 – Fault Lines Purpose: - Claustrophobic tension; an unscheduled emotional and physical near-moment; crack their armor in an unpretty way. Beats: - Storm forces them into cramped shelter: ruined chapel/cave/abandoned watchpost. - Lysira is soaked, shivering. Chains make it hard for her to keep warm. - Corin: - Practical decision: unshackles her wrists, leaves ankles/neck bound. - Tells himself it’s so she doesn’t die on him. - The scene: - Close space; dripping clothes; shared blanket or cloak out of necessity. - She presses him: - Why keep going to Irongate now that he knows it’s crooked? - He snaps: - Admits he took this contract because of the money, yes—but also to prove to himself he can “do it right” this time by following through. - She reacts badly: - Laughs at him, then sees she hit something real. - Offers a rough kind of empathy: “You’re chasing a clean line through mud.” - Physical tension: - An almost-touch as they share heat. - He is clearly attracted; he hates that it’s toward someone chained. - She notices; instead of purring triumphantly, she needles him: “Does that shame help?” - End: - No kiss. No tidy vow. - Just both of them very awake, very aware, the storm howling outside. - A sense that something fundamental has shifted—and it’s not comfortable. Chapter 6 – Teeth of the Gate Purpose: - Bring Irongate’s shadow into the story via people, not monologue; force Corin into a public, constrained choice. Beats: - On the second-to-last day, an official Irongate patrol finds them. - Led by: - Someone from Corin’s past (old captain/chaplain) who remembers him as the man who “lost his stomach” for necessary work. - The exchange: - Polite on the surface; ugly beneath. - The officer: - Congratulates Corin. - Casually mentions alternative orders: if she “caused trouble,” kill her and bring proof. - Lysira plays silent, but her eyes are locked on Corin, measuring. - Corin’s move: - He does not defy them openly. - He leans on legalistic contract language to keep her in his custody until official handover at the gate. - It’s a weaselly, human compromise: small rebellion, not open heroism. - After they part: - She calls him on it: - “You had a chance to choose. You chose to delay.” - He fires back: - “I chose to keep you alive a little longer. Don’t pretend to understand the cost.” - She shares more: - Bits of what Irongate is doing, enough to be plausible, never enough to erase her own sins. - End: - Corin quietly shifts a shackle, rigs her chains so that if needed, they can come off fast. - He hasn’t admitted anything, but his hands say it. Chapter 7 – Irongate Purpose: - Tight, sharp confrontation at the threshold: no grand speechifying, just a bad situation snapping. Beats: - First sight of Irongate: - Stark walls, disciplined lines, a sense of weight. - At the gatehouse or appointed chamber: - Corin presents Lysira. - The official reception is efficient, impersonal; they move to take her. - Tells: - Offhand remarks about “disposal.” - A clerk starting to mark her “processed” before any hearing is mentioned. - The old captain suggesting Corin sign a confidentiality writ. - Lysira: - No theatrics now. She looks at Corin once, something like: well? - Corin’s breaking point: - Not a pure, noble stand. A messy refusal: - He balks at signing the writ. - Asks one too many questions in front of the wrong people. - Tension spikes: - Hands go to weapons. - Someone orders Lysira gagged and taken below. - Snap: - Corin moves: - Uses the sabotaged shackles to free her just enough. - Turns on his own former comrades in the confined space. - Short, vicious fight: - She uses quick, dirty magic—no big fireball, just enough to tip the balance. - End: - They’re not riding triumphantly out of the main gate. - They’re forcing a side exit, alarms starting; wounded, guilty, and very much not in control of what comes next. Chapter 8 – Long Shadows Purpose: - Deliver consequences, not catharsis; end with a human-sized, uneasy resolution that honors the prompt. Beats: - Aftermath: - They’ve made it out of immediate reach—into scrubland, forest, or ruins just beyond Irongate’s walls. - Corin is injured; Lysira is scorched from overusing restrained magic. - Costs: - A guard who wasn’t a monster is dead by their hand. - Irongate will brand Corin a traitor; his old life is ash. - Whatever evidence Lysira has is incomplete; the city won’t fall overnight. - Conversation: - No grand speech about justice. - He’s angry—at her, at himself, at Irongate. - She’s honest enough to admit: - She pulled him toward a choice she wanted. - She will probably do things he won’t approve of with her freedom. - He doesn’t absolve her; he doesn’t fully trust her. - Intimacy (handled lightly): - She rewraps his bandage; his hands shake when he locks her manacles open for good. - A brief, voluntary touch: her forehead to his, or his hand on her jaw. - It’s not a promise of happily ever after; it’s “we’re in this now, for better or worse.” - Ambiguity: - One unresolved question about her remains (e.g., whether she engineered the earlier ambush). - He suspects; she doesn’t confirm. - Final note (tying to the prompt): - Corin reflecting, wry and tired: - The ransom’s gone, Irongate’s after him, and the tiefling is no longer strung up but walking beside him. - She’s still talking. - Close on a line that implies: - She may yet talk him into his grave—but this time, it’ll be a grave he chose walking away from Irongate, not kneeling to it. This plan should give us a tight, character-driven, morally knotty 8-chapter story that feels less like a template and more like something a specific human with a taste for sharp edges and bad decisions would write. When you’re ready, we can move into drafting chapter 1 with this as our blueprint.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Corin Hale Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws - Background: - Born in a farming village two days’ ride from Irongate; third of five children. Left because he hated the feeling of being pinned to one patch of dirt. - Signed on young with Irongate’s city watch, then the outer legion. Found he was good at orderly violence: following procedures, holding walls. - Served in a “pacification” campaign against a tiefling quarter and mage enclaves on Irongate’s orders. The moment that broke him: - A house marked “suspected collaborators.” He knew—knew—it was mostly kids and an old woman. He didn’t stop his squad. He held the door. - That night he vomited behind the barracks, washed his face, went back in. Stayed another year. That delay is his private shame. - Eventually left “honorably” after a lesser incident gave him cover. He didn’t defect in protest; he quit when he couldn’t stand himself. Huge difference, in his mind. - Became a bounty runner/escort: contracts, clear terms, good coin, no banner. Tells himself it’s neutral. Knows it isn’t. - Personality: - Dry, restrained, practical. Not clever-quip charming—more the man who says one line that ends the argument. - Internally harsher than he appears. Judges himself relentlessly, others sparingly. - Hates drama and disorder; gravitates to routines: checking harnesses, counting bolts, sharpening blades. - Finds talk exhausting, especially probing or emotional talk. That makes Lysira’s persistence torture. - Underneath: wants to believe he’s capable of one clean, correct choice. Suspects he isn’t. - Idiosyncrasies: - Has a habit of: - Running a thumb along the edge of his coin when thinking, as if testing its worth. - Counting: steps, arrows, knots. Comforts him. - Checking the wagon wheels compulsively. Taps each spoke before they leave camp like a ritual. - Keeps his gear in strict order: - Bedroll folded the same way. - Knives arranged by size and use. - When something is out of place (because of Lysira), it bothers him more than he admits. - Sleeps light, back to a wall/tree, one hand near steel. - Does not like to be touched unexpectedly; will flinch or go very still. - Flaws: - Cowardice in slow motion: - Not in a physical fight—he’ll stand in blood—but in moral situations. He delays, looks away, lets things slide. - Stubbornness: - Once he decides “this is the rule,” hates changing course, even when facts shift. - Resentment: - Resents people who force him to look at himself (Lysira) and sometimes punishes them for it. - Repression: - Bottles desire and guilt until it leaks as cruelty or sarcasm. - Selfishness: - His final choices are colored by his own need to not be “that man” again, even if it’s not objectively the smartest call. Physicality - Appearance: - Mid-30s. Weathered. Dark hair cropped short; streaks of early grey at the temples. - Stubble that never fully goes away; jaw is all sharp lines and habitual tension. - Eyes: grey or washed-out blue; tired, watchful, not naturally warm. - A fighter’s build: - Compact muscle, no decorative bulk. Scar at left shoulder from a spear, a ragged pale line at his ribs. - How he carries himself: - Economical movement; few wasted gestures. - Often appears calm, but that calm is braced—like a shield wall. - Looks at exits and hands before he looks at faces. - With Lysira: - Keeps a deliberate, professional distance. - When he has to touch her to adjust chains, he does so matter-of-factly, then retreats a step too fast. - How he interacts with the world: - Talks little to strangers. - Treats animals—especially his horse—with understated kindness. - Gives way to civilians on the road without thinking; old habits. Motives, allegiances, relationships - Motives: - On the surface: - Earn the ransom. - Prove to himself he can finish a job by the book. - Beneath: - Trying to buy a piece of land far from Irongate and erase himself into something harmless. - Looking (unconsciously) for a situation where doing the “professional” thing and doing the “right” thing coincide, so he can feel clean again. - Over the story: - Realizes they don’t align. - Choice becomes: live as the man who once again looked away, or accept ruin to break the pattern. - Allegiances: - No formal banners anymore. - Lingering, complicated loyalty to individual soldiers he served with. - Distrusts systems: Irongate, cults, rebels. “Everyone’s feeding someone into a fire.” - Relationships (existing, pre-story): - Family: - Mostly distant; sends money when he can, doesn’t visit. - One younger sister wrote him a letter once after hearing rumors of the purge. He never answered. - Past comrades: - Some would spit at his feet for “abandoning.” - One or two might still drink with him, but he avoids them. - No stable romantic ties: - Brothel visits, one-night comforts. Keeps emotions off-limits. It’s cheaper that way. Flavor quotes - Dialogue: - “You keep talking like we’re in the same story. We’re not. I’m the man on the wagon. You’re the one in chains.” - “Irongate doesn’t buy truth. They buy quiet.” - Internal: - “If she’d shut up for an hour I might forget her neck’s worth more gold than I’ve seen in three years.” - “Three days. I can hold myself together for three days.” --- # Lysira Vex Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws - Background: - Born in Irongate’s lower quarter to a tiefling mother who cleaned brass in a temple, father unknown. - Grew up knowing exactly what humans thought of her kind. Learned early to turn their fear and desire into leverage. - Ran messages for smugglers as a child; graduated to thief, informant, then infiltrator for those opposing Irongate’s “purity” laws. - Briefly served an infernal patronage: - Not full demonic thrall, but accepted power/knowledge under contract terms she then broke or twisted. - Some of the accusations against her are true; others are inflated propaganda. - Stole something vital from Irongate (names, contracts, plans for something ugly) not for fun but as part of a larger, ruthless attempt to expose or destabilize them. - Personality: - Verbal, quick, needling. Loves to pry at contradictions. - Keeps talking as armor: if she controls the frame, she’s safer. - Uses sexuality theatrically: - Flirtation, innuendo, provocative posture—but chooses carefully when it’s weapon, when it’s mask, when it’s genuine. - Alternates between mocking bravado and moments of disarming sincerity. - Deeply proud. Hates pity.
