[Scores] Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Pacing: 17 World Building: 18 Compelling Plot: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Coherent: 19 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 4 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 3 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 19
Avg Final Item Score: 86.0/100
+ Romance — Love in the Limelight (Chapter Avg: 78.8 | Final: 76.4)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write a short story set in Wales. Task: write a short story over several chapters. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The story takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the first scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. The story will progress beyond this synopsis, and it's up to you where it goes.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write a short story set in Wales. Task: write a short story over several chapters. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The story takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the first scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor&#x27;s charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. The story will progress beyond this synopsis, and it&#x27;s up to you where it goes. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming Characters (possible versions) - Actor: - Name ideas: - Rhys Ellery: Welsh-born, now Hollywood-famous; golden-boy rogue. - Aidan Vale: Charismatic British actor known for period dramas and superhero franchise; tabloid regular. - Cassian Hale: Smooth, wickedly charming, slightly jaded. - Core traits: - Rogue-ish charm; quick with flirting and self-deprecating jokes. - Fear of being disliked; compulsive need to win people over. - Used to being recognized and adored; disarmed when he isn’t. - Slightly vain; covers insecurity with wit and swagger. - Intelligent but underestimated; reads more than people think. - Tired of paparazzi and scripted persona; craves authenticity but is scared of it. - Backstory ideas: - Grew up in Wales, escaped small-town suffocation; complicated relationship with “home.” - Or English/Irish/Scottish actor hiding out in Wales while filming nearby. - Recently caught in a PR scandal (fake girlfriend, leaked photos, broken engagement). - Career inflection point: shifting from heartthrob to serious actor; heavy expectations. - Bookstore owner: - Name ideas: - Carys Wyn Davies: grounded, sharp-tongued, quietly romantic under layers. - Eira Morgan: reserved, observant; sense of humor drier than slate. - Lowri James: wry, bookish, kind with a crust of sarcasm. - Core traits: - Fiercely protective of her space; bookstore is sanctuary. - Appears unimpressed; uses coolness as armor. - Privately soft, intensely moved by stories and people. - Intelligent, quick to call out bullshit, but compassionate. - Not immune to charisma, just suspicious of it. - Under financial strain keeping bookstore alive. - Some unresolved wound: past relationship, caregiving responsibilities, grief, or leaving a more conventional path. - Backstory possibilities: - Inherited shop from a parent/grandparent; refuses to let it die. - Used to live in a big city (Cardiff/London) with a high-pressure job; burned out. - Past with someone who was performative/charming, leaving her wary of public figures. - Setting: - Small coastal town in Wales (e.g., fictionalized Aberfry, inspired by Tenby/Aberaeron): - Steep narrow streets, pastel houses, sea wind. - Bilingual signage, local gossip network. - Quiet except when tourists or a film crew come through. - Bookstore: - Warm, slightly chaotic; shelves of Welsh lit, poetry, romance, weird ephemera. - Bell on door, mismatched chairs, small tea corner. - Cat named: - Dylan (after Dylan Thomas) - Prydwen (Arthurian) - Biscuit (because… Biscuit) - Upstairs stockroom or reading nook that can become an intimate conversation space. Tone and style ideas - Warm, witty, and emotionally grounded. - Primary vehicle: dialogue; subtext heavy; flirtation with layered meanings. - Humor through: - His exaggerated self-awareness. - Her dry comebacks, refusal to swoon on cue. - Locals’ bluntness. - Emotional tone: - Underneath the banter: loneliness, fear of being seen vs being performed. - Slow-burn attraction building via conversations and small acts of care. - Avoid melodrama; lean into believable stakes and human-sized conflicts. Story structure over 8 chapters (~1000 words each) - Ch 1: The Meet-Cute (Paparazzi Escape) - Open on a rainy, blustery afternoon in town. - Actor flees paparazzi; ducks into the bookstore, hood up, sunglasses on. - Tense first exchange: she assumes he’s a tourist hiding from the rain; tells him if he isn’t buying, he can’t loiter. - He tries charm; she’s unimpressed, questions his entitlement; banter. - Paparazzi appear outside; she realizes who he is (or maybe not immediately). - Charged dialogue as they negotiate: can he hide here? What does she want in return? - Chemistry: his façade slipping as she doesn’t automatically adore him; she’s flustered but masks it with sarcasm. - End with her locking the door, deciding to help him—for now. - Ch 2: Locked In / First Real Conversation - After hours vibe; lights dimmed, door locked to keep paparazzi out. - Long conversation almost entirely in dialogue: - He hams it up, then slowly relaxes. - She probes: “What’s so terrible about being adored?” / “What’s so terrible about being invisible?” - Talk about books turned into films; his frustration at shallow roles. - Her pseudo-indifference cracks when he mentions an obscure poet or book she loves. - She calls out how curated his answers sound; he bristles, then laughs. - Moments of vulnerability from both: her fear of losing the shop; his fear of fading relevance. - They bicker about privacy vs public life, authenticity vs performance. - End with mutual intrigue; he leaves through back alley when safe; slips, she laughs; a small shared secret. - Ch 3: Return Visits and Rumors - He keeps coming back during filming; says it’s quiet / the coffee is decent / cat likes him. - She pretends annoyance: “You’re bad for my serious literary reputation.” - Locals slowly realize he’s there; gossip ripples. - Dialogue-heavy montage: - Quippy conversations about romance novels; she teases him about being everyone’s fantasy. - He admits reading scripts like bad fanfiction; she recommends better romances. - Shared in-jokes; glimpses of how much he enjoys being “just a bloke” here. - Undercurrent: - He’s subtly trying to win her full approval, and it unnerves him that her warmth is earned, not automatic. - She’s clearly charmed but always pulls back with dry realism. - Cliffhanger: a paparazzo snaps a photo of him leaving the bookshop; she sees flash through the window. - Ch 4: Fallout: Spotlight on the Shop - The photo hits tabloids: “Mystery Bookshop Muse”; speculation spirals. - Tourists and fans swarm; sales spike but atmosphere poisoned. - She is furious: her sanctuary invaded. - Heated dialogue: - She accuses him of using the shop for a narrative / PR. - His ego is pricked: he genuinely thought she saw the “real” him. - He tries joking it away; she won’t let him. - She says, “This isn’t a set, Rhys/Aidan; we live here.” - He offers to fix it; she doesn’t trust that interference. - Ending beat: they part on tense terms, but their mutual hurt reveals depth of feeling. - Ch 5: Repair Attempts and Real Confessions - He quietly intervenes: - Uses his influence to get security barriers; declines interviews about “mystery woman.” - Posts something redirecting fan energy away from town without naming her. - He returns to explain, non-performatively. - Intimate conversation: - He admits how much he needed a place where someone didn’t instantly worship him. - She admits she did like him from the start, which is exactly why she panicked. - They talk about their patterns: his addiction to validation; her fear of being overshadowed. - They set new boundaries: specific times he can come by; no photos inside. - Romantic tension thickens; almost-kiss interrupted (phone call, customer, town bell, etc). - Ch 6: Community, Closeness, and Crossing Lines - Montage through dialogue: - They read bits of plays/poems to each other; tease and share personal stories. - Town characters bond with or rib him; he proves surprisingly decent (supporting local charity, etc.) but not in a saintly way. - She invites him (reluctantly) to a small local event: poetry night / pub quiz / seaside bonfire. - He participates under his own name; locals’ mix of awe and bluntness. - He sees her in her element; is genuinely smitten. - After-event late-night scene in the shop or by the sea: - Honest talk about intimacy vs performance. - She accuses him (softly) of still trying to “play the good guy.” - He, hurt but honest, says: “What if the role I most want is the one where you believe me?” - They share their first real kiss—hesitant, then unmistakably real. - End with a sense of possibility and fear. - Ch 7: The Offer and the Ultimatum - His shoot wraps; he’s offered a major role that will cement his career; PR team wants to spin the bookshop romance as a narrative. - Conflict: - He wants to keep seeing her; suggests she visit him on set or in London/LA. - She struggles: - Doesn’t want to abandon shop or become tabloid fodder. - Afraid of being a footnote in his story. - He’s torn: - Needs to take the role; terrified of losing her. - Ego flares when she doubts him; he hears: “You’re not trustworthy.” - Dialogue-heavy argument: - He accuses her of never giving him the benefit of the doubt. - She counters that his whole life is designed to sell an image. - He leaves, frustrated; she’s left gutted but stubborn. - End: physical/temporal separation looming. - Ch 8: Resolution: Choosing Something Real - Time jump: weeks/months. - He’s filming; success building; glimpses via dialogue (calls, messages, some missed). - Miscommunication: - A tabloid links him to a co-star; she recoils, assumes pattern. - He realizes she’s pulling away. - Climactic choice: - He shows up back in Wales unexpectedly, low-key, without entourage. - Confession scene in the bookshop (primary in dialogue): - He turns down/reshapes PR stunts; sets firm boundaries on his public persona. - Tells her he’s tired of curating himself, but he’ll only be believed if his actions match. - She admits she mistook self-protectiveness for insincerity; owns her fear. - They negotiate: - Practical solutions: visiting schedules, how to protect the shop, communicate honestly. - Final note: - They commit to trying: him learning to live without constant external approval; her risking visibility for a person worth it. - End on them together in the closed shop at night, bantering, choosing each other in ordinary, unglamorous light; subtext that this is only “Season 1” of their story but satisfying as a standalone. Plot / thematic possibilities to weave in - Parallel between: - His scripted life vs unscripted conversations in the shop. - Her curated sanctuary vs the messy intrusion of big feelings. - Recurring motif: - Doors (locked/unlocked), windows, cameras vs pages. - Light in the shop vs limelight outside. - Chemistry in dialogue: - Teasing about: - His fanbase. - Her obsession with tragic love stories/poetry. - Welsh language pronunciation attempts. - Moments where he deliberately drops his charm and she, seeing the vulnerable version, becomes bolder. Pacing notes - Ch 1–2: Slow down and luxuriate in dialogue to cement voices and attraction. - Ch 3–4: Build routine, then break it with external pressure. - Ch 5–6: Emotional intimacy and romance deepen. - Ch 7: Escalate to a clean emotional conflict that arises naturally from their core traits. - Ch 8: Resolve with earned growth, no cheap grand gestures without matching inner change. # Reflection What seems to work well - The central dynamic: - His fragile-ego charm vs her wary independence is inherently dramatic and funny. - Dialogue-driven scenes fit their chemistry: we can show his performative habits and her ability to pierce them in real time. - The setting: - A Welsh seaside town plus a snug bookshop is atmospheric and naturally romantic without needing heavy exposition. - Wales offers cultural texture (language, poetry, landscape) that resonates with themes of voice, identity, and being seen/heard. - The actor characterization: - A rogue who needs everyone to like him creates rich internal conflict. - When he finds someone who doesn’t automatically play along, it both bruises and fascinates him, setting up his derailment from shallow charm to genuine feeling. - The bookstore owner characterization: - Her “superficial immunity” paired with secret fluster allows for layered dialogue where her words and interiority diverge. - Her emotional caution is understandable and sympathetic, especially with a public-figure love interest. - The conflict design: - Paparazzi photo → small-town/bookshop swamped → tension between private sanctuary and public spectacle: - Fits the prompt. - Stakes that are real but proportional for a short story. - Career opportunity vs relationship: - Classical romance conflict rooted in their values, not contrived villainy. - Dialogue focus: - Allows us to: - Show how his charm is a script that glitches around her. - Let readers “hear” the subtext of their growing connection. - Keeps pacing tight for 1000-word chapters. Potential pitfalls / what doesn’t work as well - Overly melodramatic external drama: - Stalker-level threats, huge scandals, or overblown betrayals could swamp the intimacy and feel off for the scale (8k words). - Making him too much of a jerk or too perfect: - If his rogue side slips into cruelty, we lose sympathy. - If he’s a flawless cinnamon roll, we lose the specific tension about his ego and performativity. - Need to balance: his missteps stem from learned defense mechanisms, not malice. - Making her too harsh or judgmental: - If she constantly undercuts him, readers might see her as unfair. - We need glimpses of the warmth she’s hiding to justify his persistence and the romantic payoff. - Rushing emotional beats: - They can’t believably go from strangers to soulmates overnight. - Within 8 chapters, need to: - Show gradual trust-building via recurring conversations, tiny gestures. - Avoid the feeling that one kiss or grand gesture magically solves fame/privacy issues. Refining toward the strongest version (still exploratory, not final decisions) - Lean into: - The interplay between performance and authenticity: - His trajectory: from compulsive people-pleaser to someone willing to be disliked for being genuine. - Her trajectory: from rigid protector of her small, safe world to someone willing to risk discomfort and visibility. - Wales and the shop as more than backdrop: - The town can reflect themes: a place often overshadowed by louder neighbors, like she is overshadowed by louder personalities. - Local characters provide grounding, humor, and a mirror to how he behaves when not “on stage.” - Dialogue that does double-duty: - On the surface: witty banter. - Underneath: faint admissions of loneliness, admiration, fear. - Keep: - First meeting tense and charged, with her not fully impressed, and him both irked and fascinated. - The paparazzi/photo conflict: it’s organic to the premise and escalates stakes without soap-opera extremes. - The eventual resolution based on mutual adjustment, not one person sacrificing everything. - Be cautious with: - Overstuffing with subplots (e.g., too many side characters or backstories). - Letting PR machinations dominate; they’re a tool for pressure, not the heart of the story. - Turning it into a manifesto about fame; keep it character-centered and romantic. Overall orientation - The most compelling approach seems to be: - A character-driven, dialogue-heavy, slow-burn romance, grounded in the specificities of a Welsh seaside town. - Centered on: - A charming, fragile actor who is disarmed into sincerity. - A wary, bookish woman who is disarmed into openness. - With conflicts that emerge naturally from who they are, their environments, and the realities of public vs private life. If you’d like next, I can turn this into a concrete 8-chapter outline with specific beats and recurring motifs, then start drafting chapter 1.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention - Core premise: - Tell an 8-chapter, approximately 8,000-word contemporary romance set in a small Welsh seaside town. - Focus on a famous actor and a bookstore owner whose connection begins when he ducks into her shop to escape paparazzi. - Emphasize a dialogue-driven slow burn where chemistry emerges through what they say and, crucially, what they don’t. - Tone: - Warm, witty, grounded; romantic without syrup. - Let humor and banter carry much of the charm. - Avoid melodrama; keep stakes human-scale but emotionally real. - Characters: - Actor: Rhys Ellery - Welsh-born, internationally famous; recently the face of a big franchise. - Rogue-ish: flirtatious, cocky, quick with a quip. - Fragile ego: addicted to being liked, uncomfortable when someone resists his charm. - Deep down: intelligent, exhausted by performance, craving being seen as a person. - Arc intention: - Start: running on persona and validation. - End: willing to risk being disliked; choosing authenticity and considered commitments, especially with Carys. - Bookstore owner: Carys Wyn Davies - Early 30s, sharp, dry sense of humor. - Owns/co-runs a cozy independent bookstore in a coastal town (Aberfry). - Appears unimpressed and self-possessed; values privacy and control over her space. - Secretly: romantic, susceptible to charm, easily flustered, fiercely loyal. - Arc intention: - Start: guarded, skeptical of glamour and big promises. - End: willing to risk vulnerability and some loss of anonymity for a relationship she truly believes in. - Relationship dynamic: - Foundation: dialogue as a battleground and bridge. - He is used to adoration; she withholds it, which first provokes him, then disarms him. - She is wary of performative charm; he gradually offers unscripted honesty. - Their attraction: - Initially expressed through banter and micro-shifts in tone. - Gradually becomes more overt, with moments of care, jealousy, fear, and choice. - Setting: - Fictional coastal town in Wales: Aberfry. - Windy harbor, pastel houses, bilingual signs, everyone-knows-everyone vibe. - The bookstore: “Pen and Tide” (or similar) - Narrow aisles, stacked shelves, reading nook, a sleepy cat. - Feels like a sanctuary; this matters to Carys and becomes symbolic of her boundaries. - Use Welsh details naturally: - Occasional Welsh phrases, references to poets, landscape, weather. - The town and shop as contrast to global spotlight (the “limelight”). - Style and craft choices: - Primarily dialogue: - Let conversations carry character development, tension, and exposition. - Use subtext, pauses, misdirections, running jokes. - Minimal but precise narration: - To ground setting, clarify physical beats, and indicate inner fluster or insecurity. - Keep it lean so dialogue remains the engine. - Distinct voices: - Rhys: - Quick, playful, occasionally theatrical. - Drops into more hesitant, unpolished speech when honest. - Carys: - Dry, observant, deadpan; uses understatement as defense. - Fluster leaks through in half-finished retorts or overly brisk subject changes. - Plot and conflict decisions: - Include: - The paparazzi escape and initial charged meeting. - Developing routine of his visits; deepening banter and trust. - Tabloid exposure of his connection to the shop → invasion of her space. - Emotional fallout and repair attempts. - Career opportunity forcing distance and decisions. - Final choice to pursue an honest relationship with practical boundaries. - Avoid: - Overblown thriller elements (no stalkers, kidnappings, etc.). - Villainizing side characters; let conflict come from their fears, careers, and media culture. - Magical fixes: resolution must be earned through behavior change and mutual understanding. - Thematic focus: - Authenticity vs performance: - Rhys learning that not every moment is a stage. - Carys learning that not all performances are lies; people can grow beyond their roles. - Privacy, sanctuary, and choosing to share your world: - The shop as Carys’s heart-space, compromised and then redefined. - The “limelight” vs ordinary life: - Romance rooted not in red carpets, but in closing up shop, shared tea, sea wind, in-jokes. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1: In From the Storm - Goal: - Establish the meet-cute, their voices, and the undercurrent of chemistry. - Beats: - Rain-lashed afternoon in Aberfry; Carys is closing up, straightening displays. - Door bursts open; Rhys enters in hoodie/cap/sunglasses, breathless, edgy. - Paparazzi voices outside; he checks street through blinds. - Carys (irritated, unaware at first): remarks on dramatic entrance; tells him no loitering. - Rhys tries reflexive charm and banter to smooth things over: - Offers a dazzling smile; asks if she has “anything for a man in dire need of an invisibility cloak.” - She responds dryly, pokes at his entitlement, suggests the travel guides. - Recognition moment: - She clocks his voice/profile; tests him by using his name without fan-girl tone. - He’s thrown off: she knows who he is but isn’t impressed. - Paparazzi spotted through window; he sheepishly asks for help hiding. - She negotiates: - Points out that helping him might put her shop in the crosshairs. - He jokingly offers autograph/bribe; she’s unimpressed. - She chooses to help anyway: - Locks door, flips sign, directs him deeper in. - Chapter ends with them alone in the quiet shop; tension and curiosity hanging. Chapter 2: After Hours - Goal: - Use extended dialogue to peel back their layers and seed mutual fascination. - Beats: - Carys brews tea in the back; Rhys loiters among shelves, comments on titles. - Banter: - She teases his film choices; he defends his superhero franchise playfully. - He brags lightly; she calls it PR-speak. - He tries tried-and-true charm: compliments her, the shop, her “mysterious eyes.” - She parries with wit, refusing obvious flattery; this shakes him. - Deeper turns: - He mentions growing up not far from here; she probes if Aberfry is too small for him. - She admits the shop is her anchor; it’s not a hobby. - He’s surprised by how seriously she takes it; respect flickers. - She calls out his media-trained answers; asks for something “unscripted.” - He reluctantly shares: - He’s tired; everything feels like selling a version of himself. - She briefly lets slip: - She left a “sensible” career; people don’t get why she’d fight for a tiny shop. - Subtle chemistry: - Moments of silence, eye contact, one or two lines where he drops the swagger, she softens. - Paparazzi eventually leave; solution found for him to exit via alley. - As he leaves: - He thanks her, unusually earnest; she brushes it off, flustered. - End on his lingering look back at the shop window; her watching after, annoyed at herself for caring. Chapter 3: Habit-Forming - Goal: - Show Rhys’s repeated visits, building rapport and attraction; seed external tension. - Beats: - A succession of short scenes, all dialogue-forward: - Rhys returns “to pay for the tea” / “to escape the chaos” / “for the cat.” - Carys feigns exasperation: “We’re not adding ‘celebrity refuge’ to the sign.” - Running jokes: - His terrible Welsh pronunciation; her corrections. - Romance novels with his face on covers; she shelves them low. - Deeper sharing: - She recommends books that challenge his image; he surprises her by reading them. - He confesses he likes how no one here screams on sight; she quips it’s because they’re polite. - She begins anticipating his visits, then berates herself mentally. - Locals start to notice: - A teen asks for a selfie; he’s gracious but low-key. - Older neighbor comments to Carys about her “fancy friend.” - Critical beat: - As Rhys exits one evening through the front to avoid suspicion, a camera flash pops. - He winces; she stiffens; they exchange an uneasy look. - End with Carys alone, realizing they may have just crossed into dangerous territory for her sanctuary. Chapter 4: Limelight in the Stacks - Goal: - Play out the consequences of exposure; use conflict to deepen stakes. - Beats: - A tabloid article circulates: Rhys in cozy Welsh bookshop; speculation about “mystery woman.” - Pen and Tide is suddenly busier with fans and gawkers. - Dialogue: - Customer fishing for gossip; Carys shuts it down curtly. - Locals making tongue-in-cheek remarks: “We’re famous now.” - Rhys arrives to find the shop crowded, cameras outside. - Tense confrontation between Rhys and Carys among the stacks: - She accuses him: “You said you wanted quiet; now this.” - He’s defensive, hurt: he didn’t tip them off; he hates this too. - His ego flares: “You think this is fun for me? You think I wanted you dragged into my circus?” - She presses on boundary: - “This place matters. If you’re here, they’re here.” - He offers reactive fixes (buying her out, moving locations, public statements); she resists anything that makes it worse or treats her like a PR problem. - They’re both raw: - Her fear of losing the shop versus his fear of losing the one place he feels normal. - He leaves abruptly, frustrated; crowd outside swallows him. - End: Carys locks up later than usual, listening to the murmur of people outside, feeling invaded and lonely. Chapter 5: Repairs and Cracks - Goal: - Begin emotional repair; expose vulnerabilities; move them toward true intimacy. - Beats: - In Rhys’s world: - Off-page but referenced in dialogue: he tells his team to stop pushing the “bookshop romance” rumor; refuses a staged photoshoot there. - Posts a careful statement asking fans to respect small businesses’ privacy (no name, but impact felt). - Aberfry response: - Gradual cooling of frenzy; still curious, but less chaotic. - Rhys returns to the shop quietly: - Asks if they can talk; she almost sends him away, but relents. - Honest conversation: - He admits how much it stung that she assumed he’d exploit her. - She admits she panicked because she did care, and that scared her. - He confesses he keeps performing because he’s terrified if people see the unvarnished version, they’ll leave. - She acknowledges she’s been assuming the worst to protect herself. - They agree on boundaries: - Specific low-key times he can come by. - No photos inside; if press comes, neither of them plays into it. - Subtler romantic beats: - He asks for a genuine book recommendation “for when I can’t sleep.” - She carefully chooses something meaningful; he takes it seriously. - Near-intimate moment: - As he’s about to leave, a charged pause; he leans in slightly. - Interrupted (doorbell, cat, phone). - End with both acutely aware the dynamic has shifted into something more fragile and real. Chapter 6: Steady Flame - Goal: - Show them growing genuinely closer, culminating in the first real crossing of the romantic line. - Beats: - A series of dialogue-centric scenes: - Shared reading: he quotes a line back to her; they debate endings. - He helps restack boxes; she mocks his lack of practical skills; he overperforms, making her laugh. - Local banter: a pub owner, a neighbor—subtle acceptance. - Carys invites him (reluctantly) to a low-key town evening: - Poetry night, charity quiz, or harbor bonfire. - He attends sans entourage; warms to the community; is roasted kindly by locals. - Later, they walk back through quiet streets: - He remarks how nobody here cares how many followers he has. - She says, “They care how you act at the quiz.” - They joke, then grow serious. - Heart-to-heart: - She voices concern about being a footnote in his narrative. - He insists he’s more himself here than anywhere. - She challenges: “Is that another line, or do you even know the difference?” - He, unguarded, admits he doesn’t always, but he’s trying. - The kiss: - Hesitant, mutual; no grand gesture, just a quiet step closer. - Dialogue before/after makes clear this is a choice, not a slip. - End on them back in the closed shop, softer, both exhilarated and a little afraid. Chapter 7: Offers and Orbits - Goal: - Introduce a career crossroads; force them to confront practical and emotional limits. - Beats: - Rhys gets a major film offer abroad; schedule: demanding, long-term. - PR team pushes a narrative; they want to either: - Go public with “heartwarming small-town love” or - Stage a fling with a co-star to distract from “the bookshop rumors.” - Dialogue: - Rhys tells Carys about the role at the shop after hours. - She’s happy for him but wary of what it means for them. - He suggests visits, long-distance calls, maybe her coming with him. - She balks: - Won’t abandon the shop, her life. - Refuses to be a prop in his PR story. - Argument: - He feels she doesn’t trust him; his ego, his fear of rejection spike. - She feels he doesn’t understand what being pulled into his world costs. - Sharp lines, but grounded: - No name-calling; just painful truths and fear. - They don’t break up explicitly, but they leave things unresolved: - “Figure your world out first.” - “Tell me when you decide I’m not just another storyline.” - End with Rhys leaving town for the job; Carys alone in the shop, trying to resume normal. Chapter 8: Choosing the Light - Goal: - Deliver an emotionally earned reconciliation; show growth; end on hopeful commitment. - Beats: - Time jump: a few weeks/months. - Via sparse exposition and dialogue snippets: - Rhys is successful; the film is in production. - They’ve texted/called; communication has grown strained. - A tabloid links him with a co-star; Carys, stung, goes further quiet. - Rhys recognizes: - He let others steer the narrative again. - Avoiding conflict with his team cost him her trust. - Decision: - He returns to Aberfry on a brief break, quietly, no PR circus. - Climactic scene in Pen and Tide: - He finds her closing up; she is cool but not cruel. - Dialogue-heavy reckoning: - He outlines changes he’s made: - Setting limits with PR on his dating life. - Turning down staged relationships; insisting some parts of his life are off-limits. - He admits: “I like being liked. I probably always will. But I’m done trading the real things for applause.” - She admits: - She hid behind cynicism; pre-emptively decided he’d fail her to avoid the risk. - Practical negotiation: - They won’t go public as a spectacle; if/when media find out, they present a united, low-drama front. - He’ll visit when he can; she might occasionally visit him, on her terms. - They agree to talk instead of assume when tabloids spin stories. - Emotional resolution: - She chooses him not as a fantasy, but as a flawed man trying to be honest. - He chooses her not as a fandom-pleasing plot, but as his quiet, complicated center. - Final moment: - In the closed shop, lights low: - Soft teasing (a callback joke from Chapter 1). - A kiss that is unhurried, familiar now. - Outside, the town is calm; cameras absent. - Implicit message: - The limelight is still there, but their love is choosing, again and again, to exist beyond it. If you’d like, next I can start drafting Chapter 1 according to this plan, keeping the style primarily in dialogue with clear, distinct voices.
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
Great question—and a smart step before drafting. Let’s break it into three parts: - How a human writer might naturally approach this piece. - Typical LLM tendencies that are risky for this kind of story. - A deep critique of the current intention/plan: where it slips toward “LLM-ish,” and how to humanize it. I’ll stay concrete and practical. 1. How a human might approach this piece A human, particularly a romance writer or someone invested in character work, would likely: - Start from voice, not outline: - They’d hear Rhys and Carys bickering in their head. - They’d feel out the rhythm of their banter, the offhand comments, the awkward pauses. - The outline would come later (if at all) to organize what already feels alive. - Be messier about emotion: - The attraction wouldn’t be perfectly articulated at each beat. - There’d be irrational reactions, pettiness, overcorrections, talking in circles. - Some scenes would exist just because they feel right—an in-joke, a quiet tea, an unnecessary walk home. - Take their time in one or two places: - A human might “overwrite” a key conversation—too long, very specific, oddly shaped in a way that feels real. - They’d let characters dwell: on a book spine, on rain on the glass, on the embarrassment of caring. - Let contradictions stand: - Rhys could be both considerate and self-absorbed in the same chapter. - Carys might be coolly logical one moment, and irrationally avoidant the next. - Motives might conflict; not every inconsistency gets neatly explained. - Use specific personal fascinations: - A human’s own obsessions leak in: a niche poet, a particular Welsh cafe, a childhood memory of storms. - Side details become oddly concrete: what kettle looks like, what cheap biscuits they always buy, the exact sound of the door chime. - Those specifics often don’t serve “the plot” cleanly, but they serve texture. - Accept some ambiguity: - The ending might be hopeful but not bulletproof. - Questions linger: Will the media find them? Can this really work? We’re left with belief, not guarantee. 2. Telltale LLM approaches that can hurt this piece Common LLM-style pitfalls (including in my own prior answers) that would be damaging here: - Safety and tidiness: - Everyone grows at a similar pace. - Conflicts are well-articulated, rational, and resolved in a single conversation. - No one says something unforgivably low; no lingering awkwardness. - The ending is strongly “wrapped with a bow,” signaling everything will be fine. - Over-schematic plotting: - Every chapter has a clear “function” and resolves its mini-arc. - Emotional beats arrive on predictable schedule (meet-cute, montage, misunderstanding, makeup, etc.). - Characters’ arcs are textbook-shaped; it feels like a template. - Over-explanation: - Subtext is spelled out. - Vulnerabilities are quickly named instead of shown. - Inner states are neatly narrated instead of peeking through dialogue, behavior, or silence. - Pseudo-impressive voice: - Reaching for lyrical, ornate phrasing. - Overly “writerly” metaphors in every paragraph. - Jargon-y emotional language instead of simple, precise feeling. - Conflict aversion: - Fights are polite, balanced, immediately productive. - No one sits with hurt for more than a scene. - Serious incompatibilities are solved via one sincere speech. - Flattened locality: - Wales used as scenery: “sea, cliffs, quaint town” without messy specifics. - Welshness as flavor text, not embedded in how people talk, joke, and judge. All of that tends toward pleasant, competent, and slightly bloodless—exactly what you’re trying to avoid. 3. Critiquing the current intention & plan: where it’s too LLM-ish, and how to make it more human The plan is structurally solid—but that’s also the danger. Let’s interrogate it. 3.1. The structure is a little too clean - Very LLM: - 8 chapters, each with clear function, rising tension, neatly escalated stakes, then resolution. - Every conflict maps directly to a craft principle. - Risk: - Feels engineered; readers sense they’re on rails. - To humanize: - Allow at least one chapter to “wander” emotionally: - e.g., a chapter mostly of them talking about an entirely tangential topic on a slow day in the shop, where tension simmers but nothing huge “happens.” - Let a conflict spill over chapters in a slightly asymmetrical way: - e.g., the fallout from the tabloid photo could simmer: awkwardness, avoidance, weirdly formal interactions before the big talk. - Build in one wrong turn: - An apology that lands badly. - A gesture that misfires. - A missed opportunity that lingers longer than is strictly efficient. 3.2. The characters’ growth is too tidy and self-aware - Very LLM: - Rhys: “I need everyone to like me; now I decide to be authentic.” - Carys: “I am guarded; now I accept vulnerability.” - Risk: - Reads like a therapy summary, not a lived experience. - To humanize: - Slow down their self-insight. - Let them misdiagnose themselves: - Rhys might initially claim, “I’m just having fun,” when he’s clearly hurting. - Carys might insist, “I don’t care,” in ways that are obviously defensive. - Show their flaws in behavior before naming them: - Rhys overcompensates, flirts with a local to test if Carys is jealous (messy, human). - Carys dismisses him in a moment when he really needed her to believe him. - Have at least one moment where they don’t articulate the lesson: - They just show up differently and let us infer it. 3.3. The conflict is a bit too balanced and reasonable - Very LLM: - Their arguments are clean: both sides valid, quickly leading to mutual understanding. - Risk: - Real couples fight sideways: via deflection, pettiness, ancient buttons. - To humanize: - Let fights be slightly unfair: - Carys might jab at his career in a low blow: “Go sell your fairy tale to someone who wants the exposure.” - Rhys might snap: “It must be nice, judging everyone from behind a till you barely keep afloat.” - Then sit with the discomfort: - No instant “I’m sorry, that was unfair” in the same scene. - Let them each stew, regret, rationalize, and only later circle back. 3.4. The emotional beats sometimes lean on exposition instead of texture - Very LLM: - Plan says: “Subtle chemistry.” “He confesses he’s tired.” “She admits she panicked.” - Risk: - On the page, that can become dialogue that’s too neat: people confessing core wounds in elegantly phrased sentences. - To humanize: - Think in micro-behaviors and sideways reveals: - Rhys lingering after closing, clearly not wanting to go back to his hotel. - Carys changing the subject abruptly whenever someone mentions past relationships. - Rhys fumbling a line when talking about “we” in interviews. - Make some key emotional admissions accidental: - Rhys blurts something when overtired. - Carys says too much after a glass of wine at the poetry night. - Let dialogue be imperfect: - Half-started sentences, contradictions, humor used as a shield mid-serious talk. 3.5. The ending is slightly too “wrapped with a bow” - Very LLM: - He sets PR boundaries, she admits fear, they negotiate, kiss, done. - Risk: - Feels like a textbook HEA: all major issues apparently solved through one final conversation. - To humanize: - Soften the certainty: - They agree to try, knowing it will be hard. - Maybe one unresolved friction point is acknowledged as ongoing work. - Add grounded details: - Instead of “We’ll present a united front,” it’s “If they camp outside again, I’m shutting the shop for a few days; we’ll go stay with my sister.” - Show their logistical thinking, not just principles. - Close on a tender, ordinary moment rather than a sermon: - A silly in-joke, a minor annoyance, something that shows they’re real people, not just a romance thesis. 3.6. Wales and the bookstore risk feeling like stage dressing - Very LLM: - Mentions of “Welsh coastal town,” “bilingual signs,” “poetry night” as generic authenticity tokens. - Risk: - Feels like we Googled Wales and sprinkled aesthetic. - To humanize: - Add specific, perhaps inconvenient details: - Weather that ruins his “romantic” gesture. - Locals who aren’t quaint extras; they’re blunt, nosy, funny, or unimpressed. - Bits of Welsh language that aren’t footnoted, just used. - Let the place push back: - Someone disapproves of Rhys (not everyone adores a celebrity). - The town’s gossip machine makes Carys’ life awkward before it becomes supportive. - Make the shop idiosyncratic: - The cat scratches Rhys. - The kettle breaks at an inconvenient time. - She hoards too many poetry collections no one buys. 3.7. Dialogue-first intention is good, but the risk is “slick banter only” - Very LLM: - “Primarily in dialogue” can devolve into: - Constantly clever repartee. - No silences, no mundane chat, no stumbling. - Risk: - Characters sound like a writers’ room, not actual people flirting awkwardly. - To humanize: - Include: - Awkward overlaps: both talking at once, then both apologizing. - Non sequiturs when someone panics. - Running bits that are actually a bit dumb—but meaningful to them. - Let some lines fall flat: - A joke that doesn’t land; they recover, and the recovery tells us something. - Use silence: - Let attraction exist in the unsaid: a beat between lines, someone changing the subject violently. 3.8. Stakes are thematic, but could use more personal specificity - Very LLM: - His stakes: authenticity vs persona. - Her stakes: sanctuary vs exposure. - Risk: - All presented at a conceptual level. - To humanize: - Tie to concrete personal history: - Rhys had a previous relationship destroyed by media spin; it informs how scared he is to involve Carys. - Carys’s shop isn’t just “important”—maybe tied to a late parent, or a personal failure she’s trying to redeem. - These details shouldn’t overshadow the romance, but anchor their reactions. 3.9. The plan treats every beat as “working toward” the romance - Very LLM: - Almost every scene is in service of their arc. - Risk: - Feels purposeful but lacks the extraneous fluff of real life. - To humanize: - Add a few indulgent touches: - A conversation about a weird customer. - A nonsensical argument about cliff paths vs beach walks. - A local legend about some rock formation they jokingly misinterpret. - These aren’t filler; they accumulate emotional reality. 4. Brainstormed tweaks to make the final story feel more human Not yet rewriting the plan, but pointing directions: - Build in one or two honest missteps: - Rhys uses her in a tiny, thoughtless way (a half-mention in an interview); realizes too late. - Carys freezes him out too hard after the photo; knows she’s overcorrecting. - Let attraction embarrass them: - Carys babbling about completely irrelevant books because he’s standing too close. - Rhys forgetting his own line from one of his films when she unexpectedly compliments him. - Seed one running joke that becomes intimate shorthand: - A bad Welsh word he keeps misusing. - A hideous book cover they keep re-shelving. - Give the town a specific complication: - A local festival that coincides with his presence; chaos not engineered purely for plot, but opportunistically used. - Allow one “ugly” scene: - Not abusive, but unflattering. One of them says the selfish thing first, rationalizes later. - Make the ending emotionally satisfying but slightly braver: - Less, “We’ve solved this,” more, “We’re choosing this with eyes open.” - Show discomfort with compromise—and willingness to live with it. If you’d like next, I can revise the chapter plan to incorporate these humanizing tweaks—keeping the core structure, but baking in more asymmetry, specificity, imperfection, and risk.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention Core promise (from the original prompt): - 8-chapter contemporary romance (about 8,000 words total) set in a small Welsh town. - Famous actor ducks into a bookstore to escape paparazzi. - First scene: charged conversation with unspoken chemistry. - Actor: charming rogue, fragile ego, addicted to being liked. - Bookstore owner: outwardly unimpressed, inwardly flustered and charmed. - Primarily in dialogue, distinct voices. - Story progresses beyond the meet-cute into something genuinely affecting. What this version aims to be: - Human, specific, slightly messy: - Less like a polished template, more like two real people colliding and trying to figure it out. - Imperfect arguments, small missteps, lingering tensions, and choices that feel earned. - Lean, not sparse: - Each chapter ~1000 words: focused, but with room for a few vivid, grounding details. - No bloated subplots, no over-writing. Just enough texture to feel lived in. Key choices - Characters: - Rhys Ellery (actor): - Welsh-born, now internationally famous; in Aberfry shooting part of a high-profile project. - Rogue: flirtatious, funny, self-aware, prone to theatricality. - Fragile ego: - Needs to be liked; charm is both habit and armor. - Rattled when someone doesn’t automatically adore him. - Humanizing flaws: - Occasionally thoughtless, centers himself without meaning to. - Uses jokes to dodge real questions. - Can get defensive and say something low when hurt. - Humanizing strengths: - Works hard; kind to crew/fans; reads more than people expect. - When he commits, he is all in, even if clumsy about it. - Carys Wyn Davies (bookstore owner): - Early 30s, runs “Pen a’r Don” (“Pen and Tide”), a cozy, slightly cluttered shop in Aberfry. - Dry wit, guarded; fiercely protective of her space and privacy. - Inwardly: - Romantic, moved by stories; embarrassingly susceptible to charm. - Anxious about finances; the shop was her mam’s, who died 3 years ago. - Past relationship with someone performative/ambitious who treated her like a supporting character. - Flaws: - Overcorrects toward cynicism. - Holds grudges; sometimes punishes before she has all the facts. - Strengths: - Observant, emotionally intelligent when she allows herself to be. - Loyal; quietly brave. - Relationship dynamic: - Built almost entirely through conversation: - Banter, petty arguments, awkward half-confessions, repeated in-jokes. - Attraction: - Starts as an undercurrent; both try to ignore it. - We see it in their missteps: trying too hard to appear indifferent or cool. - Conflict: - Emerges from who they are: his fame/PR world vs her need for a safe, uncommodified life. - No mustache-twirling villains; pressure comes from media, local gossip, their own baggage. - Setting: - Aberfry: small seaside town in Wales. - Not generic “quaint”; has its own habits: - Locals who are nosy, funny, unimpressed. - A harbor, gulls, weather that ruins plans. - Welsh sprinkled into dialogue casually, not as a novelty. - Pen a’r Don: - Narrow aisles, secondhand and new books, poetry front and center. - Slightly broken kettle. Bell on door. Cat named Dylan who bites arbitrarily. - Feels like a sanctuary because it is one—for Carys, and increasingly, for Rhys. - Style and voice: - Primarily dialogue: - Use what they say (and avoid saying) to reveal fear, desire, ego, and tenderness. - Distinct voices: - Rhys: fast, occasionally trying too hard; slips into quieter, less polished speech when truthful. - Carys: economical, dry, with small cracks when flustered. - Minimal narration: - Just enough to: - Anchor where they are. - Show silent beats, glances, physical tells (hands, distance, fiddling with a book). - Convey internal states indirectly. - Aim for: - Specific over generic. - Clean, readable prose over ornate flourishes. - Letting some ambiguity stay; not every feeling perfectly labeled. - Avoid: - Over-explaining motivation. - Overly tidy therapy-speak. - Slick, nonstop “perfect banter” with no awkwardness or missed beats. - Ending with a magic, guaranteed solution; we want a brave, hopeful choice. - Plot spine (high-level): - 1–2: Meet-cute and immediate aftermath; establish chemistry and resistance. - 3–4: Growing connection; the photo/tabloid leak and small-town invasion. - 5–6: Attempts at repair; deepening intimacy; first real crossing of the romantic line. - 7: Career and publicity pressures force a painful clash. - 8: Time jump and an imperfect, honest reconciliation. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1: The Sanctuary Breached Purpose: - Deliver the core premise as an alive, charged scene. - Establish voices, shop as sanctuary, and initial clash of charm vs indifference. Beats: - Late afternoon; rain hammering Aberfry. Carys is minutes from closing Pen a’r Don. - Door slams; Rhys bursts in: hood, cap, sunglasses, breathing hard. Bell jingles; Dylan the cat bolts. - Carys, unimpressed, tells him they’re closing: no dripping on the poetry. - Outside: distant shouts, camera flashes visible when the door opens a crack. Rhys peeks, swears softly. - Quick-fire dialogue: - Rhys tries a breezy excuse; Carys calls out the obvious hiding. - He floats small flirty lines; she deadpans them back, mildly rude but not cruel. - Recognition: - She hears his voice, puts it together. Tries not to show it. - Drops his name bluntly once: “Rhys Ellery, yes? You’re scaring my cat.” - His ego flickers: both pleased she knows him and stung she’s not dazzled. - He asks to stay until they clear off; she points out helping him risks making the shop a target. - He offers the reflexive “I’ll make it up to you” in vague celebrity terms; she says that’s not currency here. - Moment: - She hesitates. He, for a beat, lets the performance slip—he looks simply tired, cornered. - That human note tips her. - She locks the door, flips the sign, tells him, “Ten minutes. Don’t touch the displays.” - End on them alone among the books, wary and curious. Chapter 2: Closed Doors, Open Mouths Purpose: - Let them actually talk; show his persona glitching and her mask cracking. - Seed genuine interest on both sides. Beats: - Carys makes tea in the cramped back area; Rhys wanders shelves, comments on his own face on some DVD cover or movie tie-in. - Banter: - She teases him about terrible poster art. - He leans into self-mockery; she calls it “a very polished humility routine.” - Paparazzi still visible through blinds; they’re stuck a bit longer than planned. - More layered conversation: - She interrogates his “routine”; he deflects, then snaps lightly, then softens. - He asks about the shop; she mentions it was her mam’s, deflects deeper talk. - He mentions growing up not far away; says Aberfry feels like “slipping on an old accent.” - Moments of imperfection: - He tries a cheesy line; it lands flat. They both notice. He laughs at himself. - She accidentally reveals she’s seen one of his smaller, better films, then tries to downplay it. - Subtle openings: - He complains—obliquely—about living like public property. - She points out she built this place to be the opposite of that. - Eventually, his driver texts; paparazzi seem to have moved. - She shows him the back alley exit; almost an apology for giving him a hard time. - He thanks her more sincerely than necessary; she shrugs it off, slightly flustered. - Outside, he hesitates, almost says something more, then goes. - End: Carys alone, annoyed that his absence feels louder than his entrance. Chapter 3: Unwelcome Regular Purpose: - Show Rhys returning by choice; let their rapport and attraction grow in small, specific ways. - Hint at the cost of his presence. Beats: - Short time jump: a week. Rhys is filming nearby. - Montage-in-dialogue: fragments over several visits. - “You again,” Carys says, every time, a bit less sharp. - He claims various excuses (needs a book, needs quiet, Dylan likes him). - Dylan patently does not like him; bites once. Running joke. - They talk books: - She recommends something unexpected; he returns with specific opinions. - He ribs her about all the romance stock; she counters that his career lives off fantasy. - Humanizing missteps: - He enjoys being recognized by a teen customer; hams it up slightly. - Carys watches, amused and a bit put off by how easily he flips “on.” - Locals: - A neighbor spots him; news trickles through town: “Rhys Ellery in Pen a’r Don?” - Carys gets a couple of knowing comments; we see her unease. - Private tension: - One quiet visit: he lets slip how he dreads going back to his hotel alone. - She pretends not to register the loneliness there, changes the subject clumsily. - On a damp evening, he leaves via the front; a camera flash catches him with the shop sign. - He swears; she flinches; neither says what they’re both thinking. - End on that unsettled beat. Chapter 4: When the World Leans In Purpose: - Play the invasion of her sanctuary and their first real rupture. - Show both behaving a little badly, humanly. Beats: - Tabloid headline: photo of Rhys at Pen a’r Don; caption about “mystery Welsh bookshop beauty.” - The shop: - New faces, phones out; people ask, “Is this where Rhys comes?” “Are you the girl?” - Carys deflects, gets sharp; Dylan hides. - Rhys arrives to find chaos: - Tries to charm tense customers; inadvertently confirms this is “his place.” - Carys is furious; waits until they have a corner of semi-privacy. - Argument: - She accuses him of being careless, of using her shop as an aesthetic. - He’s genuinely blindsided, hurt she assumes intent. - His ego spikes: “Sorry my existing near your sacred shelves ruined your vibe.” - She jabs at his world being a circus; he jabs back that she’s naive if she thought it wouldn’t follow him. - One low blow each: - Her: “You don’t know how to be anywhere that isn’t about you.” - Him: “At least people want to be in the room with me.” - Both register they crossed a line, but pride holds. - He leaves through a gauntlet of fans and photographers, slipping fully into “celebrity mode.” - Carys watches from inside; feels both vindicated and gutted. - End: She locks up early; the bell’s cheerful jingle sounds wrong. Chapter 5: Bent, Not Broken Purpose: - Show them living with the fallout briefly, then Rhys taking clumsy, real steps to do better. - Move from narrative of “template conflict” to “these two specific people trying to fix it.” Beats: - Short passage of time: - Carys endures a rough week: people linger, gossip; some locals defensive, some mocking. - The frenzy slightly subsides but doesn’t vanish. - Rhys, off-page: - Refuses PR suggestions to milk the “bookshop romance.” - In one interview, when pushed, says sharply that his private stops are not for cameras. - He returns to the shop, without entourage, at an off hour: - She is cold but doesn’t throw him out. - Conversation (not immediately tidy): - He awkwardly apologizes; no big speech. Admits he hated how he sounded last time. - She half-apologizes for the “no one wants you” jab; can’t quite meet his eye. - He explains (less polished, more halting) that sometimes he forgets there’s any space left that isn’t public—and he panicked when she seemed to be closing hers to him. - She admits the shop is tied up with grief and pride; the idea of it turning into a backdrop terrifies her. - Misstep: - He offers to “help” financially; she bristles, offended. - He immediately clocks that, pulls back; genuine “I got that wrong, I’m sorry.” - They agree on small, practical boundaries: - If he comes by, it’s early or late; no selfies inside. - No hinting about the shop in interviews. - Emotional beat: - She recommends a particular poetry collection “for when the noise won’t shut up.” - He’s disarmed; tucks it under his arm like it matters. - Almost an intimate moment: - As he leaves, he hesitates like he might touch her arm or say more; she looks away first. - End: fragile truce, unresolved pull. Chapter 6: Something Like Normal Purpose: - Let them be close, gently and imperfectly. - Earn the first real romantic crossing without melodrama. Beats: - Another small time jump. - Dialogue snippets over a series of days: - Teasing about his pronunciation of Welsh phrases in the poems. - An in-joke about a hideous romance cover; they keep hiding it in new places. - He helps lug boxes, complaining dramatically; she calls him useless; he tries harder. - Town color: - Locals now mostly shrug about him; novelty fades, gossip settles into a background hum. - One elderly regular gives Carys a sharp look that says, “Do not let him hurt you.” - Carys invites him, last-minute, to a modest local event (poetry reading / quiz / choir). - He almost says no (tired), then shows up. - He is both a bit awkward and game; gets teased when he flubs answers. - After: - Quiet walk back by the harbor. - Softer conversation: - He admits the evening was the first time in ages he felt like “just Rhys from down the road.” - She, deflecting, says he was terrible at the quiz. - He pushes gently: asks what she’s actually afraid of with him. - She gives him a piece of the truth: “I won’t be a footnote or a rumor. I pick my chaos.” - Kiss: - Not perfectly cued; he moves a fraction close, she almost laughs from nerves, then kisses him anyway. - It’s brief but certain, followed by immediate awkwardness and a bad joke. - End: They part for the night with half-smiles, both terrified by how much they want more. Chapter 7: The Ask and the Flinch Purpose: - Bring in external pressure via his career; let them both behave in recognizably human, not idealized, ways. Beats: - Rhys gets the big offer: long shoot abroad, heavy press commitments. - PR team: - Want a clean relationship narrative: either officially single and “fun,” or in a polished, controllable romance. - Suggest leaning into co-star rumors; hint that the “bookshop girl” story is “off-brand messy.” - Rhys tells Carys at the shop after closing: - He’s excited, scared; he wants her to be part of his world somehow. - Floats ideas: visiting him, maybe doing the distance thing. - Carys’ reaction: - Proud of him, but gut-level afraid. - Bristles at the idea of slotting into a media plan. - Voice gets cool: “I won’t be something your team manages.” - Argument (slightly uglier, less balanced): - He accuses her of assuming the worst, of never trusting that he’d pick her over PR crap. - She throws back that his life is built on being liked by strangers; how can she compete with a million people he thinks he owes? - He, stung, says something sharp about her hiding in a failing shop. - She hits back that he can leave; she’s the one who has to live with the consequences. - They stop before it gets nastier. No tidy resolution: - He leaves for the shoot without a clear plan. - She doesn’t chase him; doubles down on work, but we see the hurt. - End: physical and emotional distance. Chapter 8: Not for the Cameras Purpose: - Offer an honest, hopeful reconciliation that acknowledges risk and limitation. - End on choice, not fairy-tale guarantee. Beats: - Time jump: some weeks/months. - Through minimal exposition and snippets: - Rhys shooting abroad; public sees him with co-stars. - Tabloid story tries to pair him with someone else; he doesn’t cooperate, but headlines exist. - Carys goes quiet, then quieter; answers his messages more formally. - Rhys clocks the gap: - Realizes he let silence and PR inertia speak for him. - On a brief break, he comes back to Aberfry unannounced, alone. - Evening at Pen a’r Don: - He appears at closing. Carys is wary but lets him in. - Conversation (key scene): - No grand speech; instead: - He tells her what he’s actually done: - Refused fake dating set-ups. - Set a boundary: his real relationships are off-limits as storylines. - Told his team he won’t use the shop or Aberfry for PR. - Admits he still wants to be liked, still screws up. No miracle cure. - Says he came because not knowing where he stands with her is worse than bad press. - She admits: - She punished him preemptively because with her ex, the warning signs came dressed as charm. - She hates that caring about him means sharing her safe place with everything he drags along. - They talk practically: - If tabloids pick it up again, what do they do? - He suggests concrete things: lying low at a friend’s farm, her shutting the shop for a couple of days if needed, him not performing on the street outside her door. - She sets terms: no secret-relationship nonsense; if they’re doing this, it’s real, not something he’s “trying on” for a role. - No one pretends it’s easy. - Resolution: - He asks, more simply than before, “Can we try? As ourselves. No cameras. No scripts.” - She hesitates, then says yes—not because it’s safe, but because he showed up and changed pattern, not just words. - Final image: - They close the shutters together; Dylan headbutts his leg for the first time. - A small, stupid in-joke resurfaces (e.g., hiding that awful book cover), and they both laugh. - They kiss in the quiet shop; it’s not cinematic, just right-sized. - Outside: the town at night, sea audible, no flashbulbs. - Sense that they’re stepping into something uncertain but genuine—which is exactly the point. If you’d like, next I can draft Chapter 1 following this plan: tight, dialogue-driven, with that undercurrent of chemistry and resistance front and center.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Rhys Ellery Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws - Background: - 34. Born Rhys Elidir Ellis in a town not far from Aberfry; changed to Ellery on an early agent’s advice (“less Welsh, more international”). - Working-class family: dad a mechanic, mam a nurse. Two older sisters who treat his fame as alternately hilarious and annoying. - Did school plays; one drama teacher pushed him toward RADA. He left Wales at 18, carrying equal parts ambition and guilt. - Broke-through in a BBC drama, then an indie film; became globally recognizable after a superhero franchise. - Has been famous long enough to be tired of it, but not long enough to feel secure without it. - Core personality: - Charming, fast-talking, quick with jokes. - Addicted to smoothing over tension; will self-deprecate before you can cut him down. - Competitive in subtle ways; wants to be the funniest, the kindest, the favorite. - Surprisingly bookish: reads scripts seriously, dabbles in poetry (mostly late at night, in hotels). - Straightforwardly tactile: hand on shoulders, leaning in, fidgeting with props—then realizes not everyone wants that. - Idiosyncrasies: - Touches his hair when uncomfortable, even if it ruins it; then jokes about it. - Always has a battered notebook where he jots lines (dialogue, lyrics, overheard things), but is very cagey about letting anyone read it. - Hums under his breath when nervous; often the theme music from his own movies, ironically. - Collects hotel keycards. Keeps them in a box; can tell you a story for half of them. - Eats crisps for dinner more often than he admits; defensive if teased about it. - Has a habit of trying to pay for things he’s emotionally uncomfortable accepting (coffee, help, kindness). - Flaws (with concrete texture): - Needs to be liked: - At a pub, he’ll buy a round to keep everyone happy, even if it invites more attention than he wants. - Struggles not to tailor his responses to what he thinks people want to hear. - Performative: - Slips into charming anecdote mode when cornered emotionally. - Drops PR-safe phrases even with people he trusts, then hates himself for it. - Defensive: - If accused of selfishness, he sometimes doubles down (“That’s just how it is”) before he actually listens. - Mildly self-centered by habit: - Forgets that his presence in a place has consequences that others can’t step away from. - Offers money/solutions where listening would be harder and better. Physicality and how he moves - Appearance: - Around 5'11", compact and fit, the lean strength of someone always “camera-ready.” - Dark brown hair, often mussed; strong, expressive eyebrows that give away his reactions. - Green-hazel eyes; laugh lines starting to deepen. - Handsome in a slightly boyish way; he knows it and plays it up when useful. - How he carries himself: - Moves like he expects to be watched: unconsciously “open,” smile ready. - In quiet moments, shoulders drop, voice softens, accent thickens. - Tends to lean on counters, shelves; closes distance when he’s comfortable. - Fidgets with book spines when he’s trying to appear nonchalant. - When he’s truly off-guard, you see flashes of the teenager from South Wales—less polished, more rough-edged. Motives, allegiances, relationships - Motives: - Wants to be taken seriously as an actor, but more deeply: wants to be known as a decent person beyond headlines. - Terrified of irrelevance; fame feels like proof he hasn’t made a mistake leaving home. - Craves an anchor—something/someone not contingent on box office or Twitter. - With Carys: - At first: wants to “win” her over because she doesn’t swoon. - Shifts to genuinely needing a place where he can show up unfiltered and be accepted. - Allegiances: - Deep, complicated loyalty to his family; sends money without making a show of it. - Loyal to a few long-time friends; suspicious of “industry friends.” - Tied by contract and habit to his PR team, even as he resents their control. - Existing relationships: - Parents: proud, wary of his stress; mam occasionally guilt-trips him about never slowing down. - Sisters: no-bullshit; will roast him for any whiff of diva behavior. - An ex long-term partner (actress): break-up was publicly spun; left him wary of mixing real emotion with media narrative. - Some crew and co-stars he trusts; one or two he’d call at 3am. Rare. Flavor dialogue / internal monologue - Dialogue: - “Look, if they catch me in here, your sales triple and my soul shrivels. Everybody wins.” - “You realize most people pay good money to have me lurk in their shop, right? Don’t answer that.” - “I’m not flirting, I’m… conversationally enthusiastic. There’s a difference. Barely.” - Internal monologue: - If she could just laugh, even once, that would settle something needy and stupid in his chest. Which is exactly why he’s not going to ask for it. - Don’t perform. Just… be. Christ, when did ‘being’ get harder than crying on cue? # Carys Wyn Davies Background, personality, idiosyncrasies, flaws - Background: - 32. Born and raised in Aberfry. Left for Cardiff at 18; degree in English and a half-hearted try at marketing. - Moved back at 27 when her mam got sick; helped run Pen a’r Don, then inherited it. - Stayed after her mam died, partly from love, partly from inertia, partly from fear of leaving again. - Past serious relationship with a musician who “needed” her support but never prioritized her; cheated; used their life in songs. Cured her of performative charm. - Core personality: - Dry, wry, more tender than she wants anyone to know. - Values competence, follow-through, showing up on time. - Enjoys quiet forms of drama: books, storms, sharp-tongued banter. - Proud of surviving, but sometimes confuses “surviving alone” with “virtue.” - Idiosyncrasies: - Alphabetizes some shelves obsessively, but has a “chaos corner” of random finds. - Remembers customers’ reading preferences with eerie accuracy, but forgets faces in films. - Hates dog-eared pages, but will read in the bath and get the edges warped. - Has a chipped mug with “Cariad” on it; only uses it on hard days. - Talks to Dylan as if he’s a surly coworker. - Collects abandoned bookmarks; keeps them in a tin behind the till. - Flaws (with concrete texture): - Guarded to a fault: - Uses sarcasm as her first line of defense. - When hurt or scared, goes colder instead of more honest. - Judgmental streak: - Suspects ulterior motives, especially in charming, successful people. - Sometimes confuses her intuition with certainty. - Stubborn: - Would rather struggle than accept help that feels like pity or control. - Will double down on a bad impression to avoid admitting she was wrong. - Avoidant vulnerability: - Sidesteps conversations about grief; changes subject, makes tea. Physicality and how she moves - Appearance: - Around 5'6", sturdy in a lived-in way; strong arms from lifting boxes. - Dark, wavy hair usually in a loose bun or knot with a pencil stuck through it. - Olive-pale skin that flushes easily when flustered (to her horror). - Dark grey-brown eyes; steady gaze; faint shadows from late nights. - Clothes: jeans, jumpers, cardigans with ink or dust on them; boots. A single good coat for “going somewhere.” - How she carries herself: - Behind the counter she’s centered, efficient. - Moves with awareness of the space; slips between shelves like she built them (she did, some of them). - Crosses her arms when defensive; taps a book spine when thinking. - When relaxed, leans back on the counter; one ankle crossed over the other. - Not clumsy, but has little collisions when emotionally distracted (bumping a table, dropping her keys). Motives, allegiances, relationships - Motives: - Keep Pen a’r Don alive—not just the business, but the atmosphere. - Maintain dignity and autonomy; hates the idea of being “someone’s plus-one” story arc. - Quietly yearns for someone who chooses her and her life as it is. - With Rhys: - Initially: keep him from turning her sanctuary into B-roll. - Gradually: wants him, but on terms that don’t erase her. - Allegiances: - To her mam’s memory: - The shop is a living promise; any threat to it is personal. - To Aberfry: - Knows its rhythms, its gossip; feels protective even when it annoys her. - To a small circle of locals who rely on the shop’s stability. - Existing relationships: - Dad: lives nearby, quiet, checks in without fuss. - Close friend: Anwen, who runs the café up the street; sounding board, merciless about Carys’s denial. - A few regular customers who are almost family. - Ex: distant, occasionally pops up in media; she ignores him and burns with a mix of relief and embarrassment. Flavor dialogue / internal monologue - Dialogue: - “If you’re bleeding, don’t drip on the first editions. Everything else is negotiable.” - “I’m not impressed, I’m just not throwing you out. That’s not the same thing.” - “You smile like you’re waiting for applause. Must be exhausting.” - Internal monologue: - He’s just a man hiding from the rain. A very stupidly symmetrical man with insured cheekbones. Who is none of your business. - Say no. Or say yes. But stop hovering in whatever this is, Carys; this is how you end up in the acknowledgements and nowhere else. # Dylan (supporting, but important) (Shorter, since he’s not “main,” but he shapes the dynamics.) - Background/personality: - 7-year-old rescue tom. Came with the name “Dylan,” which Carys decided was fate. - Moods: aloof, judgmental, occasionally magnanimous. - Idiosyncrasies: - Loves sleeping on obscure Welsh poetry and tax records, hates celebrity memoirs (knocks them off). - Bites Rhys once early on; later, headbutts his leg in acceptance. - Function: - Barometer: his reactions to Rhys mirror Carys’s progress. - Adds unglamorous, grounding texture. If you’d like, next we can sketch a couple of key side characters (e.g., Anwen, a PR rep, a nosy local) to round out the world and then move into drafting Chapter 1.

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell over the door went berserk. Carys looked up from the till as it clanged against the glass. Rain and a man came in together, both in a rush. He shoved the door shut behind him with his shoulder, breathing hard. Hood up, cap low, sunglasses on despite the dimness. Water dripped onto the “New Poetry” table. “Careful,” Carys said. “They don’t float.” “Sorry,” he said automatically, voice low, British with something softer underneath. He stayed with his back against the door, hand on the handle like he might have to bolt again. Outside, muffled through the glass and the rain: a shout, the tinny whine of a distant engine, a laugh too loud. He risked a look through the pane, just enough to let a streak of streetlight touch his jaw. Carys slid the plastic cover over the card machine and watched him. Not local. Not one of the usual soaked tourists, either. Too wired. Too… composed, even in his panic. Dylan launched himself off the counter with an offended chirp and vanished into the back. “He’s got sense,” she said. “You shutting the door or auditioning for something?” The man flinched, looked at her for the first time. The sunglasses pushed him into anonymity, but the profile was wrong in a very familiar way. “Sorry,” he repeated. This time the word came with a flash of teeth. Practiced, that smile. “You, ah—are you about to close?” “In two minutes,” Carys said. “You’ve got one to convince me you’re buying something and not just dripping on my floor.” “Right.” He pulled the hood back, then the cap, then, reluctantly, the sunglasses. Recognition wasn’t a thunderbolt. It was an irritating click. Rhys Ellery, in her shop, damp and too much. He ran a hand through his hair, scattering drops. “Bit of a situation outside. I’ll happily buy… several somethings. Just need a second to—” “Hide,” she said. He hesitated, caught. “Regroup.” The rain smacked the window, briefly spotlighting three shapes moving past. A flash went off, stray and white. Her jaw tightened. “Tell me you didn’t bring them here.” “I didn’t send a bloody invite,” he said. Then the charm slid back in, a practiced, boyish tilt of his head. “I can go if I’m wrecking your evening. Just thought—door was open, looked like a sanctuary. Full of judgmental paperbacks.” “We do hardbacks too.” Carys stepped around the counter and wiped at the puddle under his feet with the edge of the mat. “You’re wrecking my floor.” “I’ll pay for the mat,” he said. “Sign it, if you like. That’s a joke. Unless you’re into that. You’re not, are you.” “Into what?” “People signing things.” He gestured vaguely, as if that encompassed his entire existence. “Against my better judgment, I’m into people not bleeding on the books,” she said. “So if hiding in here means they come in, point cameras at my shelves, and drip everywhere, then no.” He winced. Outside, a scooter buzzed past; a man’s voice called his name, stretched and nasal. “Rhys! Over here, mate!” His shoulders went up. “Please,” he said, and it was quieter, the gloss slipping. “Just for a bit. Won’t touch anything. Except with my eyes. And my wallet.” There was a time Carys would have been thrilled. When she’d have rung Anwen, whispering, You’ll never guess who’s in the shop. Before she knew what it felt like to have her life turned into a backdrop. She looked at him properly. The set of his jaw; the thread of tension at his throat; the way he was pressing himself small against the door, as if he could disappear into the wood. “Take your shoes off,” she said. He blinked. “Sorry?” “You’re dripping. Shoes by the mat. And if anyone bangs on that door, you don’t make a sound.” He huffed something that wanted to be a laugh. “Yes, boss.” He toed off his boots, left them puddling on the mat. Striped socks. Of course. “Thank you.” “This isn’t altruism,” she said, walking to the door. She flipped the lock; the click sounded loud. Outside, someone rattled the handle a second later. She ignored it. “If they think I’m running some celebrity speakeasy, I’ll have the council on me.” He moved away from the door automatically when she stepped close. Up close, Rhys Ellery looked like Rhys Ellery, but also like a man whose eyes were a fraction too wide. “Do they ever stop?” she asked, not quite able to help herself. “Not if I do,” he said. “They get bored eventually. Short attention span. No offense to any photographers you might love personally.” “I don’t,” she said. “Go. Back aisle, left. They can’t see you from the street there.” He hesitated. “You sure?” “No,” she said. “But Dylan hasn’t come back to attack you, and I respect his judgment.” He made his way down the aisle, socks silent on the old boards, glancing at the shelves like he might recognize something.
