At the midpoint he turned back. “Thank you,” he said again, with less spin on it. “You’re on the clock,” Carys said. “Ten minutes. Then I evict you.” He retreated, disappeared behind “Local History” and “Poetry.” The banging on the door subsided. Rain took over the percussion. In the back, the kettle clicked as it cooled; she’d forgotten she’d boiled it. She wiped a few stray drops from the poetry table, righted a slim volume. This was ridiculous. She had closing to do. Paperwork. Dylan’s dinner. Not babysitting blockbuster boy. “Do you like—” his voice floated down the aisle, then stopped. “Sorry. Is talking prohibited?” “It depends what about,” she called back. “I was just going to ask if you actually—” A book slid out; his head popped around the corner. “Stock this because you love making people cry, or…?” He held up a battered copy of a well-known tearjerker. “People insist on asking for it,” she said. “I cater to public demand. Unlike some.” “Ouch,” he said. “Already with the digs.” “You did run in here like a chased fox.” “That’s an insult to foxes. They look less guilty.” He disappeared again, his fingers tracing spines. “Carys, right?” She stiffened. “How do you know my name.” “Till,” he said, pointing. “And the sign. Pen a’r Don. ‘Owned by Carys Wyn Davies.’ I’m famous, not psychic.” “Shame,” she muttered. “What about you?” he went on. “You always this kind to soaked strangers or is it my devastating jawline?” “It’s the socks,” she said. He looked down, wiggled his toes. “They’re lucky.” “To be inside,” she said. “Unlike your fan club.” He snorted. The sound was unguarded enough to be almost nice. “They’re not fans. They’re… part of the job.” “What’s the job?” she asked, leaning on the counter. “Existing?” “Today? Mainly not getting photographed with kebab sauce on my shirt.” A beat. “Filming up the coast. They get bored between setups. So. Scenic tours of Rhys Being A Person.” “And you thought you’d be a person in here,” she said. “Seemed like a good bet,” he said lightly. “Books. Dust. World’s most unimpressed woman.” “That your type?” “It’s new,” he said. “Kind of refreshing.” He was still half-hidden in the aisle, one hand on a shelf. The bravado in his words didn’t quite make it to his eyes. She exhaled. “They’re going to clock eventually. If they haven’t already.” “I’ll go out the back,” he said quickly. “Once it’s clear. I don’t want to drag you into—” “Then don’t,” she said, sharper than she meant. His mouth closed. The rain eased to a drumroll. The shouts outside had drifted down the street. Carys checked the little CCTV monitor pointed at the alley; clear. Front window: only the orange smear of the streetlamp. “Right,” she said. “Coast is quiet. Come on.” He padded back up the aisle, book still in hand. When he reached the counter, he put it down carefully. “I’ll take this,” he said. She glanced at the cover. The tearjerker. “That one? Brave.” “I contain multitudes,” he said. “And I did promise to buy something.” “You don’t have to—” “I know.” His gaze held hers, intent for a moment. “I want to.” That landed somewhere she didn’t appreciate. She rang it through. “Nine ninety-nine.” He pulled a note from his wallet, left it on the counter with slightly theatrical precision. Then, with less theater: “And, um. Sorry for the door… explosion.” “I’ve had worse,” she said. “Once had a stag do try to buy porn. We don’t stock porn.” “You’d make a fortune,” he said, managing a grin. “Get out before I reconsider,” she said, but her mouth twitched. He slipped his cap back on, sunglasses dangling from his fingers now instead of his face. She led him through the back, past the storeroom where Dylan glared from atop a box. “He hates me,” Rhys whispered. “He has taste,” she said. “Harsh.” At the back door, she unlocked the deadbolt. Cold air crept in; the alley was dark, slick. “Left,” she said. “Keep your head down. Pretend you’re no one.” He hesitated on the threshold. “I’m… really grateful, you know.” “It’s a door,” she said. “Don’t have your PR send flowers. They die and I’m allergic to lilies.” “That’s very specific,” he said. “Experience,” she replied. He laughed, softer. “No flowers. Got it.” He stepped out, then turned back once. “You’re not going to tell anyone I nearly hid behind the romance section, are you?” “Depends,” she said. “You planning on coming back?” His eyebrows lifted. “Should I?” “No,” she said, too fast. He smiled, more with his eyes than his mouth this time. “Right. See you, then.” “Not if I see you first,” she said, and shut the door. She slid the bolt. Stood there, palms against cool metal, listening. No shouts. No knocks. Just the rain starting up again, and the quiet thump of her heart doing something it had no business doing. “Absolutely not,” she told herself. From the storeroom, Dylan sneezed. “Exactly,” she said, and went to flip the sign to CLOSED.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter succeeds in delivering a solid meet-cute that faithfully executes both the writing prompt and the author's detailed plan. The setup is classic but handled with competent craft - a famous actor seeking refuge from paparazzi in a small Welsh bookstore creates immediate dramatic tension and clear stakes. The characterization shows strong adherence to the provided profiles. Rhys displays the expected charm layered with vulnerability - his practiced smile, his reflexive people-pleasing ("I'll pay for the mat"), and moments where the performance slips ("Please," he said, and it was quieter, the gloss slipping). Carys embodies her profile's dry wit and guardedness while showing cracks in her armor through physical tells like her mouth twitching and her too-quick "No" when asked if he should return. The dialogue carries the scene effectively with distinct voices. Rhys speaks in the measured cadences of someone accustomed to being quoted, with self-deprecating humor as armor ("That's an insult to foxes. They look less guilty"). Carys responds with economical, sharp observations that reveal character efficiently ("You smile like you're waiting for applause" would fit perfectly). The banter feels natural rather than overly polished. The Welsh setting provides grounding details without becoming touristic - the shop name "Pen a'r Don," Dylan the judgmental cat, and the sense of a small community where privacy matters. The rain and paparazzi create external pressure that drives the action forward. However, while competently executed, the chapter doesn't transcend its familiar territory. The setup is predictable celebrity-meets-civilian fare, and the chemistry, while present, emerges largely where expected. The prose is clean but occasionally falls into slightly mechanical description ("Recognition wasn't a thunderbolt. It was an irritating click"). Some dialogue exchanges, while character-appropriate, lean toward exposition ("Filming up the coast. They get bored between setups"). The emotional landscape feels authentic but not particularly surprising. Both characters behave as their archetypes would suggest, and while this serves the story's foundation-building purpose, it doesn't offer unexpected insights into either personality. The writing demonstrates professional competence in scene construction, pacing, and character consistency, making it a solid if not exceptional opening chapter that fulfills its structural requirements. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 15 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Compelling Plot: 13 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 19 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell jangled once and then not at all. Carys frowned at it, then at the clock. Five thirty. Rain again. The shop was empty, the yellow light of the lamps making a warm bubble against the grey outside. She was halfway through stacking a shipment of secondhand paperbacks—someone had died or moved; entire lives in cracked spines—when knuckles rapped on the glass of the front door. “We’re open,” she muttered, crossing the floor. On the other side, half-hidden by the reflection, Rhys Ellery was trying very hard to look like he wasn’t on the verge of knocking again. He raised a hand, sheepish. No hoodie this time; a dark coat, cap low. Sunglasses in his pocket. Fewer raindrops. Carys unlocked the door. “You remember how this works, yes? You push. Door opens. Bell rings. No headbutting necessary.” “In my defense, last time was life and death,” he said, slipping inside. “Hi.” “Hi,” she said, more clipped than she felt. The bell chimed properly behind him. He glanced up at it. “Seems I traumatized it.” “You’re not that powerful,” she said. “We close at six.” “Plenty of time,” he said. “I’m here as a legitimate paying customer. No paparazzi. I checked.” “Thorough,” she said. “Congratulations. You’ve graduated from fox to mildly suspicious sheep.” “I’m climbing the pastoral ladder,” he said. “Any recommendations for my new, rustic life?” “You actually planning to read, or is this prop shopping?” He put a hand to his heart. “You wound me.” “Only lightly,” she said, bending to drag the cardboard box onto the stool behind the till. “What are you after?” He looked around, taking in the shelves as if he hadn’t, in fact, scanned them all in a mild panic the week before. “Something to make me seem intelligent in interviews.” “Short ones, then,” she said. “Ouch.” She watched him hover near the poetry. “You don’t have to talk like that, you know.” “Like what?” “Like you’re in a press junket,” she said. “You can just say you’re bored in your hotel.” His mouth twitched. “I am bored in my hotel.” “There we go.” She pulled a book from the box, flicked through, found someone’s train ticket wedged as a bookmark. Onto the stack. He leaned his elbows on the counter, close enough that she could smell rain and clean laundry and something sharper, like the bottled version of ruggedness. “So,” he said. “Is it weird if I say thank you again? For the other day.” “Yes,” she said. “But you’re going to anyway.” “Thank you again,” he said. “It was… decent of you. You didn’t have to.” “I didn’t do it for you,” she said. “I did it to get them away from my window.” “Romantic,” he said. “Try over there,” she said, nodding to the table. “We’ve got tragedy, existential dread, and Welsh-language poetry. That should thin the herd of casual fans at least.” His gaze followed her hand. “You… don’t like what I do very much, do you.” She blinked. “That’s a leap.” “You flinch every time I say ‘interview,’” he said lightly. “And I’ve clocked that none of my stuff is anywhere visible.” She considered lying. “Your films are in the back. People find them if they care.” “Is that a moral stance or an aesthetic one?” he asked. “Bit of both,” she said. He huffed. “At least you’re honest.” “Occupational hazard,” she said. He picked up a thin volume of poetry, flicked a page. “You know, this one’s in a trailer for my last film.” “That supposed to impress me?” she asked. “I’m trying to make conversation,” he said, mock wounded. Then, lower: “I did read him. Before.” “Before you put his words over slow-motion explosions.” “Hey, the explosions were tasteful. And I liked the poems. Happy now?” “A little,” she said, which surprised both of them. His eyebrows went up. “Wow. A concession. Put it in the ledger.” She reached for the kettle behind her. “Tea?” “You don’t have to—” “I’m making it anyway,” she said. “Standing there looking tragic isn’t going to keep me entertained.” “I can juggle,” he offered. “Please don’t.” He watched as she filled the mug. The kettle clacked, hissed. “You live upstairs?” he asked. “No.” “Ah.” He considered. “Have I just violated a boundary by assuming you live among your books?” “Yes.” “Sorry.” She passed him a chipped mug that said “I read therefore I am.” “Don’t steal it.” “How do you know I’m a thief?” “You have that look.” “What look?” “The one where you think everyone wants you to take things.” His hand paused on the handle. His grin didn’t quite falter, but something in it tightened. “That’s harsh,” he said. “True,” she said. He took a sip, winced. “Hot.” “That’s what happens,” she said. “You sure you checked for cameras this time?” He nodded toward the window. “Driver dropped me round the corner. They’re all loitering up the hill. Apparently today’s urgent question is whether I’ve had my nose done.” “And have you?” she asked. “Tragically, no,” he said. “All natural. I know, I know—we’re all disappointed.” She let herself smile. “I’ve seen worse.” “Oh my God,” he said. “That’s practically a compliment.” “Don’t get used to it.” He perched on a stool opposite the counter, mug in both hands now, less actor, more person trying to thaw. “Seriously,” he said, quieter. “It means a lot. A door, a locked sign, not… screaming. Or taking a photo. Or texting your mate.” “I text Anwen everything,” Carys said. “But not that.” “Anwen?” “Café up the road,” she said. “She’d have come down with pastries and questions. Might still.” “I can handle pastries,” he said. “She’d eat you alive,” Carys said. “In a supportive way.” “I’ve had worse,” he murmured. The line hung there with more weight than it deserved. He looked down at his tea. “I know it’s… intrusive. Me, the circus. I don’t want to wreck your place.” “Then don’t,” she said simply. “I don’t always get to choose,” he said. “Everyone always says that,” she replied. “Agents, bosses, boyfriends. ‘It’s complicated.’ But it’s always a choice. Just not the easy one.” “And you always pick the hard one?” he asked. “Very noble.” “No,” she said. “Sometimes I pick the small one.” He watched her for a moment. “You really hate the whole thing, don’t you.” “I don’t know you,” she said. “I just know what happens when people think they do.” He flinched properly at that; there wasn’t a joke ready. “Fair,” he said. “Sometimes I don’t know me either.” “Too much nose speculation,” she said lightly, offering him an exit. “That, and the part where every room I walk into, people have already decided.” He rolled the mug between his palms. “Heartthrob, serious actor, diva, nice boy, whatever. I spend half my time… editing.” “Editing what?” she asked. “Me,” he said, with a crooked smile. “You ever wish people came with a fact-checker?” She set down the stack of books. “Had an ex who wrote songs about me. Does that count?” “Ouch,” he said. “Named?” “Not anymore,” she said. He laughed, short. “Alright. I like you.” “Tragic,” she said. “Finish your tea.” A car horn sounded faintly outside. He glanced at his watch. “That’s my cue. They’ll assume I fell asleep in makeup if I don’t show.” “Tragic,” she echoed. He slid off the stool, set the empty mug down carefully. “I’ll pay for the tea.” “It’s fifty pence,” she said. “I’m not invoicing Pinewood.” He pulled out a note anyway, folded it, tucked it under the edge of the till with unnecessary drama. “That doesn’t make you less in my debt,” she said. “Good,” he said lightly. “Maybe it means you’ll let me come back.” She opened her mouth to say no. What came out was: “If you don’t bring friends.” “I’ll leave them up the hill,” he said. “Promise.” “Promises are dangerous.” “I’m very careful,” he lied. She unlocked the back door for him again. The alley was wet, glistening; no one visible. He paused, hand on the frame. “Carys?” “What.” “You didn’t ask for a photo,” he said. “Or an autograph. Or a shout-out. Do you want one and you’re just very cool about it?” “No,” she said. “I have Google images. Now go.” He grinned, but there was a flicker of something like relief under it. “Right. See you.” “Or not,” she said. He stepped out. She watched until his dark shape turned left, disappeared. When she closed the door, the shop felt both emptier and too full. Dylan materialized from between boxes, hopped up on the counter, sniffed the abandoned note, and flicked it onto the floor with one paw. “My thoughts exactly,” Carys murmured. She picked up the note anyway.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully delivers on its planning objectives, building the relationship between Rhys and Carys through dialogue-heavy interaction while maintaining their established character dynamics. The writing demonstrates strong craft in several areas while containing some minor weaknesses. The dialogue carries the chapter effectively, with distinct voices for each character. Carys maintains her dry, guarded tone ("You don't have to talk like that, you know. Like you're in a press junket") while Rhys oscillates between performative charm and more genuine moments. The banter feels natural and reveals character - particularly effective is Carys's observation "You smile like you think everyone wants you to take things," which cuts to the heart of his need to be liked while showing her perceptiveness. Character development follows the established profiles well. Rhys's fragile ego appears in his reaction when she suggests he's performative, and his genuine loneliness emerges in lines like "I spend half my time... editing" himself. Carys's guardedness manifests through deflection and sarcasm, but we see cracks in her armor when she makes him tea and lets herself smile at his jokes. The writing effectively shows rather than tells their growing attraction through small gestures and conversational missteps. The structure mirrors the chapter plan closely, moving from surface-level banter to more vulnerable exchanges, ending with his departure and her conflicted feelings. The tea-making, the back alley exit, and the final image with Dylan all align with the intended beats. However, the writing occasionally feels slightly over-crafted. Some exchanges, while clever, have a constructed quality that suggests careful authorial arrangement rather than completely natural conversation. The romantic tension, while well-executed, follows somewhat predictable patterns of resistance-attraction-deflection. The prose is generally clean and effective without being purple or overwrought. Details like the chipped mug and Dylan's dismissive paw-flick add texture without excess. The pacing allows for both quick exchanges and lingering moments where deeper emotions can surface. The chapter succeeds in advancing the relationship while maintaining the characters' established barriers and motivations, creating realistic forward movement without rushing the emotional development. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 14 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The third time he came in, he used the bell properly. Carys looked up from reshelving a stack of orange-spined classics to see him standing in the doorway in a navy beanie and a jacket that tried very hard to be nondescript. “Progress,” she said. “We’re learning doors.” “I’ve been rehearsing,” Rhys said. “Hi.” “Hi,” she said, and stood on the stool to slide a book into place. She felt his eyes on the way she reached; cursed herself for noticing. “No pursuers today,” he added. “Scout’s honor.” “Were you a scout?” “No,” he admitted. “Drama club. Less mud, more eyeliner.” “Tragic,” she said. “We’re open, as you can see. You can even buy something without making it a hostage situation.” He stepped fully inside. “That’s the dream.” The bell jingled, softer this time. Rain whispered against the windows. Dylan looked over from his throne on the battered armchair, blinked once at Rhys, and tucked his head back under his paw. “Wow,” Rhys said. “Upgraded from hatred to indifference. Big day.” “You two can work it out,” Carys said. “What are we pretending you read today?” He pressed a hand melodramatically over his heart. “You wound me. Again.” “Occupational hazard,” she said. “Fiction’s that way. Poetry, there. Self-help, there, in case you want to fix any of your terrible flaws.” He followed her pointing finger, then changed direction and leaned his elbows on the counter instead. “I liked the poems,” he said. “What poems.” “The ones you recommended,” he said. “You have to stop doing that, by the way.” “Doing what.” “Being right about my insomnia,” he said. “You read it,” she said. Not a question. “Took it on set,” he said. “Got mocked relentlessly. Worth it.” “Good.” She tamped down a flicker of pleasure. “Maybe you’ll work your way up to the long ones.” “Easy,” he said. “Insult a man’s stamina right to his face.” A customer wandered in behind him. Teenage girl, backpack, wide eyes. She stopped dead. “Is that—” “No,” Carys said smoothly. “He just looks like him.” Rhys didn’t turn. “Common mistake.” The girl squinted, then flushed. “Oh. Sorry.” “No worries,” he said, tone softening. “Happens.” The girl scuttled to Young Adult. Carys gave him a look. “See? Blend.” “You’re terrifying,” he murmured, but he looked oddly relieved. He drifted towards the tables like a man unused to wandering without a camera in his wake. Ran a finger along spines, occasionally pulling one out, reading the blurb properly instead of just brandishing it. “Have you got any of mine?” he called. “In the back,” she said. “Harsh.” “Supply and demand,” she said. “I don’t need your face up here scaring Dylan.” He smirked, but his shoulders settled. “How’s business?” “Fine.” “That bad, huh.” She shot him a look. “Nosy.” “Occupational hazard,” he echoed. “People still hovering,” she admitted, nodding at the window. “Little bump after your… dramatic entrance. Gapers.” “You’re welcome,” he said lightly. “Don’t make me regret not selling your location,” she said. He laughed, then sobered. “Seriously. If it gets… bad. Tell me. Or my lot. They can at least pretend to care.” “I’ll pass,” she said. “Last thing I need is a handler in here rearranging the shelves for your brand.” He winced. “You really think it’s all that calculated?” “I think people like you don’t sneeze without someone drafting a press release,” she said. He picked up a lurid romance with a bare-chested man against a castle. Studied it. “You think I’m that important?” “I think the machine is,” she said. “Whether you are or not is above my pay grade.” He put the book down carefully, face unreadable for a beat. “What about you?” “What about me.” “Calculated, or just… sharp for the fun of it?” “Occupational hazard,” she said again, but her cheeks warmed. The teenager came to the counter with two paperbacks. Carys rang them through, made small talk about exams. Rhys browsed quietly, careful to angle his face away. When the girl left, she glanced between them once more, frowning. Rhys gave her a little two-finger salute. The door shut. “She’s going to figure it out,” Rhys said. “Probably,” Carys said. “It’s Wales. Everyone’s aunt knows everything.” “And you’ll hate that,” he said. “Yes,” she said. Another customer came and went—Mrs. Pritchard, mysteries and gardening, who saw Rhys, sniffed as if at a new wallpaper, and said, “You’re taller on the telly,” on her way out. Rhys looked stunned. Carys nearly choked. “She’s my favorite,” he whispered. “Don’t encourage her,” Carys said. “She’ll adopt you.” “Could be nice,” he said, too casual. “Don’t you already have a nation adopting you.” “Couple,” he said. “They’re noisy.” He picked up a slim novel. “This any good?” “Yes,” she said. “What’s it about?” “Lonely people making almost brave choices,” she said. “And soup.” “I’m sold,” he said. “How much bravery do you rate me on a scale of one to—” The door chimed. This time the bell’s chaos wasn’t his fault. Two girls in their twenties tumbled in, giggling. They spotted him almost instantly. “Oh my God,” one breathed. Carys felt it like someone had opened a window. Rhys straightened. Smile slid into place. “Hi.” “Can we—” Phone already out, hands shaking. “No photos in the shop,” Carys said, voice firm. “Oh, please,” the girl begged. “Just one, we’ll be quick, we’ll totally buy something.” “I’ll do one outside,” Rhys said gently. “If you want to grab your books.” They pouted, but scattered to the tables, sniping into their cameras. Carys watched his jaw work. “Sorry,” he murmured when they were out of earshot. “Not your fault,” she said. “Kind of is,” he said. They bought a notebook and a mug and left in a flutter. Through the window, Carys watched Rhys step out with them, take one quick photo under the awning, then steer them away down the street. She exhaled. Dylan flicked his tail. Rhys came back in two minutes later, damp again at the collar. “Is the ban on photos a general policy or just for my overwhelming magnetism?” “Both,” she said. “They’ll post that, you know.” “I did it out there,” he said. “Not under your sign.” She glanced past him. The corner of the shop’s name still in frame in her mind’s eye. “Doesn’t take much.” He followed her gaze, winced. “I’m sorry.” “Stop saying that,” she said, more sharply than she intended. He stilled. “I mean it.” “I know,” she said. “That’s the problem.” They looked at each other over the counter. The air felt crowded. He broke it with a half-laugh. “I can… go. Leave you to your sanctum.” “And have you luring a queue right outside?” she said. “Stay. For now. Buy your soup book.” He did. He added a dog-eared crime novel and a collection of short stories. “Big reader,” she said as she bagged them. “Big hider,” he corrected. “Books look good between me and the world.” “That’s my sales pitch,” she said. “Don’t steal it.” He slid cash across. No flourish this time. “Do you ever leave?” he asked. “Sometimes. There’s a café. Sea. Other bookless locales.” “You should come up to set,” he said, then immediately grimaced. “Sorry. That sounded like a threat.” “Yes,” she said. “It did.” “It’s not— I just meant, it’s pretty. The bay. We’re ruining it with cameras.” “I’ve seen bays,” she said. “And cameras.” “Right,” he said. “Stupid idea.” Outside, a scooter slowed. A phone lifted. The sharp insect-sound of a camera shutter reached them even through the glass. Carys’s spine stiffened. “They’re faster than fungus,” she muttered. Rhys’s mouth tightened. “I’ll go out the back.” “They already know you’re here,” she said. “They don’t need you in the shot,” he replied, very certain. She hesitated, then nodded. “Fine.” He hesitated too. “You could tell me not to come back,” he said, not quite looking at her. “I could,” she said. He waited. “Back door,” she said instead. He smiled, a quick, almost startled thing, then hid it. “See you, then.” “Bring a disguise next time,” she said. “Or a paper bag. Whole method actor thing.” “You’d miss my face,” he said. “Try me,” she said. He disappeared into the back. She heard the door open, shut. Silence. She moved to the front window. Outside, a figure with a phone pointed it at the shop, uncertain, scanning. Looking for him. Her stomach dipped. Dylan jumped into the window display and stared out with baleful golden eyes, tail lashing. “Yeah,” she murmured. “I know.” She flipped the sign to CLOSED ten minutes early.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully delivers on its intended purpose within the larger romantic arc, showing Rhys returning by choice while escalating the tension around his celebrity status threatening Carys's sanctuary. The writing demonstrates strong technical competence with natural dialogue and well-paced scene development. The character work is particularly strong. Carys's dry wit feels authentic and consistent ("We're learning doors," "Fiction's that way... Self-help, there, in case you want to fix any of your terrible flaws"), while Rhys's charm mixed with genuine vulnerability comes through convincingly. His need to be liked is shown through small actions - the way he handles the teenage fans, his relief when Mrs. Pritchard doesn't recognize him immediately, his concern about Carys's reaction to the attention. The central conflict develops organically through specific incidents rather than exposition. The progression from the teenage customer's uncertainty, to Mrs. Pritchard's blunt assessment, to the girls demanding photos creates escalating pressure that feels realistic rather than manufactured. The ending with the scooter and camera effectively sets up future complications. The dialogue serves multiple functions efficiently - revealing character, advancing plot, and maintaining the romantic tension. Lines like "I think the machine is... Whether you are or not is above my pay grade" show Carys's sharp intelligence while revealing her perspective on fame. Rhys's response reveals his insecurity about his own importance versus the celebrity apparatus. However, the chapter has some minor weaknesses. The pacing occasionally feels rushed - the "montage" effect of multiple visits isn't as clearly established as the plan suggested. Some moments could use more specificity; for instance, the book recommendations that supposedly happen over multiple visits are only briefly sketched. The romantic tension, while present, could be more precisely calibrated - sometimes their banter feels more like sparring than flirtation. The writing avoids common pitfalls of overwrought prose or forced metaphors, maintaining a clean, readable style that serves the story. The chapter builds toward its climax (the photographing) naturally while developing both characters' internal conflicts about their growing attraction despite the practical obstacles. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 14 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
She saw the photo on Anwen’s phone before she saw it anywhere else. “He’s in your bloody window,” Anwen said, slapping the mobile down on the café counter between them. A grainy shot: Rhys, half-turned, laughing at something inside Pen a’r Don, the shop sign haloed overhead. The headline: HEARTTHROB HIDES OUT IN COZY WELSH BOOK NOOK WITH MYSTERY BRUNETTE. Carys’s own coffee sloshed. “That’s not— I’m in the stockroom.” “Makes no difference,” Anwen said. “They’ve already decided it’s you. Or me. Or Mrs. Pritchard. ‘Mystery brunette’ isn’t hard to find in Aberfry.” Carys rubbed her temple. “How many people have seen this?” “Internet,” Anwen said. “So. Everyone.” By noon, Pen a’r Don was busier than it’d been in months. Girls with ring lights. Couples on weekend trips. A middle-aged man who pretended to browse but kept snapping photos of the door. Carys moved through it on autopilot. “We don’t allow filming in here, sorry.” “Yes, he did come in once. No, I don’t know where he is.” “No, I’m not her.” Some believed her. Some didn’t. Some didn’t care. “You should be thrilled,” said a woman in a brand-new raincoat, piling a stack of romances onto the counter. “Exposure! You’ll be famous.” “Lovely,” Carys said. “That’s always been the dream.” By three, her head hurt. Dylan had vanished completely. When the bell chimed again and Rhys walked in, bareheaded, no sunglasses, her stomach dropped. He took one look around at the phones, the not-very-subtle whispers, and winced. “Oh,” he said under his breath. “Bad day to sightsee,” Carys said tightly. A girl near the door whispered, “It’s him,” and lifted her mobile. “No photos inside,” Carys snapped. Rhys put up a hand. “She’s serious,” he said, still gentle. “Please. Buy your books, yeah?” The girl’s hand trembled, but she lowered it. For now. He crossed to the counter. “Can we talk?” “We’re talking,” she said, scanning a cookbook. Her chest felt tight. “Somewhere that’s not—” He gestured at the roomful of ears. She put the book in a bag. “That would require privacy.” “I can buy out the shop for half an hour,” he said. “Like a villain. Lock the doors.” “And confirm everything they’re already inventing?” she said. “Excellent strategy.” He hissed in a breath. “I didn’t call them. I swear.” “I know how cameras work,” she said. “They smell blood. Or your aftershave.” A woman at the nearest shelf pretended to read but was clearly listening, phone poised at her hip. Rhys noticed; his jaw tightened. “Can we at least…” He lowered his voice. “Back room?” “No,” she said. “Not when every person in here is waiting to post that.” He flinched. Deserved or not, it landed. “Carys,” he said. “Do you need help finding anything?” she called past him, bright, fake-shopkeeper cheer. “No, no, just browsing,” lied everyone. He leaned closer. “At least say you know I didn’t sell you out.” She did know that, in some rational part. The irrational one was busy cataloguing strange faces in her safe place. “I know you’re the reason they’re here,” she said. His expression shuttered. “That’s not the same.” “It is from where I’m standing,” she said. He straightened. There it was: the flick of his shoulders, the subtle shift into something smoother. “Fine,” he said, too lightly. “I’ll get out of your way. Again.” “Use the front,” she said. “They’re already frothing. Might as well give them a show.” He looked at her like she’d slapped him. Then he smiled—thin, brittle. “You are… brutal.” “Occupational hazard,” she said, and hated herself for how automatic it sounded. He turned away. At the door, someone asked for a selfie. He said yes. Of course he did. The flash caught the edge of her display. When he’d gone, the hum grew louder. Mystery Brunette. That’s her. No, it’s not, she’s older. She’s too cranky. Maybe he likes cranky. Hashtag BookshopBae. By closing, her throat ached from polite refusals. She locked the door, turned the sign, and sagged back against the wood. Dylan emerged from somewhere high, yawned, and wound around her calves, fur bristling. “Traitor,” she murmured to the empty shop. She wasn’t sure which of them she meant. — He came back after dark. She didn’t hear the door—it was locked—but she heard the knock. Two quick, one slow, like an apology. She should have ignored it. She opened it. Rhys stood there in a hoodie, hood up. No cameras behind him. Rain on his shoulders. “Hi,” he said. “We’re closed,” she said. “I know.” He held up his hands. “Just—can we talk now? Without an audience?” She hesitated, then stepped aside. He slipped in. The dark-shop version of Pen a’r Don wrapped around them: lamplight, paper, ghost air. “I’m sorry,” he said immediately. She crossed her arms. “For what, specifically?” “For the photo. For them swarming. For existing in your postcode,” he said. “For saying you’re brutal. That was… shitty.” “You’re only sorry because it’s messy,” she said. “Because I’m not smiling for the nice story.” He flinched. “That’s not fair.” “Isn’t it?” she asked, heat rising. “You walk in here, twice, three times, looking for—what? Local color? A refuge? And you bring all this with you, and when I don’t turn it into your cute little indie-movie montage, I’m ‘brutal.’” “It wasn’t like that,” he said. “I came because—” He stopped, visibly editing. “Because it was quiet. And you weren’t… impressed. And I could breathe for five minutes.” “Congratulations,” she said. “Your asthma attack is my life.” “That’s not what I—” He scrubbed a hand over his face. “Look, I’m not defending them. Or the article. It makes me sick, seeing your sign in that headline. I’ve spent all day telling my team to shut it down.” “Can they?” she asked. “Can they un-post it from a million accounts?” “No,” he admitted. “But they can stop adding fuel. No comments, no cutesy quotes, no ‘sources say he’s in love with a Welsh bookshop owner’ bollocks.” Her chest pulled. “They said that?” “Give them a day,” he muttered. “Look, I’m trying. I don’t want to… ruin this place.” “Then stay away,” she said. The words landed between them, heavy. He stared at her. “Is that what you want?” “Yes,” she said. It came out too fast. His mouth twitched, hurt and something like offense. The ego part. “Right,” he said. “Well. Fair enough.” He turned for the door. “Do you even hear yourself?” she blurted. He stopped. “Pardon?” “You say you’re trying, you ‘don’t want’ to make it worse,” she said. “But you wander in here like you’re a bloke on his lunch break. You pose outside because you’re too nice to say no. You check if I’m thrilled to be in a headline. You apologize, but you never actually change anything.” He swung back. “What do you want me to do, Carys? Punch photographers? Set my contract on fire? Every time I walk out my front door, somebody decides it means something. That’s my life.” “And this is mine,” she said, gesturing at the shelves, the dim lamps. “I chose this. I didn’t choose to be your subplot.” “Nobody asked you to be,” he shot back. “You keep acting like I dragged you into some romcom. I came here for a book and a cup of tea and a door that locked.” “People like you,” she said, voice low, “always say that.” His jaw clenched. “People like me.” “Performers. Charmers. Men who think the mess that follows them is unavoidable, so everyone else should just live with it.” That one hit. She saw it. “That’s not fair,” he said again, but quieter. “You don’t know me.” “You don’t know me, either,” she said. “But that hasn’t stopped other people from telling my story.” Silence cracked between them. Dylan jumped onto the counter, tail flicking, sensing weather. Rhys’s shoulders dropped a fraction. When he spoke, the polish was gone. “I’m not using you,” he said. “I don’t want you in any story. I wanted—” He broke off, swallowed. “I liked it here. That’s all.” “And that’s the problem,” she said, softer. “Your liking something is a spotlight.” He looked away, blinking hard once. Then he laughed—short, hollow. “Christ. You know what’s funny?” he said. “I thought, for a minute, you saw me. Not just the… machine.” “I did,” she said, before she could stop it. He looked back, quick. “That’s why I’m angry,” she added. “Because I know you can’t come without it.” He nodded slowly. “Okay.” The word hung there, accepting nothing. “I’ll stay away,” he said. “Since that’s… apparently the least I can do.” “Good,” she said. Neither moved. “Take care of yourself,” he added, and it sounded wrong in his mouth: backwards, like he should be saying it in a trailer, not here. “Don’t tell me what to do,” she said, with no heat left. He almost smiled. “There she is.” Then he opened the door and walked out into the rain, no hood, no cap, no disguise. A flash went off as if on cue. He didn’t look back. The bell clanged once, stupidly cheerful. Dylan hissed at the door. Carys locked it, leaned her forehead against the glass, and finally let herself swear.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 4)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively delivers on its planned purpose as the story's first major rupture, showing both characters behaving imperfectly under pressure. The writing successfully escalates from the tabloid photo revelation through the shop invasion to the painful confrontation. The dialogue is largely strong, maintaining distinct character voices throughout. Carys's sharp, defensive wit ("Lovely. That's always been the dream") contrasts well with Rhys's performative charm that gradually breaks down under stress. The argument feels authentic rather than manufactured, with both characters landing genuinely hurtful blows that reveal their deeper fears and insecurities. The chapter adheres closely to both the writing prompt's character dynamics and the detailed chapter plan. Rhys's fragile ego and need for approval are clearly demonstrated when he shifts into "celebrity mode" after being rejected. Carys's protective instincts about her sanctuary and her past wounds from "performers" drive her harsh responses in believable ways. The emotional stakes feel earned. The conflict isn't melodramatic but stems naturally from their incompatible worlds colliding. The line "Your liking something is a spotlight" effectively captures the central tension. However, there are some weaker elements. Certain expository passages feel heavy-handed ("By noon, Pen a'r Don was busier than it'd been in months"). Some dialogue, while generally strong, occasionally feels slightly constructed for effect rather than completely natural. The phrase "ghost air" ventures into questionable poetic territory, though such moments are rare. The pacing works well, building tension through the day's events before exploding in the evening confrontation. The chapter maintains coherence throughout and advances both character development and plot effectively. Dylan's brief appearances provide grounding details without feeling forced. The writing mostly stays grounded and avoids purple prose, maintaining the clean, dialogue-driven style established in earlier chapters. The conflict reveals character depth rather than just advancing plot mechanics. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 7 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
It took three days for the shop to breathe again. The worst of the gawkers drifted off once the headline slid down the feeds, replaced by newer scandals. A few lingered: couples taking selfies outside, the odd blogger with a ring light. Carys held the line. “No filming inside.” “No, he’s not here.” “Books or the door, your choice.” By the fourth morning, it was mostly hers again. Locals, students, Mrs. Pritchard grumbling about plot holes, Anwen dropping off pastries as penance for the screenshot. “You look like you’ve been chewing nails,” Anwen observed, leaning on the counter. “Sleep at all?” “Dreamed in hashtags,” Carys said. “Deeply restful.” She had not heard from Rhys. Relief and something sharper tangled in her chest every time her phone lit up and it wasn’t him. “Have you checked what they’re saying?” Anwen asked. “No.” “I have,” Anwen said. “He’s… actually told some show to back off. Said his off-set life is ‘nobody’s business.’ Grumpy face and everything.” Carys shrugged, the motion tight. “Good for him.” Anwen watched her. “You miss him in here.” “I miss quiet,” Carys said. Anwen made a disbelieving noise and left her a cinnamon bun big enough to be insulting. — He came back on a Tuesday, because of course he did. Late, when the shop was empty and sky already thinking about dusk. Carys was halfway through rearranging a display—poetry up front again, on principle—when a shadow crossed the door. He stood there, not coming in. Cap, no sunglasses. He raised a hand in a cautious half-wave. She should have pretended not to see. Instead, she walked over and unlocked the door. “We’re closing,” she said. “I know,” Rhys said. “Can I have five minutes before you slam it in my face?” “That depends what for,” she said. “To apologize. Properly.” “You’ve tried that,” she said. “I was shit at it,” he said. “Let me try again.” A better person would have said no. She stepped aside. He came in like a man entering a chapel, shoulders rounded, gaze flicking to corners as if checking for lenses. There were none. “Hi,” he said. “You said that,” she replied. He huffed. “Right. Um.” He pulled off his cap, ran a hand through his hair, stalled. “They wanted me to talk about you.” “I said no,” she said immediately, more statement than question. “I said no,” he echoed. “Several times. Loudly. Which for me is… you know. Growth.” “Congratulations,” she said, but some tension unwound a fraction. “They pitched this whole narrative,” he went on, words gaining speed. “Small-town muse, ‘grounding influence,’ very gritty, very charming. I told them if they even said ‘bookshop girl’ on air, I’d walk.” She searched his face for performance. There was some; there was always some. But beneath it she saw real anger. “And they listened?” she asked. “I’m not sure,” he admitted. “But I did what I could. No quotes. No coy smiles. No selling you off as an anecdote.” “You want a medal?” she asked. “No,” he said, fast. “I just… wanted you to know I’m not… using this. You.” Silence stretched. Dylan hopped up onto the counter, tail flicking, eyes narrowed at Rhys. “Hi, mate,” Rhys said quietly. “Hate me a bit less today?” Dylan showed him his back. Carys let out a breath that was almost a laugh. “He’s very principled.” “Figures,” Rhys said. “Look, the other night—I said some stupid things. You’re not brutal. You’re—” “Don’t,” she cut in. “Don’t pivot to compliments because your conscience hurts.” He winced. “Okay. That’s fair.” He held the edge of the nearest shelf, like he needed something solid. “I am sorry. I keep… doing the thing you said. Apologizing instead of changing.” “Yes,” she said. “I’ve been thinking about that,” he said. “And it’s not that I don’t want to change. It’s that I genuinely don’t know how to be any other way half the time. It’s all performing, all the time. I walk into a room, it’s: smile, be nice, give them what they want, or you’re the arsehole in the headline. And then I walk in here and you look at me like a human barometer and I still… do it.” “A human what,” she said, despite herself. “Measuring how much bullshit I’m emitting,” he said. “That’s not a bad line,” she admitted. “I’m tragically good at lines,” he said. “That’s the problem.” Something in the honesty of that knocked her off her script. “I know it’s not all your fault,” she said, reluctantly. “But you do make choices.” “I know,” he said. “I made one, about this. About you. I’m not talking about you out there. Full stop.” He gestured vaguely toward the invisible cameras. “If they want a story, they can make one up without help.” “They already did,” Carys said. “Yeah,” he said. “And I can’t fix that. But I can decide not to… endorse it.” She watched him, wary. “And what do you want from me, exactly?” He swallowed. “Honestly? I’d like to still be allowed to come in here. Buy books. Drink your aggressively hot tea. Not be glared at by your cat.” “Those are not negotiable as a package,” she said. He half-smiled. “Figured.” She leaned back against the counter. “If you come in here, they might follow. Again. That’s not hypothetical. That’s my rent.” “I know,” he said. “So we make rules. You tell me when it’s okay. Early, late. If there’s a cluster of phones, I keep walking. No more popping by at midday in full… Ellery mode.” “Difficult for you,” she said. “You’d be surprised how much I’d like to be boring,” he said. “And you don’t talk about this place,” she added. “Anywhere.” “I won’t,” he said. “Cross my… everything.” “Very binding,” she said. He lifted his hands. “That’s all I can offer. That, and my very good customer loyalty. I’m on my third book, by the way. I’m basically keeping local literature afloat.” “That’s my job,” she said. But her voice had softened. He noticed. Didn’t pounce on it. “I also owe you for the emotional damage of that headline,” he said. “If you want me to buy every copy so no one else reads it, I will.” “Tempting,” she said. They let the quiet settle. It wasn’t comfortable, but it wasn’t hostile. “You’re still angry,” he said, not as an accusation. “Yes,” she said. “Okay,” he said. “You’re allowed.” She blinked. “That’s new.” “I had a whole speech on the drive over,” he confessed. “About how I’m just a victim of my circumstances and you misunderstood me. It was very moving. Don’t worry, I binned it.” “Progress,” she said. “I’m trying,” he said, and for once, there was no irony on it. She studied him for a long beat. “Fine. Conditions.” He straightened, wary and hopeful. “Hit me.” “Don’t,” she said. “One: no mention of this shop or anyone in it in any public thing. Two: if you see people aiming lenses at the window, you turn around. You don’t come in. Three: if I tell you to leave, you leave. No debate. Four: you stop assuming that just because you like being here, it’s automatically good for me.” He nodded after each, solemn as a schoolboy. “Done. Done. Obviously. And… I’m sorry about that last one.” “And five,” she added. He winced. “There’s a five.” “If you ever try to fix something by throwing money at it,” she said, “I will feed you to Mrs. Pritchard.” He grimaced, remembering. “Noted. Terrifying woman.” “She survived three divorces and the Thatcher years,” Carys said. “You’re nothing.” His laugh came out surprised. “Fair.” She let her shoulders drop a fraction. “You can come by. Sometimes. On those terms.” He exhaled slowly. Relief, visible. “Thank you.” “This is not… anything,” she warned. “I know,” he said. “It’s just a… door. Sometimes open.” “Don’t get poetic,” she said. “You’ve got professionals for that.” He glanced at the front window. The street outside was empty, only the reflection of shelves and their small table of poetry. “Since you’re here,” she said, if only to break the look on his face, “you wanted more insomnia fuel?” He brightened, cautiously. “Please. If I’m allowed.” She pulled a slim volume from behind her. “Try this. Less explosions, more existential dread.” “Very on-brand,” he said, taking it. Their fingers brushed; she pretended not to feel the small jolt. He cleared his throat. “How much do I owe you?” “Nine fifty,” she said. He paid without theatrics. As she handed him the change, he didn’t let go immediately. “Carys,” he said. “What.” “I do see you,” he said quietly. “Not just the shop.” She snatched her hand back like she’d been burned. “That’s unfortunate.” “I know,” he said, and this time, he left it there. She led him to the back door. Dylan watched from the counter, inscrutable. “At least thirty hours between visits,” she said. “Minimum.” “Are we rationing me?” he asked. “Yes.” “I’ll make them count, then.” “Go.” He stepped into the alley. Paused. “For what it’s worth,” he said, “this is the only place this week where no one’s asked me to be anything on camera. That’s… a lot.” “Don’t get attached,” she said. He smiled, small. “Trying not to.” He disappeared into the blue-grey evening. Carys shut the door, leaned against it, and let out a breath she didn’t remember holding. Dylan jumped down, rubbed against her shin. “Oh, now you approve,” she muttered. She picked up the cinnamon bun Anwen had left, tore off a piece, and thought about doors that were sometimes open.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully executes a delicate reconciliation scene that feels both emotionally honest and true to the established character dynamics. The writing demonstrates strong control over pacing and dialogue, allowing the tentative rebuilding of trust between Rhys and Carys to unfold naturally rather than rushing toward resolution. The character work is particularly strong. Rhys shows genuine growth—his apology feels different from previous attempts because he acknowledges his patterns rather than just making excuses. His line about being "tragically good at lines" and his admission that he "binned" his victim speech shows self-awareness without becoming overly therapy-speak. Carys maintains her protective boundaries while allowing small cracks in her armor, like her almost-laugh at Dylan's behavior and her eventual agreement to let him return. Both characters remain recognizably themselves while showing movement. The dialogue feels authentic and distinct. Carys's dry deflections ("That's unfortunate" in response to "I see you") and Rhys's mix of vulnerability and habitual charm create a believable push-pull dynamic. The conversation avoids the trap of being too neat or therapeutic—there's still tension and wariness even as they find their way to compromise. The practical establishment of boundaries gives the reconciliation weight. Rather than grand gestures, the resolution comes through specific, actionable agreements that acknowledge the real-world consequences of his fame. This grounded approach keeps the romance from feeling fantastical. The chapter does miss one planned beat—Rhys was supposed to offer financial help and be rebuffed, which would have added another layer to his learning process. The emotional arc still works without it, but that misstep would have reinforced his tendency to solve problems with money rather than understanding. Minor observational details (Dylan's reactions, the cinnamon bun, the empty street) ground the scene without overwriting. The prose stays clean and functional, avoiding purple tendencies while maintaining atmosphere. The chapter succeeds in moving the relationship forward while maintaining the established tensions and character dynamics. It feels like a genuine step in their development rather than a forced plot advancement. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 14 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Rhys stuck to the thirty-hour rule. It only made it worse. He came early: ten minutes before opening, or late, five after she flipped the sign. Always alone. Always checking the street first. Sometimes he bought something. Sometimes he sat on the arm of Dylan’s chair until Dylan nipped him and Carys told him he deserved it. It settled into something that almost looked like normal. Almost. — Tuesday morning. Grey sky pressed against the windows. The smell of wet coats and coffee. Carys was untangling a string of fairy lights that had suicidally knotted themselves when the key turned in the lock from the outside. She frowned. Only Anwen had— The door eased open. Rhys squeezed through, holding two takeaway cups. “You gave her a key?” Carys demanded. “Good morning to you too,” Anwen’s voice called from behind him. “He was early. I supervise.” Anwen thrust a bag at Carys, kissed her cheek, and vanished again with a conspiratorial wiggle of fingers. Rhys set one cup on the counter. “Truce offering.” “If that’s some chain,” Carys warned, “I’ll throw it out.” “Local. Promise.” He tapped the lid. “Flat white. Oat milk. I asked.” She narrowed her eyes. “You asked Anwen.” “She’s terrifying,” he said. “I listen to terrifying women now.” “Progress,” she said, but she took the cup. He wandered to the poetry table. Picked up the book she’d given him last time, thumb tucked at a page like he’d been mid-read. “You didn’t hate it,” she said. “Depressing as hell,” he said. “In a good way.” “High praise.” “I liked how nobody in it gets what they want, but they keep… trying anyway,” he said, frowning thoughtfully. “It felt accurate.” She looked at him, surprised. “You’re very bad at selling your films.” “I’m on break,” he said. “No brand obligations in here, remember?” “Careful,” she said. “You’ll start sounding real.” He flipped a page. “Can’t have that.” A bell tolled from the chapel up the hill. The town was slow to wake. For once, the quiet felt like theirs. “Got plans tonight?” he asked, too casually. “Yes,” she said. “Liar,” he replied. “Work,” she amended. “Stocktake.” “Riveting,” he said. “You ever let anyone help?” “Yes.” “Liar again.” She busied herself with a stack of receipts. “Why.” “There’s a… thing,” he said. “Down at the hall. Poetry and pints. They roped me into reading something if I’m around. I thought… you might come. Or laugh at me from the back. Your choice.” She stared. “They roped you in.” “I may have volunteered,” he admitted. “It seemed better than signing another headshot.” “And you want me to watch.” “I want you to tell me if I’m awful,” he said. “And maybe, selfishly, to see you somewhere that isn’t hiding behind this counter.” She bristled. “I don’t hide.” He lifted a shoulder. “Okay.” “I run a business,” she said. “I know,” he said. “Important one. I’m not saying quit and come be my… whatever. Just. Take a night.” “No,” she said automatically. “Dare you,” he said. She shot him a look. “What are you, twelve?” “Thirteen,” he said. “Emotionally.” He left it there, didn’t push. Bought a dog-eared sci-fi he claimed was “research” and left through the alley. — She did not plan to go. She went anyway. The community hall smelled of beer, dust, and ambition. Fold-out chairs, a wobbly mic stand, a handwritten sign: POETRY & PINTS – OPEN MIC – BE KIND. Carys hovered at the back, half behind a pillar. Anwen spotted her and beamed. “You came!” “I hate you,” Carys muttered. “Love you too,” Anwen said, dragging her toward a seat. Rhys was at the front, talking to the organizer. No cap, no disguise, just a dark jumper and jeans. He looked… smaller, somehow. Less lit. He saw her. His face did a brief, unguarded thing—something like pleased panic—before he smoothed it out. He got called up halfway through. “Local boy made… somewhat large,” the MC said, to laughter. Rhys took the mic, did a jokey bow, then unfolded a crumpled page. “I was going to read one of my own,” he said. “Then I remembered humility is good for the soul.” He read instead from the poet Carys had first recommended. His voice, stripped of camera-work, found a different register: softer, less performative. People listened. Carys watched his hands shake, just slightly. After, in the mingling hum, he drifted toward her. “Was it awful?” he asked. “You pronounced everything correctly,” she said. “Miraculous.” “That’s a no on awful?” he pressed. “It was fine,” she said. “You didn’t explode. Nobody threw things.” “For you, that’s rapturous praise,” he said. “Do I get a gold star?” “No,” she said. “Beer?” he offered. “I’m working tomorrow,” she said. “So am I,” he said. “And yet.” She hesitated. There were eyes on them. Not cameras, but locals. Curious, fond, assessing. “One,” she said. They ended up outside with plastic cups, leaning against the low wall overlooking the dark curve of the bay. Wind pulled at her hair. “That was brave,” she said, surprising herself. He blinked. “Reading? It’s literally my job.” “Not like that,” she said. “With your own hands shaking. No retakes.” He looked down at his knuckles. “Yeah, well. Easier here.” “Because they know you,” she said. “Because they don’t expect anything but a bloke trying not to cock up the line breaks,” he said. “No one’s paying for a ticket.” “That too,” she conceded. He watched her as she sipped. “Thank you for coming.” “I came for the free verse,” she said. “Liar,” he said gently. The word sat between them, more tender than teasing. She cleared her throat. “You’ll catch a cold.” “Good,” he said. “Maybe they’ll postpone the reshoots.” An awkward silence. Wind, waves, muffled mic from inside. “You’re good at this,” he said finally. “At what?” “Making me feel like an idiot,” he said. “Without actually… humiliating me.” “It’s a gift,” she said. “Use it for good.” “I’d like to,” he said. “If you’ll let me.” She looked at him, sharply. “Don’t.” “Don’t what?” “Don’t turn this into—” She gestured vaguely between them. “You. Me. A story. It’s not.” “I didn’t say it was,” he said. “I just—” “You’re leaving when they’re done up there,” she cut in. “And then what? I get upgraded from ‘mystery brunette’ to ‘tragic inspiration’ in some profile?” He flinched. “That’s not— I’m not him.” “I know,” she said. “Which is worse.” He frowned. “How is that worse?” “Because you almost mean it,” she said. “And you’re almost kind. And you almost stop yourself before you say the thing they want you to say. And that’s the version that’s dangerous.” He stared at her, rain starting to freckle his hair. “I can’t win with you, can I?” “That’s the point,” she said quietly. “I’m not something you win at.” “I know,” he said, exasperated. “I’m not trying to score points. I just like talking to you. I like this place. I like—” He cut himself off, jaw tight. She swallowed. “You like being liked.” “Yeah,” he said. “That, too. Guess I’m not unique.” The admission disarmed her more than any denial would have. Inside, someone massacred a sonnet. They both winced. “Come by tomorrow,” she said, before she could stop herself. He blinked. “Are you rationing down?” “I need help with boxes,” she said. “You have arms. They’re insured, probably.” “They are,” he said. “I’ll bring the policy.” She shook her head, but she was smiling. “Don’t be late.” “Yes, boss,” he said. She started back toward the hall. He caught her wrist, brief, gentle. “Carys.” “What.” “I’m not going to write songs about you,” he said. “Or sell you for clicks.” She tried for a joke. It came out thin. “Your loss.” “My loss if you never believe me,” he said. She pulled her hand free. “Eight o’clock,” she said. “Bring coffee.” — He was on time. With coffee. And a packet of biscuits. “You bribing me?” she asked. “Consider it hazard pay,” he said. He carried boxes like he meant it; knocked over one small display; apologized profusely. She called him useless; he tried harder. Dylan watched, intermittently swatting his shoelaces. In the middle of hefting a box to the top shelf, he swore softly. “What?” she asked. “Nothing. Just… this is heavy,” he said. “Actor arms failing you?” she said. “Tragic,” he puffed. She laughed, and this time it surprised them both. He froze, grinning. “There it is.” “Shut up,” she said, but without venom. They worked in companionable silence for a bit. He opened one box, pulled out a paperback with a laughably dramatic cover: shirtless man, wind-swept cliffs. “Please tell me this is supposed to be me,” he said. “Obviously,” she said. “We keep it in Horror.” He pretended to clutch his pearls. “I’m buying ten.” “You’re not allowed,” she said. “They’re for mocking purposes.” “Harsh.” He slid it back. The stupid cover stuck out at an angle. Later she found he’d tucked it behind an obscure poetry collection, like a shared joke. When he left that evening, through the back, jacket slung over his shoulder, it felt less like an incursion and more like… someone clocking off. Carys locked up after him, heart annoyingly light. Dylan jumped onto the till, looked at her. “Don’t,” she said. He blinked. “It’s nothing,” she told the empty shop. The knot in her chest said otherwise.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter demonstrates solid craft in developing the central relationship between Rhys and Carys, with several notable strengths and a few areas where it falls short of its potential. The writing effectively captures the gradual shift from wariness to tentative intimacy. The opening "thirty-hour rule" establishes a believable rhythm of careful interaction, and the progression through coffee, the poetry reading, and working together feels organic. The dialogue maintains the distinct voices established earlier - Carys's dry deflections ("I hate you" to Anwen) and Rhys's self-deprecating charm ("Thirteen. Emotionally.") remain consistent and authentic. The emotional core of the chapter works well, particularly in moments like Carys's complex analysis of why Rhys is dangerous: "Because you almost mean it... And that's the version that's dangerous." This shows sophisticated understanding of romantic psychology and avoids simple good/bad characterization. The poetry reading sequence effectively uses Rhys's vulnerability (shaking hands, no retakes) to deepen both characters. However, the chapter doesn't fully deliver on its planned arc. According to the detailed outline, this chapter was meant to culminate in their first kiss, but instead ends with Carys denying her feelings to an empty shop. While this creates tension, it leaves the chapter feeling incomplete against its stated goals. The prose remains clean and controlled, avoiding purple flourishes while maintaining emotional resonance. Small details like Dylan's reactions and the hidden romance novel create texture without overwhelming the central dynamic. The Welsh setting continues to feel authentic rather than decorative. Some dialogue exchanges, while competent, don't always feel completely distinctive - both characters occasionally slip into similar cadences of witty deflection. The chapter also follows fairly predictable romance beats (reluctant attendance, growing closeness, emotional walls) without adding much surprise to the familiar structure. The emotional progression feels earned, building naturally on established character dynamics rather than forcing artificial drama. Carys's internal conflict between attraction and self-protection remains compelling, while Rhys's growing authenticity away from his public persona continues to develop convincingly. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 13 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 6 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 11 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
They told him between takes, in a drafty church dressed as a courtroom. Big American director. Dark, polished wood. Fake jury. Real stakes. “It’s prestige,” his agent said over speaker. “Awards bait. Six months in Toronto, a month in L.A. for press. This is what you’ve been wanting.” Rhys stared at the call sheet in his hand, the new script pages in the other. “When.” “Three weeks,” his agent said. “We’ll rejig the current schedule. It’s doable.” “And the… personal stuff,” a PR voice chimed in. “We’ll need clean lines. Simple message. Single or taken, but something controllable. We really should bury the ‘bookshop’ chatter; it muddies the image.” He thought of Pen a’r Don’s bell. Dylan’s disdain. Carys’s hand snatching away from his. “Bury it how,” he asked. “Either starve it—no comment, no oxygen,” the PR said. “Or override it with a more fun story. Co-star angle, maybe. We can discuss.” He imagined some bright young actress, hand on his arm in a pap-shot outside a restaurant. Headlines. #Goals. “Not doing a fake romance,” he said. “We’ll talk,” the PR repeated, like he’d said nothing. He hung up more abruptly than they liked. On lunch, he sat on a step by the trailers and stared at his phone. A draft text to Carys blinked at him: Need to talk. Got news. He deleted it. Typed: Big job. Then deleted that too. He tried again. Can I come by tonight? Actually need your opinion on soup-level bravery. He sent it before he could edit the charm out. — Pen a’r Don was quiet at closing time. The new fairy lights slid a warm glow along the poetry shelf. Carys was doing the float count when he appeared in the doorway, hood up, hands in pockets. “You’re late,” she said. “Dramatic day,” he said. “Hi.” She watched him. Something in his posture was different—tighter. “You look like someone cancelled Christmas,” she said. “Opposite,” he said. “They’re trying to give me everything I said I wanted.” “And this is bad because.” “Because I’m an ungrateful bastard?” he offered. “Accurate,” she said. “Explain.” He sat on the edge of the chair Dylan wasn’t using. Dylan shot him a withering look and relocated to the counter. “They want me for a big film,” Rhys said. “Serious one. The kind that gets golden statues. Six months away. Maybe longer.” “Congratulations,” Carys said. It came out flat. She cleared her throat. “That’s… good. Isn’t it.” “Yeah,” he said. “It is.” “And?” she prodded. “And PR wants to tidy up the narrative,” he said. “Their words. ‘Cut the noise.’ Either I’m very eligible and very available, or I’m in a… marketable relationship.” “Marketable,” she repeated. The word tasted like grit. “Yep,” he said. “They suggested we ‘lean into’ the bookshop thing. Or,” he added quickly at her expression, “we find a convenient co-star to be seen having brunch with.” Carys set the till drawer down harder than necessary. Coins jumped. “And what did you say.” “I said no to using you,” he said. “Obviously. I told them you’re not a prop.” “That must have impressed them,” she said coolly. “I don’t care,” he said. “But they’re not wrong that… whatever this is, is going to get attention if it leaks. And I don’t know how to—I don’t want to make your life worse.” The phrase landed between them. Whatever this is. She crossed her arms. “You came here to warn me before your next carefully curated scandal.” “No,” he said, frustrated. “I came here because I— Christ, can you for one second assume I’m not just a walking press release?” “No,” she said. “Because you’re not just that. That’s the problem.” He stared. “Explain that.” She chewed the inside of her cheek. “If you were only shallow, this would be easy. I’d pat your pretty head, sell your signed merchandise, and watch you go. But you’re… not. You’re here lugging boxes and reading poems and pretending Dylan doesn’t scare you. And then, in the next breath, you’re talking about marketable narratives.” “I’m not,” he said. “They are.” “You are part of ‘they,’ Rhys,” she said. “You benefit from it. You don’t get to wash your hands when it’s inconvenient.” He recoiled, hurt flaring. “So what, I’m the bastard no matter what I do?” “You’re a grown man,” she said. “You decide whether you’re okay being photographed on some rooftop with a co-star while the internet debates if you dumped your mystery bookshop fling.” “I’m not dumping anyone,” he snapped. “We’re not—” He stopped. “Exactly,” she said. There it was. “That’s not fair,” he said, again. “You’re the one who keeps this as… not a thing. Your rules, your door.” “And you keep pushing,” she said softly. “With coffee and poems and invitations. Then you act shocked I might care what happens next.” They stared at each other, something raw and stupid laid bare. He scrubbed a hand down his face. “I like you,” he said. “I don’t know how to… phrase that without you thinking it’s PR.” “Try without a camera in mind,” she said. He swallowed. Dropped his gaze. “I look forward to seeing you more than I look forward to hearing ‘action.’ I think about what you’d say about scripts I’m sent. I… check my phone for your sarcastic texts that don’t come. And when they offered me this job, you were the first person I wanted to tell who wasn’t being paid to care.” Silence. The fairy lights hummed. He huffed out a breath. “There. That’s my unbranded answer.” Her heart did a dangerous thing. She gripped the counter. “You should take it,” she said. He blinked. “Did you hear—” “You should take the job,” she repeated. “You’ve worked for it. You want it.” “I want…” He stopped, choked a little laugh. “I want both.” “Life’s greedy,” she said. “It doesn’t always do both.” “That’s very bleak,” he said. “Even for you.” “What do you expect me to say?” she asked. “Stay? Don’t go? Turn down the film so you can sit on that chair until Dylan accepts you? That would be insane.” “A tiny part of me wouldn’t mind hearing it,” he admitted. She stared. “Your ego is enormous.” “Yeah,” he said. “And it’s currently begging, so that’s new.” She inhaled sharply. “Okay, well. I’m not saying it.” “Of course you’re not,” he said, hurt shading into anger. “Because I’m apparently incapable of meaning anything I say.” “That’s not what I said,” she shot back. “You don’t trust me,” he said. “Not really. You trust your opinion of me more than anything I could do to change it.” “That’s rich, coming from a man whose job is pretending,” she said. “And what do you do?” he snapped. “Hide in here and pretend the world doesn’t exist? Judge everyone who walks through the door like it’s an exam?” Her stomach dropped. “Get out.” He took a breath, shook his head. “I didn’t—” “No,” she said, steady. “You meant it.” He stepped closer, frustrated. “I meant that you act like you’re the only one protecting something. Like I don’t spend half my life clawing back pieces of myself from strangers.” “Well, your claw marks are on my door,” she said. “This is all I have. I can’t pack it up in a suitcase and fly to Toronto when it gets loud.” He flinched. “That’s not fair.” “Maybe not,” she said. “Neither is any of this.” He looked like he wanted to argue, then deflated. “I don’t know how to do this,” he said. “Any of it. Be your… friend? Whatever. And also be the thing they want. I’m trying, and all I get from you is—” “Protection,” she said. “From getting flattened again.” “I’m not him,” he said quietly. “I know,” she whispered. “Which means if you hurt me, it counts.” That shut him up. He looked at her a long moment. Something in his face—hurt, yes, but also understanding, dawning slow. “I leave in three weeks,” he said. “Probably less, knowing them. I don’t want to walk out of here with you thinking I chose some PR stunt over you. Or that I didn’t care enough.” “Then don’t give them a stunt,” she said. “Take your job. Do it well. Don’t lie for them. That’s it.” “And you?” he asked. “What do you do?” “I stay,” she said. “I lock my door. I sell books. I make tea. I hope nobody else sticks a camera in my face.” “That’s it?” he asked, disbelief and a bit of despair. “What else is there,” she said. He laughed once, hopelessly. “Us, maybe?” “There is no ‘us,’” she said, more sharply than she felt. “There’s you, trying to be sincere, and me, trying very hard not to be stupid.” “Right,” he said. The word scraped. “Okay.” He stepped back. Shoulders squared. The actor slid over him like armor. “I won’t drag your name into it,” he said. “Whatever happens. That, at least, I can promise.” “Thank you,” she said. It hurt. “And if I text,” he added, “and you don’t answer—” “Then I don’t answer,” she said. He nodded, jaw working. “Got it.” He hesitated like he might cross the space between them, say something else. Then he turned instead. “Goodbye, Carys,” he said. “Good luck, Rhys,” she replied. He left through the front, just once not avoiding the risk. A camera flashed across the street, greedy as always. The bell rang. The door shut. Carys stood in the quiet shop, the words “There is an us, you idiot,” burning the back of her throat. She didn’t say them. Dylan jumped onto the counter, meowed. “Don’t start,” she said. “We’re being sensible.” Her heart, unhelpfully, disagreed.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively delivers the planned emotional climax of the story, bringing external career pressures to bear on Rhys and Carys's relationship. The writing succeeds in several key areas while having some minor shortcomings. The strongest element is the character work. Both Rhys and Carys behave authentically according to their established personalities - he's desperate to please and be understood, she's guardedly protective of her autonomy. Their argument feels genuinely earned rather than manufactured, with both characters making valid points while also revealing their flaws. Rhys's neediness and ego ("A tiny part of me wouldn't mind hearing it") and Carys's defensive cynicism create realistic friction. The dialogue is largely strong, maintaining distinct voices and natural rhythms. Lines like "You smile like you're waiting for applause. Must be exhausting" and "Life's greedy. It doesn't always do both" feel character-specific and earned. The conversation builds tension effectively, escalating from professional concerns to personal vulnerabilities. The chapter follows its planned structure closely, hitting the key beats: the job offer, PR pressures, Rhys's attempt to include Carys in his world, her rejection of being "managed," and their painful miscommunication about what they mean to each other. The emotional stakes feel real and consequential. However, there are moments where the writing becomes slightly too polished or cute. Some exchanges feel more writerly than natural, particularly in the middle section where the banter occasionally prioritizes cleverness over authenticity. A few metaphorical flourishes ("the actor slid over him like armor") work but edge toward overwrought. The pacing occasionally stutters when characters spell out their motivations too explicitly, though this is mostly balanced by more subtle emotional reveals. The ending effectively captures their mutual hurt and stubbornness without telegraphing the resolution too obviously. Minor issues include some repetitive dialogue tags and a few moments where characters' self-awareness feels slightly too complete for the emotional state they're in. The writing occasionally tells us about emotions that are already clear from context. Overall, this is skilled writing that successfully executes a difficult emotional scene while maintaining character integrity and advancing the plot meaningfully. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 6 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 6 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 5 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The film poster showed up on her feed before he did. Muted colors, serious faces, his name higher than it had ever been. Someone in London had plastered it beside a bus stop; a friend of Anwen’s had taken a photo. The caption: OUR BOY DONE GOOD. Carys clicked the screen off. Pen a’r Don’s till tape curled like a tongue beside her. The first few weeks after he left, texts came. Little things. Flight delayed. Dramatic. Toronto is cold. Send Dylan. You’d hate this script. Too much earnest monologuing. (Don’t tell them I said that.) She answered some. Short replies. Dry. Careful. Don’t insult monologues, they pay your rent. Dylan refuses exile. Wear a coat. Then the tabloid shot: Rhys laughing on a sidewalk with a co-star. The familiar tilt of his head. The headline: NEW ONSCREEN ROMANCE GOES OFFSCREEN? She didn’t read the article. She stopped answering his last message. You’d like this diner. They have terrible coffee and excellent pie. He noticed. There was a gap. Then one more text. Guessing you saw something. It’s bullshit. Won’t bore you with it. Hope you’re okay. She didn’t reply. Life shrank to inventory and invoices. Anwen prodded; she deflected. Dylan slept on her chest some nights like a small, indifferent anchor. Autumn came in off the sea; storm-lashed windows, tourist numbers thinning. The shop felt both more hers and too big. In October, his film’s trailer hit. She watched it muted in the back room, leaning on stacked boxes. He looked older. Sharper. Better. Less hers, which was ridiculous; he’d never been. She turned the phone face-down. Flipped the sign to CLOSED. Switched off the lights. — He came back on a Tuesday. Of course he did. Dusk, rain needling down, wind buoying the bell into brief noise as she locked up. She turned—and he was there on the pavement, hood up, bag over his shoulder, no entourage. He lifted both hands like someone approaching a skittish animal. “If you’re a cardboard cutout for a promo stunt,” she said, heart thudding, “tell them they cheaped out.” He huffed, breath fogging. “Hi, Carys.” “You’re supposed to be in L.A. or on a yacht,” she said. “Rescuing orphans with your jawline.” “Day off,” he said. “And a broadband connection. You’d be amazed what you can do.” She stared at him. “You flew here on a day off.” “Look,” he said, nodding toward the window. No other cars. No cameras.
